('52', 0, 5, 7, 269) 2. TO THE CULTIVATORS OF KHEDA
('52', 0, 6, 8, 300) [April 29, 1931] 2
('52', 0, 7, 9, 319) I had written in Navajivan 3 That no cultivator 4 is obliged to pay revenue by incurring debt.
('52', 0, 7, 10, 414) I write the following further to clarify the matter.
('52', 0, 7, 11, 467) 1. Whether the cultivator has gone on ‘Hijarat’ or not if he has suffered substantially by reason of satyagraha movement such a satya grahi Cultivator is not obliged to pay revenue by incurring debt.
('52', 0, 7, 12, 667) 2. The duty of all other cultivators—those who have not taken part in the satyagraha movement and those who have not suffered substantially—is to pay the revenue even if it becomes necessary to incur debt for such purpose.
('52', 0, 7, 13, 890) 3. The cultivators covered by item I should realize that in my opinion their interest lies in keeping the Truce.
('52', 0, 7, 14, 1003) I shall make every endeavour to get suspension of their land revenue up to next year but if I fail the peasants will have to undergo considerable suffering and this suggestion does not apply to those who are not prepared to undergo such suffering.
('52', 0, 7, 15, 1251) [From Gujarati] Navijivan, 3 5 1931
('52', 0, 8, 16, 1287) 1 Secretary, District Congress Committee, Mirpurkhas (Sind), who in his letter dated April 28, had sought Gandhiji’s veiws on Mirpurkhas cloth merchants’ decision to sell sealed foreign cloth against the Congress directive and the counter decision of satyagrahis to resort to picketing and hunger strike.
('52', 0, 8, 17, 1592) 2 From The Hindu, 30 4 1931 3 Dated 19 4 1931; vide “To The Satyagrahi Farmer”, 19 4 1931

('52', 1, 3, 8, 2283) Why should we be ashamed of making errors in a foreign tongue?

('52', 2, 4, 18, 4648) 5. LETTER TO C. VIJAYARAGHAVACHARIAR BORSAD, April 29, 1931
('52', 2, 5, 19, 4708) DEAR FRIEND, Ghanshyam Das Birla asks me to write to you if it is only a few lines.
('52', 2, 5, 20, 4792) I have failed because up to last week I had practically ceased to deal with voluminous correspondence that comes daily.
('52', 2, 5, 21, 4912) Pyarelal and Mahadev dealt with it as they liked and I knew that in that pressure you did not expect anything from me.
('52', 2, 5, 22, 5031) And now that I have a few moments to dictate some letters what shall I say to you?
('52', 2, 5, 23, 5114) Why do you think that because you had no acknowledgments, your wires and letters were not considered?
('52', 2, 5, 24, 5216) They were.
('52', 2, 5, 25, 5227) But the unfortunate fact is that your suggestion could not be accepted.
('52', 2, 5, 26, 5299) The legality of the convic tions 1 was discussed threadbare by jurists like Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru with the Viceroy and you know what great influence he had with him.
('52', 2, 5, 27, 5465) But it was all of no avail.
('52', 2, 5, 28, 5493) The Congress therefore had to take up the only attitude that was open to it.
('52', 2, 5, 29, 5570) I would ask you please therefore not to be sensitive.
('52', 2, 5, 30, 5624) Remember that we have a new generation of men and women dominating the Congress.
('52', 2, 5, 31, 5705) They brush aside legal forms.
('52', 2, 6, 32, 5735) 1 Of Bhagat Singh, Sukhdev and Rajguru
('52', 3, 0, 1, 5774) 4 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 3, 1, 2, 5814) have found by experience how powerless these forms have proved for advancing freedom and they have by bitter experience realized how powerful they have been for curbing freedom.
('52', 3, 1, 3, 5992) Why will you not therefore be satisfied with blessing these young men and women knowing that they are, on the whole, on the right track[?] This of course does not mean that you should not continue to give the Congress and especially me the benefit of your advice.
('52', 3, 1, 4, 6256) But that you should do without expectation of its being always followed.
('52', 3, 1, 5, 6329) I hope, in spite of old age creeping on you, you are well and able to follow the vast changes that are taking place in the country.
('52', 3, 2, 6, 6461) Yours sincerely, SYT.

('52', 3, 5, 11, 6587) 6. LETTER TO R. B. GREGG
('52', 3, 6, 12, 6612) [AS AT] SABARMATI, April 29, 1931
('52', 3, 7, 13, 6646) MY DEAR GOVIND, I have your letter and I read your letter to Mira.
('52', 3, 7, 14, 6713) I quite understand and appreciate all the anxiety shown by you in your letter to her.
('52', 3, 7, 15, 6799) I do not know that I shall be going to London at all and I shall certainly not go if the way is not clear for me to deliver my message.
('52', 3, 7, 16, 6935) That it is not likely to be accepted just now I have realized all along.
('52', 3, 7, 17, 7008) But had the Congress not accepted the offer to discuss terms, the Congress would have put itself in the wrong.
('52', 3, 7, 18, 7119) As it is we are safe either way.
('52', 3, 7, 19, 7152) It will be great, good and grand if peace can be made permanent through negotiation.
('52', 3, 7, 20, 7237) I shall therefore leave no stone unturned to reach that state but it will be equally good and grand if the negotiations proved fruitless.
('52', 3, 7, 21, 7375) Then India will be put upon her mettle and will have to show her capacity for further suffering.
('52', 3, 7, 22, 7472) There is no question of my being invited to parties, feted and lionized.
('52', 3, 7, 23, 7545) I can eat nothing and thank God my Ioin cloth will protect me from being exhibited as a specimen in Barnum’s show.
('52', 3, 7, 24, 7660) If therefore I go to London I go for solid business and to drink in the deep affection of chosen friends there.
('52', 3, 7, 25, 7772) I refuse to speculate.
('52', 3, 7, 26, 7795) I would go where the light leads me in the fullest faith that all will be well if I follow it.
('52', 4, 0, 1, 7890) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 5
('52', 4, 1, 2, 7930) Do not believe the rumours about my intended visit to America.
('52', 4, 1, 3, 7993) Much as I should like to visit that great country I know that my time is not yet and I do not want to come as a nine day’s wonder.
('52', 4, 1, 4, 8124) Love to you and Radha.
('52', 4, 2, 5, 8147) Yours sincerely,
('52', 4, 3, 6, 8164) BAPU R. B. GREGG, ESQ.

('52', 6, 5, 14, 11715) BORSAD, April 29, 1931 BHAI GHANSHYAMDAS, I have your two letters.
('52', 6, 5, 15, 11782) I send you a copy of the letter 2 I have written to Vijayaraghavachariji.
('52', 6, 5, 16, 11856) What shall I write about the Hindu Muslim problem?
('52', 6, 5, 17, 11907) The Nawab of Bhopal is doing something.
('52', 6, 5, 18, 11947) Whenever you have an oppor tunity of rendering service to a Muslim you should do so.
('52', 6, 5, 19, 12032) It does not mean financial assistance.
('52', 6, 5, 20, 12071) Financial assistance of course has to be rendered in the case of a deserving but poor Mussalman.
('52', 6, 5, 21, 12168) And it is also our duty to try and remove the rowdyism among Hindus.
('52', 6, 5, 22, 12237) The atroci ties committed by Hindus in Cawnpore and Kashi do not help the Hindu religion, but undoubtedly harm it.
('52', 6, 5, 23, 12352) I have as yet no idea whether I am to go to England or not.
('52', 6, 5, 24, 12412) The situation here is rather serious.
('52', 6, 5, 25, 12450) Do go to America.
('52', 6, 5, 26, 12468) It will certainly do some good.
('52', 6, 5, 27, 12500) Do whatever is possible for the boycott of foreign cloth.
('52', 6, 5, 28, 12558) I am well.

('52', 7, 0, 1, 12748) 8 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 7, 1, 2, 12788) 11. THE LOIN CLOTH
('52', 7, 2, 3, 12807) A critic has fallen foul of my remark made before the meeting of the Federation of Chambers of Commerce at Delhi that the Indian civilization must not be allowed to be wiped out by the inroads from the West.
('52', 7, 2, 4, 13015) The critic has confused Indian civilization with the loin cloth and then condemned it.
('52', 7, 2, 5, 13102) Mr. Churchill has been kind enough gratuitously to advertise my loin cloth to the whole world.
('52', 7, 2, 6, 13197) It has therefore become the fashion to laugh at it as the said critic has done.
('52', 7, 2, 7, 13277) Let me then explain what it means.
('52', 7, 2, 8, 13312) In 1921 Maulana Mahomed Ali was arrested at Waltair whilst he and I were going on a tour to the South.
('52', 7, 2, 9, 13415) 1 He was torn from Begum Mahomed Ali who was travelling with us.
('52', 7, 2, 10, 13480) I was deeply moved, she bore the separation bravely and attended meetings in Madras.
('52', 7, 2, 11, 13565) I left her at Madras and went as far as Madura.
('52', 7, 2, 12, 13613) On the way I saw in our compart ment crowds that were wholly unconcerned with what had happened.
('52', 7, 2, 13, 13710) Almost without exception they were bedecked in foreign fineries.
('52', 7, 2, 14, 13775) I entered into conversation with some of them and pleaded for khadi.
('52', 7, 2, 15, 13844) For I had no other way open to me to secure the release of the Ali Brothers save through khadi.
('52', 7, 2, 16, 13940) They shook their heads as they said, “We are too poor to buy khadi and it is so dear.” I realized the substratum of truth behind the remark.
('52', 7, 2, 17, 14081) I had my vest, cap, and full dhoti on.
('52', 7, 2, 18, 14120) When these uttered only partial truth, the millions of com pulsory naked men, save for their langoti four inches wide and nearly as many feet long, gave through their bare limbs the naked truth.
('52', 7, 2, 19, 14315) What effective answer could I give them, if it was not to divest myself of every inch of clothing I decently could and thus to a still greater extent bring myself in a line with the ill clad masses?
('52', 7, 2, 20, 14514) And this I did the very next morning after the Madura meeting?
('52', 7, 3, 21, 14577) Here then there is no question of loin cloth civilization.
('52', 7, 3, 22, 14636) The adoption of the loin cloth was for me a sheer necessity.
('52', 7, 3, 23, 14697) But in so far as the loin cloth also spells simplicity let it represent Indian civiliza tion.
('52', 7, 3, 24, 14791) It is a mingling of the cultures represented by the different faiths and influenced by the geographic and other environment in which the cultures have met.
('52', 7, 3, 25, 14947) Thus Islamic culture is not the same in Arabia, Turkey, Egypt and India but it is itself influenced by the conditions of
('52', 7, 4, 26, 15068) 1 Vide “Message to Bomba Citizens”, 14 9 1921 2 Held on September 22, 1921; vide
('52', 8, 0, 1, 15149) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 9
('52', 8, 1, 2, 15189) the respective countries.
('52', 8, 1, 3, 15215) Indian cult ure is therefore Indian.
('52', 8, 1, 4, 15252) It is neither Hindu, Islamic nor any other, wh olly.
('52', 8, 1, 5, 15305) It is a fusion of all and essentially Eastern.
('52', 8, 1, 6, 15352) I had in mind that cu lture.
('52', 8, 1, 7, 15381) And every one who called himself or herself an Indian is bound to treasure that culture, be its trustee and resist any attack upon it.
('52', 8, 1, 8, 15516) European civilization is no doubt suited for the Europeans but it will mean ruin for India, if we endeavour to copy it.
('52', 8, 1, 9, 15636) This is not to say that we may not adopt and assimilate whatever may be good and capable of assimilation by us as it does not also mean that even the Europeans will not have to part with whatever evil might have crept into it.
('52', 8, 1, 10, 15863) The incessant search for material comforts and their multipli cation is such an evil, and I make bold to say that the Europeans themselves will have to remodel their outlook, if they are not to perish under the weight of the comforts to which they are becoming slaves.
('52', 8, 1, 11, 16132) It may be that my reading is wrong, but I know that for India to run after the Golden Fleece is to court certain death.
('52', 8, 1, 12, 16252) Let us engrave on our hearts the motto of a Western philosopher, “Plain living and high thinking”.
('52', 8, 1, 13, 16351) Today it is certain that the millions cannot have high living and we the few who profess to do the thinking for the masses run the risk, in a vain search after high living, of missing high thinking.
('52', 8, 1, 14, 16550) Young India, 30 4 1931
('52', 8, 2, 15, 16573) 12. HE LIVES BY DYING
('52', 8, 3, 16, 16595) G. V. Ketkar writes of an example of great bravery which is worthy of record:
('52', 8, 4, 17, 16673) Purushottam, who was popularly known as Bapu Gayadhani, was a
('52', 8, 5, 18, 16735) young worker of Nasik.
('52', 8, 5, 19, 16758) For the past few years he was working as assistant
('52', 8, 6, 20, 16809) Secretary of the Gulalwadi public gymnasium of Nasik.
('52', 8, 6, 21, 16863) He was also
('52', 8, 7, 22, 16875) occasionally taking part in Congress and swadeshi propaganda.
('52', 8, 7, 23, 16937) On the 4th of
('52', 8, 8, 24, 16951) April a house in Nasik caught fire.
('52', 8, 8, 25, 16987) Bapu Gayadhani took leading part in the
('52', 8, 9, 26, 17027) work of quenching the fire.
('52', 8, 9, 27, 17055) On learning that there were children in the house
('52', 8, 10, 28, 17105) he rushed in without caring for consequences and rescued all the children.
('52', 8, 11, 29, 17180) re entered the house to save the cattle also.
('52', 8, 11, 30, 17226) Unfortunately the fire had spread
('52', 8, 12, 31, 17260) all over the house and burning beam crashed over his head.
('52', 8, 12, 32, 17319) He was badly burnt
('52', 8, 13, 33, 17338) and bruised all over his body and was taken to the civil hospital where he
('52', 8, 14, 34, 17413) succumbed to his injuries on the 11th instant.”
('52', 9, 0, 1, 17461) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 9, 1, 2, 17502) His parents, if they are alive, should be proud of their brave son.

('52', 9, 2, 5, 17642) 13. THE GUJARAT FARMER “Give a dog a bad name and hang him.” Say that the Gujarat farmer is contumacious and sell him out.
('52', 9, 2, 6, 17765) In a Press interview 1 I said some days ago that it was unfortunate that Mr. Benn was misled into saying that the Gujarat farmer was not playing the game; in other words, he was not paying up.
('52', 9, 2, 7, 17958) When the suggestion was first made I was startled, for I had faith that the Gujarat farmer though hit hard would carry out the terms of the Settlement to the full extent of his ability.
('52', 9, 2, 8, 18144) The Settlement expects nothing more.
('52', 9, 2, 9, 18181) The complaint made to me in Delhi was that whereas large sums were collected in Bardoli and Valod before 28th February, only Rs. 3,212 were collected during the fortnight ending 15th March.
('52', 9, 2, 10, 18371) The implication was that since the Settlement very little was paid.
('52', 9, 2, 11, 18439) Now, the Settlement was announced on 7th March.
('52', 9, 2, 12, 18487) Sardar Vallabhbhai and I reached Bardoli on 14th March.
('52', 9, 2, 13, 18543) It is clear that nothing could be expected before we arrived in Bardoli and explained the position to the farmers and they could return to their homes.
('52', 9, 2, 14, 18695) Here, however, are the figures of payment: Revenue Collections in Bardoli and Valod

('52', 10, 2, 5, 20154) But here I must draw the curtain.
('52', 10, 2, 6, 20188) I may say that great difficulty is being experienced in establishing friendly touch with the local officials.
('52', 10, 2, 7, 20298) The result is that many things that should have long ago been done on behalf of the Government are still not done and though there is no unwil lingness to pay, threats of coercive measures are kept hanging like Damo cles’s word over the heads of the people.
('52', 10, 2, 8, 20556) The process has begun with Kaira.
('52', 10, 2, 9, 20590) They do not seem to realize that there is peace now, provisial though it is, between the people and the Government and that efforts are being made to make enduring what is
('52', 11, 0, 1, 20762) 12 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 11, 1, 2, 20803) today only temporary and provisional.
('52', 11, 1, 3, 20841) The difficulties in the way are enormous.
('52', 11, 1, 4, 20883) But I have pledged my word to Lord Irwin that so far as it is humanly possible, I shall prevent the Truce from breaking.
('52', 11, 1, 5, 21004) The Settlement has been called a gentleman’s agreement.
('52', 11, 1, 6, 21060) I know that Lord Irwin was sincerely anxious to see that it was fully carried out by the Government’s agents as he testified more than once that I was to see it being as fully carried out by Congressmen.
('52', 11, 1, 7, 21264) It has hurt me to take the public into confidence even to the extent I have done.
('52', 11, 1, 8, 21346) But I feel that I can no longer suppress the fact that there are ominous signs on the horizon.
('52', 11, 1, 9, 21441) A satyagrahi has no weapon at his disposal but that of public opinion and suffering.
('52', 11, 1, 10, 21526) Let the public read no more into this article than the natural meaning the written word conveys.
('52', 11, 1, 11, 21623) I shall hope and pray that next week I may be able to report that the threatenig cloud has lifted.
('52', 11, 1, 12, 21722) Young India, 30 4 1931
('52', 11, 2, 13, 21745) 14. OUR DUTY TO THE VILLAGERS
('52', 11, 3, 14, 21775) The intensive political struggle of last year brought out prominently the importance of foreign cloth boycott in the fight for national freedom.
('52', 11, 3, 15, 21920) That the boycott programme has been in a measure effective, is evidenced by the fall in the import of foreign cloth.
('52', 11, 3, 16, 22037) We have reason for satisfaction in the results achieved, but let us not in our satisfaction at the measure of success gained, forget the true pur pose and implications of the boycott programme.
('52', 11, 3, 17, 22231) Let us remember that our nation lives in the millions of village homes and the true and primary aim of the boycott programme will be missed if the boycott is not worked in such a way that the benefits accrue pre eminently to the villagers.
('52', 11, 3, 18, 22471) If it is to benefit them it can only be by the nation according to khadi a position above all other indigenous cloth.
('52', 11, 3, 19, 22589) In order to do this it is necessary for us to revise our taste.
('52', 11, 3, 20, 22653) We must take to coarse, thick khadi.
('52', 11, 3, 21, 22690) The cotton grown in India is mostly short stapled and can yield only low count yarn.
('52', 11, 3, 22, 22775) The spinners who have been spinning generally only for themselves or the neighbour hood are accustomed in most of the areas only to the spinning of coarse yarn and it is difficult therefore at once to raise the count of yarn spun.
('52', 11, 3, 23, 23006) This is the case with practically the whole of North India.
('52', 11, 3, 24, 23066) In the Punjab, Rajasthan, U. P., Bihar, and Bengal, where lakhs of
('52', 12, 0, 1, 23133) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 13
('52', 12, 1, 2, 23174) unemployed or partlaily employed charkhas exist, only thich khadi is being woven.
('52', 12, 1, 3, 23256) A limited quantity of fine and medium khadi is avai lable in the South, but even there the largest quantity is only made of low count yarn.
('52', 12, 1, 4, 23396) The activities under the auspices of the All India Spinners’ Association, much as they have grown, have not touched even a tenth of the known and definitely ascertained facilities for production in these provinces.
('52', 12, 1, 5, 23611) There are practicially no limits to the possibilities of thick khadi production and if only the nation can give its reasoned preference to thick khadi, it can to a very large extent take the place till now occupied by foreign cloth and the fruits of the national programme will go to benefit the vast majority of the popu lation of the country and not merely the moneyed few.
('52', 12, 1, 6, 23987) This general plea for khadi from the point of view of the boy cott is further strengthened by one peculiar feature of the economic situation of the country in the current year and the year that is past.
('52', 12, 1, 7, 24190) The abnormally low prices of cotton and indeed of all agricultural produce, have caused great distress in the villages.
('52', 12, 1, 8, 24310) The prices prevail ing do not, in many cases, fully meet even the cultivation and other expenses.
('52', 12, 1, 9, 24408) The smaller cultivators of cotton, therefore, have sought to earn something more on their cotton by plying one or two spinning wheels in their homes.
('52', 12, 1, 10, 24558) The cultivators of other agricultural produce have also similarly sought to add to their scanty income by spinning.
('52', 12, 1, 11, 24674) The result is that in many parts of the country spinners from surrounding villages in great numbers flock to the nearest khadi depots offering the yarn for sale.
('52', 12, 1, 12, 24836) The output of hand spun yarn even before last year was very much more than what the existing depots could manage.
('52', 12, 1, 13, 24950) But now the position has become more difficult still.
('52', 12, 1, 14, 25004) With their very limited capital resources the depots are unable to take in all the yarn and have therefore to turn away many of the spinners.
('52', 12, 1, 15, 25146) If the demand for khadi can be increased the consequent increased turn over may enable the depots to afford a greater amount of relief to the spinners.
('52', 12, 1, 16, 25298) More private capital may also flow into khadi, as to some extent it did last year.
('52', 12, 1, 17, 25381) Both from the general viewpoint of the boycott, therefore, as well as the affording of immediate relief for present distress the duty of the country to give preference to khadi is obvious.
('52', 12, 1, 18, 25570) If large numbers of people.
('52', 12, 1, 19, 25598) even if they feel it difficult to wear a khadi dhoti or sari because of its heaviness, choose only khadi for their other requirements—towels, shirting, coating, and bed sheets, carpets, and the like—it will become possible not merely to absorb all
('52', 13, 0, 1, 25846) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 13, 1, 2, 25887) the hand spun yarn that is produced today but also many times the present output.
('52', 13, 1, 3, 25969) It requires only a proper exercise of imagination to realize all the possibilities.
('52', 13, 1, 4, 26053) And if we would adapt our dress to the climatic requirements and the resources of villagers, we would discard the many articles, reduce the size of the dhoti or sari, change the turban for the cap and in the bargain secure greater comfort and greater cleanliness, not to speak of the great reduction in the cost of clothes.
('52', 13, 1, 5, 26377) Young India, 30 4 1931
('52', 13, 2, 6, 26400) 15. WHAT IS THE TRUTH?
('52', 13, 3, 7, 26423) S. D. Nadkarni of Karwar writes a letter from which I take the following:
('52', 13, 4, 8, 26497) I have just noticed that in a letter addressed to you and already published
('52', 13, 5, 9, 26573) in the Press Mr. Mushir Hussain Kidwai, one of the leaders of the ‘All Parties
('52', 13, 6, 10, 26652) Muslim Conference’, referring to the minority problem in Egypt, says: ‘In my
('52', 13, 7, 11, 26729) opinion, the attitude of the Hindus here should be what Zaglul’s was in Egypt,
('52', 13, 8, 12, 26808) i.e., they should sign blindfolded the demands of the minority.
('52', 13, 9, 13, 26872) Without concerning myself here with any other statement made by Mr. Kidwai in his letter to you, I should like to draw your attention to the true fact about the one above, where a parallel is sought to be drawn from Egyptian politics.
('52', 13, 9, 14, 27107) The enclosed excerpt from a leading article in the Servant of India of
('52', 13, 10, 15, 27178) August 15, 1929, whose writer had to deal with a similar statement made about that time by Sir Ibrahim Rahimatoola, will show you how the truth about affairs in Egypt (where the Muslims are the majority, and the native Christians called Copts are the minority) is just the opposite of what your correspondent Mr. Kidwai would have you believe.
('52', 13, 11, 16, 27522) Every single statement in the excerpt, I am sure, can be vouched for by reference to any work on contemporary history or any standard work of reference.
('52', 13, 11, 17, 27675) From the excerpt referred to by Sjt.
('52', 13, 11, 18, 27712) Nadkarni, the following relevent parts are taken:
('52', 13, 12, 19, 27762) Indeed Sir Ibrahim seems to have misread history.
('52', 13, 12, 20, 27812) Look, for instance, at what he says about Egypt.
('52', 13, 12, 21, 27861) In pleading for a generous treatment to be meted out by the majority community to minority communities, he cites the example of what Saad Pasha Zaglul did to the Christians in Egypt.
('52', 13, 12, 22, 28044) He appears to think that Zaglul’s sensitive regard for the rights and interests of the Copts persuaded the latter to accept the rule of the Moslems.
('52', 13, 12, 23, 28193) The facts, however, are just the
('52', 14, 0, 1, 28226) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 15
('52', 14, 1, 2, 28267) contrary.
('52', 14, 1, 3, 28277) It is the throwing in by the Copts of their lot unreservedly with the nationalists in Egypt that has persuaded the Muslims to treat them so liberally as they have done.
('52', 14, 1, 4, 28446) The Copts were not entirely free from persecution before.
('52', 14, 1, 5, 28504) The improvement was solely due to the fact that they were not only not hostile or indifferent to the national campaign for freedom, but took a very prominent part in the Wafd.
('52', 14, 1, 6, 28680) This was a very wise policy for the Coptic community ot follow, to which they owe the inclusion of Copts in the Ministry.
('52', 14, 1, 7, 28802) I give the extract for what it is worth.
('52', 14, 1, 8, 28843) I have verified neither the statement made in the extract nor the one to which it purports to be an answer.
('52', 14, 1, 9, 28951) Nor am I interested in it except for the sake of truth.
('52', 14, 1, 10, 29007) As a satyagrahi I believe in the absolute efficacy of full surrender.
('52', 14, 1, 11, 29077) Numerically Hindus happen to be the major community.
('52', 14, 1, 12, 29130) Withour reference therefore to what the Egyptian majority did they may give to the minorities what they may want.
('52', 14, 1, 13, 29244) But even if the Hindus were in a minority, as a satyagrahi and Hindu I should say that the Hindus would lose nothing in the long run by full surrender.
('52', 14, 1, 14, 29396) To this argument a retort has thoughtlessly been made, ‘Why then do you not advise India to surrender to the English?
('52', 14, 1, 15, 29514) Give them the domination they want and be happy.’ The hasty retort ignores the vital fact that I have not advised surrender to the baynet.
('52', 14, 1, 16, 29653) In the code of the satyagrahi there is no such thing as surrender to brute force.
('52', 14, 1, 17, 29735) Or the surrender then is the surrender of suffering and not to the will of the wielder of the bayonet.
('52', 14, 1, 18, 29838) A satyagrahi’s surrender has to come out of his strength, not out of weakness.
('52', 14, 1, 19, 29917) The surrender advised by me is not of honour but of earthly goods.
('52', 14, 1, 20, 29984) There is no loss of honour in surrendering seats and positions of emoluments.
('52', 14, 1, 21, 30062) There is loss of honour in haggling about them.
('52', 14, 1, 22, 30110) Let the Englishmen give up the bayonet and live in our midst as simple friends and I should plead for them.
('52', 14, 1, 23, 30218) The law of surrender and suffering is a universal law admitting of no exceptions.
('52', 14, 1, 24, 30300) Young India, 30 4 1931

('52', 15, 8, 13, 31091) 18. INTERVIEW TO “FOX MOVIETONE NEWS”
('52', 15, 9, 14, 31129) BORSAD, [April 30, 1931 ] 1
('52', 15, 10, 15, 31157) The following is the full text of the interview intended for the Talkie that the Fox Movietone News and the Associated Press of America had with Mahatma Gandhi at Borsad.
('52', 15, 10, 16, 31328) The copy has been corrected by Gandhiji before releasing for publication, says The Bombay Chronicle.
('52', 15, 11, 17, 31429) Mr. Gandhi prefixed the interview with the following remarks: I do not like this kind of thing, but I shall reconcile myself to it, if not more than a few minutes have to be given: Although I know this sort of enterprise will advertise you, which is your primary object, I know also that it will serve to advertise the cause which I represent—India’s independence.
('52', 15, 11, 18, 31794) I do not discount the value of propaganda.
('52', 15, 11, 19, 31837) I have been described as the greatest propagandist in the world.
('52', 15, 11, 20, 31902) I may deserve the compliment.
('52', 15, 11, 21, 31932) But my propaganda is unlike the ordinary.
('52', 15, 11, 22, 31974) It is that of truth which is self propagating.
('52', 15, 11, 23, 32021) Truth abhors artificiality.
('52', 15, 11, 24, 32049) You will therefore excuse me for declining to pose for you from which, apart from the reason I have given above, I am debarred by a solemn vow I made in 1905.
('52', 15, 12, 25, 32208) 1 From The Hindu, 1 5 1931
('52', 16, 0, 1, 32235) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 17
('52', 16, 1, 2, 32276) He therefore declined to give a sitting in a suitable courtyard.
('52', 16, 1, 3, 32341) The interview took place in his room.
('52', 16, 2, 4, 32379) Q. Mr. Gandhi, Fox Movietone News and the Associated Press of America,
('52', 16, 3, 5, 32450) which combined, reach an audience of several hundred million people throughour the world, have sent us their representatives across the Seven Seas from New York to India to see if you wil be good enough to give the American people, through the medium of Fox Movietone News, a message of greeting and friendship.
('52', 16, 4, 6, 32762) probably know, there is a great deal of interest and sympathy in the United States for India’s struggle for independence, because America itself had a similar struggle for liberation 150 years ago.
('52', 16, 5, 7, 32960) A. I appreciate all the interest and sympathy America has shown in our struggle, and I hope we shall be able to retain the friendship and goodwill of the American people to the end of our struggle.
('52', 16, 6, 8, 33158) Q. When do you expect to visit America?
('52', 16, 7, 9, 33198) A. Much as I should like to visit your country, I have abso lutely no notion about it except that I should not like to visit America until the present struggle for India’s freedom has proved demons trably successful.
('52', 16, 8, 10, 33415) When do you expect to leave for London for the second Round Table Conference?
('52', 16, 8, 11, 33493) About this also, I have no idea, except that I don’t expect to go to London unless the Hindu Muslim communal question is satisfac torily solved.
('52', 16, 8, 12, 33638) Of course, if there should be a break in the present Truce, I will not go to London at all.
('52', 16, 9, 13, 33730) Have you given Lord Irwin any written message for the British Prime Minister?
('52', 16, 9, 14, 33808) It is wholly wrong to say I gave Lord Irwin any such message for Mr. MacDonald.
('52', 16, 10, 15, 33888) Do you expect England will grant all your demands at the second Round Table Conference?
('52', 16, 10, 16, 33976) It is more than I can say.
('52', 16, 11, 17, 34003) But you are really hopeful England will this time grant your demands?
('52', 16, 11, 18, 34073) All I can say is I am an optimist.
('52', 16, 12, 19, 34108) If England does not give you what you want, what course of action will you follow?
('52', 16, 12, 20, 34191) Of course, Civil Disobedience and all other phases of satya graha, (obedience to the principles of truth) are always at our dispo 
('52', 17, 0, 1, 34322) 18 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 17, 1, 2, 34363) But Whether we shall resort to these weapons immediately, or what other steps we shall take, it is not possible to say offhand at present.
('52', 17, 2, 3, 34502) Are you prepared to go back to jail if England refuses to grant your demands?
('52', 17, 2, 4, 34580) I am always ready to go to jail in the cause of India’s freedom.
('52', 17, 3, 5, 34645) Are you willing to die in such a cause?
('52', 17, 3, 6, 34685) That is a bad question.
('52', 17, 4, 7, 34709) If England should accede to your demands, do you intend to have complete prohibition in the new Indian State?
('52', 17, 4, 8, 34819) Yes, I expect to see absolute prohibition enforced in the new Indian State.
('52', 17, 5, 9, 34895) Do you intend to abolish child marriages when the new Indian State is established?
('52', 17, 5, 10, 34978) I should very much like to see child marriages abolished even before that time.
('52', 17, 6, 11, 35058) Do you expect in the new Indian State to exterminate the present caste system which makes social outcastes of India’s so called sixty million “untouchables”?
('52', 17, 6, 12, 35216) Most decidedly.
('52', 17, 7, 13, 35232) Do you intend to abolish the present system of Indian widows living lives of strict seclusion and celibacy?
('52', 17, 7, 14, 35340) There is nothing now to prevent widows from remarrying if they so wish.
('52', 17, 7, 15, 35412) It is likewise wholly wrong to say, or to suggest, that Indian widows in general live in seclusion.
('52', 17, 8, 16, 35512) I refer to the system of widows living in purdah.
('52', 17, 9, 17, 35562) The system of purdah is in fact confined to a very small number of the middle class people, and that too not over the whole of India.
('52', 17, 10, 18, 35696) In the new Indian State, do you expect there will be complete communal social
('52', 17, 11, 19, 35774) unity and harmony between Hindus and Muslims?
('52', 17, 11, 20, 35820) I certainly look forward to seeing complete social harmony and unity established between these two great branches of the Indian family in the new State.
('52', 17, 12, 21, 35973) If the King of England invites you to dinner at Buckingham Palace when you attend the second Round Table Conference, will you dress in native Indian attire or will you appear in European dress?
('52', 17, 12, 22, 36167) It would be a discourtesy to the King for me to appear in any dress other than my customary Indian apparel.
('52', 17, 12, 23, 36275) If the weather permits, I shall dress in England exactly as I do in India, that is, in loin cloth.
('52', 18, 0, 1, 36374) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 19
('52', 18, 1, 2, 36415) Mr. Gandhi, you have frequently said that you number among the British people some of your best friends and partisans.
('52', 18, 1, 3, 36534) Will you be kind enough to give a brief message of greeting to those friends and other members of the great British public, through British Movietone News, which reaches a vast audience throughout the British Empire?
('52', 18, 1, 4, 36751) I am glad to be able to say that the circle of my British friends is increasing.
('52', 18, 1, 5, 36832) It could not be otherwise, as the present satyagraha movement, however much it may be mixed with dress, is nothing but a movement for promoting the establishment of goodwill with those against whom we seem to be fighting.
('52', 18, 1, 6, 37054) Therefore, I have no misgivings as to the ultimate result.
('52', 18, 2, 7, 37113) Will you give to the world a new Decalogue, or a new Ten Commandments in the light of present day needs?
('52', 18, 2, 8, 37218) That is too big an order.
('52', 18, 2, 9, 37244) The Hindu, 5 5 1931

('52', 19, 1, 2, 38420) 20. LETTER TO G. N. COLLINS
('52', 19, 2, 3, 38448) [May 1, 1931 ] 1
('52', 19, 3, 4, 38465) DEAR MR. COLLINS, I had hoped to be able to write to you about the various cases I had in mind.
('52', 19, 3, 5, 38561) But I am sorry I am not yet ready.

('52', 20, 1, 2, 39966) 22. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS 1
('52', 20, 2, 3, 39995) BORSAD, May 2, 1931 There was no Patel who had not expressed the desire to resume service and there was no question of giving an assurance of working faithfully.
('52', 20, 2, 4, 40157) That assurance was implied in the resumption of service.
('52', 20, 2, 5, 40214) Such terms were, at the beginning stages of the settlement, issued to Patels, and on complaint being made by me, they were withdrawn.
('52', 20, 2, 6, 40348) If 25 per cent of forfeited lands has not been returned, because owners had not paid land revenue, it is a distinct breach of clause 17 B of the Settlement, because forfeited lands have to be returned unless there is reasonable ground for supposing that there is any contumacy on the part of the holder.
('52', 20, 2, 7, 40652) It is common ground that there is no question of contumacy in Bardoli or any of the effected districts.
('52', 20, 2, 8, 40756) It is wholly wrong to suggest that there is lack of discipline in any of the Congress camps and whilst I have pressed every one of the Congress workers to implement the terms of peace as zealously as they fought during the struggle I have had no occasion to admonish any of the workers.
('52', 20, 2, 9, 41043) On the contrary, it gives me great joy to find complete response to every one of the instructions given to the workers.
('52', 20, 2, 10, 41163) I have no knowledge of any worker in Congress organizations, especially in the districts of Surat and Kaira on which Vallabhbhai Patel and I are concentrating attention, having been dismissed for embezzlement of Congress funds except one unfortunate case.

('52', 25, 5, 7, 47433) 33. A TWENTIETH CENTURY SATI (?) 1
('52', 25, 7, 8, 47468) I hope that the incident as reported in the Press is not true and that the lady in question died through illness or through accident, not by suicide.
('52', 25, 7, 9, 47618) A sati has been described by our ancients, and the description holds good today, as one who ever fixed in her love and devotion to her husband signalizes herself by her selfless service during her husband’s lifetime as well as after, and remains absolutely chaste in thought, word and deed.
('52', 25, 7, 10, 47909) Self immolation at the death of the husband is not a sign of enlightenment but of gross ignorance as to the nature of the soul.
('52', 25, 7, 11, 48037) The soul is immortal, unchangeable and immanent.
('52', 25, 7, 12, 48086) It does not perish with the physical body but journeys on from one mortal frame to another till it completely emancipated itself from earthly bondage.
('52', 25, 7, 13, 48237) The truth of it has been attested to by the experience of countless sages and seers and can be realized by anyone who may wish to even today.
('52', 25, 7, 14, 48379) How can suicide be then justified in the light of these facts?
('52', 25, 7, 15, 48442) Again true marriage means not merely union of bodies.
('52', 25, 7, 16, 48496) It connotes the union of the sould too.
('52', 25, 7, 17, 48536) If marriage meant no more than a physical relationship the bereaved wife shouls be satisfied with a portrait or a waxen image of her husband.
('52', 25, 7, 18, 48678) But self destruction is worse than futile.
('52', 25, 7, 19, 48721) It cannot help to restore the dead to life, on the contrary it only takes away one more from the world of the living.
('52', 25, 7, 20, 48839) The ideal that marriage aims at is that of spiritual union through the physical.
('52', 25, 7, 21, 48920) The human love that it incarnates in intended to serve as
('52', 25, 8, 22, 48978) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan 3 5 1931. This is a translation by Pyarelal, with the following introductory note : “A lady correspondent from Ghatkopar having invited Gandhiji to express his opinion on an alleged case of sati that was recently reported in a Bombay vernacular paper Gandhiji has delivered himself on the subject in an article in the Navajivan as follows.” Vide also “Opinion Unchanged”, 17 5 1931.
('52', 26, 0, 1, 49415) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 27
('52', 26, 1, 2, 49456) a stepping stone to the divine or universal love.
('52', 26, 1, 3, 49506) That is why immortal Mira sang : “God alone is my husband—none else.” It follows from this that a sati would regard marriage not as a means of satisfying the animal appetite but as a means of realizing the ideal of selfless and self effacing service by completely merging her individuality in her husband’s.
('52', 26, 1, 4, 49814) She would prove her satihood not by mounting the funeral pyre at her husband’s death but she would prove it with every breath that she breathes from the moment that she plighted her troth to him at the saptapadi 1 ceremony, by her renun ciation, sacrifice, self abnegation and dedication to the service of her husband, his family and the country.
('52', 26, 1, 5, 50161) She would shun creature com forts and delights of the senses.
('52', 26, 1, 6, 50223) She would refuse to be enslaved by the narrow domestic cares and interests of the family, but would utilize every opportunity to add to her stock of knowledge and increase her capacity for service by more and more cultivating renunciation and self discipline, and by completely identifying herself with her husband, learn to indentify herself with the whole world.
('52', 26, 1, 7, 50588) Such a sati would refuse to give way to wild grief at the death of her husband but would ever strive to make her late husband’s ideals and virtues live again in her actions and thereby win for him the crown [of] immortality.
('52', 26, 1, 8, 50813) Knowing that the soul of him whom she married is not dead but still lives she will never think of remarrying.
('52', 26, 1, 9, 50923) The reader will here be perhaps tempted to ask, “The sati that you have pictured is a being untouched by passion or animal appetite.
('52', 26, 1, 10, 51056) She can have no desire for offspring.
('52', 26, 1, 11, 51094) Why should she marry at all?” The reply is that in our present day Hindu society, marriage, in a vast majority of cases, is not a matter of choice.
('52', 26, 1, 12, 51242) Again, there are some who believe that in our ramshackle age marriage is necessary as a shield to virtue and as an aid to selfrestraint.
('52', 26, 1, 13, 51379) And as a matter of fact, I personally know several instances of persons who, though at the time of the marriage, were not free from animal passion later on became imbued with the ideal of obsolute chastity and found in their married life a powerful means for realizing their ideal.
('52', 26, 1, 14, 51661) I have cited these instances to show that the ideal of sati that I have depicted is not merely a counsel of perfection that has no place outside the world of
('52', 26, 2, 15, 51819) 1 Seven steps
('52', 27, 0, 1, 51833) 28 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 27, 1, 2, 51874) theory but something that has to be lived up to and realized in this very matter of fact world of ours.
('52', 27, 1, 3, 51978) But I readily concede that the average wife who strives to attain the ideal of sati will be a mother too.
('52', 27, 1, 4, 52084) She must therefore add to her various other qualities mentioned above a knowledge of rearing and bringing up children so that they might live to be true servants of their country.
('52', 27, 1, 5, 52264) All that I have said about the wife applies equally to the husband.
('52', 27, 1, 6, 52332) If the wife has to prove her loyalty and undivided devotion to her husband so has the husband to prove his allegiance and devotion to his wife.
('52', 27, 1, 7, 52476) You cannot have one set of weights and measures for the one and a different one for the other.
('52', 27, 1, 8, 52571) Yet we have never heard of a husband mounting the funeral pyre of his deceased wife.
('52', 27, 1, 9, 52656) It may therefore be taken for granted that the practice of the widow immolating herself at the death of her husband had its origin in superstitious ignorance and the blind egotism of man.
('52', 27, 1, 10, 52844) Even if it could be proved that at one time the practice had a meaning, it can only be regarded as barbarous in the present age.
('52', 27, 1, 11, 52973) The wife is not the slave of the husband but his comrade, otherwise known as his better half, his colleague and friend.
('52', 27, 1, 12, 53093) She is a co sharer with him of equal rights and of equal duties.
('52', 27, 1, 13, 53158) Their obligations towards each other and towards the world must, therefore, be the same and reciprocal.
('52', 27, 1, 14, 53262) I therefore regard the alleged self immolation of this sister as vain.
('52', 27, 1, 15, 53333) It certainly cannot be set up as an example to be copied.
('52', 27, 1, 16, 53391) Don’t I appreciate at least her courage to die?— I may perhaps be asked.
('52', 27, 1, 17, 53464) My reply is ‘no’ in all conscience.
('52', 27, 1, 18, 53500) Have we not seen even evil doers display this sort of courage?
('52', 27, 1, 19, 53563) Yet no one has ever thought of compli menting them on it.
('52', 27, 1, 20, 53621) Why should I take upon me the sin of even unconsciously leading astray some ignorant sister by my injudicious praise of suicide?
('52', 27, 1, 21, 53750) Satihood is the acme of purity.
('52', 27, 1, 22, 53782) This purity cannot be attained or realized by dying.
('52', 27, 1, 23, 53835) It can be attained only through constant striving, constant immolation of the spirit from day to day.

('52', 28, 1, 11, 54951) 3. They should not write long letters.
('52', 28, 1, 12, 54990) 4. They should not repeat the same arguments again and again.
('52', 28, 1, 13, 55052) 5. As far as possible, they should not argue at all.
('52', 28, 1, 14, 55105) 6. They should write in a beautiful hand.
('52', 28, 1, 15, 55147) These rules are simple and all stem from non violence.
('52', 28, 1, 16, 55202) My handwriting is very poor.
('52', 28, 1, 17, 55231) I have full experience of what difficulties readers find in deciphering it.
('52', 28, 1, 18, 55307) To do anything which causes hardship to others implies violence.
('52', 28, 1, 19, 55372) Hence everyone can see that bad hand writing constitutes violence.
('52', 28, 1, 20, 55439) The same can be said in regard to the other conditions.
('52', 28, 1, 21, 55495) The above rules have permanent application and, in my present state of health, they are doubly relevant.
('52', 28, 1, 22, 55600) Be that as it may, if my correspondents receive no replies, they should not conclude that this is due to lack of civility.

('52', 29, 2, 6, 56763) 35. LETTER TO COLLECTOR 1, KHEDA DISTRICT May 3, 1931 It is a common cause between us that the people should pay revenue to the utmost of their capacity.
('52', 29, 2, 7, 56917) I know that in defining the word “capacity” there may be a difference, or there is a difference as I now see from your letter.
('52', 29, 2, 8, 57044) During our talk I thought that you agreed that no one need borrow money in order to pay the revenue dues.
('52', 29, 2, 9, 57150) I am carrying out that healthy formula.
('52', 29, 2, 10, 57190) I know that is has not been carried out before, and may not be carried out in future.
('52', 29, 2, 11, 57276) In any case, for this exceptional year, I think that there is no way our of it, as I hope to show conclusively in due course.
('52', 29, 2, 12, 57402) This of course, does not mean that those who wish to pay by borrowing should be prevented by me from doing so.

('52', 30, 1, 2, 58200) 37. LETTER TO HARIDAS T. MUZUMDAR
('52', 30, 2, 3, 58234) [AS AT] SABARMATI, May 3, 1931
('52', 30, 3, 4, 58265) MY DEAR HARIDAS 1, Your letter of 26th March 2 and the snatch from your diary have come upon me as a surprise.
('52', 30, 3, 5, 58376) Your certificate could not be worth much if a cablegram containing a garbled report of my doings or even an act of mine truthfully reported which you could not understand should create such a revulsion in you as to undo your previous certifi cate.
('52', 30, 3, 6, 58624) Do you see the terrible implication, namely, that your first certi ficate was based upon just as hasty calculation as your recantation?
('52', 30, 3, 7, 58760) But more surprising still is your protestation that your personal loyalty remained as deep, intense, whole hearted and unquestioning as it was a year ago.
('52', 30, 3, 8, 58915) Do you not see the flat contradiction between this statement and your latest opinion of me?
('52', 30, 3, 9, 59007) Surely your loyalty had no other foundation than your estimate of me and when your estimate had to be revised your loyalty became baseless.
('52', 30, 3, 10, 59147) If you have kept copies of your letters you will understand more fully than I can convey the implications of your letters.
('52', 30, 3, 11, 59270) However there is this consolation for me that I have survived ruder shocks than you have given.
('52', 30, 4, 12, 59366) Yours sincerely, HARIDAS T. MUZUMDAR, ESQ.

('52', 39, 6, 11, 71256) 52. LETTER TO V. T. KRISHNAMACHARYA BORSAD, May 5, 1931
('52', 39, 7, 12, 71312) DEAR DIWAN SAHEB, In Vijapur there is an industrial institution called Udyoga laya.
('52', 39, 7, 13, 71396) I procured through the good office of your predecessor a plot of ground for founding a centre for spinning and weaving especially through women and it was registered in the name of a lady co worker.
('52', 39, 7, 14, 71595) She has now retired from that work and so far as she is concerned the legal right has been transferred to the trustees of the Satyagraha Ashram.
('52', 39, 7, 15, 71740) One of the trustees is working in the Udyogalaya.
('52', 39, 7, 16, 71790) He has tried to get the land transferred in the name of the trustees of the Satyagraha Ashram.
('52', 39, 7, 17, 71885) After waiting a long time the officer concerned has rejected the application.
('52', 39, 7, 18, 71963) He has given, so far as I am aware, no reasons for it.
('52', 39, 7, 19, 72018) At one time it seemed that by giving an undertaking that the institution will have nothing to do with politics there would be no difficulty about the transfer.
('52', 39, 7, 20, 72178) Then, I believe, there was a change of officer.
('52', 39, 7, 21, 72226) Of course, from its very conception accord ing to my own method of work like my activities in other Indian States, this institution has been kept out of politics altogether.
('52', 39, 7, 22, 72400) It remained so during the last struggle.
('52', 39, 7, 23, 72441) As you may be aware, the
('52', 40, 0, 1, 72466) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 41
('52', 40, 1, 2, 72507) Baroda State has been receiving the help of the All India Spinners’ Association for village reorganization through the spinning wheel.
('52', 40, 1, 3, 72642) The Vijapur activity is also a kindred activity.
('52', 40, 1, 4, 72691) Could I trouble you to interest yourself in this matter and if you are satisfied about the facts presented by me, could you please order transfer of the land in the name of the above mentioned trustees?
('52', 40, 1, 5, 72894) At the present moment this land is given by the State for a nominal sum for benevolent purposes.
('52', 40, 1, 6, 72991) But I would like to buy it right out if the State has no objection.
('52', 40, 1, 7, 73059) It was offered before.
('52', 40, 1, 8, 73082) I may add that we have buildings on this land which have cost over Rs. 12,000. Through the institution we are supporting several poor women of Vijapur by giving them spinning work and we are supporting a colony of weavers and carders.
('52', 40, 1, 9, 73317) The institution engages in no other activity.
('52', 40, 1, 10, 73363) I am sorry to have to trouble you over a matter which may appear to be trifling.
('52', 40, 1, 11, 73444) But it is not so to me as a guardian of the several interests entrusted to my care.
('52', 40, 2, 12, 73528) Yours sincerely,
('52', 40, 3, 13, 73545) M. K. GANDHI V. T. KRISHNAMACHARYA, ESQ.

('52', 44, 7, 14, 80074) 60. MESSAGE ON KHADI 2
('52', 44, 8, 15, 80097) BORSAD, May 5, 1931 People ask me why I am khaddar mad.
('52', 44, 8, 16, 80153) There are seven lakhs of villages.
('52', 44, 8, 17, 80188) A large number of these villages are living in a con dition of semi starvation.
('52', 44, 8, 18, 80268) There is no employment for them for nearly six months in the year.
('52', 44, 8, 19, 80335) It is necessary to find for them some supplementary occupation.
('52', 44, 8, 20, 80399) We must give them an occupation they are used to.
('52', 44, 8, 21, 80449) Such an occupation is hand spinning.
('52', 44, 8, 22, 80486) If hand spinning is to be introduced in the villages, it is but natural that we should be expected to wear khaddar.
('52', 44, 8, 23, 80602) Hence it is that I have become khaddar mad.
('52', 44, 8, 24, 80646) The Bombay Chronicle, 6 5 1931

('52', 51, 1, 2, 90176) 72. LETTER TO MAGANTI BAPI NEEDU
('52', 51, 2, 3, 90209) [AS AT] SABARMATI, May 6, 1931
('52', 51, 3, 4, 90240) MY DEAR NEEDU, My whole heart goes out to you in your trouble though, if you will take it calmly and correctly it will be your making.
('52', 51, 3, 5, 90375) It is not prosperity but adversity that makes a man.
('52', 51, 3, 6, 90428) Prosperity spoils him.
('52', 51, 3, 7, 90451) And after all, if you belong to the starving group, you are one of the many millions.
('52', 51, 3, 8, 90537) But I know that this philosophy, however correct it is, will bring you no solace.
('52', 51, 3, 9, 90619) Before therefore I can make a concrete suggestion, you must let me know what your minimum requirements are, and in fixing this, do not think of what you have been materially but think of what you should be.
('52', 51, 3, 10, 90826) In fact in doing this you will have to be courageous and even apparently heartless.
('52', 51, 3, 11, 90910) You are telling me you have to support your own people and Annapurna’s.
('52', 51, 3, 12, 90982) This is absurd.
('52', 51, 3, 13, 90998) You have to support those who may be physically maimed and therefore incapable of doing anything for themselves.
('52', 51, 3, 14, 91111) You have no such in either family.
('52', 51, 3, 15, 91146) Nor must they be pampered.
('52', 51, 3, 16, 91173) They must all, men and women, work for their living and if they will do so, you will find that the problem is satisfactorily and honourably solved.
('52', 51, 3, 17, 91321) Now you know what I want from you.
('52', 51, 3, 18, 91356) Give me a letter full of particulars and it shall receive prompt attention.
('52', 51, 4, 19, 91432) BAPU SJT.

('52', 52, 6, 11, 92030) 74. SPEECH AT BOCHASAN May 6, 1931 I thank you all for giving me the honour of laying the foun dation of this Vidyalaya.
('52', 52, 6, 12, 92151) This institution has been named “Vallabh Vidyalaya” and hence it has become the duty of all—the present and future managers of the Vidyalaya and those who will receive education here—to imbibe Vallabhbhai’s virtues and to teach others to do the same.
('52', 52, 6, 13, 92402) Vallabhbhai is an embodiment of sacrifice; Vallabh bhai is synonymous with courage; Vallabhbhai stands for heroism, for removal of distinctions between high and low.
('52', 52, 6, 14, 92568) Vallab hbhai does not regard Patidars as high and the others as low because they are Bhangis, Baraias and Patanwadias.
('52', 52, 6, 15, 92687) 1 To disprove these distinctions, the laying of the foundation has been entrusted to me.
('52', 52, 6, 16, 92776) Bhai Narahari has stated in his speech that for the most part the children of Dharala Thakores, and Patanwadias will receive education in this Vallabh Vidyalaya.
('52', 52, 6, 17, 92938) I put aside my work and came here only to meet the Dharala Thakores.
('52', 52, 6, 18, 93007) Ever since I made your acquaintance, I have recognized you as Thakores [leaders].
('52', 52, 6, 19, 93089) Those brothers among you who attended the mammoth meeting at Vadtal 2 will remember

('52', 53, 1, 2, 93318) that I had described you all as Dharala Thakores.

('52', 53, 2, 4, 93388) became Raniparaj, the Dharalas became known as Thakores.

('52', 53, 2, 13, 94140) Complete swaraj means a government in which we can run our own administration.

('52', 53, 2, 18, 94597) A government other than this is no government.

('52', 53, 2, 20, 94735) That will indeed be the government of the thirty crores of people of India.

('52', 53, 2, 26, 95179) You ought to know what our duty to the people is, why we should spin, why we should wear only khadi and why we should not wear cloth made even by mills in our country.
('52', 53, 2, 27, 95347) What a sad and shameful thing it is if you do not know all this!
('52', 53, 2, 28, 95412) If you do not know this, how can our administration run?
('52', 53, 2, 29, 95469) The Dharala Thakores, the Bhangis and all other communities can participate in our adminis tration.
('52', 53, 2, 30, 95569) It is for this that Shamalbhai is here.
('52', 53, 2, 31, 95609) You may say that the Patidars have exploited you to the uttermost limit.

('52', 54, 1, 22, 97340) In this Vidyalaya, those who have no money are going to be fed and clothed.

('52', 54, 1, 24, 97460) It is my desire that those who have money should study even by paying fees and there will come a time when I shall have to say that I shall set up as many schools as you require.
('52', 54, 1, 25, 97639) You may know that we have a plentiful supply of teachers and we shall get them from anywhere.
('52', 54, 1, 26, 97733) We shall teach boys and by and by even girls.
('52', 54, 1, 27, 97779) But all that depends on the extent to which you give encouragement to the Vallabh Vidyalaya.
('52', 54, 1, 28, 97872) You have asked for my blessings.
('52', 54, 1, 29, 97905) Them you certainly have.
('52', 54, 1, 30, 97930) But you have them on the condition that you impart lustre to this Vidyalaya and its name.
('52', 54, 1, 31, 98020) The Patidars also should benefit by it and should disgrace neither the Vallabh Vidyalaya nor my name.
('52', 54, 1, 32, 98122) I do not care for the sort of Vidyalaya which may prove a millstone round my neck and be a burden to me.
('52', 54, 1, 33, 98227) Education liberates us, frees us from bondage, helps us to shine, adds to the country’s wealth, enriches character; our boys and girls become smart and intelligent thereby.
('52', 54, 1, 34, 98400) This Vidyalaya has been established with this end in view.
('52', 54, 1, 35, 98459) May this end be realized.

('52', 55, 2, 5, 98812) 75. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS BORSAD, May 6, 1931
('52', 55, 3, 6, 98859) Interviewed by the Associated Press correspondent regarding the resolution passed by the Manchester Royal Exchange, Mahatma Gandhi said : The resolution of the Manchester Royal Exchange is partly based on misapprehension.
('52', 55, 3, 7, 99081) There is no hostility towards Britain in the present movement but, on the countrary, the Congressmen are trying against heavy odds to promote goodwill as far as it is possible under the present circumstances.
('52', 55, 3, 8, 99290) It is not sufficiently realized what trem endous step the Congress had taken in lifting boycott of British goods.
('52', 55, 3, 9, 99404) The boycott of foreign cloth should not be mixed up with British goods.
('52', 55, 3, 10, 99476) It is a misnomer to call boycott of foreign cloth as boycott.
('52', 55, 3, 11, 99538) That name therefore has been intentionally omitted from the Delhi Settlement.
('52', 55, 3, 12, 99616) I use the word boycott even for the exclusion of foreign cloth because it has become a current popular expression.
('52', 55, 3, 13, 99731) Nobody, however, mistakes its purpose.
('52', 55, 3, 14, 99770) The exclusion of foreign cloth does produce political conse quences but it is a predominantly economic and social proposition and an economic necessity for the semi starved millions.
('52', 55, 3, 15, 99953) Instead therefore of agitating against the permanent movement of economic uplift, if the leading men in Lan cashire will find out ways and means of disposing of their manu factures in other countries where they are wanted, they will save much time and really promote goodwill between the two countries.
('52', 55, 3, 16, 100256) I regard the attempt to suppress peaceful picketing as fruitless.
('52', 55, 3, 17, 100322) Surely Lord Irwin did not accept peaceful picketing of foreign cloth and liquor shops without sound reasons and anyone who studies this question as patiently as he did cannot but come to the same conclu sion as Lord Irwin.

('52', 56, 1, 2, 100616) 76. NOTES
('52', 56, 2, 3, 100626) SOLD LANDS1
('52', 56, 3, 4, 100638) To sell a farmer’s land and that for a song is vivisection.
('52', 56, 3, 5, 100698) The sale of forfeited lands in Gujarat was such an operation.
('52', 56, 3, 6, 100760) The clause in the Settlement about these lands was for Sardar Vallabhbhai the biggest bite to swallow.
('52', 56, 3, 7, 100863) But he swallowed it because ultimately he shared my faith that the lands could not long be withheld by the buyers from the original owners and in any case they were bound to be restored when the full settlement was attained.
('52', 56, 3, 8, 101088) It must be said to the credit of the buyers that they are one by one realizing the necessity of restoring the lands they made the mistake of buying.
('52', 56, 3, 9, 101237) The reader already knows how through the kind intervention of Sir Cowasji Jehangir, Syts.
('52', 56, 3, 10, 101327) Nariman, Vimadalal and Modi, Sardar Garda has agreed to restore to the original holders the lands bought by him in Bardoli Taluka and how Syt.
('52', 56, 3, 11, 101470) Cowasji of Kukadbeda and Thakur Khumansing of BORSAD have returned lands bought by them without asking for a refund of money paid by them.
('52', 56, 3, 12, 101609) The latest instances are those of Sheth Virchand in Bardoli and Thakore of Dehvan in BORSAD.
('52', 56, 3, 13, 101702) The Thakore would not think of having even the price paid by him returned to him.
('52', 56, 3, 14, 101784) He had paid Rs. 1,200 for nearly 120 acres of good land.
('52', 56, 3, 15, 101841) Three poor Dharalas too returned eleven acres which they had bought for Rs. 48 stating in their letter addressed to me that they were sorry that being poor they had to ask for the refund of the actual amount paid by them although they recognized that they should not ask for it.
('52', 56, 3, 16, 102120) It reflects credit on all these buyers for their having patriotically returned the lands.
('52', 56, 3, 17, 102210) I say patriotically for there was no pressure save that of silent public opinion brought to bear upon these buyers.
('52', 56, 3, 18, 102326) Their friends certainly approached them but there was no threat or coercion employed by anybody.
('52', 56, 3, 19, 102423) Healthy public opinion has an influence of which we have not realized the full significance.
('52', 56, 3, 20, 102516) But we are not yet out of the wood.
('52', 56, 3, 21, 102552) There are yet tough buyers who have not come forward.
('52', 56, 3, 22, 102606) But I have little doubt that if the workers don’t lose patience and the Settlement does not otherwise break down, they will also respond to the influence of that opinion.
('52', 56, 3, 23, 102777) Public opinion becomes intolerable when it becomes violent and aggressive.
('52', 56, 3, 24, 102852) I am happy to be able to inform the reader that otherwise too the things in Gujarat seem to be moving, though very slowly, towards a settlement.
('52', 56, 3, 25, 102997) How we are implementing the Truce in Gujarat

('52', 57, 3, 12, 104303) But generally speaking, we must, in view of the Settle ment try to bury the dead past and hope and work for a lasting settlement.

('52', 58, 2, 7, 105827) 77. POWER OF AHIMSA 1
('52', 58, 3, 8, 105849) A correspondent writes a Gujarati letter of which the following is a translations 2: If I have anywhere referred to India haivng received the fullest support from world opinion, it should be set down as an unconscious exaggeration.
('52', 58, 3, 9, 106081) I should like to be shown such a statement of mine if I have made one.
('52', 58, 3, 10, 106152) For myself I have absolutely no idea of having made any such statement.
('52', 58, 3, 11, 106224) The correspondent, by comparing the condition of unarmed India pitted against the British military power to that of a defenceless woman thrown at the tender mercy of a ruffian, has done an injustice to the strength as well of non violence as of woman.
('52', 58, 3, 12, 106476) Had not man in his blind selfishness crushed woman’s soul as he has done or had she not succumbed to ‘the enjoyments’ she would have given the world an exhibition of the infinite strength that is latent in her.
('52', 58, 3, 13, 106687) What she showed in the last fight was but a broken and imperfect glimpse of it.
('52', 58, 3, 14, 106767) The world shall see it in all its wonder and glory when woman has secured a equal opportunity for herself with man and fully developed her powers of mutual aid and combination.
('52', 58, 3, 15, 106944) And it is wrong to say that a person is unarmed in the sense of being weak who has ahimsa as his weapon.
('52', 58, 3, 16, 107049) The correspondent is evidently a stranger to the real use or the immeasurable power of ahimsa.
('52', 58, 3, 17, 107144) He has used it, if at all, only mechanically and as an expedience for want of a better.
('52', 58, 3, 18, 107232) Had he been saturated with the spirit of ahimsa, he would have known that it can tame the wildest beast, certainly the wildest man.
('52', 58, 3, 19, 107364) If, therefore, the world’s blood did not boil over the brutalities
('52', 58, 4, 20, 107431) 1 A similar article also appeared in Navajivan, 3 5 1931 under the heading “Why Did Not Their Blood Boil?” 2 Not reproduced here
('52', 59, 0, 1, 107560) 60 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 59, 1, 2, 107601) of the past year, it was not because the world was brutal or heartless but because our non violence, widespread through it was, good enough though it was for the purpose intended, was not the non violence of the strong and the knowing.
('52', 59, 1, 3, 107837) It did not spring from a living faith.
('52', 59, 1, 4, 107876) It was but a policy, a temporary expedient.
('52', 59, 1, 5, 107920) Though we did not retaliate, we had harboured anger, our speech was not free from violence, our thoughts still less so.
('52', 59, 1, 6, 108040) We generally refrained from violent action, because we were under discipline.
('52', 59, 1, 7, 108118) The world marvelled even at this limited exhibition of non violence and gave us, without any propaganda, the support and sympathy that we deserved and needed.
('52', 59, 1, 8, 108277) The rest is a matter of the rule of three.
('52', 59, 1, 9, 108320) If we had the support that we received for the limited and mechanical non violence we were able to practise during the recent struggle, how much more support should we command when we have risen to the full height of ahimsa?
('52', 59, 1, 10, 108545) Then the world’s blood will certainly boil.
('52', 59, 1, 11, 108589) I know we are still far away from that divine event.
('52', 59, 1, 12, 108642) We realized our weakness at Cawnpore, Benares, Mirzapur.
('52', 59, 1, 13, 108699) When we are saturated with ahimsa we shall not be non violent in our fight with the bureaucracy and violent among ourselves.
('52', 59, 1, 14, 108824) When we have a living faith in non violence, it will grow from day to day till it fills the whole world.
('52', 59, 1, 15, 108929) It will be the mightiest propaganda that the world will have witnessed.
('52', 59, 1, 16, 109001) I live in the belief that we will realize that vital ahimsa.
('52', 59, 1, 17, 109062) Young India, 7 5 1931
('52', 59, 2, 18, 109084) 78. DANGERS OF DEMOCRACY 1
('52', 59, 3, 19, 109111) There is no human institution but has its dangers.
('52', 59, 3, 20, 109162) The greater the institution the greater the chances of abuse.
('52', 59, 3, 21, 109224) Democracy is a great institution and therefore it is liable to be greatly abused.
('52', 59, 3, 22, 109306) The remedy therefore is not avoidance of democracy but reduction of possibility of abuse to a minimum.
('52', 59, 3, 23, 109409) The Congress has become a vast democratic body.
('52', 59, 3, 24, 109457) It reached a high water mark during the past twelve months.
('52', 59, 3, 25, 109517) Without being technically on the register millions took possession of it and added lustre to it.
('52', 59, 3, 26, 109614) But goondaism also entered the Congress to a much larger extent than hitherto.
('52', 59, 3, 27, 109693) It was inevitable.
('52', 59, 3, 28, 109712) The ordinary rules prescribed for the selection of volunteers were practically set aside during the last
('52', 59, 4, 29, 109817) 1 Navajivan, 3 5 1931; also published an article on the same subject, under the title “A House Divided Cannot Stand”.
('52', 60, 0, 1, 109935) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 61
('52', 60, 1, 2, 109976) stage of the struggle.
('52', 60, 1, 3, 109999) The result has been that in some places goon daism has made itself felt.
('52', 60, 1, 4, 110072) Some Congressmen have even been threatened with disaster if they will not give the money demanded of them.
('52', 60, 1, 5, 110179) Of course, professional goondas may also take advantage of the atmosphere and ply their trade.
('52', 60, 1, 6, 110274) The wonder is that the cases I have in mind are so very few compared to what they might have been, regard being had to the great mass awakening.
('52', 60, 1, 7, 110419) My conviction is that t his happy state is due to the Congress creed of non violence, even though we have but crudely followed it.
('52', 60, 1, 8, 110550) But there has been sufficient expression of goon daism to warn us to take time by the forelock and adopt preventive and precautionary measures.
('52', 60, 1, 9, 110694) The measures that suggest themselves to me are naturally and certainly a scientific and more intelligent and disciplined application of non violence.
('52', 60, 1, 10, 110844) In the first place if we had a firmer faith in non violence than we have shown not one man or woman who did not strictly conform to the rules regarding the admission of volunteers would have been taken.
('52', 60, 1, 11, 111047) It would be no answer to say that in that case there would have been no volunteers during the final stage and therefore there would have been a perfect failure.
('52', 60, 1, 12, 111208) My experience teaches me to the contrary.
('52', 60, 1, 13, 111250) It is possible to fight a non violent battle even with one satyagrahi.
('52', 60, 1, 14, 111321) But it, i.e., a non violent battle, cannot be fought with a million non satyagrahis.
('52', 60, 1, 15, 111406) And I would welcome even an utter failure with non violence unimpaired rather than depart from it by a hair’s breadth to achieve a doubtful success.
('52', 60, 1, 16, 111555) Without adopting a non compromising attitude so far as non violence is concerened, I can see nothing but disaster in the end.
('52', 60, 1, 17, 111681) For, at the critical moment we may be found wanting, weighed in the scales of non violence, and may be found hopelessly unprepared to meet the forces of disorder that might suddenly be arrayed against us.
('52', 60, 1, 18, 111886) But having made the mistake of indiscriminate recruiting how are we to repair the mischief in a non violent way?
('52', 60, 1, 19, 111999) Non violence means courage of the highest order and therefore readiness to suffer.
('52', 60, 1, 20, 112082) There should therefore be no yielding to bullying, bluff or worse, even though it may mean the loss of a few precious lives.
('52', 60, 1, 21, 112207) Writers of threatening letters should be made to realize that their threats will not be listened to.
('52', 60, 1, 22, 112308) But at the same time their disease must be diagnosed and properly treated.
('52', 60, 1, 23, 112383) Even the goondas are part of us and therefore they must be handled gently and sympathetically.
('52', 60, 1, 24, 112478) People generally do not take to goondaism for the love of it.
('52', 60, 1, 25, 112540) It is a symptom of a deeper 
('52', 61, 0, 1, 112569) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 61, 1, 2, 112610) seated disease in the body politic.
('52', 61, 1, 3, 112646) The same law should govern our relations with internal goondaism that we apply in our relations with the goondaism in the system of government.
('52', 61, 1, 4, 112790) And if we have felt that we have the ability to deal with that highly organized goodaism in a non violent manner, how much more should we feel the ability to deal with internal goondaism by the same method?
('52', 61, 1, 5, 112997) It follows that we may not seek police assistance to deal with the disease although it is open, during the Truce, to any Congress man to seek it precisely in the same manner as any other citizen.
('52', 61, 1, 6, 113193) The way I have suggested is the way of reform, conversion, love.
('52', 61, 1, 7, 113258) Seeking police assistance is the way of punishment, fear, want of affection if not actual disaffection.
('52', 61, 1, 8, 113362) The two methods therefore cannot run together.
('52', 61, 1, 9, 113409) The way of reform appears at some stage or other to be difficult but it is in reality the easiest.
('52', 61, 1, 10, 113508) Young India, 7 5 1931
('52', 61, 2, 11, 113530) 79. FOR ‘FOLLOWERS’ A friend sends me the following:
('52', 61, 3, 12, 113583) It will be very helpful if you will kindly guide your followers about their
('52', 61, 4, 13, 113659) conduct when they to engage in a political controversy.
('52', 61, 4, 14, 113715) Your guidance on the
('52', 61, 5, 15, 113736) following points is particularly needed: (a) Vilification so as to lower the opponent in public estimation.
('52', 61, 5, 16, 113844) (b) Kind of criticism of the opponent permissible.
('52', 61, 5, 17, 113895) (c) Limit to which hostility should be carried.
('52', 61, 6, 18, 113943) (d) Whether effort should be made to gain office and power.
('52', 61, 6, 19, 114003) I have said before in these pages that I claim no followers.
('52', 61, 6, 20, 114064) It is enough for me to be my own follower.
('52', 61, 6, 21, 114107) It is by itself a sufficiently taxing performance.
('52', 61, 6, 22, 114158) But I know that many claim to be my followers.
('52', 61, 6, 23, 114205) I must therefore answer the questions for their sakes.
('52', 61, 6, 24, 114260) If they will follow what I endeavour to stand for rather than me they will see that the following answers are derived from truth and ahimsa.
('52', 61, 6, 25, 114401) (a) Vilification of an opponent there can never be.
('52', 61, 6, 26, 114453) But this does not exclude a truthful characterization of his acts.
('52', 61, 6, 27, 114520) An opponent is not always a bad man because he opposes.
('52', 61, 6, 28, 114576) He may be as honourable as we may claim to be and yet there may be vital differences between him and us.
('52', 61, 6, 29, 114681) (b) Our criticism will therefore be if we believe him to be guilty of untruth to meet it with truth, of discourtesy with courtesy, of bully ing with calm courage, of violence with suffering, of arrogance with
('52', 62, 0, 1, 114890) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 63
('52', 62, 1, 2, 114931) humility, of evil with good.
('52', 62, 1, 3, 114960) ‘My follower’ would see not to condemn but to convert.
('52', 62, 1, 4, 115015) (c) There is no question of any limit to which hostility may be carried.
('52', 62, 1, 5, 115088) For there should be no hostility to persons.
('52', 62, 1, 6, 115133) Hostility there must be to acts when they are subversive of morals or the good of society.
('52', 62, 1, 7, 115224) (d) Office and power must be avoided.
('52', 62, 1, 8, 115262) Either may be accepted when it is clearly for greater service.
('52', 62, 1, 9, 115325) Young India, 7 5 1931

('52', 62, 8, 26, 116651) 11th April, 1931 JAMES P. RUTNAM I do not know that in reply to this letter 1 I need do more than refer the writer to my article in Young India.
('52', 62, 8, 27, 116796) 2 It might be as well to add that in mentioning Hinduism, Islam, Zoroastrianism, etc., as India’s religi ons, I had no desire to claim them as India’s exclusively
('52', 62, 9, 28, 116959) 1 Of which only excerpts have been reproduced here.
('52', 62, 9, 29, 117011) 2 Vide “Foreign Missionaries”, 23 4 1931
('52', 63, 0, 1, 117052) 64 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 63, 1, 2, 117093) or to exclude Christianity.
('52', 63, 1, 3, 117121) The issue was Christianity on the one hand claimed as the one true religion and other religions on the other being regarded as false.
('52', 63, 1, 4, 117255) In joining issue I contended that the great world religions other than Christianity professed in India were no less true than Christianity.
('52', 63, 1, 5, 117395) It was thus neither relevant nor necessary for me to assert before Christian missionaries and their protagonists that Christianity was true.
('52', 63, 1, 6, 117536) Moreover, with my known partiality for the Sermon on the Mount and my repeated declarations that its author was one of the greatest among the teachers of mankind I could not suspect that there would be any charge against me of underrating Christianity.
('52', 63, 1, 7, 117789) As for Christian, Indians, I count among them many warm friends and I have had no difficulty whatsoever in establishing friendly touch with the Christian masses wherever I have gone.
('52', 63, 1, 8, 117972) Nor is there any fear of my estranging even the foreign missionaries among whom I claim many personal friends.
('52', 63, 1, 9, 118083) The attack against me has therefore surprised me not a little especially because the views I have now enunciated have been held by me since 1916, and were deliberately expressed in a carefully written address read before a purely missionary audience in Madras and since repeated on many a Christian platform.
('52', 63, 1, 10, 118392) The recent criticism has but confirmed the view, for the criticism has betrayed intolerance even of friendly criticism.
('52', 63, 1, 11, 118512) The missionaries know that in spite of my outspoken criticism of their methods, they have in India and among non christians no warmer friend than I. And I suggest to my critics that there must be something wrong about their method or, if they prefer, themselves when they will not brook sincere expression of an opinion different from theirs.
('52', 63, 1, 12, 118855) In India under swaraj I have no doubt that foreign missionaries will be at liberty to do their proselytizing, as I would say, in the wrong way; but they would be expected to bear with those who, like me, may point out that in their opinion the way is wrong.
