('52', 66, 9, 15, 124056) 1 In his reply dated May 13, Maxwell stated : “You have suggested that the word “returned” in clause 16(a) of the Agreement should be interpreted to mean “taken back to the place where the property was seized”.
('52', 66, 9, 16, 124267) In the absence, however, of any such explana tion in the terms of the Settlement itself, the Government are unable to attach to the word in question any but its ordinary meaning, viz., “given back”, and, while they are ready at any time to carry out the agreement in this sense, they do not feel justified in throwing On the taxpayers the expense of transporting the articles from the places where they now are.
('52', 66, 9, 17, 124679) I am to say that your further contention that the Government are responsible for delivering such articles in the same condition in which they were seized, does not appear to be warranted by anything in the terms of the Settlement.
('52', 66, 9, 18, 124910) On the contrary clause 16(c) of the Settlement expressly says that “compensation will not be given for deterioration”.
('52', 66, 9, 19, 125029) I am to add that under section 4(3) of Ordinance IX of 1930 even property seized but not forfeited may be used in such manner as the Magistrate may direct.
('52', 66, 9, 20, 125185) The motor car and cycle now in question were, however, actually forfeited and had they been sold or destroyed, the original owners would have had no further claim to them, since clause 16(a) of the Settlement agrees to the return of seized moveable property only if it is still in the possession of Government.
('52', 66, 9, 21, 125496) I am therefore to express the hope that you will now make arrangements to take delivery of these forfeited articles without more delay, since it will not be possible for Government to be responsible for their custody indefinitely if those interested do not choose to avail themselves of clause 16(a) of the Settlement.

('52', 69, 10, 17, 128959) 89. STATEMENT TO THE PRESS BORSAD, May 8, 1931
('52', 69, 11, 18, 129006) It is astonishing how ignorant responsible Englishmen, like Mr. Grey 2, are as to the real condition.
('52', 69, 11, 19, 129108) I have to impute ignorance to Mr. Grey as I could not bring myself to believe that he was wilfully distorting the real condition.
('52', 69, 11, 20, 129238) The Delhi Agreement tabooed threats, intimidation and coercion of every form in connection with picketing
('52', 69, 12, 21, 129344) 1 From Vatan G. Gidwani, President, District Congress Committee, Mirpurkhas (Sind).
('52', 69, 12, 22, 129428) He had mentioned that one Thakurdas, who had styled himself as Secretary of the Congress Committee, was inciting cloth merchants to revolt against the Congress decision to boycott foreign cloth.
('52', 69, 12, 23, 129623) 2 Acting Chairman, Master Cotton Spinners and Manufacturers’ Association
('52', 70, 0, 1, 129696) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 71
('52', 70, 1, 2, 129737) which has to be absolutely peaceful.

('52', 73, 1, 2, 135840) 93. LETTER TO DARCY LINDSAY
('52', 73, 2, 3, 135868) SABARMATI, [AS AT] May 8, 1931
('52', 73, 3, 4, 135899) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of the 24th April.
('52', 73, 3, 5, 135959) The matter you refer to is very delicate.
('52', 73, 3, 6, 136001) There is a romance around the life of Bhagat Singh.
('52', 73, 3, 7, 136053) He was no coward.
('52', 73, 3, 8, 136071) From all enquiries made by me I find that he was a man of spotless character and of great daring.
('52', 73, 3, 9, 136169) He exercised also great influence on some young men.
('52', 73, 3, 10, 136222) Somehow or other he had developed a belief that political assassination had its use.
('52', 73, 3, 11, 136307) It was impossible not to notice the execution, I believe quite unwise, of Bhagat Singh and his comrades, whom the execution made martyrs.
('52', 73, 3, 12, 136445) I have no doubt whatsoever that the execution has surrounded these lives with a halo which they would not otherwise have had.
('52', 73, 3, 13, 136571) The only thing therefore that was possible and that the Congress was bound to do was to pass a resolution 1 condemning murderous deeds as also the execution and at the same time appreciating the bravery and sacrifice underlying such deeds.
('52', 73, 3, 14, 136811) I however quite agree with you that there is undoubtedly a great deal of thoughtless approval of political murder.
('52', 73, 3, 15, 136926) But many of us are doing everything we can to counteract the growth of the violent revolutionary movement.
('52', 73, 3, 16, 137033) Whilst it is being held under check, I fear that the spirit that is at times breaking out in violence will not altogether die till India comes to her own.
('52', 73, 3, 17, 137188) I am not publishing your letter because the end both you and I have in view is not likely to be served thereby.
('52', 73, 4, 18, 137300) Yours sincerely,
('52', 73, 5, 19, 137317) SIR DARCY LINDSAY MANDELIEU CANNES, A.M. [FRANCE]

('52', 79, 4, 6, 145062) 104. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS BORSAD, May 8, 1931
('52', 79, 5, 7, 145110) Regarding the report published in a Bombay paper about the refusal by Sardar Garda to return the confiscated lands purchased by him in Bardoli Taluk, Mr. Gandhi, interviewed, said that the report was correct, but added that so far as he knew there was no obstruction deliberate or otherwise on the part of men who had strict instructions not to interfere with those who might be removing crops from the fields in question.
('52', 79, 5, 8, 145533) He had undertaken to enquire into every complaint that might be made by Sardar Garda.
('52', 79, 5, 9, 145619) He had asked for specific instances and not one was supplied to him.
('52', 79, 5, 10, 145688) He was therefore pain ed and surprised at Sardar Garda’s attempt to evade or repudiate the agreement which after full deliberation he had entered into.
('52', 79, 5, 11, 145840) Mr. Gandhi had at ready brought the matter to the notice of Sir Cowasji Jehangir 1 who was the principal negotiator.
('52', 79, 6, 12, 145957) Asked whether Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel had asked the people of Bardoli Taluk not to pay unauthorized arrears, Mr. Gandhi said it was not a question of Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel asking people not to pay arrears.
('52', 79, 6, 13, 146164) It was a question of inability on the part of people to pay.
('52', 79, 6, 14, 146225) The fact was it was really difficult to pay even the current year’s dues in many cases.
('52', 79, 6, 15, 146313) In affected areas of both Surat and Kaira districts, they were obliged to ask for suspension even in some cases in respect of current year’s dues.
('52', 79, 6, 16, 146460) The chief thing to aim at was not insisting on pound of flesh but to see that the political movement for non payment of taxes was discontinued in a bona fide
('52', 79, 7, 17, 146618) manner and people paid whatever they could under the circumstances.
('52', 79, 7, 18, 146686) The Hindu, 9 5 1931

('52', 85, 1, 2, 157281) MARRIAGE CONDITIONS The common custom in regard to marriage in the Anavil community is that the bride’s father has to pay a handsome sum to the birdegroom’s father.
('52', 85, 1, 3, 157446) In the Bardoli swaraj Ashram, there is a gentleman named Shri Dayalji Gulabbhai who lives under the care of Shri Lakshmidas.
('52', 85, 1, 4, 157571) He had married once and had lost his wife.
('52', 85, 1, 5, 157614) That was some time ago and he has no children.
('52', 85, 1, 6, 157661) He thought of marrying again.
('52', 85, 1, 7, 157691) He felt, however, that he should not marry during struggle.
('52', 85, 1, 8, 157751) When the Settlement came about, he was inclined to yield to desire.
('52', 85, 1, 9, 157819) A father was prepared to marry his daughter to Shri Dayalji by paying him a sum of Rs. 800. He may have been momentarily tempted, but was later able to overcome the temptation.
('52', 85, 1, 10, 157996) He will now marry a seventeen year old girl named Shantabehn.
('52', 85, 1, 11, 158058) As the conditions on which this marriage is to take place are both worth knowing and worth copying, I give them below : The dowry will be accepted in the form of yarn instead of cash.
('52', 85, 1, 12, 158242) And that yarn weighing eight and a quarter pounds should be spun exclusively by members of the family.
('52', 85, 1, 13, 158345) Not more than twenty five persons in all consisting of fifteen persons from the bride’s side and ten from the bridegroom’s side (including men, women and children) should be invited and all of them must be clad in khadi.
('52', 85, 2, 14, 158566) Everyone should eat food cooked in a common kitchen and the meal should consist only of dal, rice and vegetables.
('52', 85, 2, 15, 158680) As it is summer, there would be no harm in taking buttermilk.
('52', 85, 2, 16, 158742) They would stop the custom of offering ghee to Brahmins.
('52', 85, 3, 17, 158799) Whereas no gifts in the form of cash from relations or as dowry will be accepted, giving of religious books will be permitted.
('52', 85, 4, 18, 158926) After the marriage takes place, those present will be allowed to take fruits or sherbet instead of betel leaves and areca nuts.
('52', 85, 4, 19, 159054) Tea will not be served at all.
('52', 85, 4, 20, 159085) By way of dowry, only such things as a spinning wheel, carding bow, takli, or carpet or something to sit upon should be given.
('52', 85, 4, 21, 159212) Such edible items as sweet balls and puris or any such articles of food should not be accepted in any form.
('52', 85, 4, 22, 159320) At the wedding ceremony, the bride and the bridegroom will wear garments made of yarn spun with their own hands.
('52', 85, 4, 23, 159433) No clothes will be bought for this purpose.
('52', 85, 4, 24, 159477) Likewise, if anyone wishes to make a present, he would be permitted to give only yarn spun by him.
('52', 85, 5, 25, 159576) At the time of the wedding, the bride will wear no ornament other than a single piece of each item symbolizing her state of married happiness.
('52', 85, 5, 26, 159719) Later, she may accept anything, which anyone wishes to give.
('52', 86, 0, 1, 159780) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 87
('52', 86, 1, 2, 159821) The interval between arrival and departure for the wedding will be three days during which the ceremony will be performed.
('52', 86, 2, 3, 159944) Bangles made of hand spun yarn should replace those made of gold.
('52', 86, 3, 4, 160010) The marriage ceremony will be in accordance with Ashram practice.
('52', 86, 4, 5, 160076) Gandhiji’s articles on the shastrik rites regarding marriage vows and his
('52', 86, 5, 6, 160150) speeches will be read out.

('52', 86, 8, 13, 160462) Even ordinary marriages in the Anavil community involve large expenses, hence it is no small matter that in this marriage only the religious ceremony has found a place and khadi is compulsory for the bride and the groom as well as for the guests present to bless the couple and the priest.
('52', 86, 8, 14, 160752) Dhardhaman implies dowry.
('52', 86, 8, 15, 160778) The bride’s father provides all household articles by way of dowry; whereas in this marriage only the implements needed for spinning may be given, if so desired.
('52', 86, 8, 16, 160940) Let us hope that this example will be copied and such marriages will become a common practice among all communities and that the couples, united under such auspicious circumstances, will turn out to be true servants of the country.

('52', 92, 10, 10, 170608) 118. NOTES
('52', 92, 11, 11, 170619) ‘A CRY IN THE WILDERNESS’ I take the following passage with slight changes from a communication in my file : Protection of indigenous cloth by exclusion of foreign cloth and foreign yarn from the country—this is vague and gives room for suspicion.
('52', 92, 11, 12, 170867) The starving millions living in the villages cannot be fed by the Indian mills.
('52', 92, 11, 13, 170947) For the last four months the demand for khadi has been going down steadily and that for mill cloth is increasing.
('52', 92, 11, 14, 171061) The reason is that Congress organizations are supporting the Indian mill manufacture.
('52', 92, 11, 15, 171147) Gandhiji’s cry of boycott through khadi is a cry in the wilderness.
('52', 92, 11, 16, 171215) Therefore the real position of the Congress with regard to khadi must be made clear.
('52', 92, 11, 17, 171300) I have had a similar complaint from other sources too.
('52', 92, 11, 18, 171355) There is no doubt that the Congressmen think that because the Congress is having help from and dealings with mill owners, Congressmen are free to use mill manufactures in the place of khadi or at least to use either optionally.
('52', 92, 11, 19, 171583) Such however is certainly not the case.
('52', 92, 11, 20, 171623) The Con gress policy in this matter remains unchanged.
('52', 92, 11, 21, 171678) The Congress expects everyone under its influence to use hand spun and hand woven khadi to the exclusion of all other cloth.
('52', 92, 11, 22, 171803) Any laxity in this observance is not only bound to harm khadi and therefore the villages but it is also bound to harm boycott of foreign cloth.
('52', 92, 11, 23, 171947) It will be found that in the end the boycott will be possible only through khadi.

('52', 93, 1, 4, 172425) But it is contended that the mills came in when the owners realized that khadi was doing it, that khadi had shown the way, that khadi had brought about the psychological change.

('52', 94, 3, 4, 174906) 119. DANGER LOOMING 1
('52', 94, 4, 5, 174928) The public know little of what took place in Karachi the other day.
('52', 94, 4, 6, 174996) A half cracked man like me by name Gajadhar Shau from Central Provinces but as little known there as in Karachi took it into his head that he could establish swaraj in a few days.
('52', 94, 4, 7, 175176) He collected all the unemployed and other labourers, promising them two them two rupees per day and delivered an ultimatum to the merchants and moneyed men that they should stop export and import business, stop the manufacture of mill cloth, collect one crore rupees in a fortnight and utilize it for giving employment to all who were in need at a level wage of two rupees per day through the spinning wheel and the like.
('52', 94, 4, 8, 175598) Meetings were held and fierce resolutions were passed.
('52', 94, 4, 9, 175653) Keys of safes of were demanded.
('52', 94, 4, 10, 175685) The indefatigable Mayor of Karachi met the men and in a lucid moment Sjt.
('52', 94, 4, 11, 175759) Gajadhar said he would stop his activity if I disapproved of it.
('52', 94, 4, 12, 175824) This was good enough for Sjt.
('52', 94, 4, 13, 175854) Jamshed Mehta and his friends and Sjt.
('52', 94, 4, 14, 175893) Gajadhar who by this time had become a Mahatma came to me as also later Sjts.
('52', 94, 4, 15, 175971) Sidhwa and Isherdas.
('52', 94, 4, 16, 175992) I recognized in Sjt.
('52', 94, 4, 17, 176013) Gajadhar an old correspondent who always tried my and my co workers’ patience by sending long letters and even wires.
('52', 94, 4, 18, 176131) We became friends on sight.
('52', 94, 4, 19, 176159) I had to give him nearly two hours I could scarcely spare.
('52', 94, 4, 20, 176218) The upshot of it all was that he promised to stop his activity though I did not carry conviction to him.
('52', 94, 4, 21, 176323) Whether he will carry out his promise remains to be seen.
('52', 94, 4, 22, 176381) Even if he does not, the workers of Karachi will be able to deal effectively with any crisis that may arise.
('52', 94, 4, 23, 176490) But the incident of Karachi is a portent.

('52', 94, 4, 26, 176805) But discip line is to disorder what bulwarks and embankments are to storms and floods.

('52', 95, 1, 4, 177364) Gajadhar Shau there was a substratum of truth.

('52', 98, 3, 11, 185118) 122. THE ALLAHABAD CONGRESS HOSPITAL : AN APPEAL
('52', 98, 4, 12, 185167) In June last year Pandit Motilal Nehru visited Bombay and saw the good work that the Congress hospital was doing there.
('52', 98, 4, 13, 185287) He was impressed by this and, on his return to Allahabad, he expressed a desire that a similar hospital be started in Allahabad also.
('52', 98, 4, 14, 185421) Largely owing to the generosity of friends in Bombay, some funds and material were collected for the proposed hospital.
('52', 98, 4, 15, 185541) On pandit Motilalji’s discharge from prison, the hospital was formally started in a wing of Swaraj Bhawan.
('52', 98, 5, 16, 185648) The limited funds collected have now been exhausted and the committee had to consider whether it should continue the hospital or not.
('52', 98, 5, 17, 185782) This appeal for financial assistance is therefore being issued in the hope that there will be a generous response to it.
('52', 98, 5, 18, 185903) The question of having a permanent hospital in Swaraj Bhawan has not been decided yet.
('52', 98, 5, 19, 185990) But the committee would like to have sufficient funds for the carrying on of the hospital for at least three years.
('52', 98, 5, 20, 186106) The estimated expenditure on the hospital, if it is run on its present limited scale, is rupees one thousand a month.
('52', 98, 6, 21, 186224) KAMALA NEHRU
('52', 98, 7, 22, 186237) MOHANLAL NEHRU RAMAKANT MALAVIYA May 11, 1931 I hope that the foregoing appeal 1 will receive a quick res ponse from the public.
('52', 98, 7, 23, 186366) It has been purposely not signed by any except those who are connected with the management of the hospital, because it is not to be in any way considered as a national

('52', 99, 1, 2, 186622) memorial.

('52', 105, 1, 2, 198858) 131. SPEECH AT PUBLIC MEETING, SIMLA
('52', 105, 2, 3, 198895) May 14, 1931 You will like to hear why I have come to Simla and what talk I am having with the Government.
('52', 105, 2, 4, 199002) I cannot tell you everything, but I can tell you that I came to hold consultation with regard to the complaints on our side as well as on the Government side with regard to the Settlement arrived at between Lord Irwin and the Congress.
('52', 105, 2, 5, 199238) These consultations still continue.
('52', 105, 2, 6, 199274) What I have to emphasize is that if you are Congress sewak 1 and want to serve Hindustan, then it is your duty to observe that Agreement irrespective of whether the Govern ment observes it or not.
('52', 105, 2, 7, 199471) After we have fulfilled our obligation, and if after that we find the Government has not fulfilled it we can take whatever step we like.
('52', 105, 2, 8, 199608) We know that whatever settlement has been arrived at is conditional, but if we can use the settlement for some work, we should do it.
('52', 105, 2, 9, 199742) As a satyagrahi, if we get an opportunity for service as a fesult of understanding, we should welcome it.
('52', 105, 2, 10, 199848) That opportunity came your way through the Settlement.
('52', 105, 2, 11, 199903) The Karachi Congress practically unanimously adopted it.
('52', 105, 2, 12, 199960) Now our duty is what I have described.
('52', 105, 2, 13, 199999) Do not think that after this Settlement we have to go to war.
('52', 105, 2, 14, 200061) We should, on the other hand, do everything to see that we are not led to war and that the Settlement should become permanent, so that we may get purna swaraj.
('52', 105, 2, 15, 200221) You know the conditions that have been imposed by Congress on such of your delegates as will go to London to attend the Round Table Conference.
('52', 105, 2, 16, 200365) But if, as the result of settlement, we cannot get complete swaraj, it is our ill luck, and if our efforts towards a permanent settlement fail, we should be ready for a fresh struggle.
('52', 105, 2, 17, 200550) But there are two points more which I wish to emphasize besides the Settlement.
('52', 105, 2, 18, 200630) If we wish to achieve what we want at the Round Table Conference, we must be properly equipped :and that equipment is that all the people of India—people who are born here and have made India their home, whether Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Christians, Parsis and others—should unite in the demand for swaraj.
('52', 105, 2, 19, 200935) Unless we bring about such an understanding among ourselves my going to London is useless.
('52', 105, 2, 20, 201026) Therefore we should all make such efforts as would make for unity among all communities in this country.
('52', 105, 3, 21, 201131) 1 Volunteer
('52', 106, 0, 1, 201143) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 107
('52', 106, 1, 2, 201185) But I do not want unity on paper.
('52', 106, 1, 3, 201219) If we write out a pact on paper, unity is not thereby achieved.
('52', 106, 1, 4, 201283) The unity I want is the unity of heart and for that unity I always pray.
('52', 106, 1, 5, 201356) And when that unity is achieved you will gain such strength as will give us success.
('52', 106, 1, 6, 201441) I am afraid my voice is not reaching you all and that you are feeling upset by rain.
('52', 106, 1, 7, 201526) Let me pray to God that we may be saved a second struggle and that this Settlement may lead to final success.
('52', 106, 1, 8, 201636) As regards work, you have the Congress resolution before you and you have every scope for work in respect of the spread of khaddar and boycott of liquor.
('52', 106, 1, 9, 201790) I thank you all.
('52', 106, 1, 10, 201807) The Hindustan Times, 16 5 1931

('52', 109, 3, 12, 206064) 139. LETTER TO A. FENNER BROCKWAY
('52', 109, 4, 13, 206098) AS AT SABARMATI, May 16, 1931
('52', 109, 5, 14, 206128) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your cablegram which has been redirected to me here.
('52', 109, 5, 15, 206210) I am not replying by cable as my opinion remains the same as I explained to you in a previous letter.
('52', 109, 5, 16, 206312) I gave you only one reason preventing me from going to London.
('52', 109, 5, 17, 206375) But I should have mentioned another also namely the work of the Settlement.
('52', 109, 5, 18, 206451) Though I am receiving help at the centre, local authorities are giving great deal of trouble in implementing the Settlement and they are accusing local Congressmen of breach on their part.
('52', 109, 5, 19, 206640) I have ample evidence and I am investigating every case of breach on the part of individuals, but in the vast majority of cases Congressmen have fully implemented the Settle ment.
('52', 109, 5, 20, 206820) I am making no mention whatsoever of breach on the part of the authorities whilst I am still negotiating with them and in the hope that things will be put right in the near future.
('52', 109, 5, 21, 207001) But this thing practi cally takes away all my time and keeps me in India.
('52', 109, 5, 22, 207075) Yours sincerely, FENNER BROCKWAY, ESQ.

('52', 111, 2, 4, 208837) A graduate asks: 1
('52', 111, 3, 5, 208856) This is partly true.

('52', 111, 3, 7, 209153) Such reforms ought to come about at the end of a great sacrifice.
('52', 111, 3, 8, 209219) What, however, is surprising is that despite the sacrifice, despite correct understanding of the situation, untouchability has not been totally uprooted.
('52', 111, 3, 9, 209373) At many places the untouchables are still prohibited from drawing water from the village well, their children cannot freely attend all public schools, caste distinctions and conside rations of high and low still persist, mutual quarrels still take place, girls continue to be sold, young men continue to expect to receive cash from a girl’s father.
('52', 111, 3, 10, 209722) What is the reason for this?
('52', 111, 3, 11, 209751) Our attention is directed outwards, we do not look within our sleves.
('52', 111, 3, 12, 209821) We find it exciting to fight the Government.
('52', 111, 3, 13, 209866) We adopt those reforms which are absolutely necessary for carrying on that struggle and continuing it.
('52', 111, 3, 14, 209969) But we find no excitement in fighting against our selves, in carrying on a peaceful war against society, or we find it less exciting to do so.

('52', 111, 3, 18, 210466) It is clear as daylight that swaraj is nothing but the development of all sections of the people.
('52', 111, 3, 19, 210564) Hence if the rural workers now come forward in large numbers and carry out these tasks silently and with determ ination and diligence, darkness will disappear and dawn will break.

('52', 113, 2, 10, 213926) 144. PUBLIC EXPENSE 1
('52', 113, 3, 11, 213948) No province in India has enjoyed such privileges in the matter of public funds as Gujarat.
('52', 113, 3, 12, 214039) The Gujarat Provincial Congress Committee has never found its exchequer empty.
('52', 113, 3, 13, 214118) Nor have its district or taluk branches ever been left to want the funds that they needed.
('52', 113, 3, 14, 214209) It has been my conviction for years that such affluence cannot be good for any public institution.
('52', 113, 3, 15, 214308) There comes a point in the life of every institution that has a prestige in public, when it experiences this plethora of funds and all the risks and dangers attendant on it.
('52', 113, 3, 16, 214482) At that time, if it does not take care and does not spend like a miser, it is bound to come to grief.
('52', 113, 3, 17, 214584) Because an institution happens to have plenty of funds it does not mean that it should anyhow spend away every pie that it possesses.
('52', 113, 3, 18, 214718) The golden rule is not to hesitate to ask for or spend even a crore when it is absolutely necessary and when it is not, to hoard up every pie though one may have a crore of rupees at one’s disposal.
('52', 113, 3, 19, 214917) I am afraid that this golden rule has not been always followed by the Gujarat Committees.
('52', 113, 3, 20, 215007) In fact I should not be surprised if I discovered the existence even of a certain laxity in this respect.
('52', 113, 3, 21, 215113) I would therefore suggest to every Taluka and District Congress

('52', 114, 1, 3, 215460) We may not build a pucca building when a thatched cottage would do.

('52', 114, 1, 7, 216011) Ten years ago there used to be a golden rule in Gujarat that every District, Village or Taluka Congress Committee was expected to raise sufficient funds at least for its needs and to deposit them with the Provincial Congress Committee.
('52', 114, 1, 8, 216247) The practice remained in force for some years and then fell into abeyance.

('52', 115, 1, 3, 218069) It is a fundamental principle of satya graha that the tyrant whom the satyagrahi seeks to resist has power over his body and material possessions but he can have no power over the soul.
('52', 115, 1, 4, 218255) The soul can remain unconquered and unconquerable even when the body is imprisoned.
('52', 115, 1, 5, 218339) The whole science of satyagraha was born from a knowledge of this fundamental truth.

('52', 115, 1, 9, 218900) Nor should one suppose that a ‘careful for nothing’ person shall have always to be starving.
('52', 115, 1, 10, 218993) God that provides the little ant its speck of food and to the elephant his daily one maund bolus will not neglect to provide man with his daily meal.
('52', 115, 1, 11, 219143) Nature’s creatures do not worry or fret about tomorrow but simply wait on tomorrow for the daily sustenance.
('52', 115, 1, 12, 219252) Only man in his overweaning pride and egotism imagines himself to be the lord and master of the earth and goes on piling up for himself goods that perish.
('52', 115, 1, 13, 219407) Nature tries every day by its rude shocks to wean him from his pride but he refuses to shed it.
('52', 115, 1, 14, 219503) Satyagraha is a specific for bringing home to one the lesson of humility.

('52', 117, 3, 12, 222521) 148. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('52', 117, 4, 13, 222549) May 17, 1931
('52', 117, 5, 14, 222562) Mahatma Gandhi stated that he was on the whole satisfied with his visit and he was able to understand that so far as the Central Government was concerned they were trying to give effect to the terms of the Delhi Pact.
('52', 117, 5, 15, 222780) He reiterated his attitude that he would go to the London Conference if the communal question was solved and if there was a satisfactory working of the Pact throughout India.
('52', 117, 6, 16, 222955) As for the communal problem itself he recognized there was a good deal of mistrust but after Bhopal discussion; he was more optimistic.
('52', 117, 6, 17, 223091) QUESTION.
('52', 117, 6, 18, 223101) Supposing you or the Congress do not attend the Round Table
('52', 117, 7, 19, 223161) Conference and the Conference produces a constitution which is approved by Parliament.
('52', 117, 7, 20, 223248) What would be the attitude of the Congress?
('52', 117, 7, 21, 223292) ANSWER.
('52', 117, 7, 22, 223300) I may speak on behalf of the Congress that it will examine the scheme and if good, will certainly work it.
('52', 117, 8, 23, 223407) Q. Do you believe in self determination?
('52', 117, 9, 24, 223448) A. Yes.
('52', 117, 10, 25, 223456) Q. Would you allow any province to exercise self determination and separate herself from India?
('52', 117, 10, 26, 223552) A. I shall fight through reason but shall not impose my will by force of arms.
('52', 117, 11, 27, 223631) Pressed regarding his views on the communal problem, he reiterated his position that if the Sikhs and Mohammedans presented agreed demands, he would accept them unhesitatingly 1.
('52', 117, 12, 28, 223810) 1 What follows is from The Statesman.
('52', 118, 0, 1, 223848) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 119
('52', 118, 1, 2, 223890) When asked whether he did not think it a pity that nation wide progress should wait for local settlements, he said: Well, if we can look after the pennies, we can look after the pounds too.
('52', 118, 1, 3, 224080) Why do I insist on this?
('52', 118, 1, 4, 224105) These local settlements are like the straws which show the way the wind is blowing, and that wind may turn the weather vane even of the Round Table Conference—even perhaps veer it right round.
('52', 118, 2, 5, 224298) Q. The Bombay Chronicle says: “Need we repeat that the most effective
('52', 118, 3, 6, 224368) method speeding up the work of the Round Table Conference and making it completely successful, is to intensify the boycott of foreign cloth?’ That obviously means that The Bombay Chronicle regards the boycott as a political weapon and as a
('52', 118, 4, 7, 224608) discriminatory weapon, because a boycott of Japanese cloth could hardly speed up the work of the Round Table Conference.
('52', 118, 4, 8, 224729) Don’t you think that that sort of talk is inconsistent with both the spirit and the letter of the Delhi Agreement?
('52', 118, 5, 9, 224844) A. I have not seen the article from which you have quoted.
('52', 118, 5, 10, 224903) But I can say broadly that it would be inconsistent both with the spirit and the letter of the Pact to think of the foreign cloth boycott as a political weapon.
('52', 118, 5, 11, 225064) Foreign cloth includes Japanese cloth just as much as British cloth, if not much more at present, for the simple reason that it ousts khadi and Indian mill cloth far more effectively than British cloth.
('52', 118, 5, 12, 225267) The economic and social reasons for the boycott are all sufficing.
('52', 118, 6, 13, 225334) Q. How far are you prepared to go to conciliate the British Conservatives’ anxiety about safeguards?
('52', 118, 7, 14, 225435) A. To the utmost extent, consistent with the interests and honour of India.
('52', 118, 8, 15, 225511) In answer to the question whether he thought the local difficulties in respect
('52', 118, 9, 16, 225590) of the Agreement would be removed, say by July, Gandhiji replied: That I can’t say.
('52', 118, 9, 17, 225674) But of course, I hope so, and I have hopes that they will.
('52', 118, 10, 18, 225733) Q. And the Hindu Muslim question?
('52', 118, 10, 19, 225767) What do you think of the steps taken at
('52', 118, 11, 20, 225807) the Bhopal meetings of Muslims?
('52', 118, 12, 21, 225839) A. They are encouraging, and both the Muslim parties are evidently doing their best to arrive at unity among themselves.
('52', 118, 12, 22, 225960) But, of course, when I speak of the Hindu Muslim question I mean the entire communal question.
('52', 118, 12, 23, 226055) When the Hindu Muslim side of the matter is brought up, the Sikhs, for instance, will have their say.
('52', 118, 12, 24, 226157) There will be difficulties.
('52', 118, 12, 25, 226185) I hope that they will not prove insurmountable.
('52', 119, 0, 1, 226233) 120 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 119, 1, 2, 226275) Q. So you will really go to Round Table Conference, whether early or late, when those two problems are out of the way?
('52', 119, 2, 3, 226394) A. Yes, certainly.
('52', 119, 2, 4, 226413) And I shall be very pleased to go, because I hope that when I get to England I shall find the British people not uninterested in what I have to say and open to conviction by what I tell them.
('52', 119, 2, 5, 226605) Or, at the worst, I hope I shall persuade them that I am only a harmless lunatic.

('52', 119, 4, 8, 226722) even Lord Rothermere.
('52', 119, 5, 9, 226744) The Hindustan Times, 20 5 1951, and The Statesman, 19 5 1931
('52', 119, 6, 10, 226805) 149. MESSAGE TO KARNATAK PROVINCIAL CONFERENCE 1
('52', 119, 7, 11, 226854) [May 18, 1931 ] 2
('52', 119, 8, 12, 226872) The resolution on fundamental rights is the most important resolution of the Congress.
('52', 119, 8, 13, 226959) It shows what kind of swaraj the Congress wants to achieve.
('52', 119, 8, 14, 227019) That swaraj is the poor man’s swaraj or Ramarajya.
('52', 119, 8, 15, 227070) Rama symbolized justice and equity, Rama symbolized truth and charity.
('52', 119, 8, 16, 227141) The resolution insists on religious toleration, which means, that no one will be prevented from discharging his religious obligations, and the State shall favour no religion.
('52', 119, 8, 17, 227316) Justice and equity mean the establishment of just and equitable relation between capital and labour, between the landlord and the tenant.
('52', 119, 8, 18, 227454) The landlord and the capitalist will cease to exploit the tenant and the labourer but will studiously protect his interests.
('52', 119, 8, 19, 227579) Not that these things will be there as a matter of course as soon as we get the powers.
('52', 119, 8, 20, 227667) I only mean that they will follow as the natural consequence of truth and non violence if swaraj is achieved by those means.
('52', 119, 8, 21, 227792) The question is whether we are following truth and non violence.
('52', 119, 8, 22, 227857) Ramarajya cannot be the result of truth and non violence followed as a mere temporary expedient or policy.
('52', 119, 8, 23, 227964) Ramarajya can only come out of truth and non violence pursued as a creed.
('52', 119, 8, 24, 228038) Could a son ever fulfil his filial duties as a policy?
('52', 119, 8, 25, 228093) Policy is essentially a temporary expedient which one might alter as circums tances altered.
('52', 119, 9, 26, 228186) 1 Vide also “Letter to Jamnalal Bajaj”, 8 5 1931
('52', 119, 10, 27, 228235) 2 According to Mahadev Desai, Gandhiji wrote this message “last Monday”.
('52', 119, 10, 28, 228308) May 18 was a Monday.
('52', 120, 0, 1, 228329) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 121
('52', 120, 1, 2, 228371) It is easy enough to follow truth and non violence so long as no sacrifice or suffering is involved, but he who adheres to them in all circumstances even at the cost of life follows them as a creed.
('52', 120, 1, 3, 228570) It is time truth and non violence were a creed and not policy with us Congressmen.
('52', 120, 1, 4, 228653) Let us therefore find out what parts of the resolution we can enforce even now.
('52', 120, 1, 5, 228733) If we do not enforce the things that can be enforced today, swaraj will be meaningless, for we will not suddenly do after swaraj things which we can do but will not do today.
('52', 120, 1, 6, 228908) The resolution states that there shall be no untouchability under the swaraj constitution.
('52', 120, 1, 7, 228999) Have we cast out the canker of untouch ability?
('52', 120, 1, 8, 229047) The resolution says under the swaraj constitution there shall be no facilities for the licensing of liquor and drug shops.
('52', 120, 1, 9, 229170) Have we cast out the drug and drink evil from our midst?
('52', 120, 1, 10, 229227) The resolution goes on to say that under swaraj all foreign cloth would be banned from India.
('52', 120, 1, 11, 229321) But have we given up our infatuation for foreign cloth and become khaddar clad?
('52', 120, 1, 12, 229401) Similarly under swaraj, according to this resolution, Hindus and Mussalmans and Christians will live together like true blood brothers.
('52', 120, 1, 13, 229537) Have we cleansed our hearts of distrust and suspicion of one another?
('52', 120, 1, 14, 229607) Under swaraj, which the resolution pictures, there shall be no hatred or ill will between the rich and the poor.
('52', 120, 1, 15, 229720) Have the rich identified themselves with the poor, and have the poor ceased to have ill will toward the rich?
('52', 120, 1, 16, 229830) Under the swaraj constitution we want the maximum monthly emoluments of officials not to exceed Rs. 500. But do those who are getting more today devote the balance to philanthropic purposes?
('52', 120, 1, 17, 230021) Have our millionaires adjusted their standard of living to this scale of payment?
('52', 120, 1, 18, 230103) It is difficult to give a decisive reply to these questions today.
('52', 120, 1, 19, 230170) We are today slowly groping our way towards our ideal of Ramarajya or the Kindgom of Righteousness.
('52', 120, 1, 20, 230270) This resolution is intended to keep this goal constantly before our eyes and to stimulate our endeavours to attain it.
('52', 120, 1, 21, 230389) Young India, 28 5 1931

('52', 130, 2, 3, 243883) AS AT SABARMATI, May 19, 1931
('52', 130, 3, 4, 243913) DEAR MR. DAVID, I have your letter of the 14th.

('52', 130, 3, 6, 244024) You know that you have my sympathy in your laudable endeavour and just now I feel that I can best serve the common purpose by saying nothing in Young India that might in any way hamper you.

('52', 130, 3, 8, 244308) I am therefore thank ful for the copy you have considerately sent me.
('52', 130, 3, 9, 244378) It is undoubtedly a good letter.
('52', 130, 3, 10, 244411) Lord Irwin”s reply is worthy of him.
('52', 130, 3, 11, 244448) The proposed manifesto is still, I suppose, a private document.
('52', 130, 3, 12, 244512) The reference to fair trade and living conditions requires a closer examination.
('52', 130, 3, 13, 244593) I suppose you are aware that Indians in great Britain do not enjoy the rights 'the manifesto assumes they do enjoy.
('52', 130, 3, 14, 244709) There can be no comparison between the Indian demands in South Africa and the European demand in India.
('52', 130, 3, 15, 244813) The Indian in South Africa suffers from social, commercial and legal disabilities and is treated as an inferior being.
('52', 130, 3, 16, 244932) The Indian demand therefore is to rise to a status of equality.
('52', 130, 3, 17, 244996) The European in India enjoys in every walk of life a position of privilege and his demand for equality is tantamount to the retention of the privileged position.
('52', 130, 3, 18, 245158) When, therefore, India comes [in] to her own, Europeans are bound to feel the pinch if they are not satisfied, that to be just, the position of privilege must be surrendered.
('52', 130, 3, 19, 245333) Apart from this the European in Free India has not only nothing to fear but his resourcefulness and his ability will always make him a desirable citizen.
('52', 130, 4, 20, 245487) Yours Sincerely, M. I. DAVID, ESQ.

('52', 135, 6, 10, 250742) The news is painful, but cases like this are bound to occur at a time of awakening such as the present.
('52', 135, 6, 11, 250846) We cannot inform the authorities, as that might lead to the punishing of innocent people.
('52', 135, 6, 12, 250936) Informing the authorities would have been a breach of trust, and I cannot, at the moment at any rate, think of any case or example in which breach of trust becomes a duty.
('52', 135, 6, 13, 251108) It is one thing when a man puts confidence in us and confesses a crime, another when we come to have indirect information regarding any body’s crime.
('52', 135, 6, 14, 251258) In certain circumstances it may be our duty to make use of the information indirectly received, but no such duty arises in this case at all.
('52', 135, 6, 15, 251399) Hence your job at present is to bring about a refor mation, by whatever means, among those now engaged in terrorism.

('52', 136, 2, 6, 252684) 181. CONGRESS VOTERS A correspondent asks :
('52', 136, 3, 7, 252728) At the time of elections to Congress Committees
('52', 136, 4, 8, 252776) 1. Can a Congress candidate register original Congress members and himself pay the four anna fee ?
('52', 136, 5, 9, 252875) 2. In order to obtain votes can a candidate send conveyances at his own expense to the voters ?
('52', 136, 6, 10, 252971) 3. In order to influence voters can a candidate give feasts to voters?
('52', 136, 7, 11, 253042) 4. Can a voter take part in voting although he is not a habitual wearer of khadi?
('52', 136, 7, 12, 253124) These are very relevant questions.
('52', 136, 7, 13, 253159) My answer to the first three questions is that although the practice would be very reprehensible, I very much fear that there is nothing in the consti tution and there are no bye laws preventing it.
('52', 136, 7, 14, 253358) My answer regarding the fourth is an emphatic ‘no’.
('52', 136, 7, 15, 253410) Thus therefore though a candidate can, if he wishes, pay the registration fee on behalf of the members and send them conveyances and give them feasts in order to induce them to vote for him I do hope that for their own sakes and for the sake of the Congress and the country candidates will refrain from resorting to any practice that might amount to bribery or an improper inducement.
('52', 136, 7, 16, 253795) I have never been able to understand this craze for membership of Congress Committees, and Congress Committees formed in such a manner instead of being instruments of service can easily become those of mischief and disservice.
('52', 136, 7, 17, 254022) So far as the habitual wearing of khadi is concerned there is no doubt that the rule is more often broken than observed.
('52', 136, 7, 18, 254143) It is a remarkable phenomenon that habitual wearers of khadi, and they are thousands, do not care to appear on the Congress register and those who are on the Congress register do not, in many cases, take the trouble of wearing khadi.
('52', 136, 7, 19, 254377) One reason for the laxity is that partisans are brought in at the eleventh hour nominally to become members and to disappear from view as soon as the elections are over.
('52', 136, 7, 20, 254547) New lists are made at new elections or even bye elections.
('52', 137, 0, 1, 254606) 138 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 137, 1, 2, 254648) spite of this tragic fact, the Congress is daily growing in power.
('52', 137, 1, 3, 254715) It is becoming more and more popular.
('52', 137, 1, 4, 254753) It attracts more and more crowds.
('52', 137, 1, 5, 254787) Its mandates find ready acceptance from the vast mass of people.
('52', 137, 1, 6, 254852) This phenomenon can only be explained on the supposition that though the Congress has indifferent representatives, somehow or other it represents and voices the wants and aspirations of the people who remain unaffected by the improprieties of the representatives and support the Congress merely for what it stands for without looking into or caring for the quality of its representatives.
('52', 137, 1, 7, 255241) If my analysis is correct, the moral is obvious.
('52', 137, 1, 8, 255290) The Congress will cease to be the power it is if the reprehensible practices referred to by the correspondent do not cease.
('52', 137, 1, 9, 255414) Congress workers will not always be indifferent.

('52', 137, 2, 11, 255486) 182. NOTES
('52', 137, 3, 12, 255497) PICKETING
('52', 137, 4, 13, 255507) Congressmen should know that the Government of India have been receiving complaints from the provincial Governments that picketing is not always peaceful.
('52', 137, 4, 14, 255662) I do not know how far these compl aints are justified.
('52', 137, 4, 15, 255717) But we cannot be too strict in the observance of our part of the Settlement irrespective of how the authorities implement their part of it.
('52', 137, 4, 16, 255857) Let us realize that the stricter we are, the greater will be our prestige and strength.
('52', 137, 4, 17, 255945) I therefore repeat what I have said before: 1
('52', 137, 5, 18, 255991) 1. There should be no coercion direct or indirect.
('52', 137, 5, 19, 256042) 2. There should be no show of intimidation, hence not more than say five pickets should work at one and the same place at a time.
('52', 137, 5, 20, 256172) 3. There should be no more than courteous entreaty and distribution of literature.
('52', 137, 5, 21, 256255) 4. There should be no fine levied by Congress Committees for breach of promises by foreign cloth dealers.
('52', 137, 5, 22, 256361) 5. There should be no hooting of purchasers of foreign cloth.
('52', 137, 5, 23, 256423) 6. There should be no cordons formed to surround the would be purchasers.
('52', 137, 5, 24, 256497) 7. There should be no lying down to block the passage of customers or trolleys carrying foreign cloth.
('52', 137, 5, 25, 256600) If there are those who think that picketing under such restrictions will be of no avail, they may give it up and run the risk of
('52', 137, 6, 26, 256729) 1 Vide “My Notes”, sub title To Workers
('52', 138, 0, 1, 256769) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 139
('52', 138, 1, 2, 256811) foreign cloth being sold under their noses.
('52', 138, 1, 3, 256855) It is better that foreign cloth is sold than that, in order to prevent its sale, we should break the letter or the spirit of the Settlement.
('52', 138, 1, 4, 256996) Boycott of foreign cloth will ultimately succeed only when the Congress message has penetrated the masses and the khadi spirit per meates them.
('52', 138, 1, 5, 257140) The real work of propaganda and production lies in the villages.
('52', 138, 1, 6, 257205) We should remember too that boycott of foreign cloth is pursued for its great economic and social consequence.
('52', 138, 1, 7, 257316) And it is just as necessary to boycott Japanese or Italian cloth or yarn as it is to boycott British cloth or yarn.
('52', 138, 1, 8, 257432) Indeed it is more necessary to boycott Japanese cloth because it offers greater competition both tokhadi and indigenous mill cloth.
('52', 138, 1, 9, 257564) We have no ill will against Japan.
('52', 138, 1, 10, 257599) We pursue foreign cloth boycott because it is an economic necessity for the nation.
('52', 138, 1, 11, 257683) What I have said about the method of picketing applies equally to liquor picketing.
('52', 138, 1, 12, 257767) That too depends for its ultimate success in penetration into the home of the drinkers.
('52', 138, 2, 13, 257855) SETTLEMENT PRISONERS I have been receiving complaints from many provinces saying that there are still unreleased prisoners covered by the IrwinGandhi Settlement.
('52', 138, 2, 14, 258017) These are claimed by the Governments concerned as not covered by the Settlement.
('52', 138, 2, 15, 258098) The only way relief can be obtained in such cases is to study the records of each case.
('52', 138, 2, 16, 258186) I would therefore ask all Committees who have sent me lists to examine the cases themselves and where they are satisfied that the record shows violence (not merely technical, or incitement thereto), they should for the time being omit their names.
('52', 138, 2, 17, 258434) Where the local examination shows that there is no violence or incitement proved, they should send the record to me and I shall go through such records myself and wherever necessary obtain the opinion of some philanthropic counsel and press for their release.
('52', 138, 2, 18, 258694) Let it be remembered that according to the strict interpretation of the relevant clause of the Settlement we shall have to go simply by the record although those who know may be certain of the innocence of any particular prisoner.
('52', 138, 2, 19, 258925) Of those against whom the record gives no proof of violence, we can demand release.
('52', 138, 2, 20, 259009) Such was Sjt.
('52', 138, 2, 21, 259023) Rajwade’s case.
('52', 138, 2, 22, 259039) The other prisoners and their friends may derive satisfaction
('52', 139, 0, 1, 259101) 140 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 139, 1, 2, 259143) from the assurance that in the event of a final Settlement their release is a certainty and in the event of a breakdown in spite of all efforts, they will find their old companions returning to them.
('52', 139, 1, 3, 259343) For the result they will not have to wait long.
('52', 139, 2, 4, 259391) POORMAN’S SALT
('52', 139, 3, 5, 259406) I regret that as yet the public do not know how the salt law relief clause of the Irwin Gandhi Settlement is being worked.
('52', 139, 3, 6, 259529) I have suggested to the authorities that they should issue definite instructions so that the people concerned may know where they stand.

('52', 140, 0, 1, 261496) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 141
('52', 140, 1, 2, 261538) HOW HE SPENT HIS GOOD FRIDAY Father Elwin writing to Mirabehn says :
('52', 140, 2, 3, 261607) I thought I might tell you how I spent my three hours on Good Friday.
('52', 140, 2, 4, 261677) I did not go to Church but spent the time in my cell spinning.
('52', 140, 2, 5, 261740) I am sending a little of the yarn—very poor I am afraid—but it is a token.
('52', 140, 2, 6, 261815) While spinning I meditated on the crucifixion.
('52', 140, 2, 7, 261862) It seemed to fit in very well—the cry of desolation of God’s poor stretched on the cross of exploitation, the age long “I thirst” of those to whom the charkha with its message of love can bring relief, the wonderful patience of the poor—“Father, forgive them for they know not what they do.” The charkha then seemed to be the dual symbol of our union with the poor and our union with God.
('52', 140, 2, 8, 262251) It would be very good if people would generally keep Good Friday in this way.
('52', 140, 2, 9, 262329) It was a real experience of purification.
('52', 140, 2, 10, 262371) I have examined the yarn sent by Father Elwin.
('52', 140, 2, 11, 262418) It is by no means poor in quality as he thinks.
('52', 140, 2, 12, 262466) It is quite weavable.
('52', 140, 2, 13, 262488) The count is somewhere near 20. Nevertheless, I agree that it is poor for the sprit of love and dedication that lay behind the sacrificial act.
('52', 140, 2, 14, 262632) But no amount of love or dedication can make up for the want of regular and long practice.
('52', 140, 2, 15, 262723) If therefore I have agreed with the self abasing verdict of Father Elwin I have done so not by way of criticism but to tell those who might be induced to turn to the spinning wheel that they will not be satisfied with merely drawing the thread, for the thread thus drawn will not be yarn, even as any angle drawn will not be a right angle.
('52', 140, 2, 16, 263063) Just as all right angles must be 90 degrees so must all yarn be even and strong enough to be easily weavable.
('52', 140, 2, 17, 263173) The count does not matter.
('52', 140, 2, 18, 263200) A spinner who draws an even and strong thread will automatically draw at least a six count and if his wheel is good and his spindle straight and fine, he will draw without difficulty anything between 10 and 20 counts.
('52', 140, 2, 19, 263418) I commend Father Elwin’s experience to all who love and would identify themselves with the semi starved millions of India.
('52', 140, 2, 20, 263541) Young India, 21 5 1931
('52', 140, 3, 21, 263564) 183. A NOTE
('52', 140, 4, 22, 263576) NANITAL, May 21, 1931
('52', 140, 5, 23, 263598) It is my firm view that Rani Vidyavati should not involve her self with the editorship of any paper.
('52', 140, 6, 24, 263699) From the Hindi Original: Rani Vidyavati Papers.

('52', 141, 0, 1, 263792) 142 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 141, 1, 2, 263834) 184. IN 1828
('52', 141, 2, 3, 263847) Satis Chandra Das Gupta of the Khadi Pratishthan is editing a Bengali newspaper called Rastravani.
('52', 141, 2, 4, 263946) He recently unearthed a letter addressed to the Editor of Samachar Darpan which was published in Bengali in the twenties of the 19th century.
('52', 141, 2, 5, 264088) As the letter was of great importance showing how the charkha was being slowly destroyed and how it was valued by women in those days, he has published it in his paper and sent me its translation.
('52', 141, 2, 6, 264285) I am sure, it will be read with interest by all who are at all interested in the khadi movement.
('52', 141, 2, 7, 264382) Here is the letter : 1
('52', 141, 3, 8, 264405) The representation of a spinner
('52', 141, 4, 9, 264437) To the Editor, Samachar
('52', 141, 5, 10, 264461) I am a spinner.
('52', 141, 5, 11, 264477) After having suffered a great deal, I am writing this letter.
('52', 141, 5, 12, 264539) Please publish this in your paper.
('52', 141, 5, 13, 264574) When my age was five and a half gandas (22) I became a widow with three daughters.
('52', 141, 5, 14, 264657) My husband left nothing at the time of his death.
('52', 141, 5, 15, 264707) I sold my jewellery for his shraddha ceremony.
('52', 141, 5, 16, 264754) At last as we were on the verge of starvation God showed me a way by which we could save ourselves.
('52', 141, 5, 17, 264854) I began to spin on takli and charkha.
('52', 141, 6, 18, 264892) The weavers used to visit our houses and buy the charkha yarn at three tolas per rupee.
('52', 141, 6, 19, 264980) Whatever amount I wanted as advance from the weavers, I could get for the asking.
('52', 141, 6, 20, 265062) This saved us from cares about food and cloth.
('52', 141, 6, 21, 265109) In a few years’ time I got together seven ganda rupees (Rs. 28).
('52', 141, 6, 22, 265174) With this I married one daughter.
('52', 141, 6, 23, 265208) And in the same way all three daughters.
('52', 141, 6, 24, 265249) Now for 3 years, we two women, mother in law and me are in want of food.
('52', 141, 6, 25, 265322) The weavers do not call at the house for buying yarn.
('52', 141, 6, 26, 265376) Not only this, if the yarn is sent to market still it is not sold even at one fourth the old prices.
('52', 141, 7, 27, 265477) I do not know how it happened.
('52', 141, 7, 28, 265508) I asked many about it.
('52', 141, 7, 29, 265531) They say that Bilati 2
('52', 141, 8, 30, 265554) yarn is being largely imported.
('52', 141, 8, 31, 265586) The weavers buy that yarn and weave.
('52', 141, 8, 32, 265623) I had a sense of pride that Bilati yarn could not be equal to my yarn, but when I got Bilati yarn I saw that it was better than my yarn.
('52', 141, 8, 33, 265760) I heard that its price is Rs. 3
('52', 141, 9, 34, 265792) or Rs. 4 per seer.
('52', 141, 9, 35, 265811) I beat my brow and said, “Oh God, there are sisters more distressed even than me.” I know that all men of Bilat are rich but now I see
('52', 141, 10, 36, 265946) that there are women there who are poorer than me.
('52', 141, 10, 37, 265997) I fully realized the poverty which induced those poor women to spin.
('52', 141, 10, 38, 266066) They have sent the product of so much toil out here because they could not sell it there.
('52', 141, 10, 39, 266156) It would have been
('52', 141, 11, 40, 266175) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('52', 141, 11, 41, 266212) Concerning a doubt raised as to the authenticity of the letter, vide “Letter to Satis Chandra Das Gupta”, 2 6 1931
('52', 141, 12, 42, 266327) 2 Foreign
('52', 142, 0, 1, 266337) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 143
('52', 142, 1, 2, 266379) something if they were sold here at good prices.
('52', 142, 1, 3, 266428) But it has brought our ruin only.
('52', 142, 1, 4, 266462) Man cannot use the cloth out of this yarn even for two months; it rots away.
('52', 142, 1, 5, 266539) I therefore entreat the spinners over there, that, if they will consider this representation, they will be able to judge whether it is fair to send yarn here or not.
('52', 142, 2, 6, 266705) SHANTIPUR
('52', 142, 3, 7, 266715) A representation from a
('52', 142, 4, 8, 266739) suffering spinner
('52', 142, 5, 9, 266757) Samachar Darpan The reader will not fail to observe the nobility of the writer who in her blissful ignorance felt that yarn was spun by the hands of her Bilati sisters poorer than herself and therefore felt for them.
('52', 142, 5, 10, 266974) Alas, her belief was baseless.
('52', 142, 5, 11, 267005) She could have stood her own if the foreign yarn had been hand spun.
('52', 142, 5, 12, 267074) She could have stood her own even against the foreign yarn, if behind it there had been no policy of determination to capture the Indian trade and kill the national village industry.
('52', 142, 5, 13, 267257) Young India, 21 5 1931
('52', 142, 6, 14, 267280) 185. A WOMAN’S SACRIFICE
('52', 142, 7, 15, 267305) During the great awakening that took place last year amongst women there were heroines whose mute work the nation will never know.
('52', 142, 7, 16, 267436) Now and then however one gets information of such village work.
('52', 142, 7, 17, 267500) Here is one such sample sent by a friend: 1
('52', 142, 8, 18, 267544) When our Congress camp was declared illegal and locked up by the
('52', 142, 9, 19, 267609) police we shifted to the hut of a poor Mahishya woman—Habu’s mother of
('52', 142, 10, 20, 267680) Baradongal.
('52', 142, 10, 21, 267692) We have read of Gorki’s mother.
('52', 142, 10, 22, 267724) We saw her incarnate in Habu’s
('52', 142, 11, 23, 267755) mother.
('52', 142, 11, 24, 267763) Night and day she used to cook for us workers.
('52', 142, 11, 25, 267810) She nursed the sick
('52', 142, 12, 26, 267830) amongst us.
('52', 142, 12, 27, 267842) She consoled those that were troubled in heart and thus became
('52', 142, 13, 28, 267905) real mother to us who would other wise have felt motherless.
('52', 142, 14, 29, 267966) graduates and M.A.s amongst us proud of their educational gifts but all of us
('52', 142, 15, 30, 268044) were compelled to call Habu’s mother our own.
('52', 142, 15, 31, 268090) Her sacrifice and great devotion
('52', 142, 16, 32, 268123) to duty commanded that homage from us.
('52', 142, 17, 33, 268162) Young India, 21 5 1931

('52', 144, 7, 20, 269954) 190. LETTER TO MOHAMMED ISMAIL KHAN
('52', 144, 8, 21, 269990) AS AT SABARMATI, May 21, 1931
('52', 144, 9, 22, 270020) DEAR NAWAB SAHEB, I thank you for your letter of 19th instant.
('52', 144, 9, 23, 270083) I have not seen the report you refer to in your letter.
('52', 144, 9, 24, 270139) But I may state my position thus: So far as I am concerned I should endorse without hesitation any solution that Mussalman friends as a whole may present but that by itself would not solve our difficulties.
('52', 144, 9, 25, 270346) Our difficulties could only be solved by either Hindus and Mussalmans settling with the Sikhs or Hindus settling both with Mussalmans and Sikhs.
('52', 144, 9, 26, 270491) But so far as I am personally concerned I should endorse any solution presented by
('52', 145, 0, 1, 270574) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 145, 1, 2, 270616) Sikh friends as a whole as I would the Mussalman claim.
('52', 145, 1, 3, 270672) But if there is a conflict between the Sikh and the Mussalman claim, then my endorsement of the claim of each would be of little value.
('52', 145, 1, 4, 270808) I have therefore assumed that whatever Mussalman friends or Sikh friends present as a final claim would take note of the other party.
('52', 145, 1, 5, 270942) If you find any flaw in this, you will not hesitate to let me know.
('52', 145, 1, 6, 271010) All I want is an honourable settlement wholly satisfactory to the Mussalmans, to the Sikhs as also to all other communities who may wish a communal solution.
('52', 145, 1, 7, 271168) As to your other question supposing that I survive the future constitution and am allowed to have any hand in its working I would have no solution on any but strictly national lines and I would so work the constitution that I should disarm all suspicion.
('52', 145, 1, 8, 271423) So far as the Europeans are concerned, the question is not what privileges they should get by reason of their being in a minority but what privilges they will surrender so as to be on a par with us.
('52', 145, 1, 9, 271622) Am I clear?
('52', 145, 1, 10, 271634) I would ask you to believe me to be the same man whom you were good enough to have as your guest in Meerut in those days when for the moment we had begun to think that we were but children of the same mother having the same aspirations and having full trust in one another.
('52', 145, 2, 11, 271908) Yours sincerely, NAWAB MOHAMMED ISMAIL KHAN SAHEB MUSTAPHA CASTLE, MEERUT
('52', 145, 3, 12, 271982) From a photostat : S. N. 17107

('52', 148, 5, 7, 275053) 197. SPEECH AT POLITICAL SUFFERERS’ CONFERENCE
('52', 148, 6, 8, 275100) KUMAON, [May 21, 1931] 1
('52', 148, 7, 9, 275125) You must have seen the resolution regarding the declaration of fundamental rights passed by the Congress.
('52', 148, 7, 10, 275231) There are a few items in it such as the reduction of military expenditure to one half, which cannot be achieved before swaraj, but there are other items such as compulsory primary education, ban on foreign cloth, equality of rights and opportunities, for which we should not wait till the esta blishment of swaraj.
('52', 148, 7, 11, 275546) We should establish these conditions just now and this will bring us nearer swaraj.
('52', 148, 7, 12, 275630) We can open schools in every village, manufacture and encourage khaddar and make wars on untou chability.
('52', 148, 8, 13, 275736) (Here Mahatmaji referred to each item in the declaration of rights as published in an old issue of Young India seriatim.)
('52', 148, 9, 14, 275858) Referring to the maximum pay of the public servants, Mahatmaji said as follows :— You should not think that this proposal is meant to remain on paper.
('52', 148, 9, 15, 276009) This will be enforced when swaraj is obtained.
('52', 148, 9, 16, 276056) This was added to the declaration of rights after full and careful consideration.
('52', 148, 9, 17, 276138) I am old and even if I die, Jawaharlal is certain to enforce it.
('52', 148, 9, 18, 276203) But it is unjust to suppose that old people die before young men, because it is not God’s law.
('52', 148, 9, 19, 276298) Let me assure you that this proposal will be enforced.
('52', 148, 9, 20, 276353) In Japan, which is an independent country, the maximum pay of public servants is Rs. 500. Ours is a country where the average income per individual is about Rs. 40 and this includes crores of millionaires.
('52', 148, 9, 21, 276559) So anyone who
('52', 148, 10, 22, 276573) 1 From the Hindu, 21 5 1931
('52', 149, 0, 1, 276601) 150 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 149, 1, 2, 276643) lives on more than Rs. 500 lives on loot.
('52', 149, 1, 3, 276685) We regard this amount as insufficient because seeing the exploitation of the foreigners and the life they lead, we want to copy them.
('52', 149, 1, 4, 276819) It is said that lawyers and industrialists will earn more than Rs. 500 per month.
('52', 149, 1, 5, 276901) I say they should not earn more than Rs. 500 per month.
('52', 149, 1, 6, 276957) If they do so in a country like ours they will be living on loot.

('52', 149, 3, 9, 277103) 198. TELEGRAM TO VICEROY

('52', 151, 13, 21, 280483) I propose therefore to do the next best thing possible.
('52', 151, 13, 22, 280539) In the absence of response by the Government to any of the proposals made by me, I propose to tell the kisans what in my opinion is the least that they should pay, throwing

('52', 152, 5, 11, 281889) 205. TO THE KISANS OF THE U.P.
('52', 152, 6, 12, 281920) NAINITAL, May 23, 1931 During the late struggle, in some districts, the non payment of taxes was being organized as part of Civil Disobedience for the attainment of purna swaraj.
('52', 152, 6, 13, 282099) But by reason of the Settlement between the Congress and the Government Civil Disobedience was disconti nued and therefore also the non payment of taxes.
('52', 152, 6, 14, 282253) But there was then deep economic distress among you.
('52', 152, 6, 15, 282306) Bad as your condition was even in normal times, the unprecedented fall this year in the prices of the crops usually grown by you made it infinitely worse.
('52', 152, 6, 16, 282461) And Congress workers reported that many of you were utterly unable to pay in full the rents due by you.
('52', 152, 6, 17, 282565) In several districts inquiries were made in a few hundred villages disclosing a serious state of affairs.
('52', 152, 6, 18, 282671) It was found that the price of your gross produce had fallen to such an extent that the sales were not enough to pay the rents.
('52', 152, 6, 19, 282799) It was in this connection that I came to Nainital to see H. E. the Gover nor.
('52', 152, 6, 20, 282877) His Excellency gave me a patient hearing and we fully discussed the situation.
('52', 152, 6, 21, 282956) He was sympathetic.
('52', 152, 6, 22, 282976) I told him that some Congress
('52', 152, 7, 23, 283006) 1 Vide the following item.
('52', 152, 7, 24, 283033) 2 For the addressee’s reply, vide “Letter from Sir Malcolm Hailey”, 23 5 1931
('52', 153, 0, 1, 283111) 154 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 153, 1, 2, 283153) workers had assured me that the relief hitherto announced by the Government of the U.P. was hardly equal to the actual distress.
('52', 153, 1, 3, 283282) And I submitted certain proposals which he kindly promised to consider.
('52', 153, 1, 4, 283354) I was bound meanwhile to tender you such advice as it was in my power to do.
('52', 153, 1, 5, 283431) I have passed many an anxious hour discussing the situation with many co workers.
('52', 153, 1, 6, 283513) I have had the benefit of a frank and free discussion with important talukdars who were good enough to respond to my invitation to see me.
('52', 153, 1, 7, 283652) I am gald to be able to say that they were in general agreement with the proposals suggested here under.
('52', 153, 1, 8, 283757) Concentrated work was done in the following among other districts: Agra, Muttra, Allahabad, Rai Bareily, Gorakhpore, Cawnpore, Lucknow, Pratapgarh, and Etawah.
('52', 153, 1, 9, 283917) And for these it has been found that there should be a remission for the year 1338 Fasli of eight annas in the rupee in the case of statutory and non occupancy tenants and four annas in the case of occupancy tenants.
('52', 153, 1, 10, 284134) This general formula should be subject to variation as may be required by local conditions.
('52', 153, 1, 11, 284226) I have been told that in some districts the tenants are in a position to do with less reduction.
('52', 153, 1, 12, 284323) Some districts again were hard hit by local calamities.
('52', 153, 1, 13, 284379) The suggested reduction would naturally therefore not apply to the districts that might be able to pay more than what is suggested here, nor to those whose condition may be under the level found in the foregoing districts.
('52', 153, 1, 14, 284602) Indeed even in the districts menti oned those of you who are able to pay more ought to do so.
('52', 153, 1, 15, 284696) The Congress expects every tenant to pay as early as possible all the rent he can, and in no case as a general rule less than eight annas or four 1
('52', 153, 2, 16, 284844) annas as the case may be.
('52', 153, 2, 17, 284870) But just as even in the same district there may be cases in which a larger payment is possible, it is equally possible that there may be cases in which less than eight annas or four 2
('52', 153, 3, 18, 285054) annas can only be paid.
('52', 153, 3, 19, 285078) In such cases I hope the tenants will be treated liberally by the zamindars.
('52', 153, 3, 20, 285155) In every case you will see that you get against payment a full discharge from your obligation for the current year’s rent.
('52', 153, 3, 21, 285278) I understand that several tenants were ejected during the struggle and others have been ejected since.
('52', 153, 3, 22, 285381) Not to restore these to their hold ings would be clearly against the atmosphere sought to be created by the Settlement.
('52', 153, 3, 23, 285501) I have every hope, therefore, that against payment on
('52', 153, 4, 24, 285555) 1 A slip for ‘twelve’; vide “A Correction”,11 6 1931 2 ibid
('52', 154, 0, 1, 285615) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 155
('52', 154, 1, 2, 285657) the scale suggested here the ejected tenants will be fully restored without any penalty.
('52', 154, 1, 3, 285746) I am hoping that payment will begin at once.
('52', 154, 1, 4, 285791) It may be that you are not able to pay the full eight annas at once.
('52', 154, 1, 5, 285860) In that case I trust you will get suspension, and that no coercive processes will be issued whe ther for the unpaid balance or for arrears if any, till the next harvest.
('52', 154, 1, 6, 286030) I would like to suggest to the Government, in view of the loss that your inability to pay the rents in full will cause to the zamindars, that they get a proportionate reduction in the revenue payable by them to the Government.
('52', 154, 1, 7, 286257) Lastly let me warn you against listening to the advice, if it has reached you, that you have no need to pay the zamindars any rent at all.
('52', 154, 1, 8, 286396) I hope that you will not listen to such advice, no matter who gives it.
('52', 154, 1, 9, 286468) Congressmen cannot, we do not seek to injure the zamindars.
('52', 154, 1, 10, 286528) We aim not at destruction of property.
('52', 154, 1, 11, 286567) We aim only at its lawful use.
('52', 154, 1, 12, 286598) It has been suggested that you will listen to the Congress when Congressmen tell you not to pay anything at all, but you will not listen to the Congress when it asks you to pay according to your ability.
('52', 154, 1, 13, 286802) The opportunity has now come for you to falsify the calumny.
('52', 154, 1, 14, 286863) You have complained of very harsh treatment by or on behalf of some landlords.
('52', 154, 1, 15, 286942) The Congress is trying and will try to investigate all your complaints, plead with the landlords and even addvise legal relief where such becomes imperative.
('52', 154, 1, 16, 287100) But let it be also owned that sometimes some kisans too have gone astray and committed mur derous assaults.
('52', 154, 1, 17, 287208) These acts spoil the fair name of kisans, harm their cause and impair the usefulness of the Congress for service.
('52', 154, 1, 18, 287322) For in the ultimate end you are the Congress.
('52', 154, 1, 19, 287368) The Congress is incomplete in so far as it represents you insufficiently.
('52', 154, 1, 20, 287442) Please remember that the Congress aims at reaching purna swaraj through Truth and Non violence.
('52', 154, 1, 21, 287538) And it will fail in so far as the kisans fail to observe these two cardinal principles.
('52', 154, 1, 22, 287626) You are milli ons.
('52', 154, 1, 23, 287645) When millions become untruthful and violent, it will mean self destruction.
('52', 154, 1, 24, 287721) You will therefore suffer injury without retaliation.
('52', 154, 1, 25, 287775) You have now perhaps learnt that the best way of resisting injury is never to injure the injurer, but ever to refuse, no matter how much suffering the refusal costs us, to do his will when we know it to be wrong.
('52', 154, 3, 26, 287988) Your friend and servant,
('52', 154, 4, 27, 288013) M. K. GANDHI Young India, 28 5 1931

('52', 155, 1, 2, 288091) 206. LETTER TO MALCOLM HAILEY
('52', 155, 2, 3, 288121) May 23, 1931
('52', 155, 3, 4, 288134) DEAR MR. HAILEY, With reference to the Etawah case wherein the Congress Secre tary was supposed to have circulated after the date of the Settlement notice amongst tenants advising them not to pay any rent at all I have made full inquiry and find that such notice was circulated in February last, but none after the Settlement.
('52', 155, 3, 5, 288461) On the contrary a general notice withdrawing the notax agitation was circulated throughout the province on behalf of the Provincial Congress Committee.
('52', 155, 3, 6, 288613) This matter was brought to the notice of Pt. Govind Ballabh Pant by the Chief Secretary and on the day that he received the intimation he made inquiries.
('52', 155, 3, 7, 288767) The Secretary, Babu Gaya Prasad, immediately wrote in reply giving the information above mentioned.
('52', 155, 3, 8, 288867) Moreover he is no longer occupying position of General Secretary of the Local Committee in Etawah.
('52', 155, 3, 9, 288966) It would be perhaps interesting to know how the police came by the notice and came to the conclusion that it was being circulated after the date of the Settlement.
('52', 155, 4, 10, 289130) Yours sincerely,
('52', 155, 5, 11, 289147) M. K. GANDHI
