('52', 156, 5, 18, 291338) 209. NOTES
('52', 156, 6, 19, 291349) REGARDING PICKETING I extract the following questions from two letters :
('52', 156, 7, 20, 291422) 1. Can fasting be resorted to while picketing those who break the seals of cloth which has been sealed?
('52', 156, 8, 21, 291526) 2. Does fasting have a place in peaceful picketing?
('52', 156, 9, 22, 291578) 3. If those against whom peaceful picketing is being carried on do not listen to reason, can social boycott be practised against them?
('52', 156, 10, 23, 291713) 4. Can picketing be called off if a person promises not to import fresh foreign cloth and his old stock has already been sold out?
('52', 156, 11, 24, 291844) 1 Vide “Speech at Benares Hindu University”, 6 2 1916 2 Vide “Cable to v.
('52', 156, 11, 25, 291918) S. Srinivasa Sastri”, 23 5 1931
('52', 157, 0, 1, 291950) 158 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 157, 1, 2, 291992) 5. Should there be picketing against those who sell both foreign and Indian cloth?
('52', 157, 2, 3, 292075) 6. Should we boycott those who have sealed up their stock of foreign cloth and promised to pay a certain fine if they break the seal?
('52', 157, 2, 4, 292209) Shold we sit a dharna 1 before them?
('52', 157, 2, 5, 292246) The answers to these questions would be as follows : 1. Fasting can be resorted to only in regard to those who are closely associated with the person picketing, who have given a pledge out of the love resulting from that relationship and then broken it.
('52', 157, 2, 6, 292500) 2. The reply to this is contained in the rule mentioned above.
('52', 157, 2, 7, 292563) 3. Social boycott, which would imply denying the individual the services of the dhobi, the barber, the vaid, etc., should not be practised.
('52', 157, 2, 8, 292703) But one is permitted to cut off relationship with such individuals by way of going to their homes for feasts on occasions such as marriages, and indeed one should do so.
('52', 157, 2, 9, 292873) In short, they should not be harassed.
('52', 157, 2, 10, 292912) The pain which they feel when we do not go to their homes for meals cannot be regarded as harassment.
('52', 157, 2, 11, 293014) 4. It is our dharma to withdraw picketing if we are sure about the pledge.
('52', 157, 2, 12, 293089) 5. Certainly.
('52', 157, 2, 13, 293103) 6. We cannot resort to picketing if someone does not pay the fine, but we can do so if he sells foreign goods.With regard toboycott, refer to reply No.
('52', 157, 2, 14, 293255) 4 2. Dharna does not mean self torture to press one’s point.
('52', 157, 3, 15, 293316) ONE ADVANTAGE OF BOYCOTT
('52', 157, 4, 16, 293341) I take the follwing extract 3 from letters received by me: I hope that these women have given up foreign cloth and started wearing khadi.
('52', 157, 4, 17, 293479) Whether they have started doing so or not, the basic fact is that they have learnt simplicity along with the boycott of foreign goods.
('52', 157, 4, 18, 293614) Everyone has got the experience that our craving for enjoyment increases with the acceptance of foreign goods and the idea gains ground that clothes are meant for adornment rather than for the purpose of covering our body.
('52', 157, 4, 19, 293837) Our newspapers are not yet full of items on fashion but if we glance at English newspapers, we shall
('52', 157, 5, 20, 293938) 1 Squatting and fasting for the redress of a grievance 2 This should perhaps be 3. 3 Not translated here.
('52', 157, 5, 21, 294044) It described the simplicity of women in a particular household.
('52', 158, 0, 1, 294108) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 159
('52', 158, 1, 2, 294150) see every day under the heading “fashion” pictures of new types of dresses together with alluring descriptions of them.
('52', 158, 1, 3, 294270) Hence, along with the giving up of foreign cloth we also rid ourselves of the glamour for false fashion and for this very reason khadi though expensive becomes inexpensive.
('52', 158, 1, 4, 294443) A woman who used to wear separate saris while she is at home, while going out, while paying social calls, while visiting the temple, or who thus has four or five saris for daily wear now makes do with a single khadi sari and, therefore, easily saves a lot of money.
('52', 158, 1, 5, 294709) When a person wearing a turban made of twelve yards of mulmul 1 starts wearing a khadi cap made of half a yard, however expensive khadi may be, he would easily save some money.
('52', 158, 2, 6, 294886) DISHONESTY OF BUSINESS MEN An experienced gentleman makes the following compliant: 2
('52', 158, 3, 7, 294971) There is nothing in this that is not well known.
('52', 158, 3, 8, 295020) If business men had thought only of the good of the country, they would never have imported foreign cloth at all.
('52', 158, 3, 9, 295134) To a large extent, dishonesty is implicit in all business.
('52', 158, 3, 10, 295193) Merchants dealing in foreign cloth catch the eye because their business it widespread and, like a huge serpent, it has coiled itself around India and is gradually crushing her.
('52', 158, 3, 11, 295370) No one can escape from that grip.
('52', 158, 3, 12, 295404) We have now become conscious of how we are being crushed and hence we have started criticizing merchants deal ing in foreign cloth and that is only proper.This awakening provides a remedy for the abovementioned and many other similar dishonest practices.
('52', 158, 3, 13, 295659) Picketing is the ready remedy.
('52', 158, 3, 14, 295690) The true remedy lies in reaching the villages.
('52', 158, 3, 15, 295737) All such question as, for in stance, whether a particular cloth is Indian or foreign, whether it is made in a mill which is boycotted or not, whether this khadi contains warp which is mill made or hand made, etc., will automatically disappear when the villagers spin yarn in their own homes, get it woven by their own weavers and start using such khadi.
('52', 158, 3, 16, 296091) And hence I tell you for the thou sandth time that the remedy for all deceit lies in khadi that is woven from yarn spun by yourselves.
('52', 158, 3, 17, 296226) Just as adding jaggery makes a thing sweet, likewise, if we spin fine yarn, we get finer and cheaper khadi.
('52', 158, 4, 18, 296334) 1 Thin variety of plain muslim 2 The letter is not translated here.
('52', 158, 4, 19, 296402) It reported various ways in which foreign cloth was passed off as Indian cloth.
('52', 159, 0, 1, 296482) 160 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 159, 1, 2, 296524) There can be no other cloth which is as cheap or cheaper and, if there is such cloth, it deserves to be discarded as it is stained with the blood of the poor.
('52', 159, 1, 3, 296683) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 24 5 1931

('52', 162, 2, 3, 300693) AS AT SABARMATI, May 24, 1931
('52', 162, 3, 4, 300723) DEAR SATIS BABU, I have your sad letter about Bholanath Sen 1 I have read all about the murder.
('52', 162, 3, 5, 300819) I knew that both the picture and the writing were wholly inoffensive.
('52', 162, 3, 6, 300889) But the complaint was that there was any portrait of the Prophet printed at all.
('52', 162, 3, 7, 300970) Or course it is a silly complaint but anything is good enough to inflame the simple minded Pathan.
('52', 162, 3, 8, 301069) In the face of such tragedies I know nothing so efficacious as prayer and utter silence when we can present no visible remedy.
('52', 162, 3, 9, 301196) If the Hindu heart can be melted, the thing becomes easy.
('52', 162, 3, 10, 301254) But before it can melt, you and I and perhaps thousands like us will have to give our lives and in order that they may become a pure sacrifice, we have to endeavour to become purer day by day, or better put, less impure day by day.
('52', 162, 3, 11, 301486) Your description of the Bengal state of affairs is also sad.
('52', 162, 3, 12, 301547) I am today in Muttra waiting for the Frontier Mail taking me to Surat.
('52', 162, 3, 13, 301618) Most pro bably Subhasbabu will travel as far as Surat.
('52', 162, 3, 14, 301673) I have not yet seen him.
('52', 162, 3, 15, 301698) This is being dictated at the station.
('52', 162, 3, 16, 301737) I am going to Bardoli on the Sardar’s orders.
('52', 162, 3, 17, 301783) My destination is Borsad but when I shall be able to go there I do not know.
('52', 162, 3, 18, 301860) Subhasbabu is with me on the train.
('52', 162, 5, 19, 301896) BAPU SYT.

('52', 167, 1, 2, 307375) 225. LETTER TO J. N. SAHNI
('52', 167, 2, 3, 307402) AS AT SABARMATI, May 24, 1931
('52', 167, 3, 4, 307432) MY DEAR SAHNI, I have heard that you had published a report of that inter view.
('52', 167, 3, 5, 307512) I must confess that I was grieved.
('52', 167, 3, 6, 307547) Of course the proper thing for you was not to assume or receive consent either from Malaviyaji or Anasuyabehn because it was a matter in which I alone could have judged.
('52', 167, 3, 7, 307717) I do not think that any very great harm has been done.
('52', 167, 3, 8, 307772) But these little mistakes repeated by so many newspapers make up a heavy indictment and betray bad taste.
('52', 167, 3, 9, 307878) These domestic conversa tions do not admit of reporting.
('52', 167, 3, 10, 307935) They lose their weight and influence by reporting.
('52', 167, 3, 11, 307986) Anasuyabehn has also written to me about it.
('52', 167, 3, 12, 308031) She is deeply grieved and she tells me that there are many mistakes.
('52', 167, 3, 13, 308100) But I do not think that anything is to be gained by publishing corrections.
('52', 167, 3, 14, 308176) The best thing therefore is to forget all about it and the amends you can make is not to repeat such a mistake not only in connection with myself but in every case.
('52', 167, 3, 15, 308341) I think the mistake will have been well made if the point I have made is quite clear to you.
('52', 167, 3, 16, 308434) Yours sincerely, SYT.
('52', 167, 3, 17, 308456) J. N. SAHNI “HINDUSTAN TIMES”, DELHI From a microfilm: S.N. 17136

('52', 170, 6, 13, 312916) 231. LETTER TO COWASJI JEHANGIR 1
('52', 170, 7, 14, 312950) AS AT SABARMATI, May 26, 1931
('52', 170, 8, 15, 312980) DEAR SIR COWASJI, You will please forgive me for not having sent you an earlier reply.
('52', 170, 8, 16, 313067) I returned to Bardoli only yesterday from Nainital where and at Simla I was so overwhelmed with local work that I had no time to frame my reply to you or to Sardar Garda.
('52', 170, 8, 17, 313238) I am now sending you a copy of my reply to Sardar Garda 2 which will speak for itself.
('52', 170, 8, 18, 313325) I am sending you also a copy of his letter to me.
('52', 170, 8, 19, 313375) At best his allegations are vague and even these are really denied by the people.
('52', 170, 8, 20, 313457) But the complaint he could legitimately make could only be about matters happening after his promise to restore the land.
('52', 170, 8, 21, 313579) That should be after
('52', 170, 9, 22, 313600) 1 In reply to the addressee’s letter in which he had mentioned certain specific complaints of Sardar Garda and pleaded with Gandhiji that “all kind of harassment shall immediately stop .
('52', 170, 9, 23, 313787) ” 2 Vide the following item.
('52', 171, 0, 1, 313816) 172 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 171, 1, 2, 313858) the receipt of Rao Bahadur Bhimbhai’s letter or so after the 25th April when we had the first conversation.
('52', 171, 1, 3, 313966) If we were to take the 25th April as the date you will see that there is only one paragraph devoted to the happenings thereafter.
('52', 171, 1, 4, 314096) It says : “On 28th April Babla people again scared away our labourers and cartmen that came from my bet.
('52', 171, 1, 5, 314201) So also a Rajput family on the 3rd instant.
('52', 171, 1, 6, 314245) With other threats they were told that their abodes would be burnt down together with the inmates.” These allegations I have carefully enquired into and I have statements on oath made by the people concerned repudiating them.
('52', 171, 1, 7, 314471) If, however, this investigation does not satisfy you, I am quite willing that you should nominate someone on your behalf who would investigate these two complaints.
('52', 171, 1, 8, 314636) As to Bhikhabhai who is said to have refused to take up his bungalow, I understand that he denies having made the statement ascribed to him.
('52', 171, 1, 9, 314777) But even if he did not, how could we interfere in such matters?
('52', 171, 2, 10, 314841) With reference to the other complaint in your letter I was painfully surprised to find this sentence: “I desire to draw your atten tion to other cases of harassment of Parsis which have been brought to my notice.” This presupposes that you have taken the harassment of Sardar Garda for granted and you have generalized from two incidents yet unproved an indictment, I do not know against whom, for harassment of Parsis as a class.
('52', 171, 2, 11, 315272) As a matter of fact throughout the last 12 years of intense political work the relations between the Congress and the Parsis have been of the happiest character.
('52', 171, 2, 12, 315434) How can there be then any question of harassment of Parsis?
('52', 171, 2, 13, 315494) And even if it can be proved, should the harassment of the lady 1 whose case you have mentioned affect Sardar Garda’s promise of restoration of land which on his own showing he bought for a song.
('52', 171, 2, 14, 315690) I am however anxi ous to give you all the satisfaction I can that there is no desire whatsoever on the part of Congress organizations to harass Parsis.
('52', 171, 2, 15, 315842) In the lady’s case there is an impeachment of Syt.
('52', 171, 2, 16, 315893) Bharucha who has investigated the matter.
('52', 171, 2, 17, 315935) In view of the fact that there are two contrary allegations by two Parsis of position, I can only ask you to name some person who would make the investigation and report to you.
('52', 171, 2, 18, 316113) Pending
('52', 171, 3, 19, 316121) 1 Miss.
('52', 171, 3, 20, 316129) Contractor who had foreign and country liquor shops at Thana and Ghatkopar.
('52', 172, 0, 1, 316205) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 173
('52', 172, 1, 2, 316247) receipt of your letter on this point, I am staying any further investi gation into the lady’s complaint.

('52', 172, 3, 6, 316517) 232. LETTER TO FRAMROZE B. GARDA 1
('52', 172, 4, 7, 316552) AS AT SABARMATI, May 26, 1931
('52', 172, 5, 8, 316582) DEAR SARDAR GARDA, I am sorry that owing to my absence from Gujarat and other preoccupations I was not able to reply to your letter earlier.
('52', 172, 5, 9, 316723) You will notice from your complaint that except two, the other complaints refer to times prior to your decision to restore the land to the original owners.
('52', 172, 5, 10, 316879) With reference to the two incidents which you mention as having happened on the 28th April and 3rd instant.
('52', 172, 5, 11, 316987) I have enquired into your allegations and the people point blank repudiate them.
('52', 172, 5, 12, 317068) You have again mentioned some other cases before the 25th April which are before the courts.
('52', 172, 5, 13, 317161) The rest I have enquired into.
('52', 172, 5, 14, 317192) Although they are alleged to have happened before the 25th April, the alle gations are denied by the people concerned.
('52', 172, 5, 15, 317311) Of course you do not hold Congressmen responsible for things that may happen to your land in the Baroda territories through your tenants with whom Con gressmen have no dealings of concern.
('52', 172, 5, 16, 317500) As a matter of fact it was up to you to have withdrawn the cases which are before the courts after the settlement with you.
('52', 172, 5, 17, 317624) I cannot help therefore saying that you have shown absolutely no reason for going back upon your plighted word.
('52', 172, 5, 18, 317736) In any case I suggest that your proper course was to seek redress for any wrong done to you after your promise of restoration by means of arbi tration or other wise but not to repudiate the promise made after the fullest deliberation.
('52', 172, 5, 19, 317971) Yours sincerely, SARDAR FRAMROZE GARDA NAVSARI A.I.C.C. File No.

('52', 182, 3, 11, 331621) Be patient with him.
('52', 182, 3, 12, 331642) Let me know what he decides to do.

('52', 184, 4, 9, 333879) 255. TO THE U.P. ZAMINDARS
('52', 184, 5, 10, 333906) In another column will be found my manifesto to the U.P. Kisans.
('52', 184, 5, 11, 333971) 1 I know that H. E. the Governor does not quite like it inasmuch as it goes beyond the relief given by the U.P. Government.
('52', 184, 5, 12, 334095) But the advice given to the kisans in the manifesto is an honest attempt to express their capacity for payment.
('52', 184, 5, 13, 334207) I am hoping, therefore, that if the kisans pay according to the suggestion made in the manifesto, the zamindars and the local Government will accept the payments in full discharge of the kisans’ liability.
('52', 184, 5, 14, 334413) But under the land revenue system prevalent in the U.P. the brunt will in the first instance fall upon the zamindars.
('52', 184, 5, 15, 334531) I am hoping that the Government will grant proportionate relief to the zamindars who accept the tenants’ terms.
('52', 184, 5, 16, 334643) To the zamindars I can give my assurance that I endeavoured to study the rural condition as much as it was possible for me to do.
('52', 184, 5, 17, 334773) With the authoritative figures before me, it was impossible to offer better terms.
('52', 184, 5, 18, 334856) Here are the two tables of prices : Index Nos.
('52', 184, 5, 19, 334903) of the prices of the Principal Food grains (Wheat, Barley, Gram, Rice and Bajra) on the basis of 1873=100 Year Prices Year Prices 1880 118 1906 10 195 1881 85 100 1911 15 194 1886 90 119 1916 20 272 1891 95 128 1921 25 294 1896 1900 166 1926 300 1901 05 136 1931 (May, U.P.) 132

('52', 185, 1, 2, 335269) TABLE II Price per maund Year Priceper maund Year in Rupees in Rupees 1880 1.5 1906 10 3.56 1881 85 1. 68 1911 15 3.31 1886 90 2. 08 1916 20 4.63 1891 95 2. 22 1921 25 4.73 1896 1900 2. 75 1926 28 4.9 1901 05 2. 34 1931 May 2.3 They show that from 1915 there is 50% drop in the prices of staples.
('52', 185, 1, 3, 335566) These prices go back to 1886. That means that within living memory they have never been so low as now.
('52', 185, 1, 4, 335669) And if one were to go to the level of rents in those days, the tenants would have to pay much less than 8 as.
('52', 185, 1, 5, 335779) or 12 as.
('52', 185, 1, 6, 335789) as under the manifesto.
('52', 185, 1, 7, 335813) It is admitted that the condition of the tenants has at no time been prosperous during recent years.
('52', 185, 1, 8, 335914) Indeed an inquiry made in over three hundred U.P. villages in the eastern province shows that the price of the produce at the present rate does not even cover the rents payable.
('52', 185, 1, 9, 336092) This makes no allowance for the cost of cultivation.
('52', 185, 1, 10, 336145) I am prepared to admit that the inquiry was not made by experts.
('52', 185, 1, 11, 336210) It therefore lacks scientific precision.
('52', 185, 1, 12, 336251) But such as it is, it is revealing enough to make one pause and think.
('52', 185, 1, 13, 336322) Mr. Hooper, once a Settlement Officer, is said to have given the following landlords’ definition of the U.P. tenant :
('52', 185, 2, 14, 336440) One who is ready to live on one meal a day, and in native phrase to sell his wife and children to pay the highest possible rent for his holding, who submits to any cesses it may please his landlord to demand, and who is always willing to work for him without payment, to give evidence for him in court and speaking generally, to do any conceivable thing he is told.
('52', 185, 2, 15, 336806) The description is not flattering to the zamindars.
('52', 185, 2, 16, 336858) But since Mr. Hooper’s time the zamindars’ ideas have undergone revolution.
('52', 185, 2, 17, 336934) Many of them are sympathetic to their tenants.They try to make common cause with them.
('52', 185, 2, 18, 337021) But the process has to be much faster than it has been.
('52', 185, 2, 19, 337077) With the great awakening among the kisans there must be growing dissatisfaction with their lot, and a growing assertion of their rights.
('52', 185, 2, 20, 337214) I would like the zamindars to recognize the correctness of the kisans’ positio and make a corresponding change in their own outlook.
('52', 185, 2, 21, 337347) The present crisis will be somehow tided over.
('52', 185, 2, 22, 337394) But it would be wrong to go to sleep after it is over.
('52', 186, 0, 1, 337449) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 187
('52', 186, 1, 2, 337491) The zamindars would do well to take the time by the forelock.
('52', 186, 1, 3, 337553) Let them cease to be mere rent collectors.
('52', 186, 1, 4, 337596) They should become trustees and trusted friends of their tenants.
('52', 186, 1, 5, 337662) They should limit their privy purse.
('52', 186, 1, 6, 337699) Let them forgo the questionable perquisites they take from the tenants in the shape of forced gifts on marriage and other occasions, or nazarana on transfer of holdings from one kisan to another or on restoration to the same kisan after eviction for non payment of rent.
('52', 186, 1, 7, 337970) They should give them fixity of tenure, take a lively interest in their welfare, provide well managed schools for their children, night schools for adults, hospitals and dispensaries for the sick, look after the sanitation of villages and in a variety of ways make them feel that they, the zamindars, are their true friends taking only a fixed commission for their manifold services In short they must justify their position.
('52', 186, 1, 8, 338396) They should trust Congressmen.They may themselves become Congressmen and know that the Congress is a bridge between the people and the Government.
('52', 186, 1, 9, 338543) All who have the true welfare of the people at heart can harness the services of the Congress.
('52', 186, 1, 10, 338638) Congressmen will on their part see to it that kisans scrupul ously fulfil their obligations to the zamindars.
('52', 186, 1, 11, 338748) I mean not necessarily the statu tory, but the obligations which they have themselves admitted to be just.
('52', 186, 1, 12, 338855) They must reject the doctrine that their holdings are absolu tely theirs to the exclusion of the zamindars.
('52', 186, 1, 13, 338963) They are or should be members of a joint family in which the zamindar is the head guarding their rights against encroachment.
('52', 186, 1, 14, 339089) Whatever the law may be, the zamindari to be defensible must approach the conditions of a joint family.
('52', 186, 1, 15, 339193) I like the ideal of Rama and Janaka.They owned nothing against the people.
('52', 186, 1, 16, 339268) Everything including themselves belonged to the people.
('52', 186, 1, 17, 339324) They lived in their midst a life not above theirs but in correspondence with theirs.
('52', 186, 1, 18, 339409) But these may not be regarded as historical personages.
('52', 186, 1, 19, 339465) Then let us take the example of the great Caliph Omar.
('52', 186, 1, 20, 339520) Though he was monarch of a vast realm created by his great genius and amazing industry, he lived the life of a pauper and never considered himself owner of the vast treasures that lay at his feet.
('52', 186, 1, 21, 339717) He was a terror to those officials who squandered people’s money in luxuries.
('52', 186, 1, 22, 339795) Young India, 28 5 1931
('52', 187, 0, 1, 339818) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 187, 1, 2, 339860) 256. NOTES
('52', 187, 2, 3, 339871) MAHARAJA SAHEB OF MAHMUDABAD 1
('52', 187, 3, 4, 339902) The untimely death of the Maharaja Saheb of Mahmudabad removes one whose wisdom was needed at the present juncture in the life of the nation.
('52', 187, 3, 5, 340044) He was genuinely anxious to promote Hindu Muslim unity, and could be relied upon to give sound advice on national matters.
('52', 187, 3, 6, 340167) I tender my respectful condolences to the deceased’s family.
('52', 187, 4, 7, 340228) POISONOUS JOURNALISM I have before me extracts from journals containing some gruesome things There is communal incitement, gross misrepresen tation and incitement to political violence bordering on murder.
('52', 187, 4, 8, 340434) It is of course easy enough for the Government to launch out prosecutions or to pass repressive ordinances.
('52', 187, 4, 9, 340542) These fail to serve the purpose intended except very temporarily, and in no case do they convert the writers, who often take to secret propaganda, when the open forum of the Press is denied to them.
('52', 187, 4, 10, 340741) The real remedy is healthy public opinion that will refuse to patronize poisonous journals.
('52', 187, 4, 11, 340833) We have our journalists’ Association.
('52', 187, 4, 12, 340871) Why should it not create a department whose business it would be to study the various journals and find objectionable articles and bring them to the notice of the respective editors?
('52', 187, 4, 13, 341054) The function of the department will be confined to the establishment of contact with the offending journals and public criticism of offending articles where the contact fails to bring about the desired reform.
('52', 187, 4, 14, 341264) Freedom of the Press is a precious privilege that no country can forgo.
('52', 187, 4, 15, 341336) But if there is, as there should be, no legislative check save that of the mildest character, an internal check such as I have suggested should not be impossible and ought not to be resented.
('52', 187, 5, 16, 341528) NAVAJUVAN BHARAT SABHA A member of this Sabha asked me at Muttra Junction whether I had suggested that no Congress member should be a member of that body or vice versa I told him that so far as I knew I had never ex pressed any such opinion.
('52', 187, 5, 17, 341770) He immediately announced the purport of my reply to the young men on the platform, and said that some Congress member had ascribed such opinion to me, that it was wrong and that now every Congressman was free to join the Sabha as every
('52', 187, 6, 18, 342006) 1 A leading nationalist Muslim who died on May 23
('52', 188, 0, 1, 342056) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 189
('52', 188, 1, 2, 342098) member of the Sabha was free to join the Congress.
('52', 188, 1, 3, 342149) That I had expressed no such opinion as was ascribed to me did not certainly imply that all Congressmen should or were free to join the Sabha.
('52', 188, 1, 4, 342292) Every Sabha has its own rules.
('52', 188, 1, 5, 342323) And I should be sorry to find Con gressmen joining any of these Sabhas or for that matter any other institution without first ascertaining the condition of membership, the men composing it and the methods of its working.
('52', 188, 1, 6, 342544) Certainly no one can be bullied into joining an institution.
('52', 188, 1, 7, 342605) The Navajuvan Bharat Sabha will flourish if it shows a record of constructive service of the nation, never otherwise.
('52', 188, 2, 8, 342723) RIVAL CONGRESS COMMITTEES Whilst at Nainital I heard of rival Congress Committees in the U.P. and elsewhere.
('52', 188, 2, 9, 342832) I heard too of election disputes in several places.
('52', 188, 2, 10, 342884) This is a bad sign.
('52', 188, 2, 11, 342904) There must be something wrong in a place where such unhealthy rivalries take place.
('52', 188, 2, 12, 342988) The hunt for office in Congress Committees is also a very ugly sign.
('52', 188, 2, 13, 343057) A Congress office is or should be an opportunity for service.
('52', 188, 2, 14, 343119) And where service is the motive, there can be no unhealthy rivalry.
('52', 188, 2, 15, 343187) A man or a woman can easily do service without needing, or hunting for office.
('52', 188, 2, 16, 343266) Wise servants of the nation will find it more profitable to stand out than to enter into unhealthy competition.
('52', 188, 2, 17, 343378) Nor need one form a separate organization for the sake of service.
('52', 188, 2, 18, 343445) Why do I, for instance, need an organization, if I want to teach the children of my village or street, or to sweep it, or to nurse my neighbours, to carry on khadi propaganda or to do kindred acts, all of which promote national well being and keep me going the whole time?
('52', 188, 3, 19, 343718) CONGRESS AND COMMUNALISM A correspondent asks whether a Congressman who openly iden tifies himself with communal conferences, and other communal pro paganda can hold any office under the Congress organization.
('52', 188, 3, 20, 343928) I do not think there is any rule prohibiting the election of any Congressman to any office because of his communalism.
('52', 188, 3, 21, 344047) But if the Congress is to remain a purely national organization, and is to be absolutely just to all and guardian of weak minorities, Congressmen will never elect those who are known for their communal bias or tendency.
('52', 188, 3, 22, 344267) Young India, 28 5 1931
('52', 189, 0, 1, 344290) 190 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 189, 1, 2, 344332) 257. CHRISTIAN MISSIONS
('52', 189, 2, 3, 344356) I gladly publish the following from Rev.
('52', 189, 2, 4, 344397) B. W. Tucker: 1
('52', 189, 3, 5, 344413) I am in full agreement with you in your protest against the methods
('52', 189, 4, 6, 344481) employed by Christian missions in their efforts to gain proselytes through edu 
('52', 189, 5, 7, 344561) cation, medical services and the like.
('52', 189, 5, 8, 344600) Education when used for such purposes is
('52', 189, 6, 9, 344641) really no education at all, but merely the perpetuation of the present substitute for
('52', 189, 7, 10, 344727) education initiated by the Government, which no honest missionary, familiar with
('52', 189, 8, 11, 344808) educational experimentation in the lands from which he comes would tolerate for a
('52', 189, 9, 12, 344890) minute if his primary interest was education rather than proselytizing.
('52', 189, 9, 13, 344962) While not
('52', 189, 10, 14, 344972) denying the right of the sick to relief from their sufferings, it might not be altogether
('52', 189, 11, 15, 345062) unfair to presume, that it has been proselytizing zeal rather than lack of intelligence
('52', 189, 12, 16, 345150) that has caused missionary doctors to specialize in hospitals of healing to the neglect
('52', 189, 13, 17, 345238) of preventive medicine and health work.
('52', 189, 13, 18, 345278) All humanitarian work must necessarily
('52', 189, 14, 19, 345317) suffer if men are not dealt with with a single eye to their welfare and development as
('52', 189, 15, 20, 345404) personalities, and this cannot be the case when they are looked upon merely as
('52', 189, 16, 21, 345483) candidates for conversion into another social ro religious grouping.
('52', 189, 17, 22, 345552) It is the spirit of the age, that one’s devotion to religion and God should
('52', 189, 18, 23, 345628) find an immediate return in increased material prosperity, which is the negation of all
('52', 189, 19, 24, 345716) spiritual religion.
('52', 189, 19, 25, 345736) In fact the whole Christian community have had their
('52', 189, 20, 26, 345789) character vitiated by this sort of thing, .
('52', 189, 20, 27, 345833) In no walk of life can the principle be
('52', 189, 21, 28, 345873) justified that the end justifies the means, but least of all in religion where sincerity
('52', 189, 22, 29, 345962) must reign supreme.
('52', 189, 23, 30, 345982) Jesus had the same passion for social solidarity that has ever characterized
('52', 189, 24, 31, 346059) Hindu religion at its best.
('52', 189, 24, 32, 346087) While he was a devout Jew, he was never a communalist,
('52', 189, 25, 33, 346142) and set his face sternly against everything, which hindered men from realizing their
('52', 189, 26, 34, 346227) universal brotherhood.
('52', 189, 26, 35, 346250) For this reason he was opposed to the nationalism of his
('52', 189, 27, 36, 346307) day, even as you have been opposed to the current tendency towards a divisive
('52', 189, 28, 37, 346385) nationalism in India.
('52', 189, 28, 38, 346407) I believe that if modern Christian missions are to be true to
('52', 189, 29, 39, 346469) their Lord and Master, they will eschew all efforts to proselytize and thus tear men
('52', 189, 30, 40, 346554) away from their social order with the consequent lack of the sense of responsibility
('52', 189, 31, 41, 346639) for the advancement of that social order.
('52', 189, 32, 42, 346681) This Government has demanded that the non British missionary not only remain neutral in such vital matters as the economic and political evils of this country, but has compelled him to give a pledge, which the Government has inter preted to mean that the missionary shall actively support the Government.
('52', 189, 33, 43, 346986) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('52', 190, 0, 1, 347023) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 191
('52', 190, 1, 2, 347065) own case they objected even to my attending political meetings as a visitor, frankly admitting that they had no charge of moral obloquy to make against me, but that the Government interpretation of the pledge I had given would not allow me even this privilege.
('52', 190, 1, 3, 347326) It is a standing indictment of the alliance of Christian missions in India with the world’s greatest collective evil, imperialism, that they have acquiesced in this arrangement.
('52', 190, 2, 4, 347504) It is for this reason that I am pleased that you have signified that you would
('52', 190, 3, 5, 347583) not perpetuate this evil in a swaraj government by creating any legal enactment
('52', 190, 4, 6, 347663) compelling missionaries to withdraw if they failed to give up their proselytizing
('52', 190, 5, 7, 347745) activities.
('52', 190, 5, 8, 347757) No government can afford to abridge freedom of religion in this way.
('52', 190, 6, 9, 347826) While I am sympathetic with your criticism of the exclusive claim of
('52', 190, 7, 10, 347895) Christianity as the superior religion, I must protest against the implications of your
('52', 190, 8, 11, 347982) statement that the religions of India are adequate for her.
('52', 190, 8, 12, 348042) I can have nothing to add to this letter.
('52', 190, 8, 13, 348084) But I must adhere to the statement to which Rev.
('52', 190, 8, 14, 348133) Tucker takes exception and which is, “Religions of India are adequate for her.” This surely means nothing more than that she does not need to change them.
('52', 190, 8, 15, 348288) But as the context of the article in which the statement occurs shows, it does not mean that the professors of the respective faiths have nothing to learn.
('52', 190, 8, 16, 348444) If there is sympathetic contact established between the various faiths and no evil designs suspected, each can gain a great deal from the rest.
('52', 190, 8, 17, 348588) What is resisted is the idea of gaining converts and that too not always by fair and open means.
('52', 190, 9, 18, 348685) Young India, 28 5 1931
('52', 190, 10, 19, 348708) 258. PANCHAYATS
('52', 190, 11, 20, 348724) Panchayat has an ancient flavour; it is a good word.
('52', 190, 11, 21, 348777) It literally means an assembly of five elected by villagers.
('52', 190, 11, 22, 348838) It represents the system, by which the innumerable village republics of India were governed.
('52', 190, 11, 23, 348931) But the British Government, by its ruthlessly through method of revenue collection, almost destroyed these ancient repub lics, which could not stand the shock of this revenue collection.
('52', 190, 11, 24, 349118) Congressmen are now making a crude attempt to revive the system by giving village elders civil and criminal jurisdiction.The attempt was first made in 1921. It failed.
('52', 190, 11, 25, 349286) It is being made again, and it will fail if
('52', 191, 0, 1, 349330) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 191, 1, 2, 349372) it is not systematically and decently, I will not say, scientifically, tried.
('52', 191, 1, 3, 349450) It was reported to me in Nainital, that in certain places in the U.P. even criminal cases like rape were tried by the so called Panchayats.
('52', 191, 1, 4, 349590) I heard of some fantastic judgments pronounced by igno rant or interested Panchayats.
('52', 191, 1, 5, 349676) This is what comes to me from far off Assam: It has been ascertained that the Congress Committee at Chaparmukh has set up a sort of rival administrative machinery there for the trial and disposal of civil and criminal cases.
('52', 191, 1, 6, 349901) There are a few branch offices in the neighbourhood of Chaparmukh which dispose of similar business.
('52', 191, 1, 7, 350002) At Chaparmukh office regis ters are being maintained for civil and criminal cases.
('52', 191, 1, 8, 350085) It is understood that fines are imposed in criminal cases, and decrees are passed in civil suits, and that in a few cases attachments of property have been made or attempted in execution of decrees.
('52', 191, 1, 9, 350284) This is all bad if it is true.
('52', 191, 1, 10, 350315) Irregular Panchayats are bound to fall to pieces under their own unsupportable weight.
('52', 191, 1, 11, 350402) I suggest therefore the following rules for the guidance of village workers: 1. No Panchayat should be set up without the written sanction of a Povincial Congress Committee; 2. A Panchayat should in the first instance be elected by a public meeting called for the purpose by beat of drum; 3. It should be recommended by the Tehsil Committee; 4. Such Panchayat should have no criminal jurisdiction; 5. It may try civil suits if the parties to them refer their disputes to the Panchayat; 6. No one should be compelled to refer any matter to the Panchayat; 7. No Panchayat should have any authority to impose fines, the only sanction behind its civil decrees being its moral authority, strict impartiality and the willing obedience of the parties concerned; 8. There should be no social or other boycott for the time being; 9. Every Panchayat will be expected to attend to;
('52', 192, 0, 1, 351273) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 193
('52', 192, 1, 2, 351315) (a) The education of boys and girls in its village; (b) Its sanitation; (c) Its medical needs; (d) The upkeep and cleanliness of village wells or ponds; (e) The uplift of and the daily wants of the so called untouch ables; 10. A Panchayat, that fails without just cause to attend to the requirements mentioned in clause 9 within six months of its election, or fails otherwise to retain the goodwill of the villagers, or stands self condemned for any other cause, appearing sufficient to the Provincial Congress Committee, may be disbanded and another elected in its place.
('52', 192, 1, 3, 351888) The disability to impose fines or social boycott is a necessity of the case in the initial stages.
('52', 192, 1, 4, 351987) Social boycott in villages has been found to be a dangerous weapon in the hands of ignorant or unscru pulous men.
('52', 192, 1, 5, 352101) Imposition of fines too may lead to mischief and defeat the very end in view.
('52', 192, 1, 6, 352179) Where a Panchayat is really popular and increases its popularity by the constructive work of the kind suggested in clause 9, it will find its judgments and authority respected by reason of its moral prestige.
('52', 192, 1, 7, 352388) And that surely is the greatest sanction any one can possess and of which one cannot be deprived.
('52', 192, 2, 8, 352486) Young India, 28 5 1931
('52', 193, 0, 1, 352509) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 193, 1, 2, 352551) 259. SALT
('52', 193, 2, 3, 352561) Simla has issued the following welcome communique:
('52', 193, 3, 4, 352612) Since the conclusion of the Settlement between Lord Irwin and Mr. Gandhi, the Government of India have been engaged in settling the details of arrangements and regulations in various districts to give effect to clause 20 of the Settlement, which related to the collection and manufacture of salt by local residents in villages immediately adjoining the areas where salt could be collected or made.
('52', 193, 3, 5, 353010) These deatails in all cases are now practically completed, and the general manner in which effect is to be given to the arrangement may be stated as follows:
('52', 193, 4, 6, 353168) 1. Clause 20 is intended to benefit the poor classes.
('52', 193, 4, 7, 353222) It will be open, therefore, to those in villages adjoining the salt areas to make or collect salt for domestic use and sale in their respective villages.
('52', 193, 4, 8, 353376) NOTE: Domestic use shall include use for manure, cattle or fishcuring by individual fishermen.
('52', 193, 5, 9, 353471) 2. For this purpose villagers may make salt pans or beds.
('52', 193, 6, 10, 353529) 3. There should be no sale of salt for purpose of trade outside the villages.
('52', 193, 6, 11, 353607) It follows, therefore, that such salt an be carried only on foot and not in carts or such other conveyances.
('52', 193, 7, 12, 353716) 4. Wherever manufacture of salt under the foregoing clauses is permitted, salt pans will not be directed or otherwise interfered with by Government officers, and regular watches will be withdrawn.
('52', 193, 8, 13, 353913) 5. The concession will be withdrawn from the villages where it is found
('52', 193, 9, 14, 353985) that it is abused.
('52', 193, 9, 15, 354004) Wherever it is discovered that salt is manufactured or collected in
('52', 193, 10, 16, 354072) quantities above the requirements of a particular village, the abuse of the concession
('52', 193, 11, 17, 354159) will be presumed.
('52', 193, 11, 18, 354177) I hope that workers will understand and carefully explain these instructions to the villagers, so that the limits are not overstepped.
('52', 193, 12, 19, 354312) Young India, 28 5 1931
('52', 193, 13, 20, 354335) 260. TO DESHSEVIKAS
('52', 193, 14, 21, 354355) May 28, 1931
('52', 193, 15, 22, 354368) When I was in Bombay, I wished to meet the deshsevikas.
('52', 193, 15, 23, 354424) I tried to find time to do so, but I could not meet all of them.
('52', 193, 15, 24, 354489) Finally, the women contented themselves with writing a letter signed by all.
('52', 193, 15, 25, 354566) Till today, I have not been able to write even a few lines to express my
('52', 194, 0, 1, 354639) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 195
('52', 194, 1, 2, 354681) gratitude to them.
('52', 194, 1, 3, 354700) It is true that I was unnable to find time to write while travelling, but the fact is that I also forgot to write when I could have done so.
('52', 194, 1, 4, 354841) I hope these women will forgive me.
('52', 194, 1, 5, 354877) Some account of the work done by the deshsevikas did appear in the newspapers and, as I received two or three newspapers while in prison, I could get some idea of their work.
('52', 194, 1, 6, 355052) My heart used to dance with joy on reading about their ceaseless service and their fearlessness.
('52', 194, 1, 7, 355149) It is my hope that, with the very same enthusiasm, these women will do hereafter the more difficult constructive work and bring credit to themselves and to the country.
('52', 194, 1, 8, 355318) The world has certainly been astonished at what Indian women have achieved in the past twelve months.
('52', 194, 1, 9, 355420) But their task does not end there.
('52', 194, 1, 10, 355455) This is merely the beginning.

('52', 197, 8, 16, 360492) 266. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('52', 197, 9, 17, 360520) BARDOLI, May 28, 1931
('52', 197, 10, 18, 360542) Interviewed in connection with the report appearing in a Bombay paper saying that an ugly situation was again developing in and around Bardoli, Gandhiji declared : I urge upon the public to disbelieve all sensational statements and be unruffled by them.
('52', 197, 10, 19, 360796) It is news to me that the peasants have no intention to pay the land revenue.
('52', 197, 10, 20, 360874) I do know that the peasants have been paying to the utmost of their ability all the time and are still paying.
('52', 197, 10, 21, 360985) I hope to be able shortly to make a public statement to show how punctiliously correct Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and other workers in the Civil Disobedience Movement have been in implementing the Delhi Settlement.
('52', 197, 10, 22, 361198) The Hindustan Times, 30 5 1931

('52', 198, 1, 2, 361271) 267. LETTER TO R. M. MAXWELL
('52', 198, 2, 3, 361300) BARDOLI, May 29, 1931
('52', 198, 3, 4, 361322) DEAR MR. MAXWELL, I thank you for your several letters which I hope to deal with as fast as time permits me.
('52', 198, 3, 5, 361431) But I must make time to reply to your latest, i.e., of the 25th instant and the previous one, i.e., of the 24th instant.
('52', 198, 3, 6, 361552) I do not know what there can be in the prabhat pheris to object to.
('52', 198, 3, 7, 361620) Though they took from during the Civil Disobedience campaign they were in themselves quite innocent.
('52', 198, 3, 8, 361721) I do not know how far they dis turb the peace of citizens.
('52', 198, 3, 9, 361780) During my recent travels, I found them more or less in vogue in the other cities too.
('52', 198, 3, 10, 361866) I can understand prohibition of inflammatory songs.
('52', 198, 3, 11, 361918) But I do not know that the Government will be right in interfering with this innocent and beautiful institution which reminds citizens of their duty towards their Creator in early morning.
('52', 198, 3, 12, 362107) With reference to the Seva Dals the practices they go through are not new.
('52', 198, 3, 13, 362182) They have for years been going through them without any interference.
('52', 198, 3, 14, 362252) If there is anything specific that is objected to, I would like it to be specified.
('52', 198, 3, 15, 362336) I am unable without further information to endorse the suggestion that ‘these camps do not wholly reflect the spirit of the Settlement and that they are calculated in some degree to delay the restoration of normal conditions and feelings’.
('52', 198, 3, 16, 362576) As to the other letter, i.e., about liquor sales it comes upon me with painful surprise.
('52', 198, 3, 17, 362665) If whilst liquor picketing is recognized as legitimate, the Government counteract it through several practices even considered illegal, and contend that such practices are not in contravention of the Settlement, I venture to suggest that nothing that the Government may do or may not do need be deemed to be in contravention of it.
('52', 198, 3, 18, 362997) But your letter tells me that the present practice of sale out of ordinary hours and outside ordinary places of sale is perfectly legal.
('52', 198, 3, 19, 363134) This I must confess is a revelation for which I was wholly unprepared.
('52', 198, 3, 20, 363205) It means that the Collectors are guided by no legal restrictions or regulations that the public need know.
('52', 198, 3, 21, 363312) Indeed if such is the condition of liquor law or rather if the sale of liquor is governed by no law save the will of Collectors, the sooner the public is informed of the fact the
('52', 199, 0, 1, 363491) 200 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 199, 1, 2, 363533) better for it.
('52', 199, 1, 3, 363548) And it will be a serious matter for the Congress Working Committee to consider.
('52', 199, 1, 4, 363628) His Excellency will permit me to say that he is evidently unaware of the fact that picketing in Ahmedabad has been accepted by the previous District Officer and the Superintendent of Police as the most peaceful and inoffensive.
('52', 199, 1, 5, 363856) His Excellency is also evidently unaware of the fact that the picketing was started by the Labour Union in the interest of labour long before the Civil Disobedience campaign was inaugurated.
('52', 199, 1, 6, 364047) It has been admired by strangers from the West who have visited Ahmedabad.
('52', 199, 1, 7, 364122) His Excellency will pardon me for saying that the opening of the last paragraph of your letter betrays amazing ignorance of the working of picketing in Ahmedabad.
('52', 199, 1, 8, 364285) I state here for his inform ation that the Labour Union including the drinkers are thankful for this watch and it is the Union that has borne the expenses.
('52', 199, 1, 9, 364441) It was surely His Excellency’s duty to be sure of his facts on which undeserved reflections upon the conduct of an honourable body of men and women are based.
('52', 199, 1, 10, 364600) The suggestion contained in the last sentence that such picketing cannot be peaceful implies a reflection on Lord Irwin who negotiated the Settlement which reflection I am sure His Excellency could never have intended.
('52', 199, 1, 11, 364819) In conclusion I repeat my humble opinion that if the practice of liquor sales now going on in Ahmedabad continues, the continuation will be in breach of the spirit if not the letter of the Settlement.
('52', 199, 1, 12, 365020) I am, Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI A.I.C.C. File No.
('52', 199, 1, 13, 365074) 4, 1931, part II.
('52', 199, 1, 14, 365092) Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library

('52', 203, 5, 10, 369879) 277. LETTER TO F. KOTHAWALA
('52', 203, 6, 11, 369907) BARDOLI, May 30, 1931
('52', 203, 7, 12, 369929) DEAR MR. KOTHAWALA, I now send herewith a note on allegations against Patel Jehangir of Varad.
('52', 203, 7, 13, 370024) If an impartial open inquiry is held, full evidence will be led before the tribunal in support of all the allegations.

('52', 208, 21, 28, 377442) 286. THE LAW OF SWADESHI 3
('52', 208, 22, 29, 377469) Swadeshi is the law of laws enjoined by the present age.
('52', 208, 22, 30, 377526) Spiri tual laws, like Nature’s laws need no enacting; they are selfacting.
('52', 208, 22, 31, 377601) But through ignorance or other causes man often neglects or disobeys them.
('52', 208, 22, 32, 377676) It is then vows are needed to steady one’s course.
('52', 208, 22, 33, 377727) A man who is by temperament a vegetarian needs no vow to strengthen his vegetarianism.
('52', 208, 22, 34, 377814) For, the sight of animal food, instead of tempting him would only excite his disgust.
('52', 208, 22, 35, 377900) The law of swadeshi is ingained in the basic nature of man but it has today sunk into oblivion.
('52', 208, 22, 36, 377996) Hence the necessity for the vow of swadeshi.
('52', 208, 22, 37, 378041) In its ultimate and spiritual sence swadeshi stands for the final emancipation of the human soul from its
('52', 208, 23, 38, 378147) 1 Correspondent of Chicago Tribune 2 The addressee’s telegram, to which this is a reply is dated May 30. 3 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 31 5 1931. This is a translation by Pyarelal.
('52', 209, 0, 1, 378353) 210 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 209, 1, 2, 378395) earthly bondage.
('52', 209, 1, 3, 378412) For, this earthly tabernacle is not its natural or permanent abode, it is a hindrance in its onward journey, it stands in the way of its realizing its oneness with other lives.
('52', 209, 1, 4, 378589) A votary of swadeshi therefore, in his striving to identify himself with the entire creation seeks to be emancipated from the bondage of the physical body.
('52', 209, 1, 5, 378745) If this interpretation of swadeshi be correct then if follows that its votary will as a first duty dedicate himself to the service of his immediate neighbours.
('52', 209, 1, 6, 378905) This involves exclusion or even sacrifice of the interests of the rest but the exclusion or the sacrifice would be apparent only.
('52', 209, 1, 7, 379035) Pure service of one’s neighbours can never, from its very nature result in disservice to those who are remotely situated, rather the contrary.
('52', 209, 1, 8, 379178) ‘As with the individual so with the universe’ is an unfailing principle which we would do well to lay to heart.
('52', 209, 1, 9, 379290) On the other hand a man who allows himself to be lured by ‘the distant scene’ and runs to the ends of the earth for service, is not only foiled in his ambition but fails in his duty towards his neighbours also.
('52', 209, 1, 10, 379501) Take a concrete instance.
('52', 209, 1, 11, 379527) In the particular place where I live I have certain persons as my neighbours, some relations and dependents.
('52', 209, 1, 12, 379636) Naturally, they all feel, as they have a right to, that they have a claim on me and look to me for help and support.
('52', 209, 1, 13, 379753) Suppose now I leave them all at once and set out to serve people in a distant place.
('52', 209, 1, 14, 379838) My decision would throw my little world of neighbours and dependents out of gear while my gratuitous knight errantry would more likely than not disturb the atmosphere in the new place.Thus a culpable neglect of my immediate neighbours and an unintended disservice to the people whom I wish to serve would be the first fruits of my violation of the principles of swadeshi.
('52', 209, 1, 15, 380210) It is not difficult to multiply such instances.
('52', 209, 1, 16, 380258) That is why the Gita says: “It is better to die performing one’s duty or swadharma, but para dharma, or another’s duty, is fraught with danger.” 1 Inter preted in terms of one’s physical environment this gives us the law of swadeshi.
('52', 209, 1, 17, 380492) What the Gita says with regard to swadharma equally applies to swadeshi also, for swadeshi is swadharma applied to one’s immediate environment.
('52', 209, 1, 18, 380636) It is only when the doctrine of swadeshi is wrongly understood that mischief results, e.g., it would be a travesty of the doctrine of swadeshi, it to coddle my family I set about grabbing money by all
('52', 210, 0, 1, 380837) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 211
('52', 210, 1, 2, 380879) means fair or foul.
('52', 210, 1, 3, 380899) The law of swadeshi requires me no more than to discharge my legitimate obligations towards my family by just means, and the attempt to do so will reveal to me the Universal Code of Conduct.
('52', 210, 1, 4, 381090) The practice of swadeshi can never do harm to anyone and if it does it is not swadharma but egotism that moves me.
('52', 210, 1, 5, 381205) There may come occasions when a votary of swadeshi may be called upon to sacrifice his family at the altar of universal service.
('52', 210, 1, 6, 381334) Such an act of willing immolation will then constitute the highest service rendered to the family.
('52', 210, 1, 7, 381433) “Whosoever wants to save his life will lose it, and whosoever loses his life for the Lord’s sake will find it,” holds good for the family group no less than the individual.
('52', 210, 1, 8, 381606) Take another instance .
('52', 210, 1, 9, 381630) Supposing there is an outbreak of the plague in my village and in trying to serve the victims of the epidemic I, my wife and children and all the rest of my family are wiped out of existence, then in inducing those dearest and nearest to join me I will not have acted as the destroyer of my family but on the contrary as its truest friend.
('52', 210, 1, 10, 381970) In swadeshi there is no room for selfishness, or if there is selfishness in it, it is of the highest type which is not different from the highest altruism.
('52', 210, 1, 11, 382126) Swadeshi in its purest form is the acme of universal service.
('52', 210, 1, 12, 382188) It was by following this line of argument that I hit upon khadi as a necessary and the most important corollary of the principle of swadeshi in its application to society.‘What is the kind of service,’ I asked myself, ‘that the teeming millions of India most need at the present time, that can be easily understood and appreciated by all, that is easy to perform and will at the same time enable the crores of our semi starved countrymen to live, and the reply came that it is the universalization of khadi or the spinning wheel alone that can fulfil these conditions.
('52', 210, 1, 13, 382757) Let no one suppose that the practice of swadeshi through khadi would harm the foreign mill owners.
('52', 210, 1, 14, 382856) A thief who is weaned from his vice or is made to return the property that he has stolen is not harmed thereby, on the contrary he is the gainer consciously in the one case, un consciously in the other.
('52', 210, 1, 15, 383059) Similarly if all the opium addicts or the drunkards in the world were to shake themselves free from their vice, the canteen keepers or the opium vendors who would be deprived of their customers could not be said to be losers.
('52', 210, 1, 16, 383285) They would be the gainers in the truest sense of the word.
('52', 210, 1, 17, 383344) The elimination of the ‘wages of sin’ is never a loss either to the individual concerned or to society;
('52', 211, 0, 1, 383448) 212 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 211, 1, 2, 383490) it is pure gain.
('52', 211, 1, 3, 383507) It is the greatest delusion to suppose that the duty of swadeshi begins and ends with merely spinning so much yarn anyhow and wearing khadi made from it.
('52', 211, 1, 4, 383661) Khadi is the first indispensable step towards the discharge of swadeshi dharma twoards society.
('52', 211, 1, 5, 383757) One often meets men who wear khadi but in all other things indulge their taste for foreign manufactures with a vengeance.
('52', 211, 1, 6, 383879) Such men cannot be said to be practising swadeshi.
('52', 211, 1, 7, 383930) They are simply following the fashion.
('52', 211, 1, 8, 383969) A votary of swadeshi will carefully study his environment and try to help his neighbours wherever possible by giving preference to local manufactures even if they are of an inferior grade or dearer in price than things manufactured else where.
('52', 211, 1, 9, 384213) He will try to remedy their defects but will not give them up because of their defects and take to foreign manufactures.
('52', 211, 1, 10, 384334) But even swadeshi like any other good thing can be ridden to death if it is made a fetish.
('52', 211, 1, 11, 384425) That is a danger that must be guarded against.
('52', 211, 1, 12, 384472) To reject foreign manufactures merely because they are foreign and to go on wasting notional time and money to promote manufactures in one’s country for which it is not suited wuld be criminal folly and a negation of the swadeshi spirit.
('52', 211, 1, 13, 384710) A true votary of swadeshi will never harbour ill will towards the oreigner, he will not be moved by antagonism towards anybody on earth.
('52', 211, 1, 14, 384847) Swadeshism is not a cult of hatred.
('52', 211, 1, 15, 384883) It is a doctrine of selfless service that has its roots in the purest ahimsa, i.e., love.
('52', 211, 1, 16, 384973) Young India, 18 6 1931
('52', 211, 2, 17, 384996) 287. LIMITS TO FREEDOM Some Digambar 1 Jains have asked the Sardar how, in the face of the Congress resolution passed at Karachi regarding fundamental rights and duties, assuring religious freedom under swaraj, anyone can object to Digambar Jain sadhus roaming about naked in accordance with their religion.
('52', 211, 2, 18, 385304) The Sardar had replied that religious freedom could not imply that an act which appeared indecent to many or hurts their feelings was permissible.
('52', 211, 2, 19, 385451) And he had said it was his opinion that despite being sadhus, if they went about naked, it was bound to hurt people’s feelings.
('52', 211, 2, 20, 385579) I feel that the Sardar could have possibly given no other reply.
('52', 211, 2, 21, 385644) I myself believe that the ideal state for all human beings is nakedness.
('52', 211, 3, 22, 385717) 1 Literally, those who regard the sky as their garment
('52', 212, 0, 1, 385772) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 213
('52', 212, 1, 2, 385814) But an ideal human being would always be innocent and free of passions or desires.
('52', 212, 1, 3, 385897) Without such innocence, anyone roaming about naked would be regarded as a sinful man.
('52', 212, 1, 4, 385983) There is no reason to conclude that because Digambar sadhus are known as sadhus they would necessarily be free of all passions.
('52', 212, 1, 5, 386111) Even if they are so, it is their dharma to keep within the bounds of social decency.
('52', 212, 1, 6, 386196) A few Jains may understand the state of these sadhus.
('52', 212, 1, 7, 386250) But society by and large will fail to comprehend it and its feelings will be hurt.
('52', 212, 1, 8, 386333) These naked sadhus have no need to visit cities.
('52', 212, 1, 9, 386382) It they have, they should observe the minimum bounds of decency prescribed for citizens.
('52', 212, 1, 10, 386471) Instead of doing that if they insist upon entering cities in a naked state, or if the shravakas 1 insist upon this, in my opinion it would be regarded as adharma 2. I myself am fond of the state of nakedness.
('52', 212, 1, 11, 386680) If I were living in a lonely forest I would remain in that state, but in this world full of passions, there is little likelihood of this becoming the commonly accepted practice.
('52', 212, 1, 12, 386858) For the preservation of morality even great men of every persuasion have to cover their pri vate parts; it is their dharma to do so.
('52', 212, 1, 13, 386991) Freedom, both individual and religious, has always had and will always have many limits.
('52', 212, 1, 14, 387080) Religion does not hanker after rights, it hungers for restraints and restrictions.
('52', 212, 1, 15, 387163) Anyone who knows religion and practises it does not think in terms of his rights.
('52', 212, 1, 16, 387245) Nudity cannot be one’s duty.
('52', 212, 1, 17, 387274) It is one’s duty to abandon all possessions.
('52', 212, 1, 18, 387319) That is a dharma of the mind.
('52', 212, 1, 19, 387349) If anyone puts any burden on me, that is not possession.
('52', 212, 1, 20, 387406) But is becomes so if I start enjoying that burden.
('52', 212, 1, 21, 387457) The sadhu who bears the burden of the loin cloth for the preservation of the social order does not violate the principle of non possession but rather exercises selfcontrol.The sadhu who insists upon going about naked without worrying about the feelings of society is self willed.
('52', 212, 1, 22, 387737) The following dictum of the Gita is pertinent in this context: “For me there is naught to do in the three worlds, yet I am ever in action.
('52', 212, 1, 23, 387876) If I were not to perform my task, these worlds would be ruined; I should be the cause of chaos and of the end of all mankind.” 3 Sadhus should not do anything which would harm the people.
('52', 212, 1, 24, 388064) Let society never encourage them to do so.
('52', 212, 1, 25, 388107) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 31 5 1931
('52', 212, 2, 26, 388144) 1 Lay followers of Jainism 2 Violation of dharma 3 III.

('52', 213, 1, 2, 388242) 288. NOTES
('52', 213, 2, 3, 388253) DISTINGUISHING SWADESHI FROM FOREIGN GOODS The following question 1 has been received regarding this subject: No royal road has been found for distinguishing foreign from swadeshi cloth.
('52', 213, 2, 4, 388440) A picketer should acquaint himself well with this distinction.
('52', 213, 2, 5, 388503) And hence the general advice is that no one should purchase from uncertified shops.
('52', 213, 2, 6, 388587) These certificates are of two kinds: Those issued by the All India Spinners’ Association in regard to khadi and those issued by the Swadeshi Sabha in respect of cloth manufactured by Indian textile mills.
('52', 213, 2, 7, 388792) I do not know if this second type of certificate has yet been issued.
('52', 213, 2, 8, 388862) But khadi exclusively is the simpler way out.
('52', 213, 2, 9, 388908) Where falsehood has become almost universal, the sentiment for khadi alone will stand the people in good stead.
('52', 213, 2, 10, 389020) Untruth has entered even the domain of khadi, or, in other words, deceit is being practised with regard to it also; yet there is minimum room for deceit in it.
('52', 213, 2, 11, 389180) Moreover, those who spin at home have nothing to fear.

('52', 216, 1, 2, 395111) Even the violent soldiers of the world have acted in this manner and continue to do so.

('52', 216, 1, 8, 396020) Every reader should remember that a great deal of penance and constructive work lay behind the enthusiasm which was generated last year.

('52', 226, 7, 12, 410365) 310. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS June 1, 1931
('52', 226, 8, 13, 410406) Interviewed by the Associated Press regarding the statement recently made by Sir Chimanlal Setalvad in connection with Mahatma Gandhi’s attitude towards the Round Table Conference, Mahatma Gandhi said : You embarrass me by asking question on anything that Sir Chimanlal Setalvad says about me.
('52', 226, 8, 14, 410700) His age and his greatness entitle him to make statements on insufficient data and yet absolve him from criticism from one like myself.
('52', 226, 9, 15, 410835) 1 Which read : “Quarrel between Hindus Muslims over Gandhi Seva Samiti signboard.
('52', 226, 9, 16, 410917) Muslims refuse taking procession under it although board too high for interference with procession.
('52', 226, 9, 17, 411017) Hindus refuse removing it even for few hours.
('52', 226, 9, 18, 411063) panic all city .
('52', 227, 0, 1, 411080) 228 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 227, 1, 2, 411122) Moreover, whilst I am carrying on delicate negotiations, I may not be over communicative, but I can make a general statement that I am not conscious of having done anything to endanger the Settlement or in contravention of it.
('52', 227, 2, 3, 411349) Though under given circumstances, I am anxious and willing to attend the Round Table Conference, there is nothing in the Settlement, so far as I can read it, to make it compulsory for the Congress to take part in the Round Table Conference, but that discussion is purely academic, for the question of non attendance has not arisen at all.
('52', 227, 3, 4, 411688) Asked if it was true that his attitude was undergoing constant change, Mahatma
('52', 227, 4, 5, 411767) Gandhi said : I am not aware of having done such a thing.
('52', 227, 5, 6, 411825) Replying to a question whether he would take part in the Round Table
('52', 227, 6, 7, 411894) Conference, he said: If I succeed in attending the Round Table Conference, I should put forth the Congress demands with all zeal and power I may have and fully participate in the proceeding and not be a mere spectator at the Round Table Conference.
('52', 227, 7, 8, 412143) Questioned whether there was an impasse in Bardoli, Mahatma Gandhi said : I have had a happy interview with the Collector along with Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel and I am hoping that everything would be fixed up satisfactorily.
('52', 227, 8, 9, 412364) Replying to a further question if there was any breach of the Truce terms in Bardoli or Borsad, he stated: I would prefer not to answer that question, because negotiations are still going on for the settlement of outstanding questions both in Bardoli and Borsad.

('52', 229, 4, 6, 413957) 314. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('52', 229, 5, 7, 413986) AS AT SABARMATI, June 2, 1931
('52', 229, 6, 8, 414016) MY DEAR CHARLIE,
('52', 229, 7, 9, 414033) I have your two precious letters.
('52', 229, 7, 10, 414067) I see you are in a hury to have me in England through the air mail if I would fly.
('52', 229, 7, 11, 414150) But I can hardly hop.
('52', 229, 7, 12, 414172) I see no light before me as yet.
('52', 229, 7, 13, 414205) My desire is certainly to go there but the inner voice says ‘no’ and the external atmosphere confirms the guidence of the inner voice.
('52', 229, 7, 14, 414340) As you know, the Congress demands are strung in a high pitch.
('52', 229, 7, 15, 414402) They could not be otherwise.
('52', 229, 7, 16, 414431) If we cannot set our house in order here so far even as the communal question is concerned I could not speak in London as with one voice.
('52', 229, 7, 17, 414569) It therefore does seem to me that if the communal trouble is not finished and a workable formula is not arrived at by agreement I should not have the requisite self confidence to deliver the Congress message.
('52', 229, 7, 18, 414778) That is so far as the Round Table Conference is concerned.
('52', 229, 7, 19, 414837) But of course if the British Minister require my presence in order to discuss the Congress position and understand it and if they would want me to do a little lobbying also I could come whenever required.
('52', 229, 7, 20, 415042) But then there is the Delhi Settlement.
('52', 229, 7, 21, 415082) I am bound to see, as far as is possible for a single human being, that there is no breakdown.
('52', 229, 7, 22, 415177) The Bombay Government has given me cause enough to re declare hostilities but if you knew everything you would yourself be amazed at my patience.
('52', 229, 7, 23, 415323) In every little thing it is like drawing a live tooth.
('52', 229, 7, 24, 415378) But I must not weary you with these troubles of mine.
('52', 229, 7, 25, 415432) I am taking them cheerfully and breaking down opposition.
('52', 229, 7, 26, 415490) Thank God, I do receive help from the Central Government.
('52', 229, 7, 27, 415548) I believe Mr. Emerson knows me and he will play the game.
('52', 229, 7, 28, 415606) But local governments may produce situations which neither he nor I can control.
('52', 229, 7, 29, 415687) I can tell you that so far as the Congress is concerned, Congressmen are implementing the Settlement in a manner not even expected by me.
('52', 229, 7, 30, 415825) Of course there is overzeal now and again in picketing but it is immediately brought
('52', 230, 0, 1, 415910) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 231
('52', 230, 1, 2, 415952) under control.
('52', 230, 1, 3, 415967) You can give this assurance to all who may need it that I am anxious to attend the Conference and try my utmost to secure lasting peace and an honourable settlement of the constitutional question by negotiation.
('52', 230, 1, 4, 416179) It is only external circumstances which really detain me.
('52', 230, 1, 5, 416237) But in any case for reasons unconnected with my hesitation the Round Table Conference and its Committees stand postponed.
('52', 230, 1, 6, 416359) There need be therefore no hurry just now over my coming unless of course I am required there independently of the Conference.
('52', 230, 1, 7, 416486) I have now told you all that you should know.
('52', 230, 1, 8, 416532) I am just now in Bardoli fixing up things.
('52', 230, 1, 9, 416575) Gurudev seems to be ailing.
('52', 230, 2, 10, 416603) From a photostat : S.N. 968

('52', 237, 4, 9, 426203) 328. LETTER TO CHHAGANLAL JOSHI
('52', 237, 5, 10, 426235) June 2, 1931
('52', 237, 6, 11, 426248) CHHAGANLAL, Surendra’s letter seems to have confused you.
('52', 237, 6, 12, 426306) He has mixed up several issues, with the result that you could not understand my real meaning.
('52', 237, 6, 13, 426401) The idea that Surendra should return to the Ashram is independent of other considerations, and these are the reasons for my view: 1. It did not seem necessary to me to keep him at Karadi.
('52', 237, 6, 14, 426589) 2. It is not proper for us, who have taken the vow of aparigraha, to make a special effort to find out another place and stay there.
('52', 237, 6, 15, 426722) 3. In the present circumstances, it would not at all be wrong if persons like him return to the Ashram.
('52', 237, 6, 16, 426826) 4. Sardar would certainly prefer that Surendra and other work ers like him who cannot easily adjust themselves to circumstances should stay in the Ashram.
('52', 237, 6, 17, 426981) The following is the substance of the other po9ints discussed along with these : 1. Those Ashram workers who were slack in observing the Ashram rules of discipline and who were unwilling to return to the Ashram on the pretext that they should work outside should return to it.
('52', 238, 0, 1, 427258) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 239
('52', 238, 1, 2, 427300) 2. It was the duty of those Ashram, workers who were required outside the Ashram and who could observe the Ashram rules to stay outside it and do the required work.
('52', 238, 1, 3, 427465) 3. It was preferable to have only one public worker in every village.
('52', 238, 1, 4, 427535) 4. When there are more workers than one in a village, it is likely that they will not have enough work to do and that even small differences of opinion which may arise among them will confuse the minds of the residents.
('52', 238, 1, 5, 427755) 5. It is probable that Darbari left the place because he felt, when he saw three or four Ashram workers there, that he no longer enjoyed the position which he did.
('52', 238, 1, 6, 427919) 6. One should run away from a place where the necessity of one’s services is not self evident.
('52', 238, 1, 7, 428014) Before accepting anybody’s version of what I may have said, you should ask me.
('52', 238, 1, 8, 428093) Blessings from BAPU
('52', 238, 2, 9, 428113) [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro—7 : Shri Chhaganlal Joshine, p.

('52', 239, 9, 17, 429726) To reduce food or to abstain from it because a son or a dear one has died is ignorance.
('52', 239, 9, 18, 429814) I see no merit in it.Dharma and true shraddha consist in increasing work of service in the name of the departed one, recognizing the unity of all souls, and in realizing the transitoriness of the body.

('52', 247, 6, 10, 440006) 347. LETTER TO DARCY LINDSAY
('52', 247, 7, 11, 440035) AS AT SABARMATI, June 3, 1931
('52', 247, 8, 12, 440065) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter of the 30th April last.
('52', 247, 8, 13, 440130) I thought that the proposition that the Indian is a mere clerk 1 in the administration of the country was not seriously disputed by anybody.
('52', 247, 8, 14, 440271) Wish that you could read the minds even of the Indian members of the I.C.S. I know from personal experience of them that the vast majority of them do not feel anything more than mere clerks, somewhat glorified if you like.
('52', 247, 8, 15, 440494) But when I wrote the passage I had not the few of these highly paid Indians in mind but I had the army of actual clerks who, no matter what their ability may be, can never rise beyond the status of clerks.
('52', 247, 8, 16, 440700) When I said that the Indian at best was a commission agent I again thought that I was stating what was literally the truth.
('52', 247, 8, 17, 440824) Take the largest item of foreign trade.
('52', 247, 8, 18, 440864) Is not the Indian merely the agent of his foreign principals?
('52', 247, 8, 19, 440926) If he makes five rupees for himself, he makes Rs. 95 for his principal.
('52', 247, 8, 20, 440998) So long as the conditions of trade remain what they are it cannot be otherwise.
('52', 247, 8, 21, 441078) If India remains principally a country exporting raw produce and importing manufactured articles, Indian merchants must be largely commission agents whether of England,
('52', 247, 9, 22, 441247) 1 Vide “The Giant and the Dwarf”, 26 3 1931
('52', 248, 0, 1, 441291) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 249
('52', 248, 1, 2, 441333) Japan, America or any other foreign country.
('52', 248, 1, 3, 441378) How shall I prove to you the daily humiliating experience of the Indian who, no matter how wealthy he is, gets no facility whereas his English rival gets many things done for the asking.
('52', 248, 1, 4, 441565) Take the case of the British navigation companies, the concessions enjoyed by Euro peans all over India whether in mining, banking or other commercial pursuits too numerous to mention.
('52', 248, 1, 5, 441750) When I say that the English trade is founded upon the ruin of Indian trade, I have simply written what historians have stated.
('52', 248, 1, 6, 441877) If it was merely enterprise and grit that had brought about the state of things I should not grumble.
('52', 248, 1, 7, 441979) But I would like you to study the rise of the East India Co.
('52', 248, 1, 8, 442040) from the records of the India Office collected, be it said to their honour, by English historians.
('52', 248, 1, 9, 442139) In writing of the levelling process I certainly had not in mind the Soviet rule of Bolshevism.
('52', 248, 1, 10, 442234) It is perhaps somewhat shameful that I have to confess to you that I do not yet know exactly what Bolshevism is for the simple reason that I have not had time to study the inner working of the Russian revolution.
('52', 248, 1, 11, 442447) The levelling process to me simply means that the system of favouritism on which, as I believe, English commerce has been built should cease and for that purpose a double process has to begin.
('52', 248, 1, 12, 442640) Favouritism should go and young Indian enterprises should receive State help and patronage.
('52', 248, 1, 13, 442732) I know that I must not expect to convert you by argument.
('52', 248, 1, 14, 442790) What I would like Englishmen in India to do is to see them [selves] as the average Indian sees them and ask themselves why it is that the vast majority of Indians feel as I often write in the pages of Young India.
('52', 248, 1, 15, 443004) Can it be that what some English economists have written and what most Indian economists, historians and administrators have written is all untrue?
('52', 248, 1, 16, 443152) The case that I have presented is based upon their testi mony and supported by personal experience.
('52', 248, 1, 17, 443252) Lastly, however much I may differ from your views, let me assure you that I appreciate your persistence in trying to convince me of my error.
('52', 248, 1, 18, 443394) And if you will not give up the attempt I dare say that if I am not converted it is possible that in the process of friendly interchange of communications you might be able to see theother side of the shield.
('52', 248, 1, 19, 443603) Yours sincerely, SIR DARCY LINDSAY THE SPORTS CLUB ST.
