('52', 255, 0, 1, 451701) 256 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 255, 1, 2, 451743) 361. CASTE AND COMMUNAL QUESTION
('52', 255, 2, 3, 451776) A student who sends his name writes: 1
('52', 255, 3, 4, 451815) It is not quite correct to say that Hindus and Mussalmans do not greet one another on their respective sacred days.
('52', 255, 3, 5, 451931) But one would certainly like much more frequent and extensive interchange of such greetings.
('52', 255, 3, 6, 452024) As for caste I have frequently said that I do not believe in caste in the modern sense.
('52', 255, 3, 7, 452112) It is an excrescence and a handicap on progress.
('52', 255, 3, 8, 452161) Nor do I believe in enequalities between human beings.
('52', 255, 3, 9, 452216) We are all absolutely equal.
('52', 255, 3, 10, 452245) But equality is of souls and not bodies.
('52', 255, 3, 11, 452286) Hence it is a mental state.
('52', 255, 3, 12, 452314) We need to think of and to assert equality because we see great inequalities in the physical world.
('52', 255, 3, 13, 452414) We have to realize equlity in the midst of this apparent external inequality.
('52', 255, 3, 14, 452492) Assumption of superiority by any person over any other is a sin against God and man.
('52', 255, 3, 15, 452577) Thus caste, in so far as it c onnotes distinctions in status, in an evil.
('52', 255, 3, 16, 452651) I do however believe in varna which is based on hereditary occupations.
('52', 255, 3, 17, 452723) Varnas are four to mark four universal occupations, — imparting knowledge, defending the defenceless, carrying on agri culture and commerce and performing service through physical labour.
('52', 255, 3, 18, 452911) These occupations are common to all mankind, but Hinduism, having recognized them as the law of our being, has made use of it in regulating social relations and conduct.
('52', 255, 3, 19, 453081) Gravitation affects us all whether one knows its existence or not.
('52', 255, 3, 20, 453148) But scientists who knew the law have made it yield results that have startled the world.
('52', 255, 3, 21, 453237) Even so has Hinduism startled the world by its discovery and application of the law of varna.When Hindus were seized with inertia, abuse of varna resulted in innumerable castes with unnecessary and harmful restrictions as to intermarriage and interdining.
('52', 255, 3, 22, 453493) The law of varna has nothing to do with these restrictions.
('52', 255, 3, 23, 453553) People of different varnas may intermarry and interdine.These restrictions may be necessary in the interest of chastity and hygiene.
('52', 255, 3, 24, 453686) But a Brahmin who marries a Sudra girl or vice versa commits no offence against the law of varna.
('52', 255, 3, 25, 453784) Marriage outside one’s religion stands on a different footing.
('52', 255, 3, 26, 453847) Even here, so long as each is free to observe his or her religion, I can see no moral objection to such unions.
('52', 255, 3, 27, 453959) But I do not believe that these unions can bring peace.
('52', 255, 3, 28, 454015) They may follow peace.
('52', 255, 3, 29, 454038) I can see nothing
('52', 255, 4, 30, 454056) 1 The letter is not reproduced here.
('52', 256, 0, 1, 454093) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 257
('52', 256, 1, 2, 454135) but disaster following any attempt to advocate Hindu Muslim unions so long as the relations between the two remain strained.
('52', 256, 1, 3, 454260) That such unions may be happy in exceptional circumstances can be no reason for their general advocacy.
('52', 256, 1, 4, 454364) Interdining between Hindus and Mussl mans does take place even now on a large scale.
('52', 256, 1, 5, 454449) But that again has not resulted in promoting peace.
('52', 256, 1, 6, 454501) It is my settled conviction that intermarriage and interdining have no bearing on communal unity.
('52', 256, 1, 7, 454599) The causes of discord are economic and political, and it is these that have to be removed.
('52', 256, 1, 8, 454690) There is intermarriage and interdining in Europe, but the Europeans have fought amongst themselves as we Hindus and Mussalmans have never fought in all history.
('52', 256, 1, 9, 454851) Our masses have stood aside.
('52', 256, 1, 10, 454880) The untouchables are a class apart—a standing reproach to Hindu ism.
('52', 256, 1, 11, 454949) The castes are a handicap, they are no sin.
('52', 256, 1, 12, 454993) Untouchability is a sin, a grievous crime, and will eat up Hinduism, if the latter does not kill the snake in time.
('52', 256, 1, 13, 455109) Untouchables’ should no longer be the outcastes of Hin duism.
('52', 256, 1, 14, 455171) They should be regarded as honoured members of Hindu society, and should belong to the varna for which their occupation fits them.
('52', 256, 1, 15, 455302) According to my definition of varna there is no varna in operation at present in Hinduism.
('52', 256, 1, 16, 455393) The so called Brahmins have ceased to impart knowledge.
('52', 256, 1, 17, 455449) They take to various other occupations.
('52', 256, 1, 18, 455489) This is more or less true of theother varnas.
('52', 256, 1, 19, 455535) In reality, being under foreign domination we are all slaves, and hence less than Sudras—untouch ables of the West.
('52', 256, 1, 20, 455651) The correspondent being a vegetarian finds it difficult to reconcile himself to dining with meat eating Mussalmans.
('52', 256, 1, 21, 455767) But he should re member that there are many more meat eating Hindus than Mussalmans.
('52', 256, 1, 22, 455852) A vegetarian may with impunity dine with meat eaters, Hindu and others, so long as he has eatable food cleanly prepared and placed before him.
('52', 256, 1, 23, 455995) He will always have fruit and milk whereever he goes.
('52', 256, 1, 24, 456049) Young India, 4 6 1931
('52', 257, 0, 1, 456071) 258 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 257, 1, 2, 456113) 362. NOTES
('52', 257, 2, 3, 456124) SAVE ME FROM MY ADMIRERS A correspondent writes from far off Cape Comorin: 1
('52', 257, 3, 4, 456201) In the car festivals here the Image is placed in the car and taken in
('52', 257, 4, 5, 456271) procession.
('52', 257, 4, 6, 456283) One set of people want that your photo should be placed side by
('52', 257, 5, 7, 456347) side with the Image and taken in procession.
('52', 257, 5, 8, 456392) Another set of riper men say that
('52', 257, 6, 9, 456426) you would not like to be treated as God .
('52', 257, 6, 10, 456468) Another from Mathura sends me a horrible portrait representing me as lying stretched on the coil of the thousand mouthed serpent with the roll of non co operation in one hand and the spinning wheel suspended on the other arm.
('52', 257, 6, 11, 456694) My poor wife is massaging my legs.
('52', 257, 6, 12, 456729) The other celebrities have also been pressed into service.
('52', 257, 6, 13, 456788) I must not violate the reader’s feelings by describing the other features.
('52', 257, 6, 14, 456863) Suffice it to say that the picture is a caricature of the Vaishnavite legend representing Vishnu resting on the coil of Sheshanag.The correspo ndent who sends the picture asks me to plead with the publishers for its withdrawal.
('52', 257, 6, 15, 457091) He rightly adds that though they may not publicly express their resentment, the picture must hurt the feelings of orthodox Vaishnavas.
('52', 257, 6, 16, 457226) I whole heartedly endorse the sentiments of both these correspondents.
('52', 257, 6, 17, 457297) The motive in each case may be quite good.But this excessive heroworship borders on questionable idolatry, and is calculated to wound susceptibilities of the orthodox people without there being any excuse for giving such offence.
('52', 257, 6, 18, 457527) Such excesses will defeat the purpose of the blind worshippers.
('52', 257, 6, 19, 457591) If they have any regard for my feelings, let the organizers of the car festival who would put my portrait in the car and the publishers of the offending picture desist from their activity.
('52', 257, 6, 20, 457780) There are many other healthy ways of giving expression to and promoting patriotic sentiment.
('52', 257, 7, 21, 457873) REPATRIATES FROM SOUTH AFRICA Pandit Benarsidas Chaturvedi and Swami Bhavani Dayal Sannyasi have prepared a well reasoned report of an independent enquiry they held into the condition of emigrants repatriated to India under the assisted emigration scheme from South Africa.
('52', 257, 7, 22, 458147) This report and the Swami’s telegram dated 16th ultimo, asking me to comment on it, telling me, “Condition worst, many starving, women half naked, children begging”, have lain with me ever since.
('52', 257, 7, 23, 458343) I am sorry that I have not been able to deal with the report earlier.
('52', 257, 7, 24, 458413) The telegram from
('52', 257, 8, 25, 458431) 1 Only an extract is reproduced here.
('52', 258, 0, 1, 458469) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 259
('52', 258, 1, 2, 458511) which I have quoted is an epitome of the report.
('52', 258, 1, 3, 458560) The condition of our people, who find themselves strangers in their own land, is a disgrace alike to us and to the Government, but more to us than to the Government.
('52', 258, 1, 4, 458726) No Government in the world can cope fully with such cases.
('52', 258, 1, 5, 458785) Governments can only support to a limited extent voluntary public effort in such cases.
('52', 258, 1, 6, 458873) It is really up to the merchant princes and other employers of labour in Calcutta to take a real interest in the welfare of such people, and find suitable employment for them.
('52', 258, 1, 7, 459049) But the condition of these people is a small consideration, compared with the cause that has reduced those repatriates to the condition in which theyfind themselves.
('52', 258, 1, 8, 459215) There should have been no agreed repatriation at all, and if there was to be any, there should have been ample provision previously made to ensure proper occupation for them, and in any case there should never have been any consent to the repatriation of colonial born Indians, of whom there are fully thirty three per cent in the Calcutta depot.
('52', 258, 1, 9, 459562) But it is no use crying over spilt milk.
('52', 258, 1, 10, 459603) The labours of the framers of the report will not have been in vain if at the time of the revision of the Cape Agreement, the rights of the poor labouring Indian population are not bartered away for doubtful concessions to the other Indian settlers.
('52', 258, 1, 11, 459853) The position taken up by the latter is unassailable, and should depend on its own merits.
('52', 258, 1, 12, 459943) The settlers themselves should therefore refuse to be party to any bargain, which would compromise the rights of their less favourably situated brethren.
('52', 258, 1, 13, 460097) South Africa can easily absorb and accommodate the existing Indian population.
('52', 258, 2, 14, 460176) GANDHI ASHRAM, MEERUT This Ashram, a creation of Acharya Kripalani, has issued a neat little pamphlet describing its activities.

('52', 259, 3, 5, 461315) A contribution in the Times of India (26 5 ’31) has the following:

('52', 259, 6, 9, 461576) Perhaps he will explain, in the next issue of Young India, in what sense he uses that term.
('52', 259, 7, 10, 461668) information required can be supplied by answering certain questions prompted
('52', 259, 8, 11, 461745) by the piecegoods situation as it is now developing.
('52', 259, 9, 12, 461798) 1. To what extent has the decline of 1,000 million yeards in the imports of cotton piecegoods in 1930 31 been balanced by the increased production of indigenous cloth based upon the processes of hand spinning and weaving?
('52', 259, 10, 13, 462020) 2. To what extent has it been balanced by increase in mill production?
('52', 259, 11, 14, 462091) 3. Will the boycott be persisted in, regardless of the extent to which imported goods are displaced by hand made and mill made goods respectively?
('52', 259, 12, 15, 462238) 4. If so, to what extent is the boycott in the interests of Bombay as distinct from other provinces?
('52', 259, 13, 16, 462339) Clearly, if the endeavour to revive the village industry has definitely failed, as appears to be the case, however reluctant Mahatma Gandhi may be to acknowledge defeat in a campaign so close to his heart, then the time has arrived, in the interests of public honesty, to transfer the formal control of the boycott campaign to the Cotton Millowners’ Associations, acting as principals, instead of continuing the camouflage of control by Congress, acting as agents.
('52', 259, 13, 17, 462804) The answers to the specific questions are: 1. It is impossible to answer the question in terms of yards because khadi is not all commercially produced.
('52', 259, 13, 18, 462956) Home manufacture of khadi for use by manufacturers themselves is proceeding on an ever increasing scale, which it is impossible for the poor All India Spinners’ Association to measure.
('52', 259, 14, 19, 463141) 1 Vide “Notes” sub title Pciketing
('52', 260, 0, 1, 463176) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 261
('52', 260, 1, 2, 463218) 2. The indigenous mills are undoubtedly playing an important part in making good the deficit.
('52', 260, 1, 3, 463312) 3. It will be, subject to what follows.
('52', 260, 1, 4, 463352) 4. The interest of Bombay is the interest of India.
('52', 260, 1, 5, 463404) The writer perhaps includes Ahmedabad in Bombay, and evidently ignores the other important mills scattered all over India.
('52', 260, 1, 6, 463527) I have answered the specific questionsfor the satisfaction of the writer of the article than of myself or the public.
('52', 260, 1, 7, 463645) The public should know that I should lose all interest in boycott of foreign cloth, if I really discovered that khadi was a failure, as the writer is sure it has proved to be already.
('52', 260, 1, 8, 463829) I do not know the source of his assurance.
('52', 260, 1, 9, 463872) But as the party chiefly concerned in khadi production and propaganda, I make bold to say that it is not only not a failure but is making sure though slow headway all over India.
('52', 260, 1, 10, 464051) I therefore do reiterate the claim that boycott is an econo mic necessity for the masses.
('52', 260, 1, 11, 464141) It may sound strange, but it is true that it is not in the same sense and to the same extent an economic necessity for the mills as for khadi.
('52', 260, 1, 12, 464284) Mills have undoubtedly flourished beyond their expectations by reason of the boycott, but they could have, as they were doing, eked out an existence without the boycott.
('52', 260, 1, 13, 464454) They could always share with Britain and Japan the exploitation of starving millions by dumping their manufactures among the ignorant, famishing millions, who, forgetting that by using their leisure hours they could manufacture their own cloth, would buy the flimsy mill calico and thus doubly injure them selves.
('52', 260, 1, 14, 464768) Boycott cannot therefore be wholly transferred to the mills even if they wanted it.
('52', 260, 1, 15, 464852) And If they undertook it, it would fail.
('52', 260, 1, 16, 464893) The fact cannot be concealed tht the mills are interested in the boycott chiefly for their agents’ and their share holders’ profits.

('52', 260, 1, 19, 465261) The khadi method is bound to con found the orthodox economic theories, as non violence has al most already confounded the orthodox political methods.
('52', 260, 1, 20, 465411) The new method lends itself ot the orthodox statistical demonstration only to a certain extent.

('52', 277, 6, 12, 491877) 387. LETTER TO EMMA HARKER AS AT SABARMATI, June 5, 1931
('52', 277, 7, 13, 491934) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('52', 277, 7, 14, 491967) How can I remove the ban on foreign cloth and why?
('52', 277, 7, 15, 492018) And what is the meaning of the ban?
('52', 277, 7, 16, 492054) It is merely a method of persuasion.
('52', 277, 7, 17, 492091) If people want to wear foreign cloth, there is nothing to prevent them from doing so.
('52', 277, 7, 18, 492177) But if there was national government, the entry of foreign cloth would be surely prohibited as it was in the time of Elizabeth in England.
('52', 277, 7, 19, 492316) It is true that the Lancashire workmen may have to suffer during the transition stage.
('52', 277, 7, 20, 492403) But can it be any reason for India’s cottage industry.
('52', 277, 7, 21, 492458) If in trying to undo the wrong, Indians cease to use foreign cloth which it is their duty to do Lancashire has to turn to a less injurious industry.
('52', 277, 7, 22, 492607) Where is the harm and where is the wrong?
('52', 277, 7, 23, 492649) I would like you to work out this problem in its details and you will find that ban on foreign cloth is a necessary condition of the life of the millions of villagers of India.
('52', 277, 7, 24, 492826) You have evidently not studied the prohibition question in America.
('52', 277, 7, 25, 492894) I talked to both who are for prohibition and against prohi bition.
('52', 277, 7, 26, 492961) Whilst it is true that prohibition has given rise to fashionable crime it has saved tens of thousands of the labouring population of
('52', 278, 0, 1, 493094) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 279
('52', 278, 1, 2, 493136) America, who, having the temptation put away from them, are now bringing up sober families.
('52', 278, 1, 3, 493228) But the conditions in India are infinitely superior to those in America.
('52', 278, 1, 4, 493301) In America drink was the fashion and yet its great men rose against it.
('52', 278, 1, 5, 493373) We are too near the time to measure the greatness of America in having undertaken prohibition.
('52', 278, 1, 6, 493468) In India drink is considered to be a vice and is confined to only a particular class of people.
('52', 278, 1, 7, 493564) Prohibition will be therefore an unmixed good in this land.
('52', 278, 2, 8, 493624) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI MRS.
('52', 278, 2, 9, 493659) EMMA HARKER 6 BELGRAVE TERRACE KARACHI
('52', 278, 3, 10, 493698) From a photostat : S.N. 17235

('52', 283, 5, 12, 500290) 397. LETTER TO R. M. MAXWELL AS AT SABARMATI, June 6, 1931
('52', 283, 6, 13, 500349) DEAR MR. MAXWELL, Reverting to your letter of the 13th May, 1 at practically the same time that I received your letter in Simla I received the news that Syt.
('52', 283, 6, 14, 500507) Rajawade was discharged although the letter under reply left me no such hope.
('52', 283, 6, 15, 500585) I was thankful to receive the telegraphic news which was conveyed to me by Mr. Emerson.
('52', 283, 6, 16, 500673) I have now received the papers about Syt.
('52', 283, 6, 17, 500715) H. D. Rajah and on a persual of the papers I can find no incitement to violence.
('52', 283, 6, 18, 500796) The speeches themselves are not before me because I am told that they are not to be found in the record of the case, but the evidence of the Crown witnesses and the Judge’s summing up bring out the most relevant parts of the speeches, which though highly discourteous and equally seditious, contain no incitement to violence.
('52', 283, 6, 19, 501122) On the contrary, the judge himself refers to the profession of non violence by the accused but dismisses it as lip
('52', 283, 7, 20, 501237) 1 Vide “Letter from R. M. Maxwell”, 13 5 1931
('52', 284, 0, 1, 501283) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 285
('52', 284, 1, 2, 501325) service.
('52', 284, 1, 3, 501334) In the absence of any direct incitement to violence I cannot see how it is possible for a judge to infer mere lip service when there is a direct assertion of non violence.
('52', 284, 1, 4, 501506) But I have not relied upon my own opinion.
('52', 284, 1, 5, 501549) I put the thing before three legal friends, one of whom has kindly reduced his opinion to writing, copy of which I enclose herewith.
('52', 284, 1, 6, 501682) In the circumstances I request His Excellency to reconsider his decision and beg to point out that under Cl.
('52', 284, 1, 7, 501791) 13 of the Settlement there is no option but to discharge the civil disobedience prisoners who might not be guilty of offences involving violence other than technical violence or incitement to such violence.
('52', 284, 1, 8, 501998) I venture to suggest that where there is no incitement on the fact of the evidence it is not open to the Government to deduce such incitement.
('52', 284, 1, 9, 502141) Then there is the case of Ratanji Dayaram of Bardoli Taluka.
('52', 284, 1, 10, 502202) I have now studied the judgment and evidence in this case.
('52', 284, 1, 11, 502261) There is certainly no violence as contemplated in Cl.
('52', 284, 1, 12, 502315) 13 of the Settlement.
('52', 284, 1, 13, 502337) It is also moreover incorrect to say that the accused burnt his tenant’s crop.
('52', 284, 1, 14, 502416) The accused burnt his own crop which he owned jointly with the complainant Devalia Jagla.
('52', 284, 1, 15, 502506) If the complainant suffered any damage it was open to him, as it is even now, to bring a civil suit against the accused.
('52', 284, 1, 16, 502627) But where, on the evidence itself and the finding of the judge admitted by the Government, the crop was burnt in order to prevent the Government officials from collecting revenue from selling the crop, there was no question of intending to damage the partner.
('52', 284, 1, 17, 502887) And may I point out the inconsistency of the Government in releasing the co accused, Ranchhod, who had no ownership in the crop and keeping Ratanji Dayaram who was admittedly joint owner of the crop.
('52', 284, 1, 18, 503087) I must, therefore, for the same reason as in the case of Syt.
('52', 284, 1, 19, 503149) H. D. Rajah, ask for Ratanji Dayaram’s discharge in terms of the Settlement.
('52', 284, 1, 20, 503226) With reference to your second letter of 30th May last, I can only say that the position taken up by His Excellency causes me deep pain.
('52', 284, 1, 21, 503362) The reasoning given for refusing to return the press seems to me to be extraordinary.
('52', 284, 1, 22, 503448) It is giving back and not taking back.
('52', 284, 1, 23, 503487) 16 throws the burden on the Government of returning and not on the party dispossessed of going to take back.
('52', 284, 1, 24, 503596) The reason ing given in the third paragraph of your letter causes still greater pain.
('52', 284, 1, 25, 503682) I was unprepared for the interpretation that is sought to be put upon the Ordinance.
('52', 284, 1, 26, 503767) I cannot question the inter pretation but I
('52', 285, 0, 1, 503811) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 285, 1, 2, 503853) do question the propriety of putting an irritating interpretation in connection with a document of peace.
('52', 285, 1, 3, 503959) What the Government seek to do is to justify wanton destruction of property by Government officials.
('52', 285, 1, 4, 504060) But in order to bring within the smallest compass possible points of dispute between the Government and myself as representing the Congress, I have advised the owners of the motor car and bicycle to remove them, if they chose to do so.
('52', 285, 1, 5, 504296) So far as the press is concerned I am sorry to say that I must ask for due fulfilment of the terms of the Settlement.
('52', 285, 1, 6, 504414) If the Government seriously question my interpretation I am quite willing to submit the question for decision to the Chief Justice of the High Court of Bombay or any other impartial authority.
('52', 285, 2, 7, 504607) Yours sincerely, Encl.
('52', 285, 2, 8, 504630) 1 R. M. MAXWELL, ESQ.

('52', 289, 3, 6, 509689) Add a measure of water to it.
('52', 289, 3, 7, 509719) After adding water warm it and instead of sugar add honey to it.
('52', 289, 3, 8, 509784) Her stomach should be very lightly massaged with oil every day.

('52', 289, 3, 17, 510314) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Motana Man, p.
('52', 289, 4, 18, 510365) 406. WORKER VILLAGE RATIO
('52', 289, 5, 19, 510391) How many workers would be needed to cover seven lakh villages?
('52', 289, 5, 20, 510454) This question requires serious consideration.
('52', 289, 5, 21, 510500) The British flag flies in each and every village, that is to say, all of them use the Government’s currency, and pay revenue in that currency.
('52', 289, 5, 22, 510643) But the Congress has not been able to cover all the villages.
('52', 289, 5, 23, 510705) Even its name has not reached every village, let alone its message.
('52', 289, 5, 24, 510773) The Congress can reach every village through khadi, but we do not have enough interest in khadi for that purpose.
('52', 289, 6, 25, 510887) The reader will be surprised to know that, though the Govern ment’s authority is recognized in every village, every one of them does not have a Patel, a talati or a constable.
('52', 289, 6, 26, 511063) All that it has been able to do is to put a few villages under each talati and Patel.
('52', 289, 6, 27, 511149) A talati should be an educated person, for he is supposed to keep accounts.
('52', 289, 6, 28, 511225) He has, therefore, more villages under him than a Patel.
('52', 289, 6, 29, 511282) If the Government does not have a talati and a Patel for every village, how can the Congress have a worker for every one of them.
('52', 289, 6, 30, 511412) I know that the ratio of workers and villages should be exactly the opposite of that
('52', 290, 0, 1, 511497) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 291
('52', 290, 1, 2, 511539) of talatis and Patels and villages.
('52', 290, 1, 3, 511575) The Congress should have the capacity which the Government does not possess.
('52', 290, 1, 4, 511652) But we must admit with shame that it is not so.
('52', 290, 1, 5, 511700) The Government cannot afford to spend enough money to keep a talati and a Patel in each village.
('52', 290, 1, 6, 511797) The Congress does not need to spend money.
('52', 290, 1, 7, 511840) It can get volunteers but its name has not reached every corner so that it can have a volunteer in each village.
('52', 290, 2, 8, 511953) In these circumstances, it would be extravagance on the part of the Congress to have more than one worker per village.
('52', 290, 2, 9, 512072) We should group the villages into blocks, each with a radius of ten miles.
('52', 290, 2, 10, 512147) As our resources and the number of volunteers increase, we can increase the number of blocks but at present one volunteer should be able to cover ten miles from a central point.
('52', 290, 2, 11, 512325) So the diameter of his working area would be twenty miles.
('52', 290, 2, 12, 512384) But the volunteer will never have to walk twenty miles at a time.
('52', 290, 2, 13, 512450) There is no rule that he must always sleep in the central village.
('52', 290, 2, 14, 512517) Not only may he spend a night in any village within the limit of ten miles, but it would be actually his duty to spend a night in each of them by turn.
('52', 290, 2, 15, 512669) There would be at least ten villages in such a block with a radius of ten miles.
('52', 290, 2, 16, 512750) So, according to me, there would be one worker for every ten villages.
('52', 290, 2, 17, 512821) Hence we require seventy thousand men and women volunteers to cover all the villages in the country.
('52', 290, 2, 18, 512922) I said women volunteers.
('52', 290, 2, 19, 512947) But really speaking we should count their numbers on a different basis.
('52', 290, 2, 20, 513019) If, in early stages, two of them stay together then we would require more than seventy thousand volunteers, or the volunteers would have to be posted in different manner according to the number of women volunteers included in the total.
('52', 290, 2, 21, 513256) It should be obvious that to post more than one worker per village would be a crime.
('52', 290, 2, 22, 513341) Let us now think each worker can do.
('52', 290, 2, 23, 513378) He can easily : 1. collect children and teach them how to spin on the takli, card cotton, make taklis, and also teach them the three R’s; for this he can draw up a modest scheme and plan a curriculum; 2. look after the cleanlines of the villages and himself work to keep them clean; 3. give medicine to sick persons; 4. if there are quarrels among different groups and parties in a village, bring them together; 5. relieve the hardships of the untouchables, provide facilities for drinking water for them if they do not have any; 6. try to make the village self reliant in regard to khadi;
('52', 291, 0, 1, 513968) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 291, 1, 2, 514010) 7. prepare a census of each village in his block, count the number of cattle in each under the heads of cows, she buffaloes, bullocks, he buffaloes and male and female calves, calculate average yield of buffalo’s milk and cow’s milk, prepare a census of the Antyajas and write a general description of their conditions, find out the area of each village, its crops, the amount of land revenue paid by it, its crafts and industries, the number of wells in it and note whether any fruits and babul trees grow in the villages or in the fields within its limits.
('52', 291, 1, 3, 514569) Though I have mentioned this activity last, the volunteers should take it up first.
('52', 291, 1, 4, 514653) This work does not require much time.
('52', 291, 1, 5, 514691) But the volunteer who has gathered all this informationn would find his work much easier.
('52', 291, 1, 6, 514781) He should record all this information in a small exercise book.
('52', 291, 1, 7, 514845) No volunteer should say that he cannot do all this work unaided in ten villages.
('52', 291, 1, 8, 514926) Just as a school works only for a few hours daily, similarly we should not mind if it works only for one day in the week.
('52', 291, 1, 9, 515048) It will not matter if the school in each village works on every tenth day.
('52', 291, 1, 10, 515123) I have stated a extreme possibility.
('52', 291, 1, 11, 515160) I actual practice, a newly posted volunteer will immediately collect the statistics about the villages in his block and then train men and women volunteers in every village and assign them work according to their capacity.
('52', 291, 1, 12, 515383) In this way he will become a supervisor worker.
('52', 291, 1, 13, 515431) On the days on which he is not present in a particular village, the local volunteers will carry on the work.
('52', 291, 1, 14, 515540) One quality is essential in such a worker and that is purity of character.
('52', 291, 1, 15, 515615) If he is a slave of his eleven senses he will be able to do no work.
('52', 291, 1, 16, 515684) These eleven senses are the five of perception, the five of action and the mind.
('52', 291, 1, 17, 515765) If the mind is pure, then the ten senses automtically remain pure.
('52', 291, 1, 18, 515832) If the mind is impure, then everything else will be impure.
('52', 291, 1, 19, 515892) The senses of action are the arms, the legs, the mouth, and two private organs.
('52', 291, 1, 20, 515972) The senses of knowledge are the skin, the sense of touch, the palate, the ear for hearing, the nose for smelling and the eyes for sight.
('52', 291, 1, 21, 516109) Anyone who cannot control these should humbly refuse to become a volunteer.
('52', 291, 1, 22, 516185) If he has become one and then later on finds that he is unable to control his senses, he should humbly resign.
('52', 291, 1, 23, 516296) This is the right way if we want work to be done.
('52', 291, 1, 24, 516346) Some might say that this programme cannot be completed in a hundred years and we want swaraj just now.
('52', 291, 1, 25, 516449) This objection has no force.
('52', 291, 1, 26, 516478) We shall not have an abundance of workers when we get swaraj.
('52', 291, 1, 27, 516540) Those who are workers now will run the country under swaraj.
('52', 292, 0, 1, 516601) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 293
('52', 292, 1, 2, 516643) true that those who run the administration at present will be there when its control is handed over to the people.
('52', 292, 1, 3, 516758) If, however, the Congress does not have the type of volunteers that I have suggested, then we shall lose control of the administration or it will become corrupt and there will be anarchy in the country.
('52', 292, 1, 4, 516961) There is no reason to suppose that those who are hated now will become godlike overnight as soon as the control of the administration changes hands.
('52', 292, 1, 5, 517110) Hence, as we sow now, so shall we reap.
('52', 292, 1, 6, 517150) If we get sincere workers, the programme that I have chalked out can begin today.
('52', 292, 1, 7, 517232) “Let us first have seventy thousand volunteers and map out the country into blocks of ten miles each and then we shall see what work to take up.” This is not the right way to start work.
('52', 292, 1, 8, 517419) If we approach the task thus, we shall succeed in doing nothing.
('52', 292, 1, 9, 517484) The right method is this : Gujarat should start immediately.
('52', 292, 1, 10, 517545) If work cannot be started in the whole of Gujarat, it should be started in one or two districts, or even talukas, and if even that is not possible, then the few workers in the different parts in Gujarat should begin as I have suggested and leave whatever is not essential or cannot be done well.
('52', 292, 1, 11, 517841) They should start whatever they can do.
('52', 292, 1, 12, 517881) If there are more workers than one at one place, they should disperse themselves.
('52', 292, 1, 13, 517963) If they decide to stay together where they are, they should do so after considering whether that is necessary.
('52', 292, 1, 14, 518074) They should not deceive themselves or the people through mental or physical lethargy.

('52', 293, 1, 2, 518238) 407. NOTES
('52', 293, 2, 3, 518249) HINDUS’ SHAME In Dakor on 22nd May, 1931, there was a meeting of Bhangis of which Thakkar Bapa has sent me a report.
('52', 293, 2, 4, 518366) I give below its substance : About 1,500 Bhangis from 150 villages had gathered.
('52', 293, 2, 5, 518447) They had crected a mandap 1 of canvas with the ground also covered with canvas in which they could hold their meetings and sleep at night.
('52', 293, 2, 6, 518586) The meetings were held in this mandap during the day and at night they slept in it.
('52', 293, 2, 7, 518670) But no one would give them utensils for cooking and they could not get drinking water.
('52', 293, 2, 8, 518757) The water of the Gomati pond is so dirty that there are municipal signboards at numerous spots warning people not to use it for drinking.
('52', 293, 2, 9, 518895) But Bhangis can drink it!
('52', 293, 2, 10, 518921) How could they drink such dirty water at a gathering like this?
('52', 293, 2, 11, 518985) One Muslim gentleman took pity on them.
('52', 293, 2, 12, 519025) He gave them utensils, helped them in cooking and gave them water too.
('52', 293, 2, 13, 519096) No Hindu of Dakor, which is a centre of pilgrimage, felt ashamed at this or took pity on the Bangis.
('52', 293, 2, 14, 519197) The guests had come from distant places, but could get no water, no utensils and no food though there was an abundance of everything in the town.
('52', 293, 2, 15, 519343) the women volunteers of Dakor could have cooked for them.
('52', 293, 2, 16, 519401) It was the duty of the Mahajan 2 in Dakor to supply water to these people.
('52', 293, 2, 17, 519476) They failed in this duty and dimmed the lestre of Hinduism.
('52', 293, 2, 18, 519536) “But this sort of thing happens everywhere and no one cares for Bhangis.
('52', 293, 2, 19, 519609) Was it the duty of Hindus of Dakor spe cially on this occasion to do all that?” Yes, it was.
('52', 293, 2, 20, 519702) The fact that one’s for efathers have been committing a particular sin gives one no right to go on committing it.
('52', 293, 2, 21, 519816) As the days pass, the awake ning among the Antyajas increases, this e vil in Hinduism is being recognized and more and more caste Hindus feel ashamed of the practice.
('52', 293, 2, 22, 519983) The person who drafted the report is a Hindu and the person who sent it is also a Hindu.
('52', 293, 2, 23, 520072) All of us want to implement the resolution on rights passed by the Congress.
('52', 293, 2, 24, 520149) Whatever may have
('52', 293, 3, 25, 520167) 1 Covered enclosure 2 Traditional representative body looking after the affairs of a community or a professional or business group
('52', 294, 0, 1, 520298) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 295
('52', 294, 1, 2, 520340) happened before now, even caste Hindus will not tolerate now the kind of inustice that was shown in Dakor.
('52', 294, 1, 3, 520447) There will be no distinction between Antyajas and others under swaraj.
('52', 294, 1, 4, 520518) Let us, therefore, wake up.
('52', 294, 1, 5, 520546) THINK CAREFULLY OVER THIS
('52', 294, 2, 6, 520572) There is a village named Bharthari in Thasara taluka.
('52', 294, 2, 7, 520626) There a person named Dhanjibhai, an Antyaja, is trying hard to reform other Antyajas.
('52', 294, 2, 8, 520712) From the report that I have received about his work I see that he silently bears the hardship which he has to suffer because of his activities.
('52', 294, 2, 9, 520856) One of the reform which he is trying to persuade the Antyajas to adopt is to give up eating carrion and to this end to give up the work of disposal of dead cattle.
('52', 294, 2, 10, 521020) To persuade them to stop eating carrion is of course good, but to persuade them to give up the occupation of disposing of dead cattle seems to me a very harmful move.
('52', 294, 2, 11, 521187) I think myself the occupation is sacred, and certainly most useful.
('52', 294, 2, 12, 521255) It is sacred because it helps in preserving sanitation.
('52', 294, 2, 13, 521311) If dead animals were left unattended, the air whould be polluted,diseases would spread and the country’s wealth would be wasted.
('52', 294, 2, 14, 521440) Cattle serve the people after they die as much a they do while alive.
('52', 294, 2, 15, 521510) We use their skin, bones, flesh and guts for many purposes.
('52', 294, 2, 16, 521570) If we use living cattle properly and use the hide, etc., of dead cattle scientifically, their value would increase so much that it would not be profitable to slaughter them.
('52', 294, 2, 17, 521744) I would, therefore, suggest to reformers that they should not persuade Bhangis and Chamars to leave their occupation but they should, on the contrary, give them proper knowledge about their work.
('52', 294, 2, 18, 521940) This requires training.
('52', 294, 2, 19, 521964) It is only in our country that this occupation is considered low.
('52', 294, 2, 20, 522030) In the West we find even millionaires engaged in it.
('52', 294, 2, 21, 522083) If instead of becoming clerks, after graduation, young men learn the Chamar’s work, learn how to skin dead cattle and how to make use of the other parts, then the present drain of crores of rupees to foreign countries because of our ignorance in this matter would stop and Chamars would no longer look upon their occupation as low.
('52', 294, 2, 22, 522415) We shall be able to eradicate untouchability not when the Chamars give up their work but only when the Hindus realize their sin and when the Antyajas rid themselves of some evils which have entered their lives.
('52', 294, 2, 23, 522626) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 6 1931
('52', 295, 0, 1, 522662) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 295, 1, 2, 522704) 408. POOR MAN’S HUNDI
('52', 295, 2, 3, 522726) Vithaldashbai complains from his sick bed that khadi stocks are accumulating.
('52', 295, 2, 4, 522804) The workers of Gujarat write to inform me that because of this they are forced to give less work to spinners.
('52', 295, 2, 5, 522914) This complaint regarding khadi is a matter of shame for us.
('52', 295, 2, 6, 522974) Those who wear khadi know that by doing so they help women who are among the poorest in the country.
('52', 295, 2, 7, 523075) If all of us understand this fact, the demand for khadi will never go down.
('52', 295, 2, 8, 523151) As we always get the cash value of a currency note printed on, it, so we should always be able to get money for khadi at the price fixed by us.
('52', 295, 2, 9, 523295) Khadi is a sort of hundi drawn by the poor.
('52', 295, 2, 10, 523339) There should be men and women in cities who whould always accept such hundis.
('52', 295, 2, 11, 523417) And so long as this hundi is available, no one should touch any other hundi.
('52', 295, 2, 12, 523494) If I can have my way and if people co operate, khadi will always be sold at a fixed price.
('52', 295, 2, 13, 523585) The price of cotton may vary, but if the women who spin and the weavers are paid at uniform rates in their respective provinces and the rates of payment for the other proceses are also uniform, there should be no difficulty in having a fixed price for every variety of khadi.
('52', 295, 2, 14, 523861) Since we do not possess the requisite honesty, efficiency of organization and sympathy for the poor, the prices of khadi hav been changing.
('52', 295, 2, 15, 524001) However, anyone who takes the slightest interest in khadi knows that in every province the prices have declained from what they were ten years ago.
('52', 295, 2, 16, 524149) I have already pointed out in these columns 1 that, of the khadi produced in the Meerut Ashram, where it is manufactured in large quantities, those varieties which previously cost one rupee now generally cost less than six annas.
('52', 295, 2, 17, 524379) This does not mean that the women spinners are paid less.
('52', 295, 2, 18, 524437) It only means that the workers have acquired greater skill in all the processes of khadi manufacture.The quality of spinning has improved and, in consequence, the weavers’ work has become easier.
('52', 295, 2, 19, 524633) This has made it possible to reduce the rate of pay ment to weavers without reducing their total earnings.
('52', 295, 2, 20, 524740) It has been possi ble to bring about this happy result of reduction in prices because a philanthropic body is organizing khadi work.
('52', 295, 2, 21, 524873) Thanks to this fact, the quality of khadi has progressively improved and the prices have come down.There is
('52', 295, 3, 22, 524981) 1 Vide “Notes” sub title Gandhi Ashram, Meerut, 4 6 1931
('52', 296, 0, 1, 525038) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 297
('52', 296, 1, 2, 525080) considerable scope for still further improvement in quality and reduction in prices and this will happen as more and more people patronize khadi.
('52', 296, 1, 3, 525226) It is evident that, as the demand for khadi increases, a larger number of people and more skilled people will take interest in it and the quality will improve and the prices decrease.
('52', 296, 1, 4, 525410) The shareholders in the poor man’s company are not limited to a small number, but are the thirty crores in the country.
('52', 296, 1, 5, 525530) Then why should there be any difficulty in selling khadi?
('52', 296, 1, 6, 525588) But the difficulty is a fact and it is, therefore, fruitless to ask that question.
('52', 296, 1, 7, 525671) It would be wiser to dicover ways of selling it.
('52', 296, 1, 8, 525720) The following means suggest themselves : 1. To go round hawking khadi.
('52', 296, 1, 9, 525791) At all places women should do this only on fixed days, so that they will not have to go round every day.
('52', 296, 1, 10, 525896) It would be enough if they give some hours on some days in the week.
('52', 296, 1, 11, 525965) As in the West the wives of millionaires visit hospitals, etc., on certain days in the week, so the women here should go round hawking khadi.
('52', 296, 1, 12, 526107) 2. Leaflets giving a list of the varities of khadi and their prices should be distributed to every household.
('52', 296, 1, 13, 526217) 3. Talks about khadi should be arranged in all residential streets.
('52', 296, 1, 14, 526285) I have only given a few suggesions for guidance.
('52', 296, 1, 15, 526334) But those who love khadi and have resourceful brains will be able to think out many other ways of selling the accumulated stocks of khadi.
('52', 296, 1, 16, 526473) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 6 1931

('52', 297, 1, 2, 526551) 409. USE ANOTHER NAME
('52', 297, 2, 3, 526573) An Antyaja friend writes : 1
('52', 297, 3, 4, 526602) Such a feeling is natural in this age of awakening.
('52', 297, 3, 5, 526654) A person does not like the name which is applied to him in contempt, though its origin may have been quite innocent.
('52', 297, 3, 6, 526771) Formerly the name Antyaja was not felt as expressing contempt.
('52', 297, 3, 7, 526834) The names Dhed and Bhangi were disliked.
('52', 297, 3, 8, 526875) I think the term ‘Dalit’ was first used by the late Swami Shraddhanand.
('52', 297, 3, 9, 526947) Now it seems that name also is not liked.
('52', 297, 3, 10, 526989) This real explanation is that as long as the poison of untouchability exists in our society, any name that may be given will probably come to be disliked after some time.
('52', 297, 3, 11, 527160) Hence the right thing to do is to get rid of that poison and for this we need the co operation of the Antyajas men and women.
('52', 297, 3, 12, 527286) It is of course the duty of the Hindus to get rid of this poison unconditionally.
('52', 297, 3, 13, 527368) Atonement for one’s sin need not depend on any condition being fulfilled.
('52', 297, 3, 14, 527442) But however sincere the efforts of Hindus to atone for their sin, the evils which have crept into the lives of the untouchables because of the sin of Hindus can be eradicated only by their own efforts.
('52', 297, 3, 15, 527644) They will require the help of caste Hindus in their efforts.
('52', 297, 3, 16, 527705) They are getting it slowly and its tempo is likely to increase.
('52', 297, 3, 17, 527769) But even after taking all this into account, ultimately the Antyajas will have to rely on their own efforts.
('52', 297, 3, 18, 527878) Though it is thus necessary to attack the root cause, if a better word than Antyaja or Dalit occurs to anyone he may send it to me.
('52', 297, 3, 19, 528010) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 6 1931
('52', 297, 4, 20, 528046) 410. A SUPERSTITION
('52', 297, 5, 21, 528066) I give below the substance of what one cultured and very pious mother writes : “After my son’s death I have left off milk and ghee.
('52', 297, 5, 22, 528198) I live on rice, dal, roti, and buttermilk.
('52', 297, 5, 23, 528241) I have lost interest in life but I pass my time by devoting myself to service in one way or another.
('52', 297, 5, 24, 528342) I read Ramayana and other books, but deep inside the memory of my dear son continues to pain me.”
('52', 297, 6, 25, 528440) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('52', 297, 6, 26, 528477) The correspondent had expressed his sense of humiliation at the word ‘Antyaja’ and requested Gandhiji to coin some new word to denote his community.
('52', 297, 6, 27, 528626) For the choice of the word ‘Harijan’, vide “Notes”, 2 8 1931, sub title, “Harijan”.
('52', 298, 0, 1, 528710) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 299
('52', 298, 1, 2, 528752) This mother’s health was already weak and now it has become weaker.
('52', 298, 1, 3, 528820) It is not certain even whether she will survive or not.
('52', 298, 1, 4, 528876) As I have summarized the mother’s letter, I also give the substance of my reply to her.
('52', 298, 2, 5, 528964) To mourn the death of either son or husband is meaningless and shows our ignorance.
('52', 298, 2, 6, 529048) This should not be dismissed as merely wise talk; it is a truth to be pondered over till it sinks into our heart and to be acted upon.
('52', 298, 2, 7, 529183) Since death is certain for all, the only question is whether it comes today or tomorrow.
('52', 298, 2, 8, 529272) Why, then, should we grieve over anyone’s death?
('52', 298, 2, 9, 529321) It is only the body which dies.
('52', 298, 2, 10, 529353) That is its nature and therefore there is no cause for wonder when it dies.
('52', 298, 2, 11, 529429) It is certain that the soul which dwells in the body never dies, it is immortal.
('52', 298, 2, 12, 529510) When we know this as certain truth, why should we grieve over death?
('52', 298, 2, 13, 529579) Even if we assume that we are bound to be pained by death, is fasting or restriction of food a remedy for our grief?
('52', 298, 2, 14, 529696) Whom does it help?
('52', 298, 2, 15, 529715) The one who is dead?
('52', 298, 2, 16, 529736) And if so, does it help the body which has perished, or the immortal soul?
('52', 298, 2, 17, 529811) The body that used to eat is now ashes or is being eaten up by worms.
('52', 298, 2, 18, 529881) The soul neither eats nor drinks.
('52', 298, 2, 19, 529915) Why then should the mother or the wife restrict her food?
('52', 298, 2, 20, 529973) In other words, the mother or wife restricting her food has no effect on the body or the soul of the dead person.
('52', 298, 2, 21, 530087) If we desire the welfare of the departed soul or wish to keep his memory alive for ever, we shall not be able to fulfil our wish by fasting but shall fulfil both aims by retaining his virtues in ourselves.
('52', 298, 2, 22, 530293) We can also contribute to perpetuating his memory by making donations to worthy causes.
('52', 298, 2, 23, 530381) Does fasting or control over food then serve no purpose?
('52', 298, 2, 24, 530438) In this case at any rate they serve none.
('52', 298, 2, 25, 530480) They can be undertaken within certain limits, either for the purpose of self purification or for curing a disease.
('52', 298, 2, 26, 530595) We shall not discuss the second possibility.
('52', 298, 2, 27, 530640) Control of the palate, then, aims at self purification.
('52', 298, 2, 28, 530696) Restriction of food or fasting, therefore, has this limit.
('52', 298, 2, 29, 530755) Fasting is not the right way of atoning for a lie.
('52', 298, 2, 30, 530806) The right way of doing so is to take a vow always to speak the truth in future, to renounce whatever serves as a temptation to us to tell a lie.
('52', 298, 2, 31, 530951) If, however, a person cannot control his palate, the remedy is fasting or restriction of diet.
('52', 298, 2, 32, 531046) Anyone who has overcome all cravings of the palate eats only for keeping his body alive.
('52', 298, 2, 33, 531135) His diet is restricted to a few items and the quantity also is measured.
('52', 298, 2, 34, 531208) Such men and
('52', 298, 3, 35, 531221) 1 Vide “Letter to Hemprabha Das Gupta”, 2 6 1931
('52', 299, 0, 1, 531270) 300 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 299, 1, 2, 531312) women take food as medicine.
('52', 299, 1, 3, 531341) If they practise further self denial, they commit a sin because, if they do not eat, their bodies would become weak.
('52', 299, 1, 4, 531458) The body is an instrument of service.
('52', 299, 1, 5, 531496) Anyone who weakens that instrument is a thief.
('52', 299, 1, 6, 531543) Such persons number hardly a few among crores.
('52', 299, 1, 7, 531590) I have used this illustration only to explain my meaning.
('52', 299, 1, 8, 531648) We ordinary human beings daily indulge our palate.
('52', 299, 1, 9, 531699) It is, therefore, necessary that we should occasionally fast and restrict our diet.
('52', 299, 1, 10, 531783) But this should be done only to kill the cravings of the palate.
('52', 299, 1, 11, 531848) To do it because of someone’s death or for some similar reason is a form of self deception and may even be sinful.
('52', 299, 1, 12, 531963) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 7 6 1931
('52', 299, 2, 13, 531999) 411. A LETTER
('52', 299, 3, 14, 532013) BARDOLI, June 7, 1931 Sardar Garda met me at Swaraj Ashram, Bardoli, on April 25th in the company of Sir Cowasji Jehangir, Syt.
('52', 299, 3, 15, 532141) K. F. Nariman, Sjt.
('52', 299, 3, 16, 532161) Vimadalal, Rao Bahadur Bhim Bhai and another Parsi friend.
('52', 299, 3, 17, 532220) He was brought by Sir Cowasji Jehagir and other friends in connection with the forfeited land belonging to Bardoli peasants which he had purchased during the Civil Disobedience Movement.
('52', 299, 3, 18, 532407) He complained about the treatment he had received at the hands of the people.
('52', 299, 3, 19, 532485) I told him that whatever complaints he might make I would undertake to invetigate and give him satisfaction.
('52', 299, 3, 20, 532594) All the friends persuaded him to return the said land.
('52', 299, 3, 21, 532649) He insisted not only on the price he had paid for the land being returned to him, namely, Rs. 6000 in addition which he said he had spent on the land.
('52', 299, 3, 22, 532800) Sir Cowasji assured him that sum also would be forthcoming.
('52', 299, 3, 23, 532860) He then said that he would most probably decide to restore the land for the purchase price plus the said sum of Rs. 6000, but that he would have to consult his people and the give a final reply which he would do inside of two days.
('52', 299, 3, 24, 533092) In the course of the conversation Sardar Garda said that the land he had bought was fully worth four lakhs of rupees and that he would not have bought it but for the pressure that was brought to bear upon him on the part of the authorities.
('52', 299, 3, 25, 533333) This, of course, he said in confidence.
('52', 299, 3, 26, 533373) I asked him then whether I could announce to the people that most probably he would
('52', 300, 0, 1, 533457) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 301
('52', 300, 1, 2, 533499) agree to restore the land, and he said “certainly”.
('52', 300, 1, 3, 533551) Two days after, Sardar Vallabhbhai received a letter from Rao Bahadur Bhim Bhai saying that Sardar Garda had passed a note to him to the effect that he had decided to restore the land for the above sum.
('52', 300, 1, 4, 533754) The enclosed is a copy of the letter passed by Sardar Garda to Rao Bahadur Bhim Bhai.
('52', 300, 1, 5, 533840) The letter was also published in the papers and the agreement was duly announced to the people concerned.
('52', 300, 1, 6, 533946) On May 7th I received a letter from Sardar Garda as per copy to which I sent a reply hereto attached.
('52', 300, 1, 7, 534048) I also attach the further correspondence since passed between Sardar Garda and myself.

('52', 300, 6, 18, 534904) They mentioned also that personal assaults were added to the injury to property.

('52', 300, 6, 21, 535381) Suggestion has already been made that the Mukhiship should be divided into three parts, each part being held by a different person.

('52', 300, 6, 24, 535613) If he is an
('52', 300, 7, 25, 535625) 1 Village headman

('52', 301, 1, 2, 535685) undesirable person, in accordance with the terms of the Settlement and the admission made by the Commissioner, undesirable Mukhis should be removed.

('52', 301, 2, 10, 536487) 413. LETTER TO THOMAS B. LEE AS AT SABARMATI, June 7, 1931
('52', 301, 3, 11, 536546) DEAR FRIEND, I thank you for your letter.
('52', 301, 3, 12, 536588) As a matter of fact I have got ample Christian Science literature with me.
('52', 301, 3, 13, 536663) You will not mind my saying that somehow or other the message of Christian Science does not appeal to me.
('52', 301, 3, 14, 536769) I met so many Christian scientists in South Africa.
('52', 301, 3, 15, 536821) Their conversations also failed to convince me.
('52', 301, 3, 16, 536869) And why do you say that the discovery that there is really no life or sensation in the body is the most important discovery of any kind that has ever been made?
('52', 301, 3, 17, 537030) As a matter of fact the statement is not a complete proposition.
('52', 301, 3, 18, 537095) By the body is evidently meant body without life is without sensation and every Hindu child is taught that from childhood.
('52', 301, 3, 19, 537218) But I must not enter into a discussion.
('52', 301, 3, 20, 537258) I felt that your long letter was entitled to a reasoned reply from me.
('52', 301, 4, 21, 537329) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI THOMAS B. LEE, ESQ.

('52', 303, 7, 11, 539140) I am most closely watching your activity not in terms of the newspapers but its reaction upon the commual spirit.
('52', 303, 7, 12, 539254) Solution of the communal question may be beyond the powers of Conciliation Committees, but if they tend to promote peace it would be a very big step forward.
('52', 303, 7, 13, 539412) You are also interesting me in another activity of yours, bee keeping and honey making.
('52', 303, 7, 14, 539500) I would love to see the industry of bee keeping becoming universal in India.
('52', 303, 7, 15, 539577) The only question is whether it is possible to make bee keeping profitable.
('52', 303, 7, 16, 539653) I tried to make some experiments but I have failed hitherto.
('52', 303, 7, 17, 539714) You will deserve the gratitude of people if you can devise method whereby poor people can take to this industry.

('52', 304, 1, 2, 539961) 418. LETTER TO ESTHER MENON
('52', 304, 2, 3, 539989) AS AT SABARMATI, June 7, 1931 After having kept me waiting for many long months you have at last written to me.
('52', 304, 2, 4, 540101) What a bad things that Menon has not yet got his diploma.
('52', 304, 2, 5, 540159) I had a letter from a mutual friend saying that you were disheartened over this failure.
('52', 304, 2, 6, 540248) This is unworthy of you as I have known you.
('52', 304, 2, 7, 540293) No failure, no adversity should dishearten you who have a living faith in God and his goodness.
('52', 304, 2, 8, 540389) We do not know that every failure is a matter for sorrow nor do we know that every adversity is an infliction.
('52', 304, 2, 9, 540500) Do we not often find that prosperity and success mean the undoing of people whereas failure and adversity chasten them?
('52', 304, 2, 10, 540620) I do not know that I am going to London.
('52', 304, 2, 11, 540661) If I do, I will of course love to go to Denmark and if I went there I should not like to miss you.
('52', 304, 2, 12, 540760) But it is no speculating on a highly problematical thing.
('52', 304, 2, 13, 540818) I do hear from Maria, now and again.
('52', 304, 2, 14, 540855) After dictating this I came upon another letter which mentionns you more intimately.
('52', 304, 2, 15, 540940) This letter is from Dr. Henning Dalsgaard.
('52', 304, 2, 16, 540983) In that letter he says you are cheerful but he asks me concrete proposition.
('52', 304, 2, 17, 541060) Have you any such in view?
('52', 304, 2, 18, 541087) If you have, thing, you know also you can rely upon my doing it.

('52', 308, 1, 2, 544073) 426. LETTER TO KANTI PAREKH
('52', 308, 2, 3, 544101) Silence Day, June 8, 1931
('52', 308, 4, 4, 544127) Here is the reply to your letter.
('52', 308, 4, 5, 544161) The word ‘love’ has two meanings : one, ignorant attachment, and, two, non violence.
('52', 308, 4, 6, 544246) Love between man and woman mostly takes the form of ignorant attachment and, therefore, it is undesirable.
('52', 308, 4, 7, 544353) It cannot become all embracing love.
('52', 308, 4, 8, 544390) If a man marries many woman or a woman many men, the world would be destroyed.
('52', 308, 4, 9, 544469) Only that love which takes the form of non violence can become all embracing, and anybody who wishes to cultivate such love must renounce the other love, born of ignorant attachment, which a man and a woman feel for each other.
('52', 308, 4, 10, 544697) The wheel of worldly life is kept moving, and will be kept moving, by a love which is a mixture of the two kinds.
('52', 308, 4, 11, 544811) It helps human beings to satisfy their own needs and also to serve the race.
('52', 308, 4, 12, 544888) What I have written pertains to love in its purest form.
('52', 308, 4, 13, 544945) If we are clear in our minds about the ideal, it will be possible on its basis to formulate proper norms for practical life.
('52', 308, 4, 14, 545070) If we base the ideal on the prevailing practice, we would lower both the ideal and the practice.
('52', 308, 4, 15, 545167) If you do not follow anything in this, ask me again.
('52', 308, 4, 16, 545220) I am returning your letter herewith.
('52', 308, 4, 17, 545257) Blessings from BAPU
('52', 308, 5, 18, 545277) From a photostat of the Gujarati : G.N. 6269
('52', 309, 0, 1, 545322) 310 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('52', 312, 0, 1, 548826) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 313
('52', 312, 1, 2, 548868) 432. NOTES
('52', 312, 2, 3, 548879) WHO CAN BE CONGRESS OFFICE HOLDER?
('52', 312, 2, 4, 548914) A Sindhi correspondent asks :
('52', 312, 3, 5, 548944) 1. Whether a man dealing in foreign cigarettes and tobacco can be a president of the Congress Committee?
('52', 312, 4, 6, 549049) 2. Whether persons dealing in foreign cloth can be vice president and treasurer of the Congress Committee?
('52', 312, 5, 7, 549156) 3. Whether a person connected with foreign cloth dealers can be secretary of the Congress Committee?
('52', 312, 6, 8, 549257) These are bad questions.
('52', 312, 6, 9, 549282) If the correspondent had said whether such and such a person should be, I could have given my opinion for what it might be worth.
('52', 312, 6, 10, 549412) But when he asks whether a particular type of person can be officer it betrays ignorance of the democratic character of the constitution of the Congress.
('52', 312, 6, 11, 549566) Even a drunkard and a rake can become president of Congress Committee or a secretary if his constituents elect him to that office.
('52', 312, 6, 12, 549697) But one may assume that so long as the constituents are sober and pure, they will not elect a drunkard or a rake.
('52', 312, 6, 13, 549811) Similarly if they are believers in out and out swadeshi only, they will not elect anyone who deals in foreign cloth or such foreign goods as are now manufactured in India.
('52', 312, 6, 14, 549983) And so far as things injurious to the nation are concerned, as for instance intoxicating drinks and drugs, Congressmen will make no distinction between foreign and swadeshi goods.
('52', 312, 6, 15, 550163) All injurious things must be regarded as taboo whether they are foreign or home made.
('52', 312, 7, 16, 550249) COARSE MILL CLOTH AS KHADI
('52', 312, 8, 17, 550276) Complaints are being received from several quarters, Madras, Bengal and Bombay Presidencies and elsewhere that coarse mill cloth is being sold as khadi and that though since the understanding with the Congress, khadi labels are not used by mill owners, in their invoices and otherwise, coarse cloth is shown as khadi.
('52', 312, 8, 18, 550594) If the information is correct, it is clearly a breach of the agreement with the Congress.
('52', 312, 8, 19, 550684) Mills ought to be satisfied with the profits they are making by reason of the Congress campaign, but if they will greedily and unlawfully appropriate the name ‘khadi’ somehow or other and at some stage or other for their wares, they will be following the example of the miser who, in the attempt to get a cocoanut free of charge, lost his life.
('52', 313, 0, 1, 551029) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 313, 1, 2, 551071) SWARAJ BHAVAN HOSPITAL
('52', 313, 2, 3, 551094) Mohanlal Nehru writes : 1
('52', 313, 3, 4, 551120) This is apart from the collections in Nainital which will appear in this column in due course.
('52', 313, 3, 5, 551215) Young India, 11 6 1931
('52', 313, 4, 6, 551238) 433. MY FAITH
('52', 313, 5, 7, 551252) A Bangali correspondent who gives his name and address even for publication if necessary has written a long letter which I condense as follows : Much has been said about Bhagat Singh and his comrades, yet even now I find great difficulty in appreciating the wisdom of passing the resolution at the Karachi Congress.
('52', 313, 5, 8, 551568) I am afraid it will not be possible for me to explain to you properly the different peculiar and surreptitious ways in which your remarks about Bhagat Singh and the Karachi Resolution extolling him are being exploited here by some interested politicians to serve their own purpose and under mine your influence.
('52', 313, 5, 9, 551880) 1. They accuse you for the niggardly way in which the resolution had been worded by you.
('52', 313, 5, 10, 551969) These people are trying to impress upon the minds of the young men that you really had no sincere sympathy for those unfortunate men and that you gave your support to the resolution and expressed your admiration for Bhagat Singh and his comrades only being prevailed upon by the Navajuvanwallas, whose strong agitation you could not resist, and you wanted to placate Pandit Jawah arlal.
('52', 313, 5, 11, 552356) 2. They question your integrity and sincerity and try to belittle you (and your cause) by surreptitiously propagating an idea in Bengal that while you gave your active support to the resolution about Bhagat Singh at Karachi you severely criticized the late Deshbandhu Das for his responsibility in carrying out an exactly similar resolution at Faridpur Conference praising
('52', 313, 6, 12, 552729) 1 The letter, containing a list of donors, is not reproduced here.
('52', 313, 6, 13, 552796) For the appeal, vide “The Allahabad Congress Hospital an Appeal”, 14 5 1931
('52', 314, 0, 1, 552872) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 315
('52', 314, 1, 2, 552914) Gopinath Saha 1 who lost his life on the gallows under exactly similar circumstances; and in this they say you are not immune from provincial bias.
('52', 314, 1, 3, 553062) They are taking every opportunity to undermine your influence in Bengal by appealing to the sentiment of local patriotism.
('52', 314, 1, 4, 553185) They say that many Bengal youths sacrificed their lives even within this very year for the same cause for which Bhagat Singh and his comrades died.
('52', 314, 1, 5, 553333) Among those who thus died in Bengal there were Benoy Bose and his comrade, there were the Chittagong raiders—the twenty one lads, who died fighting bravely against the British troops on the Jalallabad Hills whose deeds were much more courageous and romantic than you would imagine, but how strange—you did not find romance there : not a word of sympathy passed from your lips!
('52', 314, 1, 6, 553710) The insidious appeal made to their sentiment of local patriotism easily estranges them from you and your path of non violence.
('52', 314, 1, 7, 553837) I have already expressed my doubts as to the propriety of my having drafted and sponsored the Bhagat Singh resolution not because it was wrong in principle but for the misinterpretation it has lent itself to.
('52', 314, 1, 8, 554046) But the reader must know that it was neither the fear of the Navajuvans nor my love for Pandit Jawaharlal that prompted me to initiate the resolution.
('52', 314, 1, 9, 554197) Not that I should be ashamed of yielding to Navajuvans or placating Jawaharlal.
('52', 314, 1, 10, 554277) I should be foolish if I did not yield to Navajuvans, if yielding advanced the interest of the country and involved no sacrifice of principle.
('52', 314, 1, 11, 554420) And I should go a very long way to please Jawaharlal and retain his affection which I have the privilege of posses sing in abundance.
('52', 314, 1, 12, 554554) But there was no prompting required in this case.
('52', 314, 1, 13, 554604) I had interested myself in the movement for the commutation of the death sentence on Bhagat Singh and his comra des.
('52', 314, 1, 14, 554721) I had put my whole being into the task.
('52', 314, 1, 15, 554761) I had therefore to study the life of the principal actor in the tragedy.
('52', 314, 1, 16, 554834) I had to come in contact with his devoted father and those who were attached to Bhagat Singh not for his deed but for his character.
('52', 314, 1, 17, 554967) I was thus drawn to the resolution in the natural course.
('52', 314, 1, 18, 555025) I am too sensitive not to be moved by circumstances demanding sympathy.
('52', 314, 1, 19, 555097) Therefore had I found myself impelled to interest myself in any of the Bengali youths and had fancied myself in possession of
('52', 314, 2, 20, 555223) 1 Vide “Notes”, sub title Rabbi May.

('52', 317, 2, 3, 559123) The Deshseva Mandal of Sind has published a little pamphlet on the economic condition of the Bhils of Sind.
('52', 317, 2, 4, 559231) It consists of two articles written by Sjt.
('52', 317, 2, 5, 559275) Jairamdas Doulatram after a careful study on the spot of the condition of the Bhils living in Tharparker district of Sind.
('52', 317, 2, 6, 559398) The tract is a desert.
('52', 317, 2, 7, 559421) “The profession of agriculture in the desert“, writes Sjt.
('52', 317, 2, 8, 559480) Jairamdas,“is nothing but a stupenduous struggle against nature.” “The average net yield of cultivation in that tract is not more than Rs. 5 per acre.
('52', 317, 2, 9, 559631) It is not every year that he (the cultivator) cultivates the whole area.” “With a sandy soil, low rainfall, locust pest, and cheaply priced crops, the khatedar 1 can rarely keep his head above water.” “I have come across all types of Bhils, those, very few ones, who are for the time being out of debt, those who are in permanent debt and live a semi starved life and lastly those who are living in hopeless pauperism.
('52', 317, 2, 10, 560050) I cannot do better than give to the reader a few hard facts about specific villages.” 2
('52', 317, 3, 11, 560138) These men should for years have revenue free land.
('52', 317, 3, 12, 560189) It is for people such as these that I pleaded for free salt and I know that at the end of our discussions, it became a matter of pleasure for Lord Irwin to make the concession regarding salt.
('52', 317, 3, 13, 560381) And I hope that the workers throughout the land will bring the message of free salt to the semi starved villagers and discover all the salt areas which though not good enough for mass production are good enough for village use.
('52', 317, 3, 14, 560609) It is to these people that the charkha brings hope and happiness.
('52', 317, 3, 15, 560675) Village economics is different from industrial economics.
('52', 317, 3, 16, 560733) Human economics is not the same as that of exploitation of mere dead matter.

('52', 318, 1, 2, 560939) 437. AGRARIAN SITUATION IN ASSAM
('52', 318, 2, 3, 560972) Assam is in the grip of dire economic distress.
('52', 318, 2, 4, 561020) From everywhere, from North Lakhimpur and Sibsagar, from Darrang and Nowgong, from Goal para and Kamrup, come the tales of misery and woe of the ryots for this scarcity.
('52', 318, 2, 5, 561190) Hundreds of people, generally immigrants from Mymensingh, .
('52', 318, 2, 6, 561250) have been flocking to the towns of Goalpara and Dhubri for begging, with nothing to cover their loins excepting half tattered pieces.
('52', 318, 3, 7, 561384) In Goalpara and Sibsagar, Nowgong and North Lakhimpur there has been repeated failure of crops owing to the annual visitation of floods for some years past.
('52', 318, 3, 8, 561541) An earthquake also came in as another visitation in July last.
('52', 318, 4, 9, 561604) Affected by this economic depression, from everywhere comes the cry for remission of land revenue.
('52', 318, 5, 10, 561703) It seems that the Government has not yet been able to shake off the Civil Disobedience complex from their minds.
('52', 318, 5, 11, 561816) They have taken their inability to pay land revenue to mean their unwillingness to do it and are seeking to test it till the last day of kist by all sorts of indirect pressure.
('52', 318, 5, 12, 561993) The foregoing report 1 has been received from the Assam Provincial Congress Committee.
('52', 318, 5, 13, 562080) If the report is accurate, and there is no reason to doubt its accuracy, it is a clear case for remission.

('52', 319, 1, 10, 563772) Religious neutrality means that the State will have no State religion nor a system of favouritism.
('52', 319, 1, 11, 563871) There will be no untouchability.

('52', 319, 1, 15, 564219) But he will not be able, as some do now, to punish untouchables for daring to walk on public streets or using wells.

('52', 319, 1, 17, 564485) The authority of the Vedas and the other Shastras will not be denied but their interpretation will not rest with individuals but will depend upon the courts of law in so far as these religious books will be used to regulate public conduct.
('52', 319, 1, 18, 564725) Conscientious scruples will be respected, but not at the expense of public morals or the rights of others.
('52', 319, 1, 19, 564832) Those who will have extraordinary scruples will have themselves to suffer inconvenience and pay for the luxury.
('52', 319, 1, 20, 564944) The law will not tolerate any arrogation of superiority by any person or class whether in the name of custom or religion.

('52', 320, 4, 11, 566126) June 11, 1931 I must first apologize to you for having called you at this early time.
('52', 320, 4, 12, 566212) The Hindustani Seva Dal stands for the service of India.
('52', 320, 4, 13, 566269) Till now whenever I heard the term ‘Servant of India’ it used to rouse great fear in my heart, because the rulers of India style themselves as ‘Servants of India’.
('52', 320, 4, 14, 566433) These so called‘Servants of India’ can never in reality be what they call themselves.They are the servants of the British Empire and it is an impossibility to serve the British Empire and at the same time serve India.
('52', 320, 4, 15, 566651) I can assure you, you can do no service to India if you try to follow the workings of these so called ‘Servants of India’.
('52', 320, 4, 16, 566774) You have to develop a desire for real service which these people totally lack.
('52', 320, 4, 17, 566853) If on acquiring power you begin to cruelly enforce your authority on the people how is it possible to serve the people?
('52', 320, 4, 18, 566973) It is because we lack this feeling of real service that a great deal of rivalry and dissatisfaction has spread among ourselves.
('52', 320, 4, 19, 567101) It has pained me very much to hear that out of a desire to attain high positions in the various Congress bodies people have been spending money, thus creating an atmosphere of unhealthy competition.
('52', 320, 4, 20, 567300) The real worker is he who carries on the work with a steady mind in spite of his being in the furthermost rank.
('52', 320, 4, 21, 567412) The perfection of real service does not solely depend on the magnitude of the task done but rests a

('52', 321, 1, 2, 567706) great deal on the humble spirit in which it is undertaken.Those misguided people to whom I have referred desire by force, it seems, to serve their country.

('52', 322, 6, 14, 570144) 442. INTERVIEW TO EUROPEAN DEPUTATION June 12, 1931
('52', 322, 7, 15, 570196) Gandhiji received a deputation of young Europeans, about 30 in number including four ladies.
('52', 322, 7, 16, 570289) Gandhiji, at the request of the deputation, explained the attitude of the Congress towards Englishmen and other Europeans in India.
('52', 322, 8, 17, 570421) Gandhiji said that the Congress attitude was not one of hostility to them, but of active friendship.
('52', 322, 8, 18, 570522) He recalled to them how the Congress was started by an Englishman, Mr. Hume, and was presided over by even members of Parliament.
('52', 322, 8, 19, 570652) He wanted them to study the object and history of the Congress, which never meant any harm to any community or interests.
('52', 322, 8, 20, 570774) If they sympathized with the Congress it was their duty to join it.
('52', 322, 8, 21, 570842) In India it was but natural that Indians should have full rights to rule as Englishmen had in their own country.
('52', 322, 8, 22, 570955) It was not reasonable for Englishmen to ask for safeguards and trading rights of a special character on which they were insisting.
('52', 322, 8, 23, 571086) Perpetuation of these privileges, which they had carved in their 150 years of rule in India, would amount to friendship on unequal terms.
('52', 322, 8, 24, 571224) The Congress was not merely not hostile to Englishmen, but welcome their association, assistance and co operation and their organizing capacity.
('52', 322, 8, 25, 571369) Co operation of such a kind did not mean co operation on unequal terms.
('52', 322, 8, 26, 571441) The deputation waited on Gandhiji for about 15 minutes.
