('52', 329, 6, 15, 580397) 454. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('52', 329, 7, 16, 580426) BORSAD, June 13, 1931
('52', 329, 8, 17, 580448) DEAR MR. EMERSON, You must have seen from the papers that Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan has been with me for some time.
('52', 329, 8, 18, 580562) During the few moments that I could spare for him from day to day, I carried on my conversations with him and he has left on me the impression that he is a truthful and out and out believer in non violence.
('52', 329, 8, 19, 580769) He has no connection with the Amanullah movement.
('52', 329, 8, 20, 580819) His work is solely concentrated upon the Khudai Khidmatgar movement.
('52', 329, 8, 21, 580888) This movement consists in enlisting men for service.
('52', 329, 8, 22, 580941) The following pledge is administered to them: “I shall be truthful, I shall be chaste, I shall be non violent and not quarrel with my neighbours.
('52', 329, 8, 23, 581087) I shall not covet my neighbours’ pro perty.
('52', 329, 8, 24, 581131) I shall be prepared to suffer even unto death for the freedom of the country.” Those who take the pledge and enlist themselves as Khudai Khidmatgars are expected to attend a weekly roll call in their respective villages.
('52', 329, 8, 25, 581352) He is most emphatic in his declar ation that there has been on the part of himself and his followers no breach of the Settlement and he says that he has everywhere preached to the people the necessity for carrying out its terms in so far as they are applicable
('52', 330, 0, 1, 581613) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 331
('52', 330, 1, 2, 581655) to the people.
('52', 330, 1, 3, 581670) But he says there are several breaches of the Settlement on the part of the officials and he relates the following : (a) Many civil disobedience prisoners are not yet discharged in the Frontier Province including the Agency areas.
('52', 330, 1, 4, 581901) (b) He says that the people are being molested on the slightest pretext.
('52', 330, 1, 5, 581974) The soldiers as they pass the villagers’ houses cry “Islam Murdabad”, “Gandhi Murdabad”, “Ghaffar Khan Murdabad”, and he adds that he has prohibited among his followers all objectionable cries.
('52', 330, 1, 6, 582168) Khan Saheb admits that he did not visit the Commissioner and he says he refrained because he saw no change in the attitude of local officials and if he went, he was afraid of his being mis represented.
('52', 330, 1, 7, 582370) He is quite prepared to see you or His Excellency the Viceroy provided I accompany him.
('52', 330, 1, 8, 582458) I do feel that you should make his acquaintance, and if you think it worth while I shall gladly visit Simla solely for the purpose of introducing him to you.
('52', 330, 1, 9, 582616) I think that the Settlement presumes mutual trust and it will therefore perhaps be wise on the part of the Government to know Khan Saheb personally and then test his assurances.
('52', 330, 1, 10, 582794) Pending reply to this letter I have detained Khan Saheb.
('52', 330, 1, 11, 582851) As he has been long enough with me and as I do not want to detain him longer than is absolutely necessary, I would ask you please to send me a telegraphic reply.
('52', 330, 1, 12, 583013) I should add that Khan Saheb is most insistent on my visiting the Frontier Province and seeing things for myself, making the acquaintance of the numerous Khudai Khidmatgars and studying his activity.
('52', 330, 1, 13, 583213) I do feel that there should be no objection now to my visiting the Frontier Province.
('52', 330, 2, 14, 583299) Yours sincerely, H. W. EMERSON, ESQ.
('52', 330, 3, 15, 583336) A.I.C.C. File No.
('52', 330, 3, 16, 583354) 16 B, 1931. Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('52', 330, 4, 17, 583411) 1 Emerson replied on July 6 that such a “visit would be likely to cause considerable excitement and to add to the difficulties of the local administration .
('52', 330, 4, 18, 583568) .” Vide also footnote to “Letter to H. W. Emerson”, 17 6 1931.

('52', 335, 2, 9, 588541) Mr. Khambhatta of Hornby Road knows one and he has benefited by his treatment.
('52', 335, 2, 10, 588620) His full address is Bairam Khambhatta, 275 Hornby Road, Fort Bombay.
('52', 335, 2, 11, 588689) It is difficult to say how many hours’ sleep a particular individual requires, but I can safely say for you that you should take as much sleep as you comfortably can.

('52', 335, 2, 15, 589024) You may divide it, if you like, in two or three periods.

('52', 336, 1, 2, 589509) 463. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('52', 336, 2, 3, 589538) BORSAD, June 14, 1931
('52', 336, 3, 4, 589560) DEAR MR. EMERSON, Your letter enclosing an unsigned opinion of the Legislative Department on the meaning of the word “return” in the Settlement came upon me as a bomb shell.
('52', 336, 3, 5, 589734) 1 I was wholly unprepared for such an opinion.
('52', 336, 3, 6, 589781) I had flattered myself with the belief that my knowledge of law had not become absolutely rusty.
('52', 336, 3, 7, 589878) But the opinion of your legal department shook what little confidence I had yet in my legal knowledge.
('52', 336, 3, 8, 589981) I therefore hastened to refer the matter to the best counsel available in Bombay at the present moment.
('52', 336, 3, 9, 590085) I am sending you a copy of their opinion.
('52', 336, 3, 10, 590127) 2 The first two signatories are ex Advocates General of Bombay and they are both today, as is also the third, distinguished practising lawyers.
('52', 336, 3, 11, 590271) For the moment therefore my confidence is restored, but that can be of no avail to you.
('52', 336, 3, 12, 590359) I can quite understand your not accepting the opinion of Bombay lawyers however eminent they may be, in the teeth of opinion from your legal department however contrary to common sense.
('52', 336, 3, 13, 590545) I, therefore, suggest what I have suggested of the Government of Bombay.
('52', 336, 3, 14, 590618) As the matter involved is one of principle for the Management of the Navajivan Press, I would repeat the suggestion I have made to the Government of Bombay that the Chief Justice of Bombay should be appointed sole arbitrator in the matter.
('52', 336, 3, 15, 590858) The Managing Board is naturally anxious to end this controversy and also to avoid a continuing loss that the deprivation of the press causes to them.
('52', 336, 3, 16, 591008) I hope therefore that the matter will be finished one way or the other without delay.
('52', 336, 3, 17, 591094) This impasse brings to me a matter of general importance.
('52', 336, 3, 18, 591152) I am having, as I imagine, more trouble than I have told you from the Bombay Government in connection with the matters arising out of the Settlement.
('52', 336, 3, 19, 591302) And there is trouble growing in the Madras Presidency over liquor picketing.
('52', 336, 3, 20, 591379) Here is an extract from Syt.
('52', 336, 3, 21, 591408) Rajagopalachari whose instructions on this very point you had seen and which you so admired that you asked me to congratulate him :
('52', 336, 4, 22, 591540) 1 The opinion was that the phrase “will be returned” would mean “possession will be restored” and that the Gandhi Irwin Pact was silent on the question of the place of delivery.

('52', 337, 0, 1, 591746) 338 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 337, 1, 2, 591788) I had hitherto refrained from worrying you.
('52', 337, 1, 3, 591832) The Government here are
('52', 337, 2, 4, 591856) beginning to feel that peaceful picketing is not so harmless as they had
('52', 337, 3, 5, 591929) imagined.
('52', 337, 3, 6, 591939) They have discovered that it does stop drinking most effectively
('52', 337, 4, 7, 592004) and as a result the revenue is threatened.
('52', 337, 4, 8, 592047) They may hold renters to their
('52', 337, 5, 9, 592078) contracts this year, but what about the next auction?
('52', 337, 5, 10, 592132) They see that without
('52', 337, 6, 11, 592154) any physical obstruction or coercion of any kind, picketing does keep people
('52', 337, 7, 12, 592231) away from the shops.
('52', 337, 8, 13, 592252) The renters too espected that like last year the congress activities would soon be interfered with by the police and so they did not themselves do anything at first to interfere with the volunteers.
('52', 337, 8, 14, 592451) But now they realize that the Truce has put an end to the old order to things.
('52', 337, 8, 15, 592530) They are consequently in a fright.
('52', 337, 8, 16, 592565) They have begun to make strong representations to Government demanding either police interference or writing off of dues.
('52', 337, 8, 17, 592687) Both Government officials and renters are thus opening their eyes to the reality of the moral power of picketing and the implications of the Truce.
('52', 337, 8, 18, 592835) Both Government officials and renters have, therefore, it seems, resolved on new tactics.
('52', 337, 8, 19, 592925) There is almost by concerted action a number of cases cropping up everywhere of rowdyism to intimidate volunteers.
('52', 337, 8, 20, 593040) Besides rowdyism, which might be expected, the renters whether instigated or encouraged by officials or not, I cannot yet say, are bringing up false charges through private complaints in order to get fines and imprisonments imposed on the workers and sympathizers and worry and tire out the Congress organizations.
('52', 337, 8, 21, 593355) And magistrates, too, imagine that they should support the liquor shop men.
('52', 337, 8, 22, 593431) Further, even where they know the cases are false, they dare not expose themselves to the suspicion that they favour the Congress and do not support the revenue.
('52', 337, 9, 23, 593593) Local police authorities have begun to harass and interfere with the picketing.
('52', 337, 9, 24, 593673) Finding that there is no sort of coercion or disturbance of the peace, and that they cannot legitimately object to the picketing, they are trying other ways.
('52', 337, 9, 25, 593831) They are making demonstrations of police force, pushing the volunteers away to impossible distances from the shops and from each other and demanding the observance of conditions that reduce picketing to an ineffectual farce.
('52', 337, 9, 26, 594056) Local police authorities are permitted to terrorize town and village folk and proclaim that any assistance or harbouring of Congress volunteers would amount to abetment of offenders.
('52', 337, 9, 27, 594239) In fact, the 1930 atmosphere is being sought to be brought about.
('52', 337, 10, 28, 594305) I have conscientiously tried to put the best construction on all that Government officials are doing.
('52', 337, 10, 29, 594407) But I am afraid I must confess failure.
('52', 337, 10, 30, 594447) If you have time, please go through the enclosures.
('52', 338, 0, 1, 594499) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 339
('52', 338, 1, 2, 594541) You might be unable to interfere with the working or not working of the Settlement by local governments.
('52', 338, 1, 3, 594646) Or your interfer ence may not go far enough according to my view of the Settlement.
('52', 338, 1, 4, 594730) Time has therefore perhaps arrived for the appointment of a perm anent Board of Arbitration to decide question of interpretation of the Settlement and as to the full carrying out of the terms by the one party or the other.
('52', 338, 1, 5, 594953) I would therefore like you to consider this suggestion.
('52', 338, 2, 6, 595009) Yours sincerely, Encl.

('52', 339, 2, 3, 595905) BORSAD, June 14, 1931
('52', 339, 3, 4, 595927) Interviewed by a representative of the Associated Press, Mahatma Gandhi said
('52', 339, 4, 5, 596004) he aarrived at Borsad principally to console the people of Ras who were perturbed
('52', 339, 5, 6, 596086) over the continuous destruction of their hedges and stray assaults committed by
('52', 339, 6, 7, 596166) Dharalas.
('52', 339, 6, 8, 596176) They suspected that Dharalas had been emboldened by the continuance as
('52', 339, 7, 9, 596247) the village headman of a Dharala who is an exconvict.
('52', 339, 7, 10, 596301) Gandhiji had already asked for
('52', 339, 8, 11, 596332) the cancellation of his appointment on two grounds in terms of the Delhi Settlement :
('52', 339, 9, 12, 596418) one was that he was undesirable and the other was that his appointment was not
('52', 339, 10, 13, 596497) permanent in the terms of the Delhi Settlement.
('52', 339, 10, 14, 596545) He had also asked for protection of
('52', 339, 11, 15, 596581) the non Dharala population of Ras village.
('52', 339, 11, 16, 596624) Both matters were engaging the attention
('52', 339, 12, 17, 596665) of the Collector of Kaira District.
('52', 339, 12, 18, 596701) There were other matters, too, which required his
('52', 339, 13, 19, 596751) personal attention.
('52', 339, 13, 20, 596771) He thought he need not go into these matters at present.
('52', 339, 14, 21, 596828) how long he would stay at Borsad, Gandhiji said as soon as he had finished his work
('52', 339, 15, 22, 596912) he had instructions from Sardar Vallabhbhai to go to Bardoli which he would do.
('52', 339, 16, 23, 596992) In reply to a question whether it was true, as stated by his son Mr. Devdas at
('52', 339, 17, 24, 597071) last night’s public meeting, that he intended shortly to visit the Frontier Province,
('52', 339, 18, 25, 597157) Gandhiji said it was perfectly true that Abdul Ghaffar Khan was pressing him to visit
('52', 339, 19, 26, 597243) that province.
('52', 339, 19, 27, 597258) He was equally anxious to go there and see for himself how far the
('52', 339, 20, 28, 597325) spirit of non violence had prevailed among tribes inhabiting that province, but
('52', 339, 21, 29, 597405) whilst the Truce lasted he did not want to do anything, as far as possible, that might
('52', 339, 22, 30, 597492) embarrass Government.
('52', 339, 22, 31, 597514) He was therefore in correspondence with Government on the
('52', 339, 23, 32, 597572) matter.
('52', 339, 23, 33, 597580) Asked how long Abdul Ghaffar Khan would stay with him, Gandhiji said he
('52', 339, 24, 34, 597652) would stay pending the results of the correspondence between him and Government.

('52', 343, 4, 16, 601859) 471. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS BORSAD, June 15, 1931
('52', 343, 5, 17, 601916) Interviewed by a representative of the Associated Press regarding the controversy in respect of his services in the Boer War, Mahatma Gandhi said : The Indian Ambulance Corps numbering over 1,100 reached Chieveley camp near Colenso after dusk just after the battle in which Lieutenant Roberts was killed.
('52', 343, 5, 18, 602221) I received orders from Col.
('52', 343, 5, 19, 602249) Gallwey that the deceased Lieutenant’s body had to be immediately removed.
('52', 343, 5, 20, 602324) We had then hardly pitched the tents.
('52', 343, 5, 21, 602362) I sent seven men, not “coolies”, but educated men, who returned late at night and I received special thanks from Col.
('52', 343, 5, 22, 602480) Gallwey for the prompt attention and was next day invited through Dr. Booth to meet him in his tent.
('52', 343, 5, 23, 602581) It is quite true that on this occasion there was no question of firing line, hostilities having been suspended for the collection of the wounded.
('52', 343, 5, 24, 602727) It is also true that despite our desire to work under fire, we were told that we would not be allowed to do so but after the reversea at Spion Kop, the situation became grave.
('52', 343, 6, 25, 602903) 1 Shankarlal’s daughter
('52', 344, 0, 1, 602927) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 345
('52', 344, 1, 2, 602969) General Buller came to my tent and said we would enter the firing zone in order to remove nearly 60 wounded from the foot of Spion Kop.
('52', 344, 1, 3, 603105) My companions and I were delighted to have this privi lege and led by Major Bapty, we crossed the pontoon, entered firing zone and removed the wounded including General Woodgate, Major Scott Moncrief and other officers and carried them on stretchers 25 miles.
('52', 344, 1, 4, 603365) We were again within the firing zone at Vaal Kantz soon after Kop.
('52', 344, 1, 5, 603432) For these and general services I was mentioned in General Buller’s dispatch and with over 20 leaders was recipient of a War Medal.

('52', 346, 2, 9, 606773) 475. LETTER TO ANAND T. HINGORANI BORSAD, June 17, 1931
('52', 346, 3, 10, 606829) MY DEAR ANAND, I hear all about you regularly through Mirabehn and occasionally through Jairamdas.
('52', 346, 3, 11, 606928) I know that you are refraining from writing to me purely out of pity for me.
('52', 346, 3, 12, 607005) I should not consider father’s letter disappointing.
('52', 346, 3, 13, 607058) I think that he took up the correct position.
('52', 346, 3, 14, 607104) But Jairamdas tells me that later he modified his view.
('52', 346, 3, 15, 607160) I think that it is a sound rule for people who are well to do not to go to their friends living in public institutions except when they are ready to make a grant to those institutions at least equal to what their visit to such institutions might have cost them.

('52', 350, 1, 2, 611693) 481. SUBSTANCE NOT SHADOW
('52', 350, 2, 3, 611719) The public are entitled to know why after having made repeated declarations to the contrary the Working Committee had passed the resolution 1 requiring me (other conditions being favourable) to attend the Round Table Conference, if thereto required, for the presentation of the Congress position.
('52', 350, 2, 4, 612016) Ordinarily a member of the Working Committee could not tell the public of discussions behind its resolutions, their defeated amend ments or counter resolutions.
('52', 350, 2, 5, 612177) But in the present case the Working Committee has made an exception and authorized me to take the public into confidence in order that I might clear my position and also explain that of the Working Committee.
('52', 350, 2, 6, 612386) It was my essentially democratic nature which, in spite of my very strong objection, impelled me to submit to the resolution.
('52', 350, 2, 7, 612512) One may not make a principle of every objection and, if not carried, block the way by threatening to retire from an institution or by refusing submission to the opinion of the majority.
('52', 350, 2, 8, 612698) I therefore fought the Working Committee, reminded it of my repeated public and private declarations and moved informally a resolution myself which I thought was far more consistent and desirable in the national interest.
('52', 350, 2, 9, 612920) But I could not carry with me the majority who thought that not to attend the Conference by reason of the failure of a communal settlement would be to play into the hands of the enemy and expose the Committee to unnecessary misrepresentation.
('52', 350, 2, 10, 613163) Though there is much to be said for the majority view, I regard mine to be safer and more truly in consonance with the Lahore resolution on the communal question.
('52', 350, 2, 11, 613326) 2 There was, in my opinion, sound reasoning behind my declaration that I should not attend the Round Table Conference if there was no agreed settlement of the communal question.
('52', 350, 2, 12, 613504) Absence of it would mean
('52', 350, 3, 13, 613529) 1 On June 9. It read: “The Working Committee hope that the efforts that are now being made to secure honourable and satisfactory settlement of the communal problem will meet with success.
('52', 350, 3, 14, 613717) The Committee is of opinion that, even should these efforts unfortunately fail, in order to avoid any possibility of the Congress attitude being misunderstood in any shape or form, other conditions being favourable, Mahatma Gandhi should represent the Congress at the R.T.C., if thereto required, for the presentation of the Congress position.” 2 Vide “Speech at subjects Committee, A.I.C.C. III”, 1 1 1930
('52', 351, 0, 1, 614124) 352 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 351, 1, 2, 614166) absence of unity and absence of unity would deprive the national demand of the strength required to secure its acceptance.
('52', 351, 1, 3, 614289) My proposition therefore before the Working Committee was that agreed settlement failing, the Congress should give up the hope of winning a swaraj constitution by the way of the present Round Table Conference and should wait till all the communities were satisfied to adopt a purely national solution.
('52', 351, 1, 4, 614591) The Congress could meanwhile further consolidate its position and work with greater concentration for the masses including all the communities and thus make the toilers of all the other communities regard the Congress as theirs as the Hindus do.
('52', 351, 1, 5, 614837) This does not mean giving up the struggle for freedom.
('52', 351, 1, 6, 614892) It all depends upon what we mean by and want through purna swaraj.
('52', 351, 1, 7, 614959) If we mean an awakening among the masses, a knowledge among them of their true interest and ability to serve that interest against the whole world and if through purna swaraj we want harmony, freedom from aggression from within or without and a progressive improvement in the economic condition of the masses, we can gain our end without political power and by directly acting upon the powers that be.
('52', 351, 1, 8, 615361) One form of direct action is adult suffrage.
('52', 351, 1, 9, 615406) The second and more potent form is satyagraha.
('52', 351, 1, 10, 615453) It can easily be shown that whatever is needful and can be gained by political power can perhaps be more quickly and more certainly gained by satyagraha.
('52', 351, 1, 11, 615607) If such is the case and if, in spite of all, [the] attempt to secure an honourable settlement of the communal question fails it is obvious that we should give up the attempt to secure a swaraj constitution at the present moment.
('52', 351, 1, 12, 615836) It is better and quicker to wait till the Congress has become equally popular with the other communities than to attempt to force swaraj through highly artificial surroundings.
('52', 351, 1, 13, 616013) If the Congress means what it says, it cannot be long gaining the adherence of all the other communities.
('52', 351, 1, 14, 616119) Meanwhile the Congress must fulfil its mission of representing the starving millions by fighting for their relief, if it cannot do so by gaining power then by gaining that relief through the government existing at the moment.
('52', 351, 1, 15, 616345) Whilst discussing this probability with English friends, I was reminded that this position was hardly fair, not to take the power to make the reforms and to force the hands of those who cannot carry on the administration if they grant the reforms, in their opinion only so called.
('52', 351, 1, 16, 616626) I pointed out the fallacy underlying the rebuke.
('52', 351, 1, 17, 616675) The Congress is ever ready to take the power
('52', 352, 0, 1, 616720) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 353
('52', 352, 1, 2, 616762) if it is given to it but the Congress is too weak to seize power from unwilling hands in the artificial surroundings of the Round Table Conference and that in the absence of real unity between the chief actors, the communities.
('52', 352, 1, 3, 616990) The Congress wants the substance not the shadow.
('52', 352, 1, 4, 617039) It can there fore wait for the shadow of power, it cannot wait for the substance of freedom which the dumb millions so badly need and can understand.
('52', 352, 1, 5, 617189) I have placed before the public the main part of the argument I placed before the Working Committee.
('52', 352, 1, 6, 617290) It failed to convince its majority.
('52', 352, 1, 7, 617326) It may fail therefore to convince too the majority of the public.
('52', 352, 1, 8, 617392) Nevertheless my position will probably be the same as now if and when the Conference fails to meet the Congress position.
('52', 352, 1, 9, 617514) But having accepted the resolution of the Working Com mittee, I shall faithfully carry it out and work at the Conference with all possible zeal, if I am destined to attend it.
('52', 352, 1, 10, 617690) I should not reject real power if it is real.
('52', 352, 1, 11, 617736) I should put my whole soul into working for it.
('52', 352, 1, 12, 617784) But I have wisdom and patience enough to wait for it if necessary and know that such waiting may be a process of hastening.

('52', 354, 1, 2, 620583) 484. HINDI IN THE SOUTH
('52', 354, 2, 3, 620607) It was a good sign that at the same time as the Tamil Nadu Conference a Hindi Prachar Conference too was held.
('52', 354, 2, 4, 620718) The people of the Southern Presidency are under promise to send for the next year Congress delegates who would speak and understand Hindi.
('52', 354, 2, 5, 620857) If we were not living in artificial conditions, the people living in the South will not consider the learning of Hindi as a strain on them, much less a superfluity.
('52', 354, 2, 6, 621022) It is surely more necessary for them to learn Hindi than for the Hindi speaking population to learn the Southern languages.
('52', 354, 2, 7, 621146) There are two speaking and understanding Hindi against one speaking the Southern languages in all India.
('52', 354, 2, 8, 621251) There must be for all India a common language of inter provincial contact in addition to, not in the place of, the provincial language or languages.
('52', 354, 2, 9, 621400) It can only be Hindi Hindustani.
('52', 354, 2, 10, 621433) Some who altogether dismiss the masses from their minds would regard English not merely as an alternative but the only possible medium.
('52', 354, 2, 11, 621569) This proposition would be unthinkable but for the hypnotic influence of foreign domination.
('52', 354, 2, 12, 621661) For the masses of the South who must take an ever growing part in national affairs, what can be easier—learning Hindi which has many words in common with their languages and which at once gives them access practically to the whole of the North or learn English a wholly foreign tongue spoken only by a select few?
('52', 354, 2, 13, 621975) The choice really depends upon one’s concep tion of swaraj.
('52', 354, 2, 14, 622035) If it is to be of and for only the English knowing Indians, English is undoubtedly the common medium.
('52', 354, 2, 15, 622137) If it is to be for and of the starving millions, of the illiterate millions, of the illiterate women, of the suppressed untouchables, Hindi is the only possible common language.
('52', 354, 2, 16, 622315) Those who think like me will therefore welcome the report of the great progress made by Hindi during the past twelve years of the existence of organized propaganda.

('52', 363, 5, 15, 635436) 498. LETTER TO C. F. ANDREWS
('52', 363, 6, 16, 635465) Private AS AT SABARMATI, June 19, 1931
('52', 363, 7, 17, 635504) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your two letters, both of them quite like you.
('52', 363, 7, 18, 635575) Here is my answer to the moral questions you have placed.
('52', 363, 7, 19, 635633) It is perfectly true that I would have prohibition of foreign cloth by one blow if I could manage it and would not feel that there was the slightest trace of violence in it.
('52', 363, 7, 20, 635807) At this conclusion I arrived in 1889 and ‘90 when I was studying in London and keenly following the controversy between
('52', 363, 8, 21, 635927) 1 Sub Divisional Officer for the Charsadda sub division of Peshawar District in 1930; he wrote to Gandhiji on June 14, 1931 describing Abdul Ghaffar Khan’s speeches as “inflammatory”.
('52', 364, 0, 1, 636111) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 365
('52', 364, 1, 2, 636153) total prohibitionists and temperance reformers.
('52', 364, 1, 3, 636201) The former were led by Sir Wilfred Lawson who contended that all public houses could be closed without any compensation being paid to the keepers.
('52', 364, 1, 4, 636348) The temperance party which was really the party financed by the public house keepers put up a strong and successful fight for compensation and graduation.
('52', 364, 1, 5, 636503) If a man is making a living out of wrongdoing he gains no prescriptive right and therefore is entitled to no compen sation or consideration when his business is stopped whether by the ‘State or by his customers refusing to deal with him.
('52', 364, 1, 6, 636741) It is irrelevant to consider what would happen to the many labourers who might be engaged unconsciously in helping the wrongdoer.
('52', 364, 1, 7, 636871) The assumption at the back of this argument is that wrong must be righted at any cost and that the harm that may temporarily seem to result to the wrongdoer and his dependents is only apparent and that in the end he and they are all the better for it.
('52', 364, 1, 8, 637123) If such was not the case, many a reform would become impossible.
('52', 364, 1, 9, 637188) Of course it is open to you to say that you will not put foreign cloth trade on a level with liquor or opium trade.
('52', 364, 1, 10, 637304) But this is a matter of opinion.
('52', 364, 1, 11, 637337) If I was bolstering up the Bombay mills in any shape or form it would undoubtedly be violence.
('52', 364, 1, 12, 637432) But my conscience is quite clear on that point.
('52', 364, 1, 13, 637480) I am not only not bolstering up the Indian mills but I am fighting them in many matters.
('52', 364, 1, 14, 637569) My intervention has resulted in steady improvement of the conditions of labour.
('52', 364, 1, 15, 637649) If these mills interfered with khaddar I should desire their boycott just as strongly as that of foreign mills.
('52', 364, 1, 16, 637761) The remedy for unemployment in England is not thoughtless generosity of India but a complete realization by England of the awfulness of exploitation of people, violently brought under subjec tion by her, and consequent radical changes in her conception of the standard of life and a return to simplicity.
('52', 364, 1, 17, 638066) Has generosity, in respect of a man more fortunate than himself, any meaning for the man who is living in a state of chronic starvation?
('52', 364, 1, 18, 638203) The South African analogy you have quoted is improper.
('52', 364, 1, 19, 638258) What you regard as generous action was really necessary action in terms of non violence.
('52', 364, 1, 20, 638347) In order to show that my fight was not intended to embarrass the Government or to seize power I was bound in pursuance of non violence to suspend the struggle 1 in order to show
('52', 364, 2, 21, 638525) 1 In 1914, during the European railway workers’ strike; vide “Interview to “Pretoria News” “, 9 1 1914
('52', 365, 0, 1, 638628) 366 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 365, 1, 2, 638670) that I had no sympathy with the Europeans who were bent on embarrassing the Government to the point of making it so powerless as to enable them to seize the reins themselves.
('52', 365, 1, 3, 638845) Occasions here for what you would call generosity occurred at the time of the Delhi Settlement 1 and are occurring whilst the Settlement is being worked and it would delight your heart if you knew how every such occasion has been fully availed of.
('52', 365, 1, 4, 639093) And even with reference to the present unemployment in England, many a generous gesture is possible but none is possible if it means continuance of injury to India or fresh injury.
('52', 365, 1, 5, 639274) If England ceased to think imperially, if India came to her own and instead of being a dependency of England became a real partner or ally, England could get preferential treatment in hundreds of things, which an awakened India on her road to prosperity would require from the West.
('52', 365, 1, 6, 639557) If therefore Lancashire cannot keep all its labour going through spinning and weaving mills working for other markets, it should find out some other use for it.
('52', 365, 1, 7, 639718) Lastly, remember that even if there was no boycott of foreign cloth and open competition Japan would outdistance Lancashire as it is already doing.
('52', 365, 1, 8, 639866) I have your cable.
('52', 365, 1, 9, 639885) Of course if I came to London my movement will be in your hands and I would gladly go to Lancashire as early as you would want me to.
('52', 365, 1, 10, 640019) I quite agree with you that your name should remain in the background as much as possible.
('52', 365, 1, 11, 640110) What undignified controversy over my part in the Boer War.
('52', 365, 1, 12, 640169) I had to give the facts to Reuter & The Statesman 2. Love.
('52', 365, 1, 13, 640228) MOHAN From a photostat: G.N. 969

('52', 370, 1, 2, 646064) 505. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('52', 370, 2, 3, 646093) BORSAD, June 20, 1931
('52', 370, 3, 4, 646115) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I have your letter of 16th June enclosing extract from an account received from the Madras Government regarding picketing.
('52', 370, 3, 5, 646256) It does make bad reading if the report is true.
('52', 370, 3, 6, 646304) But what I am receiving almost daily from Madras from workers who are thoroughly reliable eye witnesses makes me distrust the reports that you are receiving.
('52', 370, 3, 7, 646462) But I know that this takes us no further.
('52', 370, 3, 8, 646504) So far as the Congress is concerned I want it to implement the Settlement to the fullest extent.
('52', 370, 3, 9, 646601) I therefore make an offer.
('52', 370, 3, 10, 646628) Will you advise local governments to appoint a Board of Enquiry consisting of a nominee on their behalf and a nominee on behalf of the Congress to conduct a summary enquiry into the allegations on either side, and wherever it is found that the rule of peaceful picketing has been at all violated picketing would be entirely suspended, the Government undertaking on its part to stop prosecutions wherever it is found that they have been undertaken in spite of peaceful picketing.
('52', 370, 3, 11, 647107) And if my suggestion does not commend itself to you, you will perhaps suggest something better and more acceptable.
('52', 370, 3, 12, 647223) Meanwhile I am enquiring into the specific charge mentioned in your letter.
('52', 370, 4, 13, 647299) Yours sincerely,
('52', 370, 5, 14, 647316) M. K. GANDHI
('52', 370, 6, 15, 647329) From a photostat: C.W. 9369. Courtesy: India Office Library
('52', 370, 7, 16, 647389) 1 For the addressee’s reply, vide “Letter from H. W. Emerson”, 4 7 1931

('52', 373, 9, 11, 650376) You must have forgotten Gujarati now.

('52', 373, 9, 13, 650493) I have no interest in examinations at all.

('52', 373, 9, 15, 650604) A certificate from the place of study should be sufficient.
('52', 373, 9, 16, 650664) The best certificate is one’s own.
('52', 373, 9, 17, 650699) What is the point of my having a certificate for proficiency in arithmetic if I cannot do addition and substraction?
('52', 373, 9, 18, 650816) If I do not know who Ashoka was and what he did, what is the use of my having a similar certificate in history?

('52', 374, 8, 19, 651945) It is good that khadi is being hawked.
('52', 374, 8, 20, 651984) Here is my message: “If swaraj means food for the poor, can any aspirant for swaraj, man or woman, use any cloth other than khadi?

('52', 376, 0, 1, 653921) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 377
('52', 376, 1, 2, 653963) 515. MY NOTES
('52', 376, 2, 3, 653977) NUDITY AND SOCIETY
('52', 376, 3, 4, 653996) An article on this subject has appeared in Jain Mitra.
('52', 376, 3, 5, 654051) Its author, Jain Nyaya Tirtha Paramesthidas, has asked me to reply to the article; I wished to express my view in this issue, but in spite of best effort I could not find the necessary time.
('52', 376, 3, 6, 654242) I hope to reply to it at the earliest opportunity.
('52', 376, 3, 7, 654293) 1 As the problem is not of immediate importance, I have had naturally to give priority to other more urgent matters.
('52', 376, 3, 8, 654410) STUDENTS 2
('52', 376, 4, 9, 654421) A student writes: 3
('52', 376, 5, 10, 654441) I hear that such undertakings are demanded in other provinces also.
('52', 376, 5, 11, 654509) I will not discuss here the question whether this involves a violation of the Settlement but this raises another question which requires discussion.
('52', 376, 5, 12, 654658) Why should parents give such an undertaking; and if they do, what would be its value?
('52', 376, 5, 13, 654744) It is likely that the authorities will act wrongly in many things which lie outside the terms of the Settlement.
('52', 376, 5, 14, 654857) When that happens, one’s duty lies not in acquiescing in such action or co operating with the authorities but in not co opera ting with them.
('52', 376, 5, 15, 654999) No one should interpret the Agreement to mean that the people should now give up resistance to authority and sit back with folded hands.
('52', 376, 5, 16, 655136) An agreement may clarify certain things, but may not clarify some others.
('52', 376, 5, 17, 655210) The people should certainly not sacrifice their self respect in matters not so clarified.
('52', 376, 5, 18, 655300) Hence I would certainly advise parents or students not to give such undertakings if they are demanded from them and if for that reason the latter cannot attend Government schools, they should stay away from them.
('52', 376, 5, 19, 655513) All persons thus concerned should remember that the present uncertain state will not last long.
('52', 376, 5, 20, 655609) Before the beginning of the next year at the latest, we shall have known whether the Congress demand is going to be accepted.
('52', 376, 5, 21, 655735) There is no need to say what should be done in case it is rejected.
('52', 376, 6, 22, 655803) 1 Vide “Digambar Sadhus”, 5 7 1931.
('52', 376, 7, 23, 655839) 2 Vide “Notes”, sub title, “Self respect above All”.
('52', 376, 8, 24, 655892) 3 The letter is not translated here.
('52', 376, 8, 25, 655929) It enclosed a guarantee form to be filled in by guardians that their wards would not participate in political activities.
('52', 377, 0, 1, 656051) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 377, 1, 2, 656093) FREEDOM ABOUT SALT
('52', 377, 2, 3, 656112) Can we carry salt from a village where it may be manufactured and sell it in surrounding villages where it cannot be?
('52', 377, 2, 4, 656230) If the villages are so near that one can reach them on foot one can certainly sell there the salt manufactured by oneself.
('52', 377, 3, 5, 656353) Does the Simla Notification make any difference to the law hitherto in force that, within 10 miles of the coastline, no one could stock more than one Bengal maund of salt?
('52', 377, 3, 6, 656525) There can be no such law though I had heard of a notification to that effect having been issued.
('52', 377, 3, 7, 656622) The latest notification issued should be understood to cancel all previous notifications that may be inconsistent with it.
('52', 377, 3, 8, 656745) The correct position is this: According to the Agreement one may stock the salt needed for one’s consumption or manufactured by oneself within the limits of one’s village and intended for sale in places which one can reach on foot.
('52', 377, 4, 9, 656977) Can one stock salt for sale?
('52', 377, 4, 10, 657006) Fishermen need more salt in the month of Bhadrapad.
('52', 377, 4, 11, 657058) Can one stock enough salt for them and sell it to them at that time?
('52', 377, 4, 12, 657127) The answer to this is included in the reply above.
('52', 377, 5, 13, 657178) Can we make in Government land the pits and beds for manufacturing salt?
('52', 377, 5, 14, 657251) Or should we make them in our own?
('52', 377, 5, 15, 657286) Such pits can be made wherever salt can be manufactured.
('52', 377, 5, 16, 657343) As for private land the owner’s permission would be required, and hence the Agreement implies that pits may be made in Government land or one’s own.
('52', 377, 6, 17, 657492) IRRELIGION IN THE NAME OF RELIGION
('52', 377, 7, 18, 657527) There is a village, named Raghvanaj in Matar Taluka.
('52', 377, 7, 19, 657580) It is well known that under Thakkar Bapa’s supervision, wells for Antyajas are being dug at many places in Gujarat, and one such well is being dug at Raghvanaj.
('52', 377, 7, 20, 657741) The person supervising the work there had sent to Thakkar Bapa a report, the following extract from which deserves to be pondered over by all Hindus.
('52', 377, 8, 21, 657891) This is the height of tyranny.
('52', 377, 8, 22, 657922) I do not blame the Dharalas much for the incident.
('52', 377, 8, 23, 657973) The blame lies with the so called highcaste Hindus.
('52', 377, 8, 24, 658025) The Dharalas are merely acting under the influence of the atmosphere which the former have created.
('52', 377, 8, 25, 658125) In wielding this whip of my pen, I
('52', 377, 9, 26, 658160) 1 The passage is not translated here.
('52', 377, 9, 27, 658198) It described how Dharala masons were punished for working alongside Dhed volunteers.
('52', 378, 0, 1, 658283) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 379
('52', 378, 1, 2, 658325) have little hope of waking up the Dharala men and women, but I do certainly hope to be able to wake up Congress workers and the readers of Navajivan.
('52', 378, 1, 3, 658475) In such a situation, the Congress workers who come to know of it should themselves take up the spade and start working, explain the meaning of dharma to Dharalas and others who may be oppressing the Antyajas and teach the latter to shed fear and to be self reliant.
('52', 378, 1, 4, 658741) All this can be easily done as soon as we get ready to work with our own hands.
('52', 378, 1, 5, 658821) But we would do so only if we feel revolted by such oppression.
('52', 378, 1, 6, 658885) MILLIONS SMOKED AWAY A correspondent from Calcutta writes as follows: 1
('52', 378, 2, 7, 658957) It is not very likely that my writing on the subject would end the present waste of millions on smoking.
('52', 378, 2, 8, 659062) But, apropos of this letter, I may remark here on a phenomenon which I have been observing.
('52', 378, 2, 9, 659154) We seem to have become indifferent in keeping up the reforms which had spontaneously spread during the satyagraha movement.
('52', 378, 2, 10, 659278) The inference to be drawn from this is alarming.
('52', 378, 2, 11, 659327) If we behave well only while we are fighting and lapse into slackness as soon as the intoxication of battle is over, it would be difficult, if not impossible, to preserve swaraj after it is won.
('52', 378, 2, 12, 659522) In that case, would it not be desirable that the struggle be prolonged?
('52', 378, 2, 13, 659594) Perhaps such a conclusion is not altogether justified, but I certainly fear that it may be in the interest of the country that the struggle should continue sufficiently long so that the people may acquire the capacity to preserve swaraj.
('52', 378, 2, 14, 659832) The fight ended before we had acquired strength enough to assimilate the reforms brought about while it was going on.
('52', 378, 2, 15, 659950) May I hope that readers who have become indifferent in this matter will draw the appropriate lesson from this, shake off their indifference and wake up others as well?
('52', 378, 2, 16, 660118) To those who realize that the satyagraha fight is a fight for self purification, every day is a day of battle or, if you like, of peace, for the effort for self purification should not be relaxed even for a moment.
('52', 378, 2, 17, 660333) [From Gujarati] Javajivan, 21 6 1931
('52', 378, 3, 18, 660370) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('52', 378, 3, 19, 660407) It said that cigarettes, boycotted during the struggle, were coming back into use.
('52', 379, 0, 1, 660490) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 379, 1, 2, 660532) 516. WHEAT OR CHAFF 1
('52', 379, 2, 3, 660554) Everyone must have read the resolution of the Congress Working Committee.
('52', 379, 2, 4, 660628) It says in substance that if other conditions are favourable and if I am invited, I should attend the Round Table Conference to put before it the Congress demand even if the communal question remains unsolved.
('52', 379, 2, 5, 660838) I did not like the resolution.
('52', 379, 2, 6, 660869) I opposed it.
('52', 379, 2, 7, 660883) I even placed before the Committee for discussion a draft resolution along the lines I desired.
('52', 379, 2, 8, 660979) But I was defeated and the resolution to the above effect was passed by a majority.
('52', 379, 2, 9, 661063) Though I am often described as an autocrat, I consider myself a man who accepts the supremacy of the people’s voice; it is in my nature to give in to a panch.
('52', 379, 2, 10, 661222) Panch means the voice of the people.
('52', 379, 2, 11, 661259) I, therefore, accepted the resolution passed by the majority.
('52', 379, 2, 12, 661321) There is an exception to this rule.
('52', 379, 2, 13, 661357) We cannot give in to anyone on a question of principle.
('52', 379, 2, 14, 661413) But there are not many principles in life.
('52', 379, 2, 15, 661456) one who at every step refuses, in the name of principle, to listen to others is autocratic and selfish.
('52', 379, 2, 16, 661560) Questions of principle arise only rarely.
('52', 379, 2, 17, 661602) Here there was no such question, and so I gave in.
('52', 379, 2, 18, 661653) I had often declared my determina tion not to attend the Round Table Conference if the Hindu Muslim, i.e., the communal question was not solved.
('52', 379, 2, 19, 661798) But I could not convince the Working Committee of the correctness of my position.
('52', 379, 2, 20, 661880) Ordinarily it would not be proper for me to put before the public my argument.
('52', 379, 2, 21, 661959) No member has a right to publish anything that is discussed in the Working Committee.
('52', 379, 2, 22, 662045) But in this case, the Committee has given me permission to do so.
('52', 379, 2, 23, 662111) The Committee felt that in order to enable me to explain my position as also its own policy it was necessary to give me such permission.
('52', 379, 2, 24, 662248) The reasoning behind my reluctance to go to the Round Table Conference without solving the communal question was as follows: Even if the question was solved, the acceptance of the Congress demand in England was unlikely, but if it was not solved the sanction behind the demands would be lost.
('52', 379, 2, 25, 662541) ‘You cannot put your own house in order and cannot unite yourselves, and still you ask for indepen dence!’ Even if the members do not say this openly out of politeness, they would think thus and we would read their thought in their eyes.
('52', 379, 2, 26, 662779) And they would, on the whole, be justified in taunting us thus.
('52', 379, 3, 27, 662843) 1 Vide footnote 2, “My Notes”
('52', 380, 0, 1, 662873) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 381
('52', 380, 1, 2, 662915) It would be better to accept our weakness rather than invite ridi cule by going in such a pitiable condition.
('52', 380, 1, 3, 663025) A satyagrahi never hides his weakness.
('52', 380, 1, 4, 663064) According to the law of satyagraha, from the admission of weakness new strength is born.
('52', 380, 1, 5, 663153) The first step in conquering weakness is its admission.
('52', 380, 1, 6, 663209) No one should conclude from my argument that the Working Committee’s resolution is an attempt to hide our weakness.
('52', 380, 1, 7, 663325) It reflects the consequence of weakness and hence amounts to unconscious hiding of it.
('52', 380, 1, 8, 663412) The logical consequence of the admission of the weak ness would be not to go to the Round Table Conference.
('52', 380, 1, 9, 663520) That alone would be true admission of the weakness.
('52', 380, 1, 10, 663572) One who does not have the strength to walk and admits that in words but actually tries to walk, has not truly admitted his weakness and by walking weakens himself all the more.
('52', 380, 1, 11, 663749) He may even faint and collapse.
('52', 380, 1, 12, 663781) Now if we admit our incapacity to solve the problem and do not send a representative of the Congress to the Round Table Conference, what should we do instead?
('52', 380, 1, 13, 663940) That would not mean that we give up our fight for purna swaraj.
('52', 380, 1, 14, 664004) The Round Table Conference is only one means of securing it.
('52', 380, 1, 15, 664065) We may have to let go that means.
('52', 380, 1, 16, 664099) Everyone will understand this much at once.
('52', 380, 1, 17, 664143) But we should even give up the desire and the hope to secure purna swaraj through the Round Table Conference.
('52', 380, 1, 18, 664253) We have then to swallow one bitter dose, and that is that whatever fight we start will not be for purna swaraj in name, though the result would be the same.
('52', 380, 1, 19, 664410) If the communal question cannot be solved satisfactorily now, then it means that the methods which we have tried so far to solve it were wrong or inadequate.
('52', 380, 1, 20, 664568) The attempts so far made aimed at brin ging about understanding among the Hindu and Muslim politicians.
('52', 380, 1, 21, 664672) They were of the nature of a fight for power among them.
('52', 380, 1, 22, 664729) From such fighting no unity can come, none has come at least.
('52', 380, 1, 23, 664791) If, therefore, the Congress desires unity of the heart, it should get out of that field and try to gain power over the hearts of Muslims and the other commu nities as it has gained over those of the Hindus.
('52', 380, 1, 24, 664998) Such an attempt is bound to result in a unity of hearts.
('52', 380, 1, 25, 665055) There is no scope for failure in it.
('52', 380, 1, 26, 665092) The power of the Congress has its source in service of the people.
('52', 380, 1, 27, 665159) If the Congress programme is so organized that the Muslims and the others continue to get equal benefit, then they also will come to know the Congress.
('52', 381, 0, 1, 665311) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 381, 1, 2, 665353) It is not that today nothing is done for their service.
('52', 381, 1, 3, 665409) Nevertheless we must acknowledge the fact that Muslims, Sikhs and others do not respond to the Congress as much as the Hindus do.
('52', 381, 1, 4, 665539) Instead of finding fault with these communities for this state of affairs, it would be better and more graceful for the Congress to admit its deficiency.
('52', 381, 1, 5, 665693) When the Congress will be overflowing with Indians other than Hindus, then there will be no difference between a communal solution and a national solution, the Muslims or other communities will not be afraid, because they are fewer in number, of the far more numerous Hindus, and the Hindus, physically weaker though in a majority, will not be afraid of the physically stronger Mussalmans or Sikhs.
('52', 381, 1, 6, 666092) Each community’s strength will benefit the other communities.
('52', 381, 1, 7, 666154) Unless such conditions are created, paper swaraj will fly off with a puff like the sheet of paper on which it is written.
('52', 381, 1, 8, 666276) What is paper swaraj, and what is the other swaraj?
('52', 381, 1, 9, 666328) Let us see.
('52', 381, 1, 10, 666340) The swaraj got through the Round Table Conference means the swaraj constitution accepted by us and passed by British Parliament into law.
('52', 381, 1, 11, 666478) This is the swaraj on the statute book, i.e., paper swaraj.
('52', 381, 1, 12, 666538) Behind it, there would not be the signatures of the millions; in fact the millions would not be trusting one another.
('52', 381, 1, 13, 666656) If Hindus and Muslims in Kanpur and Kashi are fighting one another, then such swaraj would be no better than chaff.
('52', 381, 1, 14, 666772) True swaraj is that which will have signatures of the millions behind it, whose cool shelter the millions would enjoy, and in which the incidents at Kanpur and Kashi would be past history to us and we would laugh heartily at our past follies.
('52', 381, 1, 15, 667015) Whether or not such swaraj has become statutory, it would be true swaraj and would be like wheat, for it would be nourishing.
('52', 381, 1, 16, 667141) I am of the view that if we cannot solve the communal question satisfactorily and if we decide to fight for the swaraj of my concep tion, then our boycott of the Round Table Conference will be a sign of our strength and will uphold our self respect.
('52', 381, 1, 17, 667391) This is the fight of my conception.
('52', 381, 1, 18, 667427) Even if the communal question is not solved and the representative of the Congress does not attend the Round Table Conference, something is bound to be done.
('52', 381, 1, 19, 667585) Let the communal minded Hindus and Muslims and others share a little power with the British under that Constitution and think that they are participating in ruling the country.
('52', 381, 1, 20, 667762) The Congress instead of asking for power from that Government will demand the things for which
('52', 382, 0, 1, 667857) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 383
('52', 382, 1, 2, 667899) they want power and, if they are refused, it will fight through satya graha.
('52', 382, 1, 3, 667976) We do not want political power for its own sake, we want it for a certain end.
('52', 382, 1, 4, 668055) That end is service of the millions.
('52', 382, 1, 5, 668092) If we cannot get today the reins of power in our hands to improve their economic, moral and social conditions, we need not on that account stop that work.
('52', 382, 1, 6, 668247) By giving such a turn to the fight for swaraj, we can bypass the communal tangle and invite all the people to join the fight.
('52', 382, 1, 7, 668373) Nobody will be able to keep out of it.
('52', 382, 1, 8, 668412) Those who refuse to join will lose their face.

('52', 382, 1, 10, 668603) For example, a fight for revision of the land revenue laws to make them more equitable and to reduce the burden of land revenue would be for the benefit of all communities and in time everybody would join it.
('52', 382, 1, 11, 668812) Such a fight would result either in the desired reforms being effected or in those holding power handing over the power to the rebellious people.

('52', 393, 7, 16, 685376) 531. ADVICE TO FARMERS, BORSAD
('52', 393, 8, 17, 685407) BORSAD, June 22, 1931
('52', 393, 9, 18, 685429) Answering various questions put to him, Mahatma Gandhi said that everyone
('52', 393, 10, 19, 685503) who could afford should pay all dues, including past dues and taqavi.
('52', 393, 10, 20, 685573) By affording, he
('52', 393, 11, 21, 685590) meant ability to pay without borrowing and without selling their belongings.
('52', 393, 11, 22, 685667) He had,
('52', 393, 12, 23, 685675) from the moment he entered Borsad, made it clear to the authorities and in his
('52', 393, 13, 24, 685754) personal conversation with the Collector, that it was on that basis that he proposed
('52', 393, 14, 25, 685839) to work and offer help and it was on that basis that the lists were prepared and
('52', 393, 15, 26, 685920) payments made.
('52', 393, 16, 27, 685935) He was happy to see that all but Rs. 2,000 to Rs. 3,000 had been paid and he
('52', 393, 17, 28, 686012) had been given an assurance that this sum also would be paid up in two or three days.
('52', 393, 18, 29, 686098) There was now, therefore, no question of further calls upon them during the present
('52', 393, 19, 30, 686182) He had, however, written to the Collector, asking him to furnish the names of
('52', 394, 0, 1, 686260) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 395
('52', 394, 1, 2, 686302) those whom he might suspect of having withheld their correct position from him.
('52', 394, 2, 3, 686382) would be severely disappointed if he had been misled by any of the landholders.
('52', 394, 3, 4, 686462) He warned them and told them that if there were any whom they knew, they should bring their names to his notice and induce them to pay land revenue.
('52', 394, 3, 5, 686611) Regarding village officers who were still awaiting reinstatement, he said that he was in correspondence with the authorities and hoped to have a satisfactory decision about them.
('52', 394, 4, 6, 686790) Concluding, Mahatma Gandhi exhorted Patidars 1, who had taken prominent part in the struggle, to get rid of untouchability and treat other backward commu nities, such as Dharalas and Barias, as themselves.
('52', 394, 5, 7, 686996) Asked what they should do regarding their confiscated lands sold to third parties, Mahatma Gandhi said that he hoped still to secure all such lands, but if the so called purchasers came to take possession no opposition should be offered them.
('52', 394, 5, 8, 687239) If they were still in possession, they could till the land but they should realize that they ran the risk of having to lose labour and seed if they were called upon to give up possession, which they would have to do.
('52', 394, 5, 9, 687456) Whilst no one should work on such land on behalf of purchasers, no molestation should be offered against those who wished to work.
('52', 394, 5, 10, 687587) The Bombay Chronicle, 24 6 1931

('52', 404, 3, 5, 702721) You will agree with me that no assurance on paper can possibly bring relief to those who are actually being injured.
('52', 404, 3, 6, 702838) The only relief they can see and feel is when the injury ceases.
('52', 404, 3, 7, 702903) Unfortunately the same injury that I complained of seems to be continuing.

('52', 404, 3, 10, 703134) The enclosed is his report.
('52', 404, 3, 11, 703162) You will see therefrom that the hedges of the poor cultivators are still being destroyed.
('52', 404, 3, 12, 703252) Valuable babul trees are being cut down and wood taken away.

('52', 404, 3, 14, 703457) I wonder if the police is able to afford any protection to the Patidars and others.

('52', 405, 2, 3, 704224) AS AT SABARMATI, June 24, 1931
('52', 405, 3, 4, 704255) MY DEAR CHARLIE, I have your letter.
('52', 405, 3, 5, 704292) I shall look forward to Mrs. Polak’s book 1. I know it will revive old and pleasant memories and it will tell me of things I have perhaps altogether forgotten.
('52', 405, 3, 6, 704452) It is a good thing that your two books 2 are reaching the proper people.
('52', 405, 3, 7, 704525) As is your wont you are distressed over what your eyes see and ears hear.
('52', 405, 3, 8, 704599) This time it is the terrible unemployment in Lancashire and what you see and hear acts as an effective barrier against perceiving the truth.
('52', 405, 3, 9, 704740) I have seen from extensive experience the truth of a legal maxim which says: “Hard cases make bad law.” Many legal maxims are also sound moral maxims as this one is.
('52', 405, 3, 10, 704906) I can say with perfect detachment although I am immersed in the Indian turmoil that the way you suggest is not the way to help Lancashire.
('52', 405, 3, 11, 705045) If it was wrong any time for Lancashire to impose its cloth upon India by hook or by crook it is wrong also today and more so because India has become conscious of the wrong.
('52', 405, 3, 12, 705220) And if India now refuses to be party to the wrong, surely she won’t be adding wrong to wrong but she would be assisting the process of undoing the wrong done by Lancashire.
('52', 405, 3, 13, 705393) That the labourers were not conscious of the wrong that was being done is no justification for the wrong itself being sustained by the party wronged, that is, India or anybody else.
('52', 405, 3, 14, 705575) The proper course is to show the labourers how they have been unconsciously assisting the wrong done by Lancashire to India and therefore how necessary it is to retrace the step.
('52', 405, 3, 15, 705754) The first thing to do therefore is, if Lancashire cloth cannot be sold outside India, to find some other employment.
('52', 405, 3, 16, 705871) What that can be it is difficult for me to say.
('52', 405, 3, 17, 705919) I do not know how England itself is clothed.
('52', 405, 3, 18, 705964) Why should not the same machinery be used for preparing the clothing of the kind required by England or better still, why should not the machinery be scrapped and the unemployed take

('52', 406, 1, 2, 706324) to handicrafts?
('52', 406, 1, 3, 706340) I know these are vague ideas without any basis for them but I have given them to show which way my mind is working.
('52', 406, 1, 4, 706456) Let me help you by putting before you another fact.
('52', 406, 1, 5, 706508) Foreign cloth boycott has created a kind of atmosphere.
('52', 406, 1, 6, 706564) Its effect upon Lancashire is nothing so serious as it is made out.

('52', 410, 1, 2, 712335) 553. SLAVE COMMUNITIES
('52', 410, 2, 3, 712358) We have the untouchables, the shame and curse of the Hindu society.
('52', 410, 2, 4, 712426) But we have also other communities whom we—the so called higher classes—treat almost as slaves and keep in quarters designed for our cattle.
('52', 410, 2, 5, 712567) Representatives of one such community have addressed a letter which I condense as follows: 1
('52', 410, 3, 6, 712660) We are representatives of the Rajwar community living in the districts of Gaya, Patna, Monghyr and Palamau, in the Province of Bihar and Orissa.
('52', 410, 3, 7, 712805) On refusal to give begar 2 the zamindar forthwith begins a suit for arrears of rent, gets decree, puts the jot 3 to auction and evicts the tenant from the land in his possession.
('52', 410, 3, 8, 712984) A Rajwar child, no sooner he reaches his 6th or 7th year, becomes almost the property of his parents’ landlord; he is made to tend the landlord’s cattle and do all sorts of odd jobs.
('52', 410, 3, 9, 713167) In fact he leads the life of a slave, a mere chattel of the landlord.
('52', 410, 3, 10, 713237) For working from 6 a.m.
('52', 410, 3, 11, 713261) to 6 p.m.
('52', 410, 3, 12, 713271) Rajwars are paid at the rate of 3 seers of unhusked rice per diem and no wages in cash are ever paid to them.
('52', 410, 3, 13, 713381) The Rajwar children are not allowed to be sent to the primary schools and the teachers too are not allowed to teach the boys by the landlord.
('52', 410, 3, 14, 713523) Whenever there is any theft or larceny or dacoity or any crime whatever in the locality where this community is living, the first suspicion and the first brunt of the police enquiry must be borne by it, although there may not be the slightest evidence for the same.
('52', 410, 3, 15, 713789) We have already submitted these memorials to the District Magistrates of Gaya and Patna, and to the Chief Secretary, Bihar and Orissa Government but we have not as yet learnt what steps the respective authorities have taken.
('52', 410, 3, 16, 714014) We hope that you will do something to ameliorate our condition.
('52', 410, 3, 17, 714078) The letter is written for the representatives and probably
('52', 410, 4, 18, 714137) 1 Only extracts are reproduced here.
('52', 410, 4, 19, 714174) 2 Forced labour 3 Holding
('52', 411, 0, 1, 714200) 412 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 411, 1, 2, 714242) also prompted by some unknown reformer among them.
('52', 411, 1, 3, 714293) It is signed by about twenty five representatives.
('52', 411, 1, 4, 714344) What however matters is not who wrote it but the statements made therein, if they are true.
('52', 411, 1, 5, 714436) They are highly likely to be true in the main.
('52', 411, 1, 6, 714483) For such treatment is not an isolated phenomenon of Bihar.
('52', 411, 1, 7, 714542) Almost all the provinces have these backward, suppressed, slave communities.
('52', 411, 1, 8, 714619) They are no heritage from the British.
('52', 411, 1, 9, 714658) We have had them for ages and all the greater shame on us for that.
('52', 411, 1, 10, 714726) We may plead a thousand excuses for their existence in the days gone by.
('52', 411, 1, 11, 714799) But in these days of enlightenment, awakening and insis tence on swaraj, we have no excuse for tolerating the atrocity.
('52', 411, 1, 12, 714919) Con gress workers have to take up the cause of these communities wher ever they are found.
('52', 411, 1, 13, 715010) They should try to enlist the sympathy and co operation of those who ‘own’ these men and women.
('52', 411, 1, 14, 715106) Swaraj is the sum total of all the activities that go to build up a free and vigorous nation concious of the strength that comes from right doing.
('52', 411, 1, 15, 715253) The existence of slave communities is aterrible wrong and must therefore be a hindrance in our march towards the goal.
('52', 411, 1, 16, 715372) Young India, 25 6 1931
('52', 411, 2, 17, 715395) 554. A GENTLE REBUKE
('52', 411, 3, 18, 715416) C. Rajagopalachari’s eagle eye sees everything that appears in print about the drink evil.
('52', 411, 3, 19, 715507) He saw a report of my very innocent speech at the village of Maroli 1 where the other day I laid the foundation of a weaving institute.
('52', 411, 3, 20, 715643) I had there attempted to show the connection that exists between factory labour and drink and said how mithubehn Petit had, whilst doing prohibition work, discovered that if the people who ceased to visit the liquor shops she picketed were to be permanently weaned from drink, they should have some ambition provided in life, some work found for them during their idle hours.
('52', 411, 3, 21, 716019) I then showed how she found such occupation in hand spinning and weaving.
('52', 411, 3, 22, 716093) I further went on to show that if people had to do excessive labour, they would want some stimulant and illustrated it by an experience from my own life when during the Boer War I had to issue from the commissariat rations of rum for those bearers who were used to drink and who pleaded with me for rum which, they said, would enable them to bear the fatigue and resume next day’s march.

('52', 412, 1, 4, 716625) Rajagopalachari feared that the report that he had read would be distorted to yield all kinds of meanings favourable to the opponents of prohibition.
('52', 412, 1, 5, 716775) His fear has been justified.

('52', 412, 1, 7, 716878) They embarrass me because I am not conscious of the conversion imputed to me.

('52', 412, 1, 10, 717199) If I was appointed dictator for one hour for all India, the first thing I would do would be to close without compensation all the liquor shops, destroy all the toddy palms such as I know them in Gujarat, compel factory owners to produce humane conditions for their workmen and open refreshment and recreation rooms where these workmen would get innocent drinks and equally innocent amusements.
('52', 412, 1, 11, 717593) I would close down the factories if the owners pleaded want of funds.
('52', 412, 1, 12, 717663) Being a teetotaller, I would retain my sobriety in spite of the possession of one hour’s dictatorship and therefore arrange for the examination of my European friends and diseased persons who may be in medical need of brandy and the like at State expense by medical experts and where necessary they would receive certificate which would entitle them to obtain the prescribed quantity of the fiery waters from certified chemists.
('52', 412, 1, 13, 718092) The rule will apply mutatis mutandis to intoxicating drugs.
('52', 412, 1, 14, 718152) For the loss of revenue from drinks, I would straightway cut down the military expenditure and expect the Commander in Chief to accommodate himself to the new condition in the best way he can.
('52', 412, 1, 15, 718345) The workmen left idle by the closing of factories, I would remove to model farms to be immediately opened as far as possible in the neighbourhood of the factories unless I was advised during that brief hour that the State could profitably run the factories under the required conditions and could therefore take over from the owners.

('52', 413, 2, 3, 718766) I take the following from a complaint about picketing:
('52', 413, 3, 4, 718821) In rural areas there is definite evidence that everything short of physical violence has been resorted to by volunteers.
('52', 413, 3, 5, 718942) Would be customers are obstructed, abused and generally harassed, and toddy shop renters have been put to considerable loss and in some instances have been so discouraged that they have ceased to get trees marked for tapping and closed their shops rather than suffer further indignities.
('52', 413, 3, 6, 719230) The Congress office in Tellichery issued summonses to the principal renters to appear before them and few had the courage to disobey.
('52', 413, 3, 7, 719364) Those who appeared were summarily told to close their shops, and when they asked for compensation they were told that Congress would do nothing for them.

('52', 415, 2, 9, 724413) 556. A MARTYR
('52', 415, 3, 10, 724427) Whilst the Working Committee was deliberating in Bombay during the early part of the month, there was a public meeting in Dongri at which there was an uproar and at which a youth was fatally stabbed.
('52', 415, 3, 11, 724627) The news of the death was brought to the Working Committee.
('52', 415, 3, 12, 724687) It created a sensation but at the time it was thought that some unknown unidentifiable person had died.

('52', 415, 3, 15, 724929) I thereupon asked him to procure fuller details which I now have.
('52', 415, 3, 16, 724995) Brave and good Pannalal was only 22 years old when he received the fatal stab on that fateful night from one of the excited Mussalman crowd.
('52', 415, 3, 17, 725136) Accompanied by his father and younger brother, Pannalal had gone to the Dongri meeting specially to hear Khan Saheb Abdul Ghaffar Khan who was among others advertised to speak at the meeting.
('52', 415, 3, 18, 725328) After they had heard the Khan Saheb the father hailed a victoria and they got in.
('52', 415, 3, 19, 725410) Being khaddar clad they were taken for nationalist leaders.
('52', 415, 3, 20, 725470) A howling crowd surrounded them.
('52', 415, 3, 21, 725503) Stones were rained on them.
('52', 415, 3, 22, 725531) All of them were hurt.
('52', 415, 3, 23, 725554) Pannalal’s left eyebrow was bleeding.
('52', 415, 3, 24, 725592) Nothing minding, in order to lighten his father’s sorrow, he made light of his wound.
('52', 415, 3, 25, 725678) Suddenly there came into his left ribs a deep stab.
('52', 415, 3, 26, 725730) Blood gushed from the wounded side.
('52', 415, 3, 27, 725766) Out came the entrails.

('52', 418, 2, 3, 729957) SELF RESPECT ABOVE ALL
('52', 418, 3, 4, 729980) I have letters 1 from several provinces saying that the education authorities are imposing conditions on the return of students who had left their schools or colleges during the struggle.
('52', 418, 3, 5, 730168) A circular of which a copy has been sent by one of the correspondents requires parents to give guarantees that their children will not take part in politics.
('52', 418, 3, 6, 730326) These correspondents ask me whether these conditions are consistent with the Settlement.
('52', 418, 3, 7, 730415) Without entering into that question for the time being, I have no hesitation in saying that neither students nor parents if they have any self respect left in them should accept such conditions.
('52', 418, 3, 8, 730610) What will it profit the students or the parents if they have to lose their souls to gain the questionable advantage of a public education and a certificate?
('52', 418, 3, 9, 730767) There are the national institutions open to the students.

('52', 418, 3, 15, 731221) Wheat is left out and mere husk is taken in.

('52', 418, 3, 18, 731340) But we are making altogether too much of them.
('52', 418, 3, 19, 731387) They are but one of the many means of gaining knowledge.

('52', 421, 3, 9, 737103) 560. INTERVIEW TO THE PRESS
('52', 421, 4, 10, 737131) BOMBAY, June 25, 1931
('52', 421, 5, 11, 737153) To a question put about his participation in the Federal Structure Committee [Gandhiji replied:] If I attend the Round Table Conference, I shall possibly attend the Federal Structure Committee also.
('52', 421, 6, 12, 737352) Asked whether he had finally decided to go to the London Conference and when he was likely to start, Gandhiji said that the Working Committee would decide all those questions for him.
('52', 421, 6, 13, 737536) His theory and views had been exploded and he would willingly obey whatever the Committee asked him to do.
('52', 421, 7, 14, 737643) Asked whether the situation in Gujarat was satisfactory, after hesitating for a while, Gandhiji replied that the situation was not satisfactory.
('52', 421, 7, 15, 737788) But he had been corresponding with the Government of India.
('52', 421, 7, 16, 737848) Incidentally, he mentioned that he had been receiving reports from all over India forwarded by reliable trusted workers like Mr. C. Rajagopalachari, that a deliberate policy of repression of strictly peaceful picketing, in the shape of faked prosecutions, physical interference and lathi charges was hindering the working of the Settlement.
('52', 421, 7, 17, 738189) None of these complaints had escaped his attention, and he could not publish them as he was carrying on delicate negotiations with the Central Government from and through which he expected to gain relief.
('52', 421, 7, 18, 738394) He hoped that things would not assume serious proportions as to endanger the Truce.
('52', 421, 7, 19, 738478) He had one word to say to Congressmen, that the safety and honour of the Congress demanded meticulous performance by the Congressmen of all the conditions of the Truce.
('52', 421, 8, 20, 738647) Gandhiji proposed to place the Working Committee in full possession of all the complaints.
('52', 422, 0, 1, 738738) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 423
('52', 422, 1, 2, 738780) Gandhiji profoundly regretted the failure of the efforts in Bhopal to effect a settlement between the two sections of the Muslim group.
('52', 422, 1, 3, 738916) It was a very unfortunate incident.
('52', 422, 1, 4, 738952) The Working Committee would discuss what next should be done in view of the failure.
('52', 422, 2, 5, 739037) Gandhiji was confident that the Foreign cloth Export Scheme would prove a success and the scheme did not amount to a breach of the Truce as alleged by certain interested parties.
('52', 422, 3, 6, 739216) Is the contention made by a new political school of thought to the effect that the Congress, by accepting the Truce, accepted the principle of Federation as enunciated in the last R.T.C. true?
('52', 422, 3, 7, 739409) If so where does the Congress resolution of Indepcndence passed at the Lahore Congress and reiterated at Karachi stand?
('52', 422, 4, 8, 739529) A. This question need not be answered.
('52', 422, 4, 9, 739568) The Hindu, 25 6 1931
('52', 422, 5, 10, 739589) 561. DISCUSSION ON FOREIGN CLOTH BOYCOTT 1
('52', 422, 6, 11, 739632) BOMBAY, June 25, 1931
('52', 422, 7, 12, 739654) Mr. Gandhi said he was aware of the position, but it was an article of faith with him that the use of any foreign manufactured articles in the composition of cloth turned out by Indian mills was detrimental to the interests of the masses.
('52', 422, 7, 13, 739893) He explained his view at some length and regretted his inability to deflect from the course [in spite] of any disadvantage, which might accrue to the industry, which he thought would only be of a temporary character.
('52', 422, 8, 14, 740110) Gandhiji however realized very fully the menace of Japanese competition, and said he would leave no stone unturned to deal with it effectively.
('52', 422, 8, 15, 740254) The Congress policy was certainly not intended to merely restrict imports from Lancashire, but all imports of foreign cloth, and he would direct particular attention to the growing menace from Japan.
('52', 422, 8, 16, 740454) If and when a satisfactory settlement was reached, Japanese competition might be dealt with by means of a special tariff.
('52', 422, 8, 17, 740576) The whole position was one which would have to be seriously considered in the nearest future.
('52', 422, 8, 18, 740670) The Hindu, 26 6 1931
('52', 422, 9, 19, 740691) 1 With H. P. Mody, Chairman of the Mill owners’ Association, S. D. Saklatwala, and Lalji Naranji.
('52', 422, 9, 20, 740789) The discussion turned on the increasing imports of Japanese piece goods, particularly artificial silk goods.
('52', 422, 9, 21, 740898) It was pointed out that while the industry was being asked to give up the use of artificial silk yarn, Japanese imports of this class of goods were increasing at an alarming rate, disorganizing trade not merely in artificial silk goods, but also in other varieties.
