('52', 423, 1, 2, 741206) 562. SPEECH AT WOMEN’S MEETING, BOMBAY
('52', 423, 2, 3, 741245) June 26, 1931
('52', 423, 3, 4, 741259) Mahatma Gandhi first congratulated the women of India and particularly the
('52', 423, 4, 5, 741334) women of Bombay for the great and heroic part they had taken in the last fight.
('52', 423, 5, 6, 741414) had shown unparalleled courage and their capacity to suffer and make supreme
('52', 423, 6, 7, 741491) sacrifices in the cause of the country was fully tested.
('52', 423, 6, 8, 741548) When Gandhiji started on his
('52', 423, 7, 9, 741577) pilgrimage to Dandi 1 he had entrusted to the women of India a twofold mission.
('52', 423, 8, 10, 741657) Firstly the women of India must help the nation to exterminate all foreign cloth and
('52', 423, 9, 11, 741742) secondly they must help to enforce total prohibition.
('52', 423, 9, 12, 741796) Gandhiji entrusted this task to
('52', 423, 10, 13, 741828) the women, having full faith that it would be carried out.
('52', 423, 10, 14, 741887) What the women had
('52', 423, 11, 15, 741906) achieved by selfless work and during such a short time was far beyond his most
('52', 423, 12, 16, 741985) sanguine hopes.
('52', 423, 13, 17, 742001) The women of India, proceeded Gandhiji, had enhanced the prestige of the
('52', 423, 14, 18, 742074) whole nation.
('52', 423, 14, 19, 742088) They were the cynosure of all eyes.
('52', 423, 14, 20, 742124) The whole world looked up to them
('52', 423, 15, 21, 742158) with admiration for their patriotism.
('52', 423, 15, 22, 742196) But that was not enough.
('52', 423, 15, 23, 742221) The praise that was
('52', 423, 16, 24, 742241) showered on them by the world must encourage them to look forward to their future
('52', 423, 17, 25, 742323) work with greater faith and zeal.
('52', 423, 18, 26, 742357) They should with more vigour carry out the work entrusted to them during the
('52', 423, 19, 27, 742434) They should persuade dealers in foreign cloth as well as consumers to shun
('52', 423, 20, 28, 742509) foreign cloth.
('52', 423, 20, 29, 742524) They should beg of those who are addicted to drink to give up the vice
('52', 423, 21, 30, 742595) and they should induce the dealers in liquor to stop the evil traffic.
('52', 423, 21, 31, 742666) During the last
('52', 423, 22, 32, 742682) fight men and women volunteered their services for this work but now this task had
('52', 423, 23, 33, 742765) become more onerous and difficult.
('52', 423, 23, 34, 742800) There was both laxity in work and lack of
('52', 423, 24, 35, 742842) workers.
('52', 423, 25, 36, 742851) The need for a regular and disciplined army of workers was therefore all the greater.
('52', 423, 25, 37, 742937) They should not be disappointed by the results of their efforts.
('52', 423, 25, 38, 743002) If they had complete faith in their mission and believed that they were going to succeed, it would not only be possible to exterminate foreign cloth from India but also root out the drink evil in a short time.
('52', 423, 25, 39, 743212) But this kind of work required discipline and united efforts.
('52', 423, 25, 40, 743274) He noticed among the audience a few women wearing the orange colour saris but a majority of them did not wear this emblem.
('52', 423, 25, 41, 743397) This colour was symbolic of the dedication of their services in the cause of the country.
('52', 423, 25, 42, 743487) It also indicated that they were members of the local organization of women which carried out the mission of boycott and prohibition.
('52', 423, 26, 43, 743621) 1 On March 12, 1930; ads Vol. XLIII.
('52', 424, 0, 1, 743658) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 425
('52', 424, 1, 2, 743700) My appeal to you women, therefore, is to come out and adopt this symbol of the orange colour sari and join the band of those brave and selfless women whose services are pledged to the country.
('52', 424, 2, 3, 743893) He then sounded a note of warning to such of the women who took to khaddar
('52', 424, 3, 4, 743968) during the last struggle but were now tempted to go in for foreign fineries.
('52', 424, 3, 5, 744045) It had been
('52', 424, 4, 6, 744057) brought to his notice that a few Khoja 1 women who had taken part in the movement
('52', 424, 5, 7, 744139) and had become converts to the gospel of khaddar were now showing an inclination
('52', 424, 6, 8, 744220) to buy foreign cloth.
('52', 424, 6, 9, 744242) This was not the case with Khoja women alone but Hindu women
('52', 424, 7, 10, 744303) If they had the slightest regard and pity for the millions of their countrymen
('52', 424, 8, 11, 744382) who were facing starvation and worse they should cease patronizing foreign cloth.
('52', 424, 9, 12, 744464) They should prefer either khaddar or India made cloth to the exclusion of all
('52', 424, 10, 13, 744542) foreign cloth.
('52', 424, 10, 14, 744557) But he would point out that Indian mill cloth was meant for those to
('52', 424, 11, 15, 744626) whom the message of the starving millions had not reached and for such persons who
('52', 424, 12, 16, 744709) were not of Congress persuasion.
('52', 424, 12, 17, 744742) But every Congressman and woman and everyone
('52', 424, 13, 18, 744787) who believed in the Congress creed must adopt khaddar and khaddar alone even to the
('52', 424, 14, 19, 744871) exclusion of mill cloth.
('52', 424, 15, 20, 744896) No doubt the use of mill cloth would benefit a few lakhs of workers living in
('52', 424, 16, 21, 744974) industrial towns, a few thousands of shareholders and a smaller number of agents and
('52', 424, 17, 22, 745059) directors.
('52', 424, 17, 23, 745070) But there were seven lakhs of villages in India and 30 crores of
('52', 424, 18, 24, 745135) poverty stricken peasants in them.
('52', 424, 18, 25, 745170) Should one place the interest of 30 crores of
('52', 424, 19, 26, 745216) peasants first or a few lakhs of industrial workers ?
('52', 424, 19, 27, 745270) Their duty should be to relieve the
('52', 424, 20, 28, 745306) poverty of the 30 crores of peasants by patronizing khaddar and khaddar alone.
('52', 424, 21, 29, 745385) Mahatmaji thought that the best education for girls and women was not the kind of university education that they were getting in schools but that they should be taught thoroughly to master the art of spinning and carding.
('52', 424, 21, 30, 745607) The message of the charkha must be popularized throughout the length and breadth of the country and women were best fitted for the propagation of this message.
('52', 424, 21, 31, 745767) If every woman learnt to spin and cultivated the habit of wearing only selfmade khaddar clothes they would go a long way in winning their freedom.
('52', 424, 21, 32, 745914) [Concluding, Gandhiji said:] In khaddar alone lies your salvation and in your salvation lies the salvation of your country.

('52', 425, 6, 8, 746440) deputationists that everything that he would urge at the Round Table Conference

('52', 425, 7, 10, 746592) He would not
('52', 425, 8, 11, 746605) promise that the very same formula suggested by the deputation will be placed before
('52', 425, 9, 12, 746690) the Conference but if a better one suggested itself to him he would give it preference.
('52', 425, 10, 13, 746778) As regards providing educational facilities to the ‘depressed’ classes, Mahatmaji
('52', 425, 11, 14, 746860) would like to do much more than was suggested to him.
('52', 425, 12, 15, 746914) But Gandhiji was himself not sure whether the present Settlement with the
('52', 425, 13, 16, 746988) Government was a temporary settlement or permanent one.
('52', 425, 13, 17, 747044) If it was a permanent one

('52', 425, 16, 21, 747232) awakening of the people the stigma of untouchability would soon disappear
('52', 425, 17, 22, 747306) altogether from the country.
('52', 425, 18, 23, 747335) Mahatmaji wanted to say how much the Congress had been doing for the uplift
('52', 425, 19, 24, 747411) and general advancement of the ‘depressed’ classes.
('52', 425, 19, 25, 747463) After the question of
('52', 425, 20, 26, 747485) untouchability was taken up by the Congress, it had spent more than 20 lakhs of
('52', 425, 21, 27, 747565) rupees for starting ashrams and schools for ‘depressed’ classes and untouchable
('52', 425, 22, 28, 747645) classes where free education was imparted.
('52', 425, 22, 29, 747688) There was a network of ashrams in Gujarat
('52', 425, 23, 30, 747730) where ‘depressed’ class boys were taught free.

('52', 431, 2, 3, 755228) GANGABHEN, I got both your letters.
('52', 431, 2, 4, 755264) You seem to feel worried and upset.
('52', 431, 2, 5, 755300) If you are very much worked, come over for a day.
('52', 431, 2, 6, 755350) “Never lose heart” 1 means that, if we get unhappy experiences in society or do not succeed immediately in our undertakings, we should not give way to despair but should remain cheerful and go on doing our work.
('52', 431, 2, 7, 755562) This is what is meant by never losing heart.
('52', 431, 2, 8, 755607) By saying you are a member of the Managing Committee, I tried to remind you of your responsibility and your powers You can say in the Committee what you wish to and persuade it to accept your proposal.
('52', 431, 2, 9, 755809) What I expect from you is this.
('52', 431, 2, 10, 755841) Even if others lose heart, you should not.
('52', 431, 2, 11, 755884) Swallow all bitter draughts, go ahead and do the work expected of you.
('52', 431, 2, 12, 755955) This is what I want from you.
('52', 431, 2, 13, 755985) All my expectations of you concern strength of heart and not intellectual ability.
('52', 431, 2, 14, 756068) The intellect has less value, the heart has more.
('52', 431, 2, 15, 756118) And the heart is something which everyone has.
('52', 431, 2, 16, 756165) “Do not try to jump too high” 2 means that, instead of planning big things, you should try to improve what we are already doing.
('52', 431, 2, 17, 756294) If you are impatient to take up new things, the task on hand will suffer.
('52', 431, 2, 18, 756368) In my thoughts, I am always there.
('52', 431, 2, 19, 756403) But how can I come away?
('52', 431, 2, 20, 756428) I must finish the task that has come to me unsought.
('52', 431, 2, 21, 756481) Blessings from BAPU [From Gujarati] Bapuna Patro 6: G. S. Gangabehnne, p.

('52', 432, 1, 2, 756739) 573. STATEMENT ON BAN BY SACHIN STATE 1
('52', 432, 2, 3, 756779) BORSAD, June 29, 1931 Let the public know that the change of venue 2 has nothing to do with the order.
('52', 432, 2, 4, 756882) Neither Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel nor I knew anything about it when the change of venue was decided upon.
('52', 432, 2, 5, 756984) The date and venue had to be changed for the convenience of, and at the request of Dr. Ansari, Maulana Abul Kalam and Mr. Mohamed Alam.
('52', 432, 2, 6, 757120) Nevert heless, I am sorry for the order.
('52', 432, 2, 7, 757161) Some States do not seem to realize that at present there is agreement between the Government and the Congress.
('52', 432, 2, 8, 757272) Such an order might therefore easily embarrass the Government which to the State is the paramount power.
('52', 432, 2, 9, 757377) Indeed, Dumas was thought of merely for its being a seaside resort.
('52', 432, 2, 10, 757445) Nobody dreamt that the Working Committee meeting in the cool air of the sea near Dumas would harm Sachin.
('52', 432, 2, 11, 757551) However, I am thankful that the accident of the change of venue has prevented an awkward situation arising.
('52', 432, 2, 12, 757659) I hope, however, that order means no more than overzeal on the part of the District Magistrate of Sachin.

('52', 434, 6, 12, 759643) 578. LETTER TO H. W. EMERSON
('52', 434, 7, 13, 759672) BORSAD, June 30, 1931
('52', 434, 8, 14, 759694) DEAR MR. EMERSON, I have your lettcr of 23rd inst.
('52', 434, 8, 15, 759745) setting forth objections raised against the recent resolution of the Working Committee on boycott of foreign cloth.
('52', 434, 8, 16, 759861) I have re read the resolution in the light of the objec tions raised and I have come to the conclusion that the objections are based on an insufficient reading of the resolution and ignorance of the previous history of the Congress policy in the matter.
('52', 434, 8, 17, 760115) Long before the civil disobedience campaign and ever since the Bengal Partition days, boycott of foreign cloth and especially British cloth and general British goods became the policy of the Congress.
('52', 434, 8, 18, 760316) In 1920 boycott of British goods was dropped at my instance and replaced by boycott of foreign cloth on predominantly economic grounds and ever since it has so remained.
('52', 434, 8, 19, 760486) Whilst I was in Yeravda jail between 1922 and ‘24 a resolution adopting boycott of British goods was passed at one of the sessions of the Congress and since then, boycott of foreign cloth and boycott of British goods have run on parallel lines.
('52', 434, 8, 20, 760731) During the last struggle these assumed an aggressive political character and became practically merged.
('52', 434, 8, 21, 760835) As a result of the Delhi Settlement, boycott of British goods was discontinued and the effect of discontinuance was so immediate that within a week of the Settlement orders for British
('52', 435, 0, 1, 761020) 436 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 435, 1, 2, 761062) machinery and other goods were freely sent.
('52', 435, 1, 3, 761106) Boycott of foreign cloth however remained not as a political weapon but as an economic necessity.
('52', 435, 1, 4, 761204) Thus complete prohibition of the sale of foreign cloth as an economic necessity has been the settled Congress policy since 1920. It was torn from its original anti British setting.
('52', 435, 1, 5, 761385) A mere pursuit of this policy can in no sense be interpreted to mean interference with the liberty of action of the individual unless the policy was enforced through violent measures.
('52', 435, 1, 6, 761569) But the history of the methods adopted by the Congress since the Settlement, I think, furnishes sufficient evi dence to show that both the letter and the spirit of the Settlement have been adhered to in the vast majority of cases by Congress organi zations and prompt measures have been taken wherever any departure from peaceful methods has been detected.
('52', 435, 1, 7, 761926) Objection has been taken to the use of the word ‘permit’ in the resolution in question.
('52', 435, 1, 8, 762014) Of course the word has reference only to those who put themselves under Congress discipline and so long as the Congress retains the influence it has over the people, the use of the word ‘permit’ is not only legitimate but necessary if the Congress resolutions are to convey the intention of the authors.
('52', 435, 1, 9, 762318) So long as the Congress policy remains what it is, it is not open to Congress organi zations to permit all those under their influence importation of foreign cloth even if individuals desired it.
('52', 435, 1, 10, 762514) As to disciplinary action the words of the resolution are surely quite clear.
('52', 435, 1, 11, 762592) Disciplinary action contemplated is “against the Commit tee or the individual as the case may be” and Committee or the indivi dual means only a Congress Committee or its individual members.
('52', 435, 1, 12, 762782) That all the obligation that is imposed by the Congress is purely moral and devoid of any violence is abundantly clear from the fact that breaches of pledges given to the Congress continue to be reported, the Congress remaining helpless.
('52', 435, 1, 13, 763020) At the same time it is to be confessed that in a majority of cases the moral authority of the Congress is felt and accepted by the people.
('52', 435, 1, 14, 763159) Lastly, I entirely endorse your remark that “it is most undesi rable that there should be any ground for misunderstanding as to the attitude of the Congress in this matter.” And I assure you that mem bers of the Working Committee are most anxious to avoid any mis understanding, their desire being, for the good name of the Congress
('52', 436, 0, 1, 763492) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 437
('52', 436, 1, 2, 763534) if for nothing else, to be meticulous in the performance of all the obligations undertaken on behalf of the Congress in the Delhi Settlement.
('52', 436, 1, 3, 763676) Yours sincerely,
('52', 436, 2, 4, 763693) M. K. GANDHI
('52', 436, 3, 5, 763706) Home Department, Political, File No.
('52', 436, 3, 6, 763743) 33/6,1931. Courtesy: National Archives of India.

('52', 448, 3, 4, 781183) LETTER FROM H. W. EMERSON 1
('52', 448, 5, 5, 781211) April 30, 1931
('52', 448, 6, 6, 781226) MY DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('52', 448, 7, 7, 781246) You will remember that, when I last saw you in Bombay, I promised to write to
('52', 448, 8, 8, 781324) His Excellency Sir Malcolm Hailey with the object of arranging for you to have an
('52', 448, 9, 9, 781406) interview with him.
('52', 448, 9, 10, 781426) I wrote to him the next day and have just received a letter from
('52', 448, 10, 11, 781491) He has been unable to reply before, because he has been busy in studying the
('52', 448, 11, 12, 781568) revenue and rent position.
('52', 448, 11, 13, 781595) He feels that is is no use discussing the matter with you
('52', 448, 12, 14, 781653) until he is fully informed of the facts and is clear in his own mind what relief is
('52', 448, 13, 15, 781737) necessary.
('52', 448, 13, 16, 781748) In other words, he wants to be quite sure that any assurance he may give
('52', 448, 14, 17, 781821) you will cover the case.
('52', 448, 14, 18, 781846) At present, reports from all districts have not come in; but Sir
('52', 448, 15, 19, 781911) Malcolm Hailey hopes to be fully acquainted with the situation within a week and in a
('52', 448, 16, 20, 781997) position to discuss it.
('52', 448, 16, 21, 782021) I will let you know when I hear further from him.
('52', 448, 17, 22, 782071) 2. I am sorry to see in the papers that you have not been fit, and I hope the
('52', 448, 18, 23, 782149) reports were not true, or, if they were true, that you are now alright again.
('52', 448, 19, 24, 782227) Yours sincerely,
('52', 448, 20, 25, 782244) H. W. EMERSON M. K. GANDHI, ESQ.
('52', 448, 20, 26, 782277) AHMEDABAD
('52', 448, 21, 27, 782287) Home Department, Political, File No.

('52', 449, 0, 1, 782424) 450 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 449, 1, 2, 782466) APPENDIX II
('52', 449, 2, 3, 782478) NOTE BY H. W. EMERSON ON INTERVIEW BETWEEN HIMSELF AND GANDHIJI1
('52', 449, 3, 4, 782543) Confidential
('52', 449, 4, 5, 782556) I had prolonged discussions with Mr. Gandhi on the 13th, 14th, 15th and 16th of May on matters arising out of the Settlement, also incidentally on general questions.
('52', 449, 5, 6, 782722) 2. The first subject of importance discussed was the situation in Gujarat.
('52', 449, 5, 7, 782797) Particular matters raised were the followings :
('52', 449, 6, 8, 782845) (a) Mr. Gandhi said that in the Kaira District, and particularly in the Borsad Taluka, matters were on the whole proceeding very satisfactorily owing to the system of co operation between himself and Mr. Perry, the Collector.
('52', 449, 6, 9, 783071) He said that the people were paying land revenue as quickly as they could and that he was satisfying himself by personal enquiry into cases that they were paying as much as their circumstances would permit.
('52', 449, 6, 10, 783278) He was worried about the question of unauthorized arrears.
('52', 449, 6, 11, 783337) He said that it was common ground that those who could pay the current demand and arrears should pay; but there would be undoubtedly numerous cases in which revenue payers were able to pay the current ones, but would not be able to pay arrears; that what he would like was a declaration of announcement from the local Government of a general character that in such cases the arrears would be automatically suspended.
('52', 449, 6, 12, 783754) He argued that when the arrears of those who had not joined the Civil Disobedience Movement had been suspended and so had become authorized arrears, there was a stronger reason for suspending the arrears of those who had suffered a great deal from the Civil Disobedience Movement and were, therefore, prima facie in a worse position to pay.
('52', 449, 7, 13, 784095) I said that, so far as I understood the case, there had been no general suspension of the demand in cases of those who had not joined the Civil Disobedience Movement, but that in accordance with the ordinary system of land revenue administration certain arrears had been suspended where there was sufficient reason.
('52', 449, 7, 14, 784411) It could not be assumed that because people had joined in the civil disobedience movement, they were, therefore, less able to pay than people who had not joined in it.
('52', 449, 7, 15, 784579) Of those who had joined many had not suffered serious loss, a good number had suffered no loss at all, and in any case the test was not the losses they had suffered, but their present capacity to pay.
('52', 449, 7, 16, 784780) I did not, therefore, see how a general order could be issued.
('52', 449, 7, 17, 784843) He then said that many revenue payers were paying money representing the current demand and, in some cases, also part of the arrears, on the understanding that this represented all that they could pay at present, and that the balance of the arrears would be suspended, that Government officers were taking these sums, knowing what the intentions of the
('52', 449, 8, 18, 785196) 1 Vide “Interview to the Press”, 15 5 1931
('52', 450, 0, 1, 785239) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 451
('52', 450, 1, 2, 785281) people were and that a very difficult situation would arise if later coercive processes were issued for the balance.
('52', 450, 1, 3, 785398) I said that it would clearly not be possible for Government to accept the position that the tax payers should determine what amount of Government dues should be paid.
('52', 450, 1, 4, 785565) He admitted this as a general proposition, but said that where, as at present in Kaira, he himself and other Congress workers in pursuance of the Settlement were satisfying themselves that people were paying as much as they could pay, the position was different, and that they became more or less involved in the transaction.
('52', 450, 1, 5, 785891) I suggested to him that all Congress workers in Gujarat were inspired by the same honesty of purpose as he himself, and that for this reason also the Collector had to satisfy himself that there was a case for suspension, that my information was that in some parts of Gujarat revenue payers were being encouraged not to pay unauthorized arrears, although many of them were able to do so.
('52', 450, 1, 6, 786278) I assumed generally that neither the local Government nor the local officers desire to squeeze money out of persons who could not pay and that it really resolved itself into a question of good faith.
('52', 450, 1, 7, 786478) If the Congress and the people genuinely played up and paid all they could pay, then I imagined nobody would wish to resort to coercive processes.
('52', 450, 1, 8, 786625) If, on the other hand, they did not play up, I did not see how coercive processes would be avoided.
('52', 450, 1, 9, 786725) At any rate it was not necessary to take this particular fence at the present time, and it would be sufficient to consider any difficulty, if and when it arises.
('52', 450, 2, 10, 786887) My general impression about this part of the conversation was that Mr. Gandhi foresees trouble in regard to the collection of unauthorized arrears, and that while he is playing the game in Borsad, attempts are being made elsewhere to defer the payment of unauthorized arrears on a large scale under the cover of inability to pay.
('52', 450, 2, 11, 787217) The nature of the difficulty that is likely to arise will depend on the extent to which this movement succeeds, but if complications are to be avoided, it will probably be necessary for the local officers not to press collection of unauthorized arrears in cases where there will be real difficulty in paying.
('52', 450, 2, 12, 787526) (b) We had a long talk about the reinstatement of village officials.
('52', 450, 2, 13, 787595) Mr. Gandhi made the point that no new Patels had been appointed permanently in the sense that they had been appointed for life and that the appointments were for a term of years, e.g., 3, 5, or 10 years, and that even these were subject to further notice.
('52', 450, 2, 14, 787851) He contended that such appointments could not be treated as permanent and that they were not, therefore, completely protected under para 19 of the Statement of the 5th of March.
('52', 450, 2, 15, 788029) I told him that I understood that this particular system of appointment was usual and that it was not the practice in Gujarat even if normal times to appoint Patels permanently in the sense in which he used the word.
('52', 450, 2, 16, 788246) The local Government take the view that “permanently” means substantively and that this was at least a reasonable interpretation.
('52', 450, 2, 17, 788376) Personally I did not press this, because I knew that when this clause was under discussion in New Delhi, neither Lord Irwin nor Mr. Gandhi was aware of
('52', 451, 0, 1, 788528) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 451, 1, 2, 788570) the fact that the appointments made had been of this character, and the impression was that they were either of a permanent or purely temporary character.
('52', 451, 1, 3, 788725) The actual wording of the clause did not, however, affect the broad principle which underlay this and similar provisions.
('52', 451, 1, 4, 788847) That principle was that where third party rights had been created, the local Government were under an obligation to protect the rights and this principle obviously applied to appointments for a term of years.
('52', 451, 1, 5, 789056) It might be contended that when the third party rights so created had been satisfied, then effect should be given to the Settlement and return should be made to the status quo ante;
('52', 451, 2, 6, 789238) instance at the end of an appointment of three years the claims of the original holder, if in the meantime there was no cause of disqualification against him, might be given preferential treatment.
('52', 451, 2, 7, 789436) This seemed to be a view of the case which the local Government might be inclined to take, but I could not commit them in any way.
('52', 451, 2, 8, 789567) Mr. Gandhi was not very satisfied with this, but felt, I think, that he was not in a strong position.
('52', 451, 3, 9, 789669) He then pursued another line, namely, that it was generally recognized that the new men who had been put in were unable to carry on the work, that in many cases they were criminals or of bad character, that in fact they were unable to collect the land revenue and it was the resigned Patel who had been doing this work; that there could be no peace in a village where a new Patel had been appointed until he was removed from it; and that in the interest of good administration a remedy should be found either by compensating the new Patels or by finding them jobs elsewhere.
('52', 451, 3, 10, 790244) I said that, so far as I knew, the local officers were quite prepared to enquire into bonafide complaints against particular Patels, but they of course had to protect them
('52', 451, 4, 11, 790416) against frivolous complaints; that the third party right in such cases was the right to a particular appointment; and that com pensation would not be regarded by the Patels themselves as a satisfaction of those rights.
('52', 451, 4, 12, 790635) Something might perhaps be done to ease what was admittedly a difficult problem by putting in Patels who had resigned in vacancies elsewhere as they occur; but I did not know whether this was, in fact, practicable.
('52', 451, 4, 13, 790850) This question evidently is also causing him a good deal of concern.
('52', 451, 5, 14, 790918) (c) In regard to the repurchase of lands that had been sold, he appeared to be fairly happy.
('52', 451, 5, 15, 791011) He was very critical of the difficulties experienced in ascertaining what lands had been sold and at what price; but he admitted that the present arrangement under which the entries relating to all such transactions have been or will shortly be entered up in the village registers, to which the public have access, would meet the requirements of the case.
('52', 451, 5, 16, 791367) He said that he was having more success in getting back lands from Dharalas than he had anticipated, and in fact he was getting on better with them than with others in regard to whom he had not expected so much difficulty.
('52', 451, 5, 17, 791590) I asked him why Garda had repudiated his transaction.
('52', 451, 5, 18, 791644) He would not admit that Garda had any reasonable cause for complaint against the Congress for any deviation from their side of the bargain and said he was in correspondence with Sir Cowasjee
('52', 452, 0, 1, 791835) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 453
('52', 452, 1, 2, 791877) Jehangir.
('52', 452, 2, 3, 791887) He said that in some cases in the Kaira District land had been forfeited for arrears of land revenue, had then been declared to be Government property and had been sold, that none of the sale price had been credited to the account of the defaulter, and that, in fact, the amount in regard to which the land had been forfeited was still being demanded.
('52', 452, 2, 4, 792239) I expressed doubts about this, although I did understand that where land had been forfeited the whole of the sale price had been credited to Government, even although this exceeded the amount of the demand.
('52', 452, 2, 5, 792446) I gathered that the Collector of Kaira had referred this question to the local Government and they will doubtless consider, if cases, such as stated by mr.
('52', 452, 2, 6, 792602) Gandhi, have actually occurred, whether the collection of the demand in addition to forfeiture of the land is not unduly severe.
('52', 452, 3, 7, 792731) On the whole Mr. Gandhi was more happy about Gujarat than he was when I last saw him, and the situation there has undoubtedly improved.
('52', 452, 3, 8, 792867) He himself appears to have worked very hard to get things cleared up, but there appear to be several troublesome matters ahead and these may create difficulties, especially where Gandhi has not tried his hand and Vallabhbhai’s influence has been at work.
('52', 452, 4, 9, 793122) I may observe that during the course of the discussion about Gujarat and also on one or two other occasions Mr. Gandhi dropped the claim, if he ever seriously entertained it, that Congress should be recognized as an intermediary between Government and the people, although he did claim, and not without reason, that where, as in the case of Kaira, the local officers are co operating with himself and other workers, action should be avoided which will embarrass him and his helpers, unless it is clear that they are not playing the game.
('52', 452, 4, 10, 793660) I tackled him about the statements attributed to him in the Press that he had advised revenue payers not to pay land revenue if they had to borrow to do so on interest.
('52', 452, 4, 11, 793829) I told him that this was a principle that Govern ment could not accept, that it was a well known fact that revenue payers had often to borrow money in order to meet their revenue demands, and that if I had credit at the Bank, my creditors would not let me off, because I had no ready cash.
('52', 452, 4, 12, 794119) He admitted that in ordinary circumstances his advice was not justifiable, but on the merits of this particular case he eliminated further argument by saying that in Kaira, where the advice was given, the Collector had accepted the principle as a working basis.
('52', 452, 5, 13, 794381) 3. We then had some discussion about salt, which was resumed later in connection with a reference from the Central Board of Revenue.
('52', 452, 5, 14, 794514) The main points, which were raised, were the following :
('52', 452, 6, 15, 794571) (a) Mr. Gandhi is anxious that Government should issue some communication amplifying the relevant clause of the Statement of March 5th, so that persons entitled to the concession will know more about its character.
('52', 452, 6, 16, 794786) I showed him the lengthy and detailed circulars issued by the Central Board of Revenue for various
('52', 453, 0, 1, 794885) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 453, 1, 2, 794927) areas, and explained to him, what I understand to be the view of the Central Board of Revenue, namely, that while these were necessary for departmental guidance, they were too complicated to be of real assistance to the public, that in fact specific difficulties were still continually cropping up, that these were being dealt with ad hoc in a liberal and practical spirit, and that until the various points had been settled the publication of a detailed statement would in any case be premature.
('52', 453, 1, 3, 795424) Moreover, anything in the nature of a lengthy statement would probably give rise to questions of hypothetical character, which it was better not to raise.
('52', 453, 1, 4, 795579) Mr. Gandhi accepted all this and said that he had not intended anything in the nature of a long statement, but that he felt it very desirable that the main principles should be published.
('52', 453, 1, 5, 795767) I suggested that he should try his hand on a draft and Government would then see whether it could be accepted by them with such modifications as might be necessary.
('52', 453, 1, 6, 795932) He promised to let me have one.
('52', 453, 2, 7, 795964) (b) He then got on to the question of the fish curing industry.
('52', 453, 2, 8, 796028) I told him that I understood that this matter was already under consideration by the Central Board of Revenue, who had addressed the Madras Government.
('52', 453, 2, 9, 796180) Briefly the points which he made were the followings :—
('52', 453, 3, 10, 796236) (i) Fishermen along the East and West Coast already enjoy the concession of duty free salt.
('52', 453, 4, 11, 796328) (ii) On the West Coast, where fish curing is carried on by contractors in special yards, salt has to be purchased from Government.
('52', 453, 4, 12, 796459) Mr. Gandhi agreed that this was quite right and that the salt concession should not be extended to the fish curing industry when the curing is done on a big scale by contractors.
('52', 453, 5, 13, 796638) (iii) He said, however, that even on the West Coast there was a certain amount of curing done by fishermen in their own homes, that it was carried on as a domestic and not as a big scale industry, and that it was reasonable to allow the concession in such cases.
('52', 453, 6, 14, 796901) I declined to express any opinion in ignorance of the facts, but promised to let the C.B.R. know the gist of the Conversation.
('52', 453, 7, 15, 797028) (c) I then mentioned to him the case reported by the Collector of Salt Revenue, Bombay, in which it was said that Congress workers were making salt in works situated on privately owned land at Shiroda, that there was a fairly large force of labour employed, and that a stock of salt of 500 to 600 maunds was being collected.
('52', 453, 7, 16, 797353) We were agreed that the salt concession did not anticipate that Congress would come in as an organization engaged in the manufacture of salt, and he admitted that an impossible situation would arise if local Congress organizations as such took up the manufacture of salt even for the purpose included in the Settlement.
('52', 453, 7, 17, 797673) He also admitted that if salt is being manufactured at Shiroda by paid labour, then this is not covered by the Settlement, but he claimed that if the villagers entitled to the
('52', 454, 0, 1, 797849) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 455
('52', 454, 1, 2, 797891) concession had combined for the manufacture of salt and were making it themselves and not through paid labour, then the case was covered by the Settlement provided the relevant provisions of the Settlement were observed.
('52', 454, 1, 3, 798112) He also claimed that the mere manufacture of a stock of 500 or 600 maunds did not necessarily constitute a breach, since it was natural that the people concerned should manufacture a sufficient quantity of salt to see them over the close period.
('52', 454, 1, 4, 798358) He claimed to be acquainted with the facts of the manufacture at Shiroda, and the C.B.R. may find it necessary to collect further information in regard to them before they can reach a decision.
('52', 454, 1, 5, 798552) If it is decided that the facts do not preclude this system of manufacture, then a practical solution may be to limit the quantity of salt to be manufactured in accordance with an estimate of local requirements.
('52', 454, 2, 6, 798764) (d) Mr. Gandhi agreed that the practical test of removal on foot should not include the removal of manufactured salt by gangs of coolies.
('52', 454, 3, 7, 798902) 4. Mr. Gandhi then mentioned the matter of releases of prisoners, about which we had a general and somewhat infructuous talk.
('52', 454, 3, 8, 799028) He still seems to think that there are cases which come within the amnesty in which releases have not been granted, and he promised to let me have lists of these.
('52', 454, 3, 9, 799191) I told him that we had sent the previous lists to local Governments, and the replies we had so far received definitely indicated that local Governments had very scrupulously honoured the Settlement in this respect.
('52', 454, 3, 10, 799406) I mentioned the case of the Punjab list in which, for lack of accurate information, the local Government had been unable to identify a number of prisoners mentioned, and of the 75 who had been identified 47 had been released before the list was sent.
('52', 454, 3, 11, 799657) This went to show that the information supplied to Mr. Gandhi was inaccurate.
('52', 454, 3, 12, 799735) I also reminded him that local Governments generally have interpreted the Settlement very liberally in cases of technical violence and that while they have been more strict in cases of incitement to violence, there are good reasons for this.
('52', 454, 3, 13, 799977) I took the opportunity of reminding him that within the last three weeks there have been three incidents connected with the terrorist movement in the Punjab alone, namely, the Shalimar affair, the Sialkot incident and the very recent bomb explosion in the Jullundur District.
('52', 454, 3, 14, 800253) He had not heard of the last and was shocked to hear that the two persons concerned were connected with the Congress.
('52', 454, 3, 15, 800371) He agreed that local Governments were justified in taking a serious view of incitement to violence, and he did not attempt to raise the question of cases under section 124 A., I.P.C., and section 108, Criminal Procedure Code, which at one time threatened to be a matter of controversy.
('52', 454, 3, 16, 800657) Two cases appeared to be worrying him.
('52', 454, 3, 17, 800696) One was the case of an editor 1
('52', 454, 4, 18, 800728) convicted in Sholapur, in regard to which he urges that there was neither violence nor incitement to violence, and the second case was one from the Surat District, where a youth had been convicted for arson.
('52', 454, 4, 19, 800936) His crop had been attached, and he then set fire to
('52', 454, 5, 20, 800988) 1 Emerson has made a note here : “He has since been released.”
('52', 455, 0, 1, 801051) 456 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 455, 1, 2, 801093) Mr. Gandhi then attempted to argue that violence within the terms of the Settlement had reference only to violence to person and that, therefore, this particular incident was not violence.
('52', 455, 1, 3, 801282) This of course could not be accepted.
('52', 455, 1, 4, 801320) I understood that he was in correspondence in regard to both cases with the local Government.
('52', 455, 2, 5, 801414) He wanted to know what was to happen if there were a deadlock between Congress and the local Government in regard to particular cases.
('52', 455, 2, 6, 801549) I said that the intention was that the local Government should be the final authority, that so far no such case has arisen, and we might wait and see.
('52', 455, 2, 7, 801700) The Government of India had in the case of several representations made to them requested local Governments to inform them of the facts, and since neither the Government of India nor any local Government has any desire to evade the obligations of the Settlement, there is no reason to suppose that a solution will not be found if there is any particular case in which there has been a genuine mistake.
('52', 455, 2, 8, 802102) I informed him that local Governments had attached very great importance to this part of the Settlement and that in some province the Governor had himself scrutinized all doubtful cases.
('52', 455, 2, 9, 802289) I imagine that Mr. Gandhi is being given a good deal of trouble by provincial Congressmen in this matter.
('52', 455, 3, 10, 802395) 5. We then had a humorous discussion about bicycles and a motor car which led up to the case of the Young India Press.
('52', 455, 4, 11, 802514) Under clause 16 of the Statement Government have agreed to return movable property, not being an illegal possession, which was seized during the civil disobedience movement and which at the time of the Settlement was still in the possession of Government.
('52', 455, 4, 12, 802770) A motor car was seized in the Kaira District and was quite properly used for official purposes.
('52', 455, 4, 13, 802866) It is now, I gathered, in a somewhat dilapidated condition and is out of action at some distance from its original home.
('52', 455, 4, 14, 802987) Mr. Gandhi claims that it should be returned at the place where it was seized.
('52', 455, 4, 15, 803066) The local officers will not admit this, and I gather that they cannot, in any case, return it there, either by putting it into running condition or transporting it as scrap iron.

('52', 455, 4, 17, 803338) This was
('52', 455, 5, 18, 803347) seized in Ahmedabad under the Press Ordinance and is of considerable value.
('52', 455, 5, 19, 803423) Part of it is still in Ahmedabad, while part of it was sent to Bombay for sale.
('52', 455, 5, 20, 803503) Mr. Gandhi claims as a right that he is entitled to its delivery at Ahmedabad, and he has recently addressed the Bombay Government on the subject.
('52', 455, 5, 21, 803650) He made it clear that he did not want the Bombay portion of the press returned to him at Ahmedabad as a matter of grace, if he was not entitled to this under the Settlement.
('52', 455, 5, 22, 803824) I promised that we would look into the legal aspect of the case, and if necessary, address the local Government.
('52', 455, 5, 23, 803937) 1 He on his part promised that if the decision is in his favour he will not use it for vexatious purposes, e.g., the return of a useless motor car.

('52', 456, 0, 1, 804151) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 457
('52', 456, 1, 2, 804193) 6. Under the same clause of the Settlement he raised the question of the return of arms, the licences of which had been cancelled in connection with the Civil Disobedience Movement.
('52', 456, 1, 3, 804375) He had mentioned this before at previous talks, but I had not appreciated the fact that the claim was under the clause, and had imagined that what he desired was a more liberal policy within the spirit of the Settlement in re granting licences when previous ones had been cancelled.
('52', 456, 1, 4, 804658) I told him that, so far as the clause was concerned it seemed to me that as soon as an arms’ licence was cancelled, the arm became an illegal possession and that, therefore, the case was not covered.
('52', 456, 1, 5, 804858) In any case, even if the clause did technically apply, local Governments would obviously be unwilling to return arms where there was reason to suppose that these arms might be used for terrorist purposes, and this applied particularly to the Punjab and Bangal.
('52', 456, 1, 6, 805119) Mr. Gandhi accepted this as reasonable and said that a way out of the difficulty might be found by formally returning the arms, cancelling the new licences and recovering them.
('52', 456, 1, 7, 805296) I suggested that this would lead to a good deal of friction.
('52', 456, 1, 8, 805357) I promised to have the legal aspect examined.
('52', 456, 2, 9, 805403) I explained that if the matter did not come within the scope of the Settlement, there were difficulties in addressing local Governments in regard to the re grant of licences, that the Arms Rules gave wide discretionary powers to District Magistrates in regard to the grant and cancellation of licences, and that while it did not seem improvable that they would take a reasonable view in the case of licences cancelled during the civil disobedience movement when the licensees were responsible persons, they would be sticky before giving licences to persons about whom they were not satisfied.
('52', 456, 3, 10, 805996) 7. He then mentioned the case of restoration of pensions forfeited during the Civil Disobdience Movement.
('52', 456, 3, 11, 806102) I said that this had not been discussed with local Governments; previous to the Settlement and that they and the Army Department in the case of military pensions would certainly take strong exception to the restoration of military and police pensions, and that, this being so, it would be difficult for them to discriminate in favour of other civil pensions.
('52', 456, 3, 12, 806461) Local Governments would, however, doubtless consider in the ordinary course of business any applications made to them, but I did not see how the Government of India could make any general suggestion to them on this matter.
('52', 456, 3, 13, 806684) Mr. Gandhi recognized the difficulty of restoring military and police pensions and did not press the matter.
('52', 456, 4, 14, 806793) 8. Mr. Gandhi mentioned the case of boys and students who had been expelled from educational institutions on account of participation in the Civil Disobedience Movement.
('52', 456, 4, 15, 806963) He said that in several provinces they were being allowed to return only on condition that they gave a declaration that they would take no part in politics.
('52', 456, 4, 16, 807120) He seemed to think this was wrong.
('52', 456, 4, 17, 807155) I explained to him that in some Government’s institutions in the Pubjab (and probably else where) such declarations were taken from students on first entry—let alone from students who were allowed re 
('52', 457, 0, 1, 807356) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 457, 1, 2, 807398) admission after expulsion; that the latter were fortunate to be allowed to return and knowing the importance that local Government rightly attached to discipline in schools and colleges.
('52', 457, 1, 3, 807585) I saw no point in raising this matter with them, even if the Government of India were prepared to take a more lenient view which I did not think they would.
('52', 457, 2, 4, 807742) 9. We next got on to the important question of the North West Frontier Province.
('52', 457, 2, 5, 807823) I had a preliminary talk with hin on one matter, giving him the main facts as known to us, and Mr. Howell later joined us and explained the peculiar difficulties of the Frontier situation.
('52', 457, 2, 6, 808012) The points on which I laid emphasis in the preliminary discussion were :
('52', 457, 3, 7, 808085) (1) Abdul Ghaffar’s activities and speeches since the amnesty.
('52', 457, 4, 8, 808148) (2) His continued insistence on the Settlement being a truce and therefore a period of preparation.
('52', 457, 5, 9, 808248) (3) The continuous recruitment of Red Shirts, their organization, drilling, etc.
('52', 457, 6, 10, 808329) (4) Abdul Ghaffar’s attempt to spread agitation across the border.
('52', 457, 7, 11, 808396) (5) His deliberate and discourteous refusal to see the Chief Commissioner or
('52', 457, 8, 12, 808473) local officials.
('52', 457, 9, 13, 808490) (6) The encouragement he has given to the non payment of land revenue and the consequent effects on the land revenue administration of the Peshawar District.
('52', 457, 10, 14, 808648) (7) The increase in crime that has occurred there.
('52', 457, 11, 15, 808699) I suggested to Mr. Gandhi that even in other provinces where we might tolerate and had, in fact, tolerated in the past the recruitment of Congress volunteers up to a certain point, we could not even in those provinces tolerate either the unlimited recruitment of volunteers or the establishment of bodies of trained volunteers.
('52', 457, 11, 16, 809027) The fact that their immediate activities were comparatively harmless was not a decisive test.
('52', 457, 11, 17, 809121) We had to look to the use to which they might be put, and if at any time we came to the conclusion that they constituted a serious menace to future peace, we might have to take action.
('52', 457, 11, 18, 809306) At any rate, we obviously could not accept the argument that because we do not think it necessary at present to take action against Congress volunteers in a particular province, therefore our hands are tied either in regard to volunteers generally or in regard to volunteers in places where they do constitute a menace; nor, having regard to the peculiar conditions in the North West Frontier Province the obvious danger of the Red Shirt Movement being misunderstood in tribal territory and its possible effects in Afghanistan, could we regard its extension with equanimity.
('52', 457, 11, 19, 809881) Mr. Gandhi appreciated these peculiar difficulties, but was inclined to attach weight to Abdul Ghaffar’s own statement of the case, which appeared in the Press a few days ago and in which he naturally attempted
('52', 458, 0, 1, 810092) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 459
('52', 458, 1, 2, 810134) to place the odium on the local administration.
('52', 458, 2, 3, 810182) The further discussion of the matter is given in Mr. Howell’s note below :
('52', 458, 3, 4, 810257) “By arrangement with Mr. Emerson I went yesterday afternoon to interview Mr. Gandhi.
('52', 458, 3, 5, 810342) Before I arrived Mr. Emerson had already dissuaded Mr. Gandhi from his intention of visiting the North West Frontier Province and had secured from him a promise to get into touch either personally or by letter with Abdul Ghaffar Khan and induce the latter at least to examine and reconsider his methods if not to abandon, at any rate temporarily, his campaign.
('52', 458, 3, 6, 810703) There was therefore very little for me to do except to go over the ground again, and this I did with the special idea of impressing upon Mr. Gandhi the dangers of Abdul Ghaffar Khan’s programme in the Frontier Province.
('52', 458, 3, 7, 810923) The gist of what Mr. Emerson and I said to him in the course of the interview was as follows :
('52', 458, 4, 8, 811018) We had no intention of questioning Abdul Ghaffar Khan’s sincerity, but we did think the wisdom of his procedure open to question.
('52', 458, 4, 9, 811148) Why for instance had he steadily refused to have an interview with the Chief Commissioner who had shown exemplary patience and had done his best to get into contact with him?
('52', 458, 4, 10, 811323) If they were bound to fall out at a later stage, was that any reason for not walking together so far as their ways lay together?
('52', 458, 4, 11, 811452) Again was it wise to stage an exciting drama in the presence of an exceedingly excitable audience, such as the frontier tribes, all of them well armed, and many of them only waiting for a favourable opportunity to go and loot the box office?
('52', 458, 4, 12, 811694) If Mr. Gandhi thought this was prudent, let him listen to what Bhai Parmanand and other Frontier Hindus, who had reason to know what they were talking about, had recently been saying at Lahore.
('52', 458, 4, 13, 811888) The basic fact of the situation was that, as these frontier Hindus realize, security for life and property on the Frontier, especially Hindu life and property, and the whole stability of society depended on the maintenance of respect for the existing Government.
('52', 458, 4, 14, 812151) And if the Frontier tribes, who were never tired of proclaiming themselves to be as good as or better than anybody else, saw Abdul Ghaffar Khan here, or X there, or Y in another place successfully defying Government, they too might be tempted to take a hand in the same game.
('52', 458, 4, 15, 812427) Hence the paramount importance of preventing the Red Shirts Movement from being spread across the border.
('52', 458, 4, 16, 812533) Once there it could not fail to take on a militant form and, as last summer in Waziristan, might assume the appearance of a pro Amanullah campaign which would cause anxiety to King Nadir.
('52', 458, 5, 17, 812721) Throughout stress was laid not on the contention that tribal territory was beyond the scope of the Civil Disobedience Movement, since that is dead or at any rate dormant, or of the Irwin Gandhi Pact, since that might give Mr. Gandhi a clue that in the event of a further struggle he would do well to make a point of extending activities into tribal territory, that being a weak spot on our side, but on the danger, especially the danger to Hindu life and property, to which opposition to Government
('52', 459, 0, 1, 813220) 460 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 459, 1, 2, 813262) in the Frontier region was likely to lead.
('52', 459, 1, 3, 813305) He was asked whether in his opinion it was wise for anyone conducting a difficult and an unprecedented experiment, such as is now in progress throughout India, to begin by tampering with the breakwater which keeps the flood waters out.
('52', 459, 1, 4, 813541) Mr. Gandhi seemed to grasp the point of this question.
('52', 459, 2, 5, 813596) We also put Sir Steuart Pears’ remaining points to Mr. Gandhi, and asked him to consider whether there really could be any use for such a body of men as 13,000, the latest figure we had had—admittedly only an estimate— of the number of Red Shirts.
('52', 459, 2, 6, 813844) Finally the revenue situation, with special reference to Peshawar District, was discussed at some length, and Mr. Gandhi was informed of the startling rise in the figures of crime.
('52', 459, 2, 7, 814025) He wished to know how land and water rates compared in Peshawar with the adjoining districts in the Punjab and seemed surprised to learn that, while agricultural conditions in the irrigated area of the Peshawar District generally compared favourably with anything in northern India, rates of land revenue and water rates were distinctly lower than in the adjoining districts of the Punjab.
('52', 459, 2, 8, 814415) This Mr. Gandhi’s interlocutors thought might be taken as fair evidence of the constant Pathan tendency to have things both ways at which the Pathan is an adept and frequently successful.
('52', 459, 2, 9, 814603) Mr. Gandhi took note of this and also of the fact that liberal remissions had been, were being and would be granted according to the necessities of the case.
('52', 459, 2, 10, 814761) He seemed disposed to agree that whatever the land revenue policy of the future Government might be, it was perhaps bad tactics to interfere too much with revenue collection under the existing regime.
('52', 459, 2, 11, 814962) On Mr. Gandhi’s side a promise was given that he would send for Abdul Ghaffar Khan as soon as possible, and in the meantime would both telegraph and write to him.”
('52', 459, 3, 12, 815126) 10. We had some talk about the boycott and the attitude of Lancashire.
('52', 459, 3, 13, 815197) Mr. Gandhi was more sorrowful than resentful about the latter.
('52', 459, 3, 14, 815260) He claimed that the Settlement had produced a great change in the position regarding the boycott of foreign cloth, that there had been a very large reduction in picketing, that discrimination against British cloth had ceased and that while there were still causes of complaint these should be regarded in the light of the situation as a whole and not advanced as though they represented the general position.
('52', 459, 3, 15, 815669) He claimed (and I believe rightly) that he was doing his utmost to secure the strict observance of the Settlement and he asked that any breaches of it should be at once brought to his notice.
('52', 459, 4, 16, 815861) I admitted the truth of a great deal of what he said; but gave him a number of illustrations of the sort of thing that was going on, and in particular, dwelt on the prevalence of social pressure.
('52', 459, 4, 17, 816057) I said that the general impression was that freedom of action of the individual has not been secured and that it was this belief that was responsible for reactions in Lancashire, which were of first class political importance in England.
('52', 459, 4, 18, 816295) I emphasized the harm that was being done by every instance of violation of the Settlement that was communicated to the British Press and I dwelt
('52', 460, 0, 1, 816441) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 461
('52', 460, 1, 2, 816483) at length on a particular case that had come to the notice of Government.
('52', 460, 1, 3, 816557) This case is briefly as follows : “The British Goods Boycott Committee of Ahmedabad sent a letter, dated the 7th of April 1931, to the Cawnpore Chemical Works, Cawnpore, asking them various questions, among which were the following : (a) Do you use any British materials in the process of manufacture?
('52', 460, 1, 4, 816859) (b) Has any Englishman or foreigner any interest whatever, either direct or indirect, in your concern?
('52', 460, 1, 5, 816962) If so, what is the extent of such interest?
('52', 460, 1, 6, 817006) Mr. Gavin Jones is very closely interested in this concern and sent the letter on to us.
('52', 460, 1, 7, 817095) We had enquiries made about it and were informed that the active workers on the Committee were members of the Congress.
('52', 460, 1, 8, 817215) After the Settlement the Committee changed its name, but apparently sent out notices on the note paper with the old heading and also included in their questions matters which directly offended against the Settlement.” I told Mr. Gandhi that in this particular case the attack was on the concern of an Englishman, who was a member of the Round Table Conference Delegation and who had strongly supported the Indian case in London.
('52', 460, 1, 9, 817644) It would hardly be a matter of surprise if activities of this kind were to make Europpeans doubtful of their previous attitude and that if this particular instance were communicated to the British Press or raised in Parliament, it could not fail to have very unfortunate results.
('52', 460, 1, 10, 817924) Mr. Gandhi admitted all this and expressed regret that the matter had not been brought to his notice even once.
('52', 460, 1, 11, 818036) I said that we could not do this until we knew that Congress were concerned in it and we had just received this information.
('52', 460, 1, 12, 818161) I promised to let him have a copy of the relevant correspondence, and he said he would have the matter put right at once and let me know the results in a letter which Government could, if they thought it desirable, communicate to Mr. Gavin Jones.
('52', 460, 1, 13, 818408) Mr. Gandhi is, I think, uneasy about the fulfilment of the boycott provi sions of the Settlement, and while he is as keen as ever on the replacement of Indian for foreign cloth and is convinced that the movement has come to stay, he realizes that methods of coercion and pressure will not succeed in the long run and that any abuse of the Settlement has adverse effects in India and in England out of proportion to the benefit to the movement itself.
('52', 460, 1, 14, 818859) He has, however, still to get his own principles across to Congress organizations and workers as a whole and although he has done a good deal in this direction, there is still much more to do.
('52', 460, 1, 15, 819052) It will help if local Government either directly tackle provincial Congress organizations in regard to violation of the Settlement in this respect or communicate at once specific instances to the Home Department to pass them on to Mr. Gandhi.
('52', 460, 2, 16, 819295) 11. During the course of our talk with Mr. Gandhi a number of general questions were incidentally discussed, and one sitting was almost entirely devoted to big issues.
('52', 460, 2, 17, 819463) An attempt is made below to summarize the points which arose.
('52', 461, 0, 1, 819525) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 461, 1, 2, 819567) Mr. Gandhi appears to have little hope at present of an early communal settlement and realizes the bitterness of feeling.
('52', 461, 1, 3, 819689) He expressed himself as reluctant to go to England unless a solution is reached, for he would then feel that he could not either with decency or consistency press for self government when Indians them selves were at sixes and sevens.
('52', 461, 1, 4, 819923) He is also sensitive as to taunts being made in this respect.
('52', 461, 1, 5, 819985) I took the following line with him :
('52', 461, 2, 6, 820022) (a) If there were no communal settlement in India, then the logical conclu sion of Mr. Gandhi to this would be that unless and until there were a settlement, there could be no further advance in the constitutional field.
('52', 461, 2, 7, 820243) Even if Mr. Gandhi himself felt this, it was not possible for Government to accept it.
('52', 461, 2, 8, 820330) Government had often been accused of Machiavellian methods, and if it adopted the line taken by Mr. Gandhi himself, there would be an immediate outcry accompanied by political agitation on an intense scale.
('52', 461, 2, 9, 820537) This must, therefore, be ruled out, and Government must assume constitutional advance, even if no agreed communal settlement were reached.
('52', 461, 2, 10, 820676) Why should Mr. Gandhi take in this matter a more reactionary attitude than Government were prepared to take?
('52', 461, 2, 11, 820785) Moreover, even if a settlement were not reached in India, this did not necessarily mean that one would not be reached in England.
('52', 461, 2, 12, 820915) Conditions were in some respects more favourable there than here : representations of various interests would be in constant touch with each other; atmosphere would be better; British leaders were prepared to give the greatest assistance possible and in fact an agreement had almost been reached in London on the last occasion.
('52', 461, 2, 13, 821243) Moreover, Lord Irwin would be certainly ready to help.
('52', 461, 2, 14, 821298) (Here at this point Mr. Gandhi made the suggestion that Lord Irwin might even act as an arbitrator—an admission entirely contrary to some of his previous declarations that Indians should settle among themselves.) A settlement in London was more likely to be secured if Congress were represented and Mr. Gandhi himself might be expected to play a considerable part in it.
('52', 461, 2, 15, 821669) In any case, he would not help by staying in India and, so far as the communal question was concerned, his clear duty was to go to England.
('52', 461, 3, 16, 821809) I asked him what his friends thought about this matter, and I understood that
('52', 461, 4, 17, 821887) while two or three Congressites doubted, the mjority considered that he ought to go.
('52', 461, 5, 18, 821972) Mr. Gandhi did not commit himself to any clear decision as to whether he would go or
('52', 461, 6, 19, 822057) not, but my own very definite impression is that the failure of a communal settlement
('52', 461, 7, 20, 822143) will not in itself prevent his attendance.
('52', 461, 8, 21, 822186) (b) I asked him what he was going to do about Congress representatives at the Conference and suggested that even if he went as the sole representative it would be convenient to have available Congress representatives who could be appointed to Sub Committees, since even a Mahatma could not be in three places at once.
('52', 461, 8, 22, 822504) He was very vague about this part of the business and confessed that he had been so occupied in local affairs in Gujarat that he had not had time to give consideration to the Round
('52', 462, 0, 1, 822685) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 463
('52', 462, 1, 2, 822727) Table Conference arrangements.
('52', 462, 1, 3, 822758) The impression he gave was that he was very reluctant to have anyone else as representing Congress in the picture and that he has an idea that he can carry on alone coming in with his views at the final stage.
('52', 462, 1, 4, 822968) He obviously does not realize the amount of detailed discussion involved and the nature and extent of the difficulties.
('52', 462, 1, 5, 823088) On the other hand, he has no objection to Congressmen being invited in their individual capacity to the Round Table Conference.
('52', 462, 1, 6, 823216) I specifically asked him this on a point raised by His Excellency when I last saw him.
('52', 462, 1, 7, 823303) In fact, he says that Lord Irwin had accepted this position and accordingly had invited Malaviya, and he had indicated his intentions of also asking Mrs.Naidu and Dr. Ansari.
('52', 462, 1, 8, 823478) There would thus be, from Mr. Gandhi’s point of view, no objection in inviting Congress Muslims as such, or indeed in inviting any Congress member in any capacity other than as representative of Congress.
('52', 462, 1, 9, 823683) This may assist in removing difficulties which will almost certainly arise if Mr. Gandhi insists on being the sole representative of the Congress.
('52', 462, 2, 10, 823830) (c) Another constitutional matter that Congress are now taking up is as to whether—
('52', 462, 3, 11, 823914) (a) they should serve on Sub Committee formed previous to the Round Table Conference, and
('52', 462, 4, 12, 824004) (b) whether they should give evidence before such Committee.
('52', 462, 5, 13, 824065) I fancy this question was brought to a head by the resignation of AhmadShah from the North West Frontier Provinces Subjects Committee.
('52', 462, 5, 14, 824200) Mr. Gandhi knew nothing about his appointment or his resignation, and the latter was not, I think, given under the orders of the Congress.
('52', 462, 5, 15, 824339) It was probably given under the orders of Abdul Ghaffar, and I gathered that Mr. Gandhi thought that Ahmad Shah should have referred both his acceptance of the appointment and his resignation to the Congress.
('52', 462, 5, 16, 824548) He agreed that the case had not been in any way prejudged and that Ahmed Shah was wrong in making this the ground for his resignation, but he did not think that anything could now be done to put this right, although I gave him the opportunity of suggesting a successor.
('52', 462, 5, 17, 824818) In these circumstances he agreed that the best thing was to leave the place vacant.
('52', 462, 6, 18, 824902) On the general question the Working Committee are to hold a meeting shortly.
('52', 462, 6, 19, 824979) I very strongly urged that the decision should be in favour of co opera tion both as regards accepting places and giving evidence, and I said on my own authority that I thought there would be no difficulty, if the principle were accepted, in asking Congress to nominate members to Committees where the principle of Congress representation was accepted by Government.
('52', 462, 6, 20, 825346) Mr. Gandhi’s doubt seemed to be as to whether it was right to take part in Committees previous to the Round Table Conference when he had not made up his mind about attendance at the Conference himself.
('52', 462, 6, 21, 825548) I pointed out that whatever might be his final decision in regard to London,
('52', 463, 0, 1, 825625) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 463, 1, 2, 825667) one important and main object of the Settlement would be defeated if Congress did not co operate in constitutional matters, and that, even if for any reason the Settle ment broke down, their present participation would not commit them.
('52', 463, 1, 3, 825903) I am rather afraid that the Working Committee will come to a wrong decision in this matter.
('52', 463, 2, 4, 825995) (d) The question of land revenue cropped up in several connection, e.g., Gujarat, U.P. and North West Frontier Province.
('52', 463, 2, 5, 826116) Mr. Gandhi did not attempt to press the idea formerly favoured by him that Congress should act generally as an intermediary between Government and the revenue payer, but he still seems to think that it is possible for Congress to act as the friend of the landlord or tenant and advise him on revenue and rent matters without coming into conflict with Government or without causing serious embarrassment.
('52', 463, 2, 6, 826520) He was impressed by the attitude I took on the matter.
('52', 463, 2, 7, 826575) I told him that there was no Government in the world that would allow a political organization to come between them and the tax payer, when their intervention took the form of advice to the latter as to what taxes they should pay; that if this was tried in Afghanistan, the agitator would be quickly put against the wall and blown from the cannon; that in the Indian States he would be deported or imprisoned; and that in the most advanced European countries the whole resources of the Government would be used against an organized movement of this kind carried out by a powerful political party.
('52', 463, 2, 8, 827172) In India it was particularly necessary that agitation of this kind should be avoided and the more so in existing economic conditions and immediately after a direct campaign against rent and revenue.
('52', 463, 2, 9, 827371) I made it quite clear that personally I regarded activities, such as those in the U.P. as a very grave breach of the whole spirit of the Settlement.
('52', 463, 2, 10, 827520) I explained that local Governments were fully alive to the gravity of the economic situation and the necessity of being lenient in land revenue policy.
('52', 463, 2, 11, 827672) Even so they had a very difficult task in deciding what the people could pay and could not pay, and this task could only be complicated by the interference of Congress, one result of which was to introduce the doubt as to whether a person was refusing to pay land revenue because he genuinely could not pay or because Congress advice had induced him to try and get off without payment.
('52', 463, 2, 12, 828058) Mr. Gandhi was not able to accept the idea of Congress standing aside from helping persons in distress; but he did, I think, realize some of the difficulties in the way of intervention, and so far as he himself is concerned, he is worried less by the thought that inaction will remove the great opportunity of getting at the rural masses than by the failure to do something for the oppressed.
('52', 463, 2, 13, 828451) We have here a definite potential source of trouble.
('52', 463, 2, 14, 828504) On the other hand, he had no hesitation in condemning pressure being brought on landlords, direct appeals not to pay, creating false expectations on the Congress creed of a 50 per cent reduction in revenue and generally of any refusal to pay less than a person’s capacity to pay.
('52', 463, 2, 15, 828784) The results of his forthcoming discussion with Sir Malcolm Hailey ought to clear up the position in this respect.
('52', 463, 2, 16, 828898) (e) I attempted to give Mr. Gandhi an appreciation of the present situation
('52', 464, 0, 1, 828974) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 465
('52', 464, 1, 2, 829016) in the various provinces and made special reference to the North West Frontier Provinces, Punjab, United Provinces, Bihar and Orissa and Bengal.
('52', 464, 1, 3, 829161) I emphasized the fact that some of the local Governments who had been satisfied with the early results of the Settlement were getting apprehensive because of Congress activities.
('52', 464, 1, 4, 829340) I pointed out that difficulties were almost unprecedented—Constitutional, political, Commu nal, financial, agrarian and terrorist—that we had a good chance of surmounting them if everyone pulled together, but that otherwise the prospects were gloomy.
('52', 464, 1, 5, 829591) I said it was the deliberate and definite policy of the Government of India to implement the Settlement and to make every effort within reason to prevent a break down.
('52', 464, 1, 6, 829759) There were no reactionary forces at work in this respect.
('52', 464, 1, 7, 829817) At the same time, they had necessarily to exercise constant vigilance and they could not allow a situation of danger to develop either generally or locally, even if action meant the disappearance of the Settlement.
('52', 464, 1, 8, 830032) In this respect the outstanding danger was the mentality of the Congress and the constant advocacy, on the contrary, of preparation for a further struggle.
('52', 464, 1, 9, 830188) This mentality was inevitably having effects elsewhere.
('52', 464, 1, 10, 830244) It was partly because of the reaction in England and unless we could check the reaction there, the atmosphere would become entirely unfavourable.
('52', 464, 1, 11, 830390) In regard to constitutional discussion at the Conference, I suggested that his own position would be very unpleasant if, when he was in London, a state of affairs existed in India which irritated and even outraged public opinion in England.
('52', 464, 1, 12, 830631) I gave him many instances from different provinces of Congress subversive action.
('52', 464, 1, 13, 830713) Mr. Gandhi was, I think, generally impressed by the above factor.
('52', 464, 1, 14, 830779) He had already realized the significance of the reaction in England and he did not, as I rather expected he might do, criticize the reactionary forces at work.
('52', 464, 1, 15, 830939) Similarly he made no protest whatever against the line taken by His Excellency the Governor of the Punjab in his recent speech, and he seemed to accept the view I took that the speech was the natural consequence of hard facts for which Congress were largely responsible, but his only complaint was that I had suggested a widespread suspicion of the objects and activities of the Congress, that these in fact were good and that they did want a peaceful solution.
('52', 464, 1, 16, 831401) He admitted that particular activities were bad and had his complete disapproval.
('52', 464, 1, 17, 831483) He also appreciated the necessity of getting the situation on to a more peaceful plane, and he will, I hope, definitely use his influence to this end.
('52', 464, 1, 18, 831634) I showed him a circular issued by the Provincial Congress Committee of Madras, a copy of which is attached to this note, and said that while there were one or two things in it which might be better expressed, Government would have little cause for complaint if Congress as a whole acted on the principles stated in it.
('52', 464, 1, 19, 831953) I also told him that the line he had taken in his own speech at Simla would definitely help, and begged him to carry on in the same spirit and get his leaders to do likewise.
('52', 464, 1, 20, 832128) I have personally no doubt that he will do his best.
('52', 464, 2, 21, 832181) 12. I may close this note (which is already of inordinate length) with some
('52', 465, 0, 1, 832257) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 465, 1, 2, 832299) personal impressions.
('52', 465, 2, 3, 832321) Mr. Gandhi is, I think, more sincere than ever in his desire to see the Settlement through, and he will do his utmost in this respect.
('52', 465, 2, 4, 832456) It is probably less likely to break down from the Congress side on a big issue than on some irritating and comparatively unimportant matter of detail.
('52', 465, 2, 5, 832607) This danger would be lessened if Congress activities, especially in rural areas, were materially to moderate, for it might then be possible and even desirable for local Government to stretch a point here and there in response to Congress action.
('52', 465, 2, 6, 832853) If and when this becomes feasible, the atmosphere will improve.
('52', 465, 3, 7, 832917) Mr. Gandhi himself has definitely mellowed during the past few months.
('52', 465, 3, 8, 832988) He has been up against concrete difficulties and has had to face constructive work.
('52', 465, 3, 9, 833072) This has made him less confident in regard to preconceived ideas and more ready to see the other side of the case, although I have always found him very fair in this respect.
('52', 465, 3, 10, 833247) Personal contact with various officers of Government has increased his desire to co operate and while I realize only too well the difficulties and dangers in the way of closer co operation with Congress leaders so long as Congress are out to increase their prestige and influence at the expense of Government and other parties, I feel that, where it is possible to avoid these difficulties and dangers, personal contact will definitely help to relieve the situation.
('52', 465, 3, 11, 833714) This will be particularly the case if, as I hope, Mr. Gandhi tries with success to tone down the war mentality.
('52', 465, 3, 12, 833826) If there is no response by Government, we shall get back into the same vicious circle.
('52', 465, 4, 13, 833913) Mr. Gandhi himself is at present too involved in detail to give the attention he should be giving to big questions.
('52', 465, 4, 14, 834029) He receives many complaints of failure on the part of Government to carry out their part of the agreement, and although the great majority of these are untrue, they doubts and suspicions.
('52', 465, 4, 15, 834217) The sooner the matters immediately arising out of the Settlement are would up the better.
('52', 465, 5, 16, 834307) Mr. Gandhi is under no illusion as to the consequences of the break down of the Settlement.
('52', 465, 5, 17, 834399) He realizes the renewal of the Civil Disobedience Movement will compel Government to hit hard and hit at once and I have made this perfectly clear to him on many occasions.
('52', 465, 5, 18, 834572) He accepts this as quite fair and will, if necessary, face the consequences.
('52', 465, 5, 19, 834649) But if it can be avoided, he does not want another fight and this fact and his sense of obligation to honour promises given to Lord Irwin are factors of very great importance in the situation.
('52', 465, 6, 20, 834842) The 18th May, 1931 H. W. EMERSON
('52', 465, 7, 21, 834875) From a photostat : India Office Records
