('52', 466, 3, 4, 835032) May 20, 1931
('52', 466, 4, 5, 835045) My discussion with Mr. Gandhi today turned mainly on the agrarian situation, but there were also some subsidiary points mentioned.
('52', 466, 5, 6, 835176) 1. As regards releases, he had little to say; he had not at all events come prepared with a list of cases in which there were any complaints that we had not observed the Agreement.
('52', 466, 5, 7, 835357) I told him that if there were any cases which he wished to refer to us, I should be glad if he would send them to Chief Secretary; and he agreed.
('52', 466, 6, 8, 835503) 2. He mentioned the cases of students who had been rusticated, etc., for
('52', 466, 7, 9, 835576) taking part in Civil Disobedience.
('52', 466, 7, 10, 835611) I have not the full facts, but the D.P.I. has
('52', 466, 8, 11, 835657) informed me that before being re admitted they were required to undertake that they
('52', 466, 9, 12, 835741) were to observe the disciplinary rules of the institution.
('52', 466, 9, 13, 835800) This does not seem to be a
('52', 466, 10, 14, 835827) very onerous obligation, and failing any more definite complaint from Congress, I
('52', 466, 11, 15, 835909) would let the matter rest there.
('52', 466, 11, 16, 835942) Mr. Gandhi did not seem to attach any great
('52', 466, 12, 17, 835986) importance to it at the time.
('52', 466, 13, 18, 836016) 3. He attached some importance to the question of arms for which licenses
('52', 466, 14, 19, 836090) had been confiscated owing to their owners taking part in Civil Disobedience.
('52', 466, 15, 20, 836168) were I believe some such cases, though I do not now if we have anything about them
('52', 466, 16, 21, 836251) at headquarters.
('52', 466, 16, 22, 836268) He told me that the Commissioner in Gujarat had recognized that this
('52', 466, 17, 23, 836337) fell within the terms of the Agreement, that Mr. Emerson had said he thought it did
('52', 466, 18, 24, 836421) so, but that he would consult legal opinion before issuing anything to local
('52', 466, 19, 25, 836498) Governments.
('52', 466, 19, 26, 836511) Chief Secretary might ascertain any facts that he can on the subject,
('52', 466, 20, 27, 836581) and at the same time write demi officially to Mr. Emerson, asking if the Government
('52', 466, 21, 28, 836665) of India think that arms licenses should be restored, where they have been confiscated
('52', 466, 22, 29, 836752) strictly on the ground that owners have taken part in Civil Disobediences.
('52', 466, 23, 30, 836827) 4. As I have said, the main point was the agrarian situation.
('52', 466, 23, 31, 836889) We discussed
('52', 466, 24, 32, 836902) this at great length, and I for my part avoided any point of principle, such as whethere
('52', 466, 25, 33, 836991) the Congress was really entitled under the Agreement to be recognized as the
('52', 466, 26, 34, 837068) ,representative of the people, etc., and too him at once to the facts of the situation
('52', 466, 27, 35, 837155) in the districts in which Congress had been most active.
('52', 466, 27, 36, 837212) I pointed out that however
('52', 466, 28, 37, 837239) the situation had been arrived at, the danger was that tenants would now refuse to pay
('52', 466, 29, 38, 837326) rents at all and resort to acts of violence if they were pressed by l andlords.
('52', 466, 30, 39, 837406) naturally quoted Chauri Chaura to him.
('52', 466, 30, 40, 837445) He at once dis claimed any idea of a no

('52', 467, 1, 2, 837567) rent campaign, and was somewhat aghast when I gave him a copy of the resolution of
('52', 467, 2, 3, 837650) the Etawah Congress Committee which he said he would look into at once.
('52', 467, 3, 4, 837722) admitted that where compromises had been made by landlords with Congress, the
('52', 467, 4, 5, 837800) latter had not been able to persuade tenants to pay up.
('52', 467, 4, 6, 837856) He said it was no part of
('52', 467, 5, 7, 837882) Congress plans to establish an organization of tahsils and thanas; they were quite
('52', 467, 6, 8, 837965) opposed to the idea of actually starting a parallel government or anything of the
('52', 467, 7, 9, 838047) Having got thus far, I then again but to him the actual difficulty arising from the
('52', 467, 8, 10, 838131) situation in these districts.
('52', 467, 8, 11, 838161) He said that it could only be solved by enlisting the
('52', 467, 9, 12, 838215) effective co operation of Congress in persuading tenants to pay their rents.
('52', 467, 10, 13, 838292) could not promise this, nor could he engage to use his own active efforts of
('52', 467, 11, 14, 838369) persuasion direct to tenants unless Congress had something better to put forward than
('52', 467, 12, 15, 838455) the mere announcement of remissions by Government.
('52', 467, 12, 16, 838506) His workers had narrowly
('52', 467, 13, 17, 838531) examined the conditions of numerous districts and were confident that tenants could
('52', 467, 14, 18, 838615) not pay even the reduced rentals in present circumstances.
('52', 467, 14, 19, 838674) He indeed suggested that
('52', 467, 15, 20, 838699) the enquiry showed that rents were so high as practically to be unpayable even in
('52', 467, 16, 21, 838781) ordinary years, though he admitted that this conclusion might need some modifying
('52', 467, 17, 22, 838863) in the light of the fact that many of these rentals were old and spread over a long
('52', 467, 18, 23, 838947) series of years.
('52', 467, 18, 24, 838964) He suggested the adoption of one of the three following courses :
('52', 467, 19, 25, 839030) First, (though he did not press this) he suggested that we might accept the
('52', 467, 20, 26, 839106) figures arrived at by Congress workers, which he assured me were not a mere rough
('52', 467, 21, 27, 839188) shot but the result of actual inquiries.
('52', 467, 21, 28, 839229) I pointed out to him that it was quite impossible
('52', 467, 22, 29, 839279) to assume that these general figures were equally correct for all classes of tenants and
('52', 467, 23, 30, 839368) for all parts of the province.
('52', 467, 24, 31, 839399) Secondly, he suggested that our officers might hold a kind of summary inquiry
('52', 467, 25, 32, 839477) with selected Congressmen in each district or division with a view of getting better
('52', 467, 26, 33, 839562) figures.
('52', 467, 27, 34, 839571) Thirdly, if neither course was acceptable to Government, he asked that
('52', 467, 28, 35, 839642) Government itself should hold a public inquiry at which Congressmen could give
('52', 467, 29, 36, 839721) evidence as to the capacity of tenants to pay rentals.
('52', 467, 29, 37, 839776) I pointed out to him that either
('52', 467, 30, 38, 839809) of the latter courses would mean delay with every prospect that no money would be

('52', 467, 31, 40, 839932) If tenants get over the payment of any rental at
('52', 467, 32, 41, 839981) all this harvest, it is pretty certain that they would pay nothing for kharif.
('52', 467, 32, 42, 840060) It was quite
('52', 467, 33, 43, 840073) impossible to make summary inquiries in three or four days as he thought, and a
('52', 467, 34, 44, 840153) general inquiry on the lines of that which he had in mind, namely, the Commission
('52', 467, 35, 45, 840235) on Champaran in 1916 would take many months.
('52', 467, 35, 46, 840280) Anything that we did now would not
('52', 467, 36, 47, 840315) only very gravely affect the landlords, but also might have an abiding effect on our
('52', 467, 37, 48, 840400) own finances for many years to come; it was not, therefore, reasonable to ask
('52', 468, 0, 1, 840478) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 469
('52', 468, 1, 2, 840520) Government to adopt a summary p rocedure which might have such far reaching

('52', 468, 2, 4, 840605) I told him that I would consider his proposals, but it seemed to me that the
('52', 468, 3, 5, 840682) result of delaying collections would be so dangerous that it would be difficult to
('52', 468, 4, 6, 840765) accept them.
('52', 468, 4, 7, 840778) I pointed out that there were many districts in which our officers thought
('52', 468, 5, 8, 840853) that collections might now proceed without great difficulty, and that in my opinion
('52', 468, 6, 9, 840937) the best course was to set to work on collections wherever possible in the hope that if
('52', 468, 7, 10, 841025) these proceeded smoothly it will have its effect on the attitude of the tenants
('52', 468, 8, 11, 841105) generally.
('52', 468, 8, 12, 841116) We left the matter at that, and it may be that it is not a very satisfactory
('52', 468, 9, 13, 841193) conclusion, for I did not get his definite engagement to do nothing except to
('52', 468, 10, 14, 841271) discountenance anything like a no rent campaign or an attempt to set up Congress
('52', 468, 11, 15, 841352) tribunals.
('52', 468, 11, 16, 841363) As Mr. Emerson had warned me, Mr. Gandhi feels deeply that Congress
('52', 468, 12, 17, 841431) cannot entirely retire from its position of championship of tenants and small
('52', 468, 13, 18, 841509) landowners.
('52', 468, 14, 19, 841521) 5. We discussed the question of picketing though at no great length.
('52', 468, 15, 20, 841590) pointed out to him the danger that it was becoming communal owing to the

('52', 468, 17, 22, 841744) out that the snatching away of liquor or the infliction of fines is quite beyond the
('52', 468, 18, 23, 841829) spirit of the Agreement.
('52', 468, 18, 24, 841854) Here is agreed and said that he would do his best to
('52', 468, 19, 25, 841907) discountenance it and had indeed already issued orders against the taking of fines.

('52', 469, 8, 16, 843036) APPENDIX V (A)
('52', 469, 9, 17, 843051) LETTER FROM SIR MALCOLM HAILEY 2
('52', 469, 10, 18, 843084) May 23, 1931
('52', 469, 11, 19, 843097) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('52', 469, 12, 20, 843114) I have just received your letter of today, and as you ask for a very early, I have given it urgent but very anxious consideration and write at once to give you my views on the subject.
('52', 469, 13, 21, 843299) Thought I welcome much that is contained in your proposed manifesto, such as the advice to tenants to begin making payments at once, your condemnation of the use of violence by kisans, and your strongly expressed desire that they should not
('52', 469, 14, 22, 843540) injure their own cause by undersirable action, yet I much regret that I could not associate myself in any way with the manifesto as a whole.
('52', 469, 14, 23, 843681) It practically embodies a decision that it is necessary to make for a large number of districts in the province a rental remission for the whole year 1338 Fasli of eight annas in the rupee in the case
('52', 469, 15, 24, 843882) 1 Vide“Speech at Nainital”, 20 5 1931 2 Vide “Letter to Malcolm Hailey”, 23 5 1931
('52', 470, 0, 1, 843965) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 471
('52', 470, 1, 2, 844007) of statutory and non occupancy tenants and four annas in the case of occupancy tenants.
('52', 470, 1, 3, 844095) Though I admit that it is stated that in some cases a larger payment is possible, yet tenants generally could not understand it as anything but a direction to confine their payments to this level as a whole.
('52', 470, 1, 4, 844303) I am myself far from convinced by anything that I have seen or heard that a reduction on this scale is required by the circumstances, and I am certainly clear that no one formula, whether it embraces reductions of this amount or otherwise, could with equity be applied to the very different conditions pevailing throughout the province.
('52', 470, 2, 5, 844640) I am advised that collections of rentals are already proceeding in many of our
('52', 470, 3, 6, 844719) districts on the basis of the reductions made by Government, and though it is not
('52', 470, 4, 7, 844801) possible at the moment to say whether these collections can everywhere be made
('52', 470, 5, 8, 844880) absolutely in full, yet to my mind the right policy is to allow collections to proceed
('52', 470, 6, 9, 844967) on this basis and to watch the results carefully.
('52', 470, 6, 10, 845017) I have in conversation with you
('52', 470, 7, 11, 845049) pointed out the danger of doing anything which would encourage tenants to withhold
('52', 470, 8, 12, 845132) rentals at this stage, for if collections are not made at once, there will be little
('52', 470, 9, 13, 845217) chance of securing any payment at all at a subsequent stage.
('52', 470, 9, 14, 845278) It is for this latter reason
('52', 470, 10, 15, 845307) in particular that I have deprecated proposals for general inquiries into the present
('52', 470, 11, 16, 845393) pitch of rentals throughout the province, for no summary inquiry of this nature can do
('52', 470, 12, 17, 845480) justice to a very complicated and involved case, a decision on which will not only
('52', 470, 13, 18, 845563) affect vitally the finances of Government, but will involve far reaching effects on the
('52', 470, 14, 19, 845651) relations of tenants and landlords.
('52', 470, 15, 20, 845687) With best wishes,

('52', 471, 11, 18, 847096) APPENDIX VII
('52', 471, 12, 19, 847109) LETTER FROM R. M. MAXWELL 2
('52', 471, 13, 20, 847137) GOVERNMENT HOUSE, MAHABALESHWAR,
('52', 471, 14, 21, 847170) May 13, 1931
('52', 471, 15, 22, 847183) DEAR MR. GANDHI,
('52', 471, 16, 23, 847200) At your interview with His Excellency Sir Frederick Sykes on the 17th April His Excellency promised that certain cases which you mentiioned, pertaining to the Home Department, would be reconsidered by the Government.
('52', 471, 16, 24, 847417) I am now to inform you of the results of that review.
('52', 471, 17, 25, 847471) 1 Vide “Letter to Malcolm Hailey”, 23 5 1931 2 Vide “Letter to R. M. Maxwell”, 6 6 1931
('52', 472, 0, 1, 847559) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 473
('52', 472, 1, 2, 847601) 2. I am to deal firstly with your suggestions for the release of certain prisoners.
('52', 472, 2, 3, 847685) (i) You represented that the Sholapur Martial Law prisoners who had not been released should have been released according to the Settlement, and you were informed at the time that there were three such persons.
('52', 472, 3, 4, 847896) In the case of Mr. Rajwade you are right in your supposition, to which you have referred in your letter of the 1st instant to Mr. Collins, that no other writing was placed before the Court except the issue of the Karmayogi in question.
('52', 472, 3, 5, 848132) Many of the
('52', 472, 4, 6, 848144) allegations in that document were either false or so grossly exaggerated (or, when he referred to the incidents of the riots, minimized) as to be untrue to the facts.
('52', 472, 4, 7, 848311) The chief consideration, however, is that their publication at that time and in the conditions then prevailing in Sholapur inevitably tended to inflame the population against the authorities and thus amounted to a direct and real incitement to further violence.
('52', 472, 4, 8, 848573) Their actual effect was to make more difficult the restoration of peace, and it is impossible to doubt that this result was foreseen by Mr. Rajwade when he published the article.
('52', 472, 4, 9, 848752) The Government, therefore, on reconsideration adhere to their view that this is not a case which can properly claim the benefit of the amnesty.
('52', 472, 5, 10, 848896) The other two persons were convicted of tampering with justice by bribing witnesses in the case which arose from the murder of two policemen, and on reconsideration Government are unable to see that the Settlement can apply to a case of this description or that the persons concerned deserve any clemency.
('52', 472, 6, 11, 849202) (ii) The Government have reconsidered the cases of persons convicted under Section 124 A of the I.P.C. You expressed the opinion that the writing of articles and the making of speeches were not contemplated when i t was decided that the Settlement should not apply to cases of violence and incitement to violence.
('52', 472, 6, 12, 849516) The Government are unable to accept this view, for it is clear that such writings and speeches can, and often did, contain incitement to violence which is real and not technical, and that such incitement is often more dangerous and far reaching than other forms of incitement to violence.
('52', 472, 6, 13, 849805) The Government find that the cases of the individuals detained in jail satisfied this test, and they are therefore in no doubt that those persons were rightly excluded from the benefits of the amnesty.
('52', 472, 6, 14, 850007) I am to add that Government are always ready to show leniency, as in many cases in the past, to any person convicted under Section 124 A of the I.P.C., who makes adequate apologies and gives an undertaking not to repeat the offence but this is a point unconnected with the Settlement, which makes no provision for conditional release.
('52', 472, 7, 15, 850342) (iii) You referred to the case of Ratanji Dayaram of Bardoli taluka, who you said was convicted of burning his own crop and should therefore have been released.
('52', 472, 8, 16, 850503) On examining his case Government find that he was convicted of deliberately burning his tenant’s crop in order that the revenue due to Government should not be
('52', 473, 0, 1, 850663) 474 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 473, 1, 2, 850705) paid on the land in question.
('52', 473, 1, 3, 850735) He has not made any reparation to the sufferer which might have entitled his case to consideration on grounds of clemency as distinct from the terms of the Settlement, which, as I have pointed out, make no provision for conditional release.
('52', 473, 1, 4, 850976) Apart from this circumstance, Government consider that violent mischief of this description does not come within the terms of the amnesty.
('52', 473, 2, 5, 851115) (iv) His Excellency understood you to say that there were certain prisoners convicted of offences in connection with the salt campaign who had not been released.
('52', 473, 2, 6, 851277) The Home Department are however unable to trace any such cases.
('52', 473, 3, 7, 851341) (v) You stated that there were certain prosecutions which were still being carried on for offences which took place during the civil disobedience campaign contrary to the terms of the Settlement, and you referred in particular to a case in Belgaum.
('52', 473, 4, 8, 851590) It was pointed out to you at the time that the particular case to which you referred was a case of Nipani in that district.
('52', 473, 4, 9, 851714) The facts of this case are that, following the conviction of two local leaders in April 1930, a mob collected with the intention of enforcing hartal, and after damaging public and private property and destroying the royal portraits in the school, came into conflict with the police whom they proceeded to stone, with the result that three policemen and some village servants were injured.
('52', 473, 4, 10, 852103) There was thus real violence and Government feel that the decision to proceed with the case cannot be altered.
('52', 473, 5, 11, 852214) The other prosecutions which were still pending at the time of your conversation with His Excellency were those of (a) Mahadev Kuverji and Hira Vallabh (b) Vishnu Sali, (c) Shiva Mattur, all of S urat district, who were accused respectively of setting fire to attached crops, severely assaulting a police constable, and setting fire to an attached crop after beating the village servant in charge.
('52', 473, 5, 12, 852612) These are clear cases of violence which cannot be reviewed.
('52', 473, 6, 13, 852672) 3. As regards the orders of deportation passed under the Foreigners’ Act, the Government have already, on reconsideration, withdrawn these orders in all cases, six in number, and the persons who were in prison for failing to observe the orders have been released.
('52', 473, 6, 14, 852936) In this connection you stated that there were 30 such cases in the Karnatak and you were informed that Government were not aware of them, on which you agreed to furnish particulars of them to the Secretary, Home Department.
('52', 473, 6, 15, 853160) As you have not done so, His Excellency assumes that you were misinformed on the point.
('52', 473, 7, 16, 853248) 4. You stated that certain movable and immovable property forfeited had not been returned.
('52', 473, 7, 17, 853339) His Excellency finds that all the buildings seized under Ordinance IX have been restored.
('52', 473, 7, 18, 853429) The delay in some cases was due to the time which necessarily elapsed in finding, and making the necessary arrangements with, the persons entitled and authorized to take delivery.
('52', 473, 8, 19, 853609) As regards the return of movable property, the position has been discussed in
('52', 474, 0, 1, 853687) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 475
('52', 474, 1, 2, 853729) my separate letter of today, in reply to yours of the 7th May.
('52', 474, 2, 3, 853792) 5. As regards the Chirner case, which you represented should be withdrawn, you were informed at the time that as the persons concerned were accused of rioting, being armed with deadly weapons, dacoity, conspiracy to commit dacoity and causing grievous hurt to public servants in the performance of their duty, while six of them are directly charged with murder, the case was obviously one shich must be allowed to take its course.
('52', 474, 3, 4, 854223) Yours sincerely,

('52', 474, 6, 8, 854354) APPENDIX VIII
('52', 474, 7, 9, 854368) OPINION 1
('52', 474, 8, 10, 854378) June 13, 1931
('52', 474, 9, 11, 854392) 1. (1) The question which has arisen between the Government and the Navajivan Press is :
('52', 474, 10, 12, 854481) “What are the obligations of the Government as regards returning the press which was seized at Ahmedabad from the premises of the Navajivan Press?” The question depends primarily on the language of the Instrument which says “movable property .
('52', 474, 10, 13, 854725) will be returned”.
('52', 474, 10, 14, 854744) The meaning of the word “return” as given by Webster is “to bring, carry, put, or send back; to restore”.
('52', 474, 10, 15, 854850) According to Murray’s Oxford Dictionary the word “return” has, among others, the following meaning :
('52', 474, 11, 16, 854951) “to bring or convey to a place or person; to send bac again; to give or render back”.
('52', 474, 11, 17, 855037) From this it is plain that where a party in possession (in this case the Government) has agreed to return a movable property, the obligation undertaken can only be said to have been performed when the party in possession brings or conveys back to the place from where the thing was taken and hands it over to the person from whom it was taken.
('52', 474, 11, 18, 855381) We are, therefore, of opinion that the terms of the Agreement are not only not silent as to the place of delivery, but are clear as to the place of delivery, viz., the place from where it was taken or where it was seized.
('52', 474, 12, 19, 855603) 2. In an Indian Statute, the word “return” has also been used in the sense of taking a thing back to the place from which it was brought.
('52', 474, 12, 20, 855741) Section 43 of the Indian Sale of Goods Act runs as follows :
('52', 474, 13, 21, 855802) “Unless otherwise agreed, where goods are delivered to the buyer and he refuses
('52', 474, 14, 22, 855882) 1 Vide “Letter to H.W. Emerson”, 14 6 1931
('52', 475, 0, 1, 855925) 476 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 475, 1, 2, 855967) to accept them, having the right so to do, he is not to return them to the seller, but it is sufficient if he intimates to the seller that he refuses to accept them”.
('52', 475, 2, 3, 856134) It is obvious that the word “return” must mean taking bac to the place from which it was taken, and it is used in contradistinction to “offer to return” or “holding it at the disposal of the party from whom it was taken”.
('52', 475, 2, 4, 856356) The action of the Government in this case merely amounts to “offer to return” or to “hold it at the disposal of the previous owner”, but does not amount to the performance of the obligation to return.
('52', 475, 2, 5, 856557) As is pointed out above, the obligation to return requires that the thing should be restored to the place and the person from which and from whom it was taken.
('52', 475, 3, 6, 856717) 3. We are of opinion that the section dealing with the subject of delivery of goods as between the seller and the buyer, has got nothing to do with the present question as no question of return arises in such a case.
('52', 475, 4, 7, 856934) 4. While clearly disagreeing with the view that the agreement in question is silent as to the place of “return”, we are of opinion that even in that view, the place of performance of the obligation, in an agreement like the present, is the place from or at which the thing was taken or seized.
('52', 475, 4, 8, 857228) The place in such a case has to be determined by a reference to the object of the agreement.
('52', 475, 4, 9, 857321) It is clear that in this case, the object is to restore status quo ante.
('52', 475, 5, 10, 857394) 5. Even on the assumption, which is denied, that the agreement in this present case is silent as to the place of “return”, by reason of the provisions of Section 49 of the Indian Contract Act, if no place of performance was agreed upon, the promisee has the right to appoint the place of performance and the promisor is bound to perform the promise (in this case, the promise to return the press) at such place, provided it is reasonable.
('52', 475, 5, 11, 857833) In this case, the promisee is entitled to name a reasonable place for performance and the reasonable and proper place is prima facie
('52', 475, 6, 12, 857966) the place from where it was taken or where it was seized; for it is conceivable that after the seizure, the thing may be removed, for a variety of reasons, to a distant place and it would be clearly reasonable for the promisee to claim that it should be returned to the place from where it was taken or where it was seized.
('52', 475, 7, 13, 858290) 6. In every view of the matter, therefore, the position taken up by the Government in the matter of the Navajivan Press cannot be sustained.
('52', 475, 7, 14, 858431) They can be said to have fulfilled the agreement only when they have taken it to Ahmedabad (from where it was seized) and offer to return it to the person from whom it was taken.
('52', 475, 7, 15, 858610) BHULABHAI DESAI D. N. BAHADURJI K. M. MUNSHI
('52', 475, 8, 16, 858655) A.I.C.C. File No., 2/1931. Courtesy : Nehru Memorial Museum and Library
('52', 476, 0, 1, 858727) VOL. 52 : 28 APRIL, 1931 1 JULY, 1931 477
('52', 476, 1, 2, 858769) APPENDIX IX
('52', 476, 2, 3, 858781) LETTER FROM H. W. EMERSON 1
('52', 476, 3, 4, 858809) SIMLA, July 4, 1931
('52', 476, 4, 5, 858829) In your letter of June 14, you suggested that the time had perhaps arrived for the appointment of a permanent Board of Arbitration to decide questions of the interpretation of the Settlement and as to the full carrying out of the terms by the one party or the other.
('52', 476, 4, 6, 859096) Again in your letter of June 20, you made the farther suggestion that in regard to picketing, the Government of India should advise local Governments to appoint a Board of Inquiry, consisting of a nominee on their behalf and a nominee on behalf of the Congress, to conduct a summary inquiry into the allegations on either side and wherever it is found that the rule of peaceful picketing has been violated picketing should be entirely suspended, the Government undertaking on its part to stop prosecutions wherever it is found that they have been undertaken in spite of peaceful picketing.
('52', 476, 5, 7, 859686) I much appreciate your object of removing the possible causes of dispute arising out of the Settlement, but there are, I am afraid, serious difficulties in the way of accepting either proposal.
('52', 476, 5, 8, 859880) To take the lesser one first.
('52', 476, 5, 9, 859910) Its scope, as I understand it, is mainly limited to cases in which it is alleged that the methods of picketing have contravened the ordinary law and that the police have, therefore, prosecuted or propose to prosecute the picketer.
('52', 476, 5, 10, 860141) One effect of your proposal would be that before bringing the law into operation there should be a summary inquiry carried out by a nominee of Government and a nominee of Congress and that further proceedings would depend on their decision.
('52', 476, 6, 11, 860382) In other words, the duty of maintaining the law in this particular respect would be transferred from the police, who have statutory duties, to a Board of Inquiry, the members of which might well arrive at different conclusions.
('52', 476, 7, 12, 860610) While the police, of course, must act only in accordance with the law, it is not practicable nor was it intended by the Settlement that their duty in this respect should in any way be abrogated.
('52', 476, 8, 13, 860805) In cases of this kind a practical test as to whether the law has or has not been contravened is the decision of the Court, which tries the case, and unless its decision is reversed on appeal the finding of the Court that picketing has contravened the law and consequently the terms of the Settlement should prima facie be followed
('52', 476, 9, 14, 861136) automatically by a suspension of picketing.
('52', 476, 9, 15, 861180) The above illustrates one of the difficulties, that would also arise in the case of Standing Boards of Arbitration.
('52', 476, 10, 16, 861296) 1 Vide “Letter to J. H. Garrett”, 20 4 1931
('52', 477, 0, 1, 861340) 478 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('52', 477, 1, 2, 861382) The obligations imposed on Congress by the Settlement relate largely to
('52', 477, 2, 3, 861454) matters affecting Law and Order, the freedom of action of the individual and the
('52', 477, 3, 4, 861535) carrying on of the administration, that is to say, any serious breach of it has
('52', 477, 4, 5, 861615) important reactions on one or other of these matters.
('52', 477, 4, 6, 861669) So far as individual breaches
('52', 477, 5, 7, 861699) contravened the ordinary law, the position would be the same as for picketing.
('52', 477, 6, 8, 861778) general breaches of it raised questions of policy affecting Law and Order or the
('52', 477, 7, 9, 861859) effective working of the administration, it would be clearly impossible for
('52', 477, 8, 10, 861935) Government to restrict their freedom of action by reference to a Board of Arbitration.
('52', 477, 9, 11, 862022) This was not contemplated when the Settlement was made and in particular when the
('52', 477, 10, 12, 862104) last clause of it was drafted.
('52', 477, 10, 13, 862135) Nor would it be consonant with the discharge by
('52', 477, 11, 14, 862183) Government of fundamental responsibilities.
('52', 477, 12, 15, 862227) It seems to me that the working of the Settlement must depend primarily on
('52', 477, 13, 16, 862302) the good faith of the parties to it.
('52', 477, 13, 17, 862339) So far as Government are concerned they desire to
('52', 477, 14, 18, 862389) adhere strictly to its terms and our information shows that the local Governments
('52', 477, 15, 19, 862471) have been scrupulous in carrying out the obligations imposed on them.
('52', 477, 15, 20, 862541) Doubtful
('52', 477, 16, 21, 862550) cases are of course inevitable, but local Governments are prepared to give them most
('52', 477, 17, 22, 862635) careful examination and the Government of India will continue to bring to the notice
('52', 477, 18, 23, 862720) of local Governments any cases that are reported to them and if necessary satisfy
('52', 477, 19, 24, 862802) themselves in regard to the facts.
('52', 477, 20, 25, 862837) Young India, 20 8 1931
